{"uri": "8252003271", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:01:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:01:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:01:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/southport-rioters-will-feel-full-force-of-the-law-says-starmer-1656176.html", "title": "Southport rioters will feel 'full force of the law', says Starmer | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Violence against police in Southport after three girls were killed in a knife attack has been condemned, as Sir Keir Starmer said rioters would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club in the Merseyside seaside town on Monday.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe UK prime minister said rioters in Southport on Tuesday evening had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nNorth West Ambulance Service said 39 people were treated, \"all of which were police officers\".\n\n\"27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene\", a statement on X said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nThe force said those involved set cars belonging to members of the public alight, threw bricks at the local mosque and damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nWriting on X, Mr Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nUK home secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting outside a mosque in Southport as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters that she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said officers had faced violence from \"thugs\", while Southport MP Patrick Hurley said it was \"distressing\" to see \"people from outside our Southport community attacking our police and local people\".\n\nHundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a separate protest outside a local mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said that shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said it was \"sickening\" to see the disorder \"happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives\".\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Goss added: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nThe man was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"Our officers should not have to face this, {"uri": "8251400792", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:02:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:02:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:01:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.thenationalnews.com/news/uk/2024/07/30/violent-uk-protest-against-mosque-after-southport-stabbings/", "title": "Violent UK protest against mosque after Southport stabbings | The National", "body": "Police were involved in violent clashes with protesters outside a mosque in Southport, England, after three girls were killed in a knife attack.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were stabbed to death in Southport, Merseyside, on Monday.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nHundreds of people took part in a vigil on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a protest outside a mosque in Southport as demonstrators chanting far-right slogans clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw missiles at the mosque at about 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nMerseyside Police said an officer suffered a suspected broken nose in chaotic scenes outside the mosque.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, is in custody accused of murder and attempted murder after the stabbing incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\n\"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said of the protest.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face.\n\n\"Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"Our officers should not have to {"uri": "8251568702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:32:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:32:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:30:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/southport-rioters-will-feel-full-force-of-the-law-says-starmer/a553450863.html", "title": "Southport rioters will feel 'full force of the law', says Starmer", "body": "Violence against police in Southport after three girls were killed in a knife attack has been condemned, as Sir Keir Starmer said rioters would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club in the Merseyside seaside town on Monday.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters in Southport on Tuesday evening had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nMerseyside Police said 22 officers were hurt during the violent disorder, with eight suffering serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nThe force said those involved set cars belonging to members of the public alight, threw bricks at the local mosque and damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting outside a mosque in Southport as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters that she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said officers had faced violence from \"thugs\", while Southport MP Patrick Hurley said it was \"distressing\" to see \"people from outside our Southport community attacking our police and local people\".\n\nHundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a separate protest outside a local mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said that shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said it was \"sickening\" to see the disorder \"happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives\".\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Goss added: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nThe man was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251319778", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:45:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:45:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:44:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/southport-violent-clashes-police-6450917-Jul2024/", "title": "Violent clashes break out between protesters and police in Southport after knife attack vigil", "body": "Merseyside Police said an officer suffered a suspected broken nose in chaotic scenes outside the mosque as missiles were thrown at the police.\n\nVIOLENT CLASHES BETWEEN protesters and police have erupted outside a mosque in Southport in the UK after three girls were killed in a knife attack.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport, Merseyside, yesterday.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nHundreds of people took part in a vigil this evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a protest outside a mosque in Southport as demonstrators chanting far-right slogans clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nMerseyside Police said an officer suffered a suspected broken nose in chaotic scenes outside the mosque as missiles were thrown at the police.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nAssistant chief constable Alex Goss said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nAfter being heckled while visiting the scene of the knife attack today, Prime Minister Keir Starmer's office issued a statement urging people not to speculate about the attacker and to let the police conduct their investigation.", {"uri": "8251910108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:58:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:58:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:58:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/29581744/southport-riots-cops-injured-cars-torched-shops-looted/", "title": "'Sickening' riots leave 39 cops injured as Southport locals slam mob", "body": "ALMOST 40 police officers have been injured in \"sickening\" riots in Southport as cars were torched and shops looted.\n\nCops clashed with rioters outside a mosque in the Merseyside town last night near where three children were killed in a horror stabbing.\n\nThose involved in the unrest included supporters of the English Defence League.\n\nThe mob set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nNorth West Ambulance Service said 27 officers were taken to hospital.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga, suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing attack in Southport on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nThe attack saw Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nEight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nSpeculation about the alleged attacker's identity circulated online, fuelling the tension that already existed after Monday's horrific attack.\n\nDespite social media claims, the suspect was born in Cardiff.\n\nSir Keir Starmer said rioters would \"feel the full force of the law\" and accused rioters of hijacking \"the vigil for the victims\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nOne Southport resident added: \"They have no respect for a town that's grieving.\"\n\nJenni Stancombe, whose seven-year-old daughter Elsie was killed in Monday's attacks, issued a plea to \"stop the violence\".\n\nIn a message widely shared on social media, she wrote: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nHundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue.\n\nMany were in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a separate protest outside a local mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said that shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced, giving police the power to direct people engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents.\n\nMerseyside police said these powers would not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting outside a mosque in Southport as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters that she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"", "source": {"uri": "thesun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-439238752", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:38:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:38:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:50:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/police-injured-bricks-thrown-protest-062832395.html", "title": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of three girls", "body": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of three girls\n\nJosh Payne\n\n31 July 2024 at 8:50 am\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nChairman of Merseyside Police Federation Chris McGlade said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said on Wednesday that rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nMr Hurley condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nHe also hit out at the \"swirling morass\" of social media \"lies and propaganda\", saying they have fuelled rumours about the attacker's identity as well as criticism of politicians.\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "josh_payne@aol.co.uk", "name": "Josh Payne", {"uri": "2024-07-439126607", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:52:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:52:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:52:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.salisburyjournal.co.uk/news/national/24487288.police-injured-bricks-thrown-protest-following-stab-deaths-three-girls/", "title": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of three girls", "body": "Police officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nThe violent scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "salisburyjournal.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Salisbury Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251884624", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:40:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:40:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:38:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/keir-starmer-says-southport-rioters-062924033.html", "title": "Keir Starmer says Southport rioters will 'feel full force of law' after nearly 40 police officers injured", "body": "Almost 40 police officers have been injured in violent disorder in Southport after three girls were killed in a knife attack, emergency services said.\n\nNorth West Ambulance Service said 27 police officers were taken to hospital and 12 more were treated at the scene, while police dogs were also injured.\n\nThe violence on Tuesday evening came as mourners gathered in the seaside town of Southport for a vigil in honour of Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, who were all fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club on Monday.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured.\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer said rioters in Southport had \"hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery\" and vowed they would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries in the unrest, including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nNorth West Ambulance Service said on X: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\"\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with dogs named Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at a local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nWriting on X, the Prime Minister said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting outside a mosque in Southport as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters that she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced, giving police the power to direct people engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing attack in Southport on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain says Islamaphobic backlash began with a false rumour on the internet which was then stoked by misinformation from a Russian news site, which wrongfully associated the crime with Muslims.\n\nThe MCB paid tribute to the three young girls killed in Southport on Monday, before condemning \"shocking scenes of far-right rioters running amok outside a mosque\".", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8252003273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:02:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:02:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:01:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/police-injured-as-bricks-thrown-in-protest-following-stab-deaths-of-three-girls-1656168.html", "title": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of three girls | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Police officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nChairman of Merseyside Police Federation Chris McGlade said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said on Wednesday that rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nMr Hurley condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nHe also hit out at the \"swirling morass\" of social media \"lies and propaganda\", saying they have fuelled rumours about the attacker's identity as well as criticism of politicians.\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe UK prime minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nUK home secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking News.ie"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438846417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:06:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:06:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:01:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.itv.com/news/2024-07-30/southport-rioters-will-feel-full-force-of-the-law-says-starmer", "title": "Southport rioters will feel 'full force of the law', says Starmer", "body": "Violence against police in Southport after three girls were killed in a knife attack has been condemned, as Sir Keir Starmer said rioters would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club in the Merseyside seaside town on Monday.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters in Southport on Tuesday evening had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, formerly Twitter, Sir Keir said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting outside a mosque in Southport as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters that she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nMs Cooper added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said officers had faced violence from \"thugs\", while Southport MP Patrick Hurley said it was \"distressing\" to see \"people from outside our Southport community attacking our police and local people\".\n\nHundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a separate protest outside a local mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nMerseyside Police said a number of officers were injured during the disturbances, including one who suffered a suspected broken nose.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said that shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said it was \"sickening\" to see the disorder \"happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives\".\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Goss added: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nThe man was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "itv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ITV Hub"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8251885742", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:40:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:40:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:39:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/31/police-injured-as-bricks-thrown-in-protest-following-stab-deaths-of-three-girls/", "title": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of three girls", "body": "Police vehicles were set on fire in violent scenes in Southport on Tuesday evening following a vigil for the victims of the holiday club knife attack.\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nThe violent scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. {"uri": "8251900127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:51:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:51:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:50:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/world/uk/2024/07/31/police-injured-in-rioting-following-stab-deaths-of-three-girls-in-southport/", "title": "Police injured in rioting  following stab deaths of three girls in Southport", "body": "Members of far-right group attack mosque following false report about knife attacker\n\nEight police officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club in the UK.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar (9) Bebe King (6) and Elsie Dot Stancombe (7) were fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nAccording to authorities and media reports, the suspect was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents. A false report had circulated online that the suspect was a recent immigrant who crossed the English Channel last week and was \"on an MI6 watchlist.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\n[ Southport stabbing: Clashes between protesters and police erupt after vigil for victimsOpens in new window ]\n\nThe violent scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe violence followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three girls who died, eight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nBritain's prime minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, eir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was {"uri": "8251912023", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:04:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:04:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:59:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13692047/Police-injured-bricks-thrown-protest-following-stab-deaths-three-girls.html", "title": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of...", "body": "Police officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nViolence at the Southport protest, which saw a police van set alight (Richard McCarthy/PA)\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nThe violent scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nTrouble flares during a protest in Southport, after three children died in a stabbing during a Taylor Swift event at a dance school (Richard McCarthy/PA)\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nMembers of the public take part in a vigil near the scene of the attack in Hart Street, Southport (James Speakman/PA)\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-439110278", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:34:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:34:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:34:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.impartialreporter.com/news/national/24487288.police-injured-bricks-thrown-protest-following-stab-deaths-three-girls/", "title": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of three girls", "body": "Police officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nThe violent scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "impartialreporter.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Impartial Reporter"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251357839", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:14:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:14:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:14:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.clactonandfrintongazette.co.uk/news/national/24487151.violent-clashes-protesters-police-southport-following-stabbings/", "title": "Violent clashes between protesters and police in Southport following stabbings", "body": "Violent clashes between protesters and police have erupted outside a mosque in Southport after three girls were killed in a knife attack.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club in Southport, Merseyside, on Monday.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said officers had faced violence from \"thugs\" on Tuesday evening.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said it was \"appalling\" police officers in Southport were facing attacks from \"thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community\", adding: \"It's a total disgrace.\"\n\nHundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a separate protest outside a local mosque as demonstrators chanting far-right slogans clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nMerseyside Police said an officer suffered a suspected broken nose during the chaotic scenes.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nIn a post on social media, Chief Constable Kennedy said: \"I am incredibly proud of my officers and staff who have worked so hard to save the lives of children, investigate the horrific incident from yesterday, working with partners to provide reassurance to our communities and now they are facing this level of violence from these thugs.\n\n\"Over 1,000 residents from Southport came together this evening to remember the little girls who have died, those who are still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed and are traumatised by the events from yesterday.\n\n\"This is where all of our focus should be.\"\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said it was \"sickening\" to see the disorder \"happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives\".\n\nIn a statement, Assistant Chief Constable Goss added: \"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife on Eastbank Street near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nThe man was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer visited the seaside town on Tuesday and thanked emergency service workers, telling them: \"I hope you feel proud of the part that you played in the most difficult circumstances, to do what you could for those young lives.\"\n\nHe laid down his wreath and stood momentarily in silence, but more than one person shouted: \"How many more, Starmer? When are you going to do something?\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper updated MPs on the attack in the House of Commons on Tuesday evening, where she described it as an \"unspeakable tragedy\".\n\nShe told the Commons: \"These were young children, dancing to Taylor Swift and celebrating the start of the school holidays.\n\n\"What should have been a joyful start to the summer turned into an unspeakable tragedy.\"\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nMs Cooper said Merseyside Police were leading an \"extremely serious criminal investigation\", telling MPs the force is \"being supported by counter-terrorism police\".\n\nThe force said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice said a name shared on social media in connection with the suspect is \"incorrect\", adding: \"We would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.\"", "source": {"uri": "clactonandfrintongazette.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Clacton and believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nThe violent scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in
