{"uri": "8252015705", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:09:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:09:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:08:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.edp24.co.uk/news/national/24487413.police-injured-bricks-thrown-protest-following-stab-deaths-three-girls/", "title": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of three girls", "body": "Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nChairman of Merseyside Police Federation Chris McGlade said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said on Wednesday that rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nMr Hurley condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nHe also hit out at the \"swirling morass\" of social media \"lies and propaganda\", saying they have fuelled rumours about the attacker's identity as well as criticism of politicians.\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "edp24.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eastern Daily Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251416675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:19:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:19:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:18:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/southport-riot-merseyside-police-b2588529.html", "title": "Police clash with far-right mob outside Southport mosque after knife killings", "body": "{{ #verifyErrors }}{{ message }}{{ /verifyErrors }}{{ ^verifyErrors }}Something went wrong. Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nViolent clashes between far-right protesters and police have erupted outside a mosque in Southport following a knife attack that killed three children.\n\nFootage from Southport showed gangs of men chanting and throwing bricks at a wall of riot police. A police van was blazing behind them, with black smoke filling the air.\n\nMasked men were seen scouring the ground for bricks littering the floor to throw at the officers while heavy thuds were heard as the vans took hits and police raised their shields against incoming projectiles. Fires were also started down the streets and in wheelie bins. A police helicopter was also flying overhead.\n\nHome secretary Yvette Cooper described the violence as \"a total disgrace\", adding that it was \"appalling\" that police officers, some of whom had responded to Monday's attack, were now combating \"thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community\".\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club in Southport, Merseyside, on Monday.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nHundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nBut the vigil was followed by a separate protest outside a local mosque as demonstrators chanting far-right slogans clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nMerseyside Police said an officer suffered a suspected broken nose during the chaotic scenes.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nAfter the boy's arrest a fake name has been circulated on social media alongside a number of other untrue accusations.\n\nIn a post on social media, Chief Constable Kennedy said: \"I am incredibly proud of my officers and staff who have worked so hard to save the lives of children, investigate the horrific incident from yesterday, working with partners to provide reassurance to our communities and now they are facing this level of violence from these thugs.\n\n\"Over 1,000 residents from Southport came together this evening to remember the little girls who have died, those who are still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed and are traumatised by the events from yesterday.\n\n\"This is where all of our focus should be.\"\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said it was \"sickening\" to see the disorder \"happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives\".\n\nIn a statement, Assistant Chief Constable Goss added: \"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", {"uri": "8251877513", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:34:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:34:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:33:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/uknews/2024/07/31/police-injured-as-bricks-thrown-in-protest-following-stab-deaths-of-three-girls/", "title": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of three girls", "body": "Police officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nThe violent scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was {"uri": "8252403881", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:02:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:02:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:02:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/locals-clean-up-after-people-from-out-of-town-cause-mayhem-in-southport-1656353.html", "title": "Locals clean up after 'people from out of town cause mayhem' in Southport | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Locals in Southport have gathered for a clean-up operation outside a mosque after right-wing rioters brought further misery to a town already reeling from a knife attack that left three children dead.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nOfficers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine; Bebe King, six; and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\n\"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said, on Wednesday, that rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe UK prime minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nUK home secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking News.ie"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251879881", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:35:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:35:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:35:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/uk-news/39-police-officers-injured-southport-29646657", "title": "Southport stabbing: 39 police officers injured as violence erupts", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nNearly 40 police officers sustained injuries at the scene of violent disorder in Southport following Monday's knife attack, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nThe rioting followed a mass stabbing in Southport at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club which claimed the lives of three young girls: Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven. A 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nThe ambulance service said 27 police officers were taken to hospital following the \"shocking\" scenes of violence as riots erupted on the streets of Southport on Tuesday evening. Other officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious, the PA news agency reports.\n\nREAD MORE: Hero teacher fighting for life after saving children during Southport stabbing\n\nKeep up to date with all the latest breaking news and top stories from the North East with our free newsletter\n\nA statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\" Merseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them. A third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire. Extra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence. A Section 34 Order has also been introduced, giving police the power to direct people engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support. Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer said the rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and would \"feel the full force of the law\". Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting outside a mosque in Southport as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nHundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance. The vigil was followed by a separate protest outside a local mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nEight other children were also stabbed in Monday's attack, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition. {"uri": "8251368385", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:25:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:25:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:25:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/violent-clashes-between-protesters-police-9448434", "title": "Violent clashes between protesters and police erupt in Southport", "body": "Violence has erupted outside a mosque in Southport which has seen a police officer hurt. It comes after three girls were killed in a knife attack.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club in Southport, Merseyside, on Monday (July 29). Eight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said officers had faced violence from \"thugs\" on Tuesday evening. Hundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance, PA reports.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a separate protest outside a local mosque as demonstrators chanting far-right slogans clashed with police in St Luke's Road. Merseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire. Merseyside Police said an officer suffered a suspected broken nose during the chaotic scenes.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street. In a post on social media, Chief Constable Kennedy said: \"I am incredibly proud of my officers and staff who have worked so hard to save the lives of children, investigate the horrific incident from yesterday, working with partners to provide reassurance to our communities and now they are facing this level of violence from these thugs.\n\n\"Over 1,000 residents from Southport came together this evening to remember the little girls who have died, those who are still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed and are traumatised by the events from yesterday. This is where all of our focus should be.\"\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said it was \"sickening\" to see the disorder \"happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives\".\n\nIn a statement, Assistant Chief Constable Goss added: \"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside. There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time. Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife on Eastbank Street near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening. The man was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer visited the seaside town on Tuesday and thanked emergency service workers, telling them: \"I hope you feel proud of the part that you played in the most difficult circumstances, to do what you could for those young lives.\"\n\nHe laid down his wreath and stood momentarily in silence, but more than one person shouted: \"How many more, Starmer? When are you going to do something?\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper updated MPs on the attack in the House of Commons on Tuesday evening, where she described it as an \"unspeakable tragedy\". She told the Commons: \"These were young children, dancing to Taylor Swift and celebrating the start of the school holidays.\n\n\"What should have been a joyful start to the summer turned into an unspeakable tragedy.\"\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related. Ms Cooper said Merseyside Police were leading an \"extremely serious criminal investigation\", telling MPs the force is \"being supported by counter-terrorism police\".\n\nThe force said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon. Police said a name shared on social media in connection with the suspect is \"incorrect\", adding: \"We would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.\"", "source": {"uri": "bristolpost.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bristol Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": "annette_belcher@bristolpost.co.uk", "name": "Annette Belcher", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merseyside_Police", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Merseyside Police"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vigil", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Vigil"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosque", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Mosque"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southport", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Southport"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Southport"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_constable", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Chief constable"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8251876976", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:33:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:33:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:33:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/31/police-injured-as-bricks-thrown-in-protest-following-stab-deaths-of-three-girls/", "title": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of three girls", "body": "Police vehicles were set on fire in violent scenes in Southport on Tuesday evening following a vigil for the victims of the holiday club knife attack.\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nThe violent scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting outside a mosque in Southport as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters that she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nMs Cooper added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nTrouble flares during a protest in Southport, after three children died in a stabbing during a Taylor Swift event at a dance school (Richard McCarthy/PA)\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said officers had faced violence from \"thugs\", while Southport MP Patrick Hurley said it was \"distressing\" to see \"people from outside our Southport community attacking our police and local people\".\n\nHundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a separate protest outside a local mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nMerseyside Police said a number of officers were injured during the disturbances, including one who suffered a suspected broken nose.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said that shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nViolence at the Southport protest, which saw a police van set alight (Richard McCarthy/PA)\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said it was \"sickening\" to see the disorder \"happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives\".\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Goss added: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nMembers of the public take part in a vigil near to the scene of the attack in Hart Street, Southport (James Speakman/PA)\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nThe man was taken into custody and there were no "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.ayradvertiser.com/news/national/24487350.police-injured-bricks-thrown-protest-following-stab-deaths-three-girls/", "title": "Police injured as bricks thrown in protest following stab deaths of three girls", "body": "Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nThe violent scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said on Wednesday that rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nMr Hurley condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nHe also hit out at the \"swirling morass\" of social media \"lies and propaganda\", saying they have fuelled rumours about the attacker's identity as well as criticism of politicians.\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters she saw a community \"coming together\" during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their \"heroism\".\n\nShe added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was {"uri": "2024-07-439296813", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:26:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:26:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:15:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/locals-clean-people-town-cause-091518638.html", "title": "Locals clean up after 'people from out of town cause mayhem' in Southport", "body": "Locals clean up after 'people from out of town cause mayhem' in Southport\n\nPA Reporters\n\n31 July 2024 at 10:15 am\n\nLocals in Southport have gathered for a clean-up operation outside a mosque after right-wing rioters brought further misery to a town already reeling from a knife attack that left three children dead.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nOfficers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine; Bebe King, six; and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\n\"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said, on Wednesday, that rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was {"uri": "8252116056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:12:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:12:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:11:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/southport-riot-everything-know-40-29646996", "title": "Everything we know as Southport riot sees 40 officers injured in disorder", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nA riot in Southport saw almost 40 police officers injured and 27 taken to hospital after scenes of violent disorder outside a mosque. The riots flared just over 24 hours after a fatal stabbing spree in the town which saw three young girls killed and others injured on Monday, July 29.\n\nThe trouble on Tuesday night flared at around 7.45pm when what Merseyside Police described as a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League - began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road, which is just around the corner from the scene of the knife attack on Hart Street.\n\nThe force said bottles and wheelie bins were being thrown and one officer had suffered a suspected broken nose as a result. By around 9.45pm, the violence had calmed down with numbers on the street having dwindled as darkness descended, the PA news agency reported.\n\nREAD MORE: Nearly 40 police officers injured in riots after Southport stabbings\n\nREAD MORE: Huw Edwards to appear in court charged with making indecent images of children\n\nThe violence happened just after hundreds of people attended a vigil to remember the three girls killed in the mass stabbing at a Taylor Swift-themed event held in a nursery. Police confirmed they had arrested a man and seized a flick knife just around the corner from the site of the vigil at 6.55pm.\n\nPolice are continuing to question a 17-year-old boy following the horrendous incident. Emergency services were called to reports of a stabbing in Hart Street at around 11.50am on Monday, July 29. Armed police arrested a male and seized a knife. The 17-year-old boy from Banks in Lancashire, who was born in Cardiff, has been arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder, Merseyside Police said.\n\nCatch up on our live coverage of the devastating stabbings and the aftermath here. This is everything we know about the violent disturbance in Southport on Tuesday, July 30.\n\nWhy were people rioting?\n\nThe riots happened after a mass stabbing incident at a Taylor Swift-themed summer holiday class which killed three children on Monday. Tuesday's violence happened just after hundreds of people attended a vigil to remember the three girls who list their lives.\n\nThe victims of the stabbing have been named as Bebe King, six, Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Merseyside Police confirmed on Tuesday, July 30. Eight other children remain in hospital, with five in a critical condition. Two adults are also in hospital with severe injuries.\n\nThe trouble flared at around 7.45pm when what Merseyside Police described as a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League - began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road, which is just around the corner from the scene of the knife attack on Hart Street.\n\nIt is believed they gathered after what police have called \"speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody\", with the force saying that \"some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nThe Mirror reports that local residents were up all night trying to clear their streets after rioters turned them into a \"war zone.\" After calm was finally restored the extent of the chaos could be seen with rubbish burnt out vehicles and smashed windows. One local said: \"At least the bin men don't have to empty the bins today - they've all been burnt.\"\n\nWho was injured in the riots?\n\nNearly 40 police officers sustained injuries at the scene of violent disorder in Southport, North West Ambulance Service said. The service said 27 officers were taken to hospital.\n\nA statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\" Merseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious. Three police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nWhat have police said about the riots?\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident. Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside. There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time. Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nPolice said an incorrect name for the alleged Southport attacker, along with false details about his past, had been widely shared online. A Merseyside Police statement said: \"A name has been shared on social media in connection with the suspect in the incident in Southport. This name is incorrect and we would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.\" Join our WhatsApp news community here for the latest breaking news", More info\n\nViolence erupted between protesters and police outside a Southport mosque following the tragic stabbing of three young girls.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all tragically killed in a knife attack in Southport, Merseyside, on Monday. In addition to the fatalities, eight other children sustained stab wounds, with five currently in critical condition. Two adults were also critically injured in the incident, according to police reports.\n\nOn Tuesday evening, hundreds gathered for a vigil outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, many visibly upset as they laid flowers and cards in memory of the young victims. The peaceful vigil was followed by a protest outside a local mosque, where demonstrators chanting far-right slogans clashed with police on St Luke's Road.\n\nRead more: Police name three young victims as families release heartbreaking statements Keep up to date with all the latest breaking news and top stories from the North East with our free newsletter\n\nMerseyside Police reported that \"a large group of people believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" began hurling items towards the mosque around 7.45pm.\n\nPolice officers donned helmets and riot gear as stones and bottles were thrown at them, resulting in damage to police vehicles and some being set alight.\n\nAn officer suffered a suspected broken nose amidst the chaos outside the mosque, as projectiles continued to be launched at the police.\n\nA 17 year old boy, who cannot be named due to legal reasons, is currently in custody, facing charges of murder and attempted murder in relation to the incident at the Hart Street dance studio.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss remarked: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\"\n\nHe further noted, \"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\"\n\nReflecting on the challenges faced by emergency services, he said, \"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\"\n\nACC Goss also pointed out, \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the {"uri": "8252109721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:08:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:08:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:07:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/world/523774/thugs-hijacked-southport-and-families-grief-mp", "title": "Thugs 'hijacked' Southport and families' grief - MP", "body": "\"Thugs\" were to blame for the violence that saw 39 police officers injured in Southport, the town's MP has said.\n\nUnrest broke out in the Merseyside town hours after a vigil to remember the victims of Monday's knife attack at a dance school in which three young girls were killed.\n\nOfficers were pelted with bricks, a police van was set on fire, and eight officers were seriously hurt, Merseyside Police said.\n\nMP Patrick Hurley described the violence - close to a mosque - as \"horrific\".\n\nHurley told BBC's Radio 4 Today programme that the \"riot\" was \"led by people from outside the town\".\n\nPolice said the violence was believed to have involved English Defence League supporters.\n\nHurley condemned \"thugs who had got the train in\" who were using the \"deaths of three little kiddies for their own political purposes\".\n\nOn Tuesday, Merseyside Police named the three girls who were killed at a Taylor Swift-themed dance workshop at the Hart Space studio in Hart Street.\n\nThey were six-year-old Bebe King, Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine.\n\nAt about 6pm local time, a peaceful vigil was held outside the Atkinson gallery in Lord Street, with more than 1000 people estimated to have attended.\n\nThroughout the day, though, there had been rumours circulating online of a planned demonstration near to a mosque on St Luke's Road.\n\nAt about 19:45, demonstrators began to gather and engaged in a stand-off with police officers.\n\nAs the disorder escalated, officers donned protective gear and used riot shields to defend themselves from bricks, wheelie bins and other objects being hurled towards them.\n\nA police vehicle was also set on fire.\n\nHurley said it was \"reprehensible\" that police officers who had, the day before been attending to injured victims, were finding themselves \"being pelted with bricks by these thugs\".\n\nThe MP said they had \"hijacked the grief\" of the town and families.\n\nHe said: \"These people are utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured and totally disrespecting the town.\"\n\nIn total, 27 officers were taken to hospital, and 12 were treated and discharged at the scene, the ambulance service said.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order has been put in place, giving police extra stop and search powers.\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced, allowing police to direct people who are engaging in antisocial behaviour or are \"likely to become involved in such behaviour\" away from the area.\n\nMerseyside Police said extra officers would remain in the area \"to provide a visible presence and reassure communities\".\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said it was \"sickening\" that this was happening within a \"devastated\" community.\n\nHe said the force has faced \"serious violence\" and was \"so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\"\n\nACC Goss also thanked officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police for providing mutual aid and support.\n\nHe added the disorder involved many people \"who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside\".\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park,\" he said.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nA 17-year-old boy was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after Monday's attack.\n\nACC Goss said: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK, and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nPM Sir Keir Starmer said on X that the people of Southport were \"reeling\" after the \"horror inflicted on them yesterday\".\n\nHe said that those who had \"hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery\" had insulted the community and would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nFamilies living nearby told the BBC they feared for their safety as stones flew past and police officers rushed to put on riot gear and pick up shields.\n\n\"I can't believe this is happening in Southport,\" one young woman shouted from the front of her car as she tried to drive her young daughter away.\n\nThe disorder began after hundreds of people gathered near a local mosque attacking the front of it, throwing bricks, bottles, fireworks and rocks, many with hoods up and scarves hiding their faces.\n\nMerseyside Police said those behind the violence had been fired up by social media posts which incorrectly suggested an Islamist link to Monday's stabbings.\n\nThe Home Secretary Yvette Cooper had earlier warned about disinformation linked to the attack.\n\nThe suspect has no known links to Islam.\n\nCooper later said it was \"appalling\" that police officers in Southport were facing attacks from \"thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community\".\n\n\"I think everyone should be showing some respect for the community that is grieving and also for the police who are pursuing an urgent criminal investigation now, and who showed such heroism and bravery yesterday in the face of these horrific attacks,\" she said.\n\nIn a statement on X, Merseyside Police and Crime Commissioner Emily Spurrell also said she was \"absolutely appalled by the disgraceful scenes of violence\".\n\n\"This is a community which has faced unimaginable tragedy, and it is grieving.\n\n\"Such behaviour is abhorrent and only causes further harm and suffering,\" she added.\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy posted on X that more than 1000 residents from Southport had come together at the vigil to remember the little girls who had died, those who were still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed and were traumatised by the events from yesterday.", "source": {"uri": "rnz.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "RNZ"}, {"uri": "8252604158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:06:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:06:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:06:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/clashes-with-police-in-southport-after-three-girls-killed-in-stabbing-attack-5696972", "title": "Clashes With Police in Southport After Three Girls Killed in Stabbing Attack", "body": "There were clashes with police in Southport, Merseyside, on Tuesday night as violence broke out following the deaths of three young girls in a mass stabbing attack.\n\nOfficers suffered serious injuries after bricks, stones and bottles were thrown at them as cars and police vehicles were set ablaze after a vigil for the girls turned into a riot.\n\nMerseyside Police said that \"a large group of people,\" whom they \"believed to be supporters of the English Defence League,\" started throwing missiles towards a mosque in the seaside town at around 7:45 p.m.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted,\" adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice.\"\n\nEight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured.\n\nA 17-year-old, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff, Wales to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, outside Southport, and police have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nOn Wednesday, detectives were granted more time to question the suspect.\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight. The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nSome 27 officers were taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, according to the North West Ambulance Service.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force.\"\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nChairman of Merseyside Police Federation Chris McGlade said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nThe protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAround the time of the vigil, a 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nHe posted on social media platform X: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets,\" which she branded \"appalling.\"\n\nShe added: \"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside. There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our {"uri": "8251977095", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:43:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:43:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:42:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/news/24487368.southport-riots-almost-40-police-officers-injured-violent-protest/", "title": "Almost 40 officers injured following riot in Southport after deaths of three girls", "body": "ALMOST 40 police officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars set alight during violent protests in Southport.\n\nThe disorder spread following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said that a \"large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - had started to throw items such as bricks towards a mosque in a seaside town around 7.45pm.\n\nThe Prime Minister has already said that the rioters will \"feel the full force of the law\" while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper (below) described the scenes as \"appalling\" and branded the protesters \"violent thugs\".\n\nFormer first minister Humza Yousaf also took to Twitter/X with a statement, writing: \"Attacking mosques and chanting Islamophobic abuse. Let's not pretend the far-right care one jot about children murdered in Southport.\n\n\"These thugs are scum who are exploiting the killing of children for their own bigoted ends. This is what happens when you appease the far-right.\"\n\nPrior to the riot, Downing Street had been forced to issue a statement over concerns that misreporting online could inflame tensions in the community.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted,\" adding that those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nThe violent scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nREAD MORE: Anas Sarwar must apologise for misleading voters on cuts, say Greens\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into
