{"uri": "8252142875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:33:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:33:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:27:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13692605/Locals-clean-people-town-cause-mayhem-Southport.html", "title": "Locals clean up after 'people from out of town cause mayhem\u00b4 in...", "body": "Locals in Southport have gathered for a clean-up operation outside a mosque after right-wing rioters brought further misery to a town already reeling from a knife attack that left three children dead.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nOfficers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine; Bebe King, six; and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\nResponse workers clear Sussex Road in Southport, Merseyside (James Speakman/PA)\n\n\"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\nViolence at the Southport protest, which saw a police van set alight (Richard McCarthy/PA)\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nTrouble flares during a protest in Southport, after three children died in a stabbing during a Taylor Swift event at a dance school (Richard McCarthy/PA)\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nA police van set alight as trouble flares during a protest in Southport (Pat Hurst/PA)\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said, on Wednesday, that rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nMembers of the public take part in a vigil near the scene of the attack in Hart Street, Southport (James Speakman/PA)\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8252136240", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:25:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:25:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:24:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/31/locals-clean-up-after-people-from-out-of-town-cause-mayhem-in-southport/", "title": "Locals clean up after 'people from out of town cause mayhem' in Southport", "body": "Dozens of volunteers gathered near the town's mosque with brushes and shovels after a night of violent protest.\n\nLocals in Southport have gathered for a clean-up operation outside a mosque after right-wing rioters brought further misery to a town already reeling from a knife attack that left three children dead.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nOfficers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine; Bebe King, six; and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\n\"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said, on Wednesday, that rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n\"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was {"uri": "8251937437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:16:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:16:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:15:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/southport-rioters-will-feel-full-29646835", "title": "Southport rioters will feel 'full force of the law', says PM Sir Keir Starmer", "body": "Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters who 'hijacked' a peaceful vigil would 'feel the full force of the law' after violence flared and police were attacked in Southport last night.\n\nThree young girls - Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven - died after a knifeman walked into a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club and attacked those inside on Monday morning. Eight other children suffered stab wounds during the attack - with a number of them said to remain in a critical condition in hospital. Two adults were also injured 'bravely' trying to save children. One is said to be fighting for her life.\n\nViolence flared on the streets after police said a large group believed to be linked to the English Defence League attacked a mosque just hours after a vigil was held for the victims, their families - and the community.\n\nREAD MORE: Southport stabbings LIVE: Nearly 40 police officers injured after violent unrest erupts following vigil\n\nNorth West Ambulance Service said 39 people were treated, \"all of which were police officers\".\n\n\"27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene\", a statement on X said. Merseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nThe force said those involved set cars belonging to members of the public alight, threw bricks at the local mosque and damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect. She added: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said officers had faced violence from \"thugs\", while Southport MP Patrick Hurley said it was \"distressing\" to see \"people from outside our Southport community attacking our police and local people\".\n\nHundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a separate protest outside a local mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road. {"uri": "8252255903", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:36:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:36:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:36:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/article/2024/jul/31/southport-mp-condemns-rioters-as-victims-mother-calls-for-calm", "title": "Southport MP condemns rioters as victim's mother calls for calm", "body": "Dozens of police officers injured in violent protests following vigil for victims of Monday's knife attack\n\nThe Southport MP, Patrick Hurley, has said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\" after 39 police officers suffered serious injuries during violent protests following a vigil for the victims of Monday's knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nMerseyside police said those involved in the violent unrest in the north-west seaside town on Tuesday evening - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars, threw bricks at a local mosque, damaged a local convenience store and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nThe violent protests, which began at about 7.45pm, followed a peaceful vigil for the victims of the attack outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue attended by hundreds of people, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe mother of one of the three girls killed in the knife attack made an impassioned plea to \"stop the violence\", the Liverpool Echo and PA Media reported.\n\nJenni Stancombe, the mother of Elsie Dot Stancombe, reportedly wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight. The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nElsie, seven, Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, and Bebe King, six, were fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday. Eight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody.\n\nNorth West Ambulance service said 27 officers were taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene of the rioting. Merseyside police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Three police dogs were also injured.\n\nHurley said the violence was the result of \"propaganda and lies\" circulated on social media about the identity of the attacker within minutes of Monday's tragic incident.\n\nThe MP condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"These were thugs who got the train in, these were not the people from Southport.\n\n\"They were using the horrific incident on Monday, the deaths of three little kiddies, for their own political purposes and actually to attack the very same first responders and the very same police, who had been on the scene on Monday, were then being pelted with bricks the day after by these thugs.\"\n\nHe hit out at the \"swirling morass\" of social media \"lies and propaganda\", saying they had fuelled rumours about the attacker's identity as well as criticism of politicians. False claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nHe told Times Radio: \"We'd had all sorts of lies being spread and misinformation being spread about the alleged perpetrator and some people with the best of intentions then they tried to rebut this, they tried to argue back, but all that happens is you're just amplifying people's false messaging.\"\n\nHe added: \"This misinformation doesn't just exist on people's internet browsers and on people's phones. It has real world impact.\"\n\nDozens of local residents turned up outside Southport mosque on Wednesday morning with brushes and shovels to help with the clean-up operation.\n\nWriting on X, Keir Starmer, the prime minister, said on Tuesday night: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nThe home secretary, Yvette Cooper, described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nIn a post on social media, Merseyside police said shops had been broken into and looted, adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport. A road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack was unclear, it was not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick-knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside police said.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8252018570", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:12:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:12:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:10:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/police-van-set-alight-protest-204807624.html", "title": "Thugs 'hijacked' Southport and families' grief - MP", "body": "Stewart Whittingham, Marc Waddington & Ian Shoesmith - BBC News\n\n\"Thugs\" were to blame for the violence that saw 39 police officers injured in Southport, the town's MP has said.\n\nUnrest broke out in the Merseyside town hours after a vigil to remember the victims of Monday's knife attack at a dance school in which three young girls were killed.\n\nOfficers were pelted with bricks, a police van was set on fire, and eight officers were seriously hurt, Merseyside Police said.\n\nMP Patrick Hurley described the violence - close to a mosque - as \"horrific\".\n\nMr Hurley told BBC's Radio 4 Today programme that the \"riot\" was \"led by people from outside the town\".\n\nPolice said the violence was believed to have involved English Defence League supporters.\n\nMr Hurley condemned \"thugs who had got the train in\" who were using the \"deaths of three little kiddies for their own political purposes\".\n\nOn Tuesday, Merseyside Police named the three girls who were killed at a Taylor Swift-themed dance workshop at the Hart Space studio in Hart Street.\n\nThey were six-year-old Bebe King, Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine.\n\nAt about 18:00 BST, a peaceful vigil was held outside the Atkinson gallery in Lord Street, with more than 1,000 people estimated to have attended.\n\nThroughout the day, though, there had been rumours circulating online of a planned demonstration near to a mosque on St Luke's Road.\n\nAt about 19:45, demonstrators began to gather and engaged in a stand-off with police officers.\n\nAs the disorder escalated, officers donned protective gear and used riot shields to defend themselves from bricks, wheelie bins and other objects being hurled towards them.\n\nA police vehicle was also set on fire.\n\nMr Hurley said it was \"reprehensible\" that police officers who had, the day before been attending to injured victims, were finding themselves \"being pelted with bricks by these thugs\".\n\nThe MP said they had \"hijacked the grief\" of the town and families.\n\nHe said: \"These people are utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured and totally disrespecting the town.\"\n\nIn total, 27 officers were taken to hospital, and 12 were treated and discharged at the scene, the ambulance service said.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order has been put in place, giving police extra stop and search powers.\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced, allowing police to direct people who are engaging in antisocial behaviour or are \"likely to become involved in such behaviour\" away from the area.\n\nMerseyside Police said extra officers would remain in the area \"to provide a visible presence and reassure communities\".\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said it was \"sickening\" that this was happening within a \"devastated\" community.\n\nHe said the force has faced \"serious violence\" and was \"so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\"\n\nACC Goss also thanked officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police for providing mutual aid and support.\n\nHe added the disorder involved many people \"who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside\".\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park,\" he said.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nA 17-year-old boy was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after Monday's attack.\n\nACC Goss said: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK, and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nPM Sir Keir Starmer said on X that the people of Southport were \"reeling\" after the \"horror inflicted on them yesterday\".\n\nHe said that those who had \"hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery\" had insulted the community and would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nFamilies living nearby told the BBC they feared for their safety as stones flew past and police officers rushed to put on riot gear and pick up shields.\n\n\"I can't believe this is happening in Southport,\" one young woman shouted from the front of her car as she tried to drive her young daughter away.\n\nThe disorder began after hundreds of people gathered near a local mosque attacking the front of it, throwing bricks, bottles, fireworks and rocks, many with hoods up and scarves hiding their faces.\n\nMerseyside Police said those behind the violence had been fired up by social media posts which incorrectly suggested an Islamist link to Monday's stabbings.\n\nThe Home Secretary Yvette Cooper had earlier warned about disinformation linked to the attack.\n\nThe suspect has no known links to Islam.\n\nMs Cooper later said it was \"appalling\" that police officers in Southport were facing attacks from \"thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community\".\n\n\"I think everyone should be showing some respect for the community that is grieving and also for the police who are pursuing an urgent criminal investigation now, and who showed such heroism and bravery yesterday in the face of these horrific attacks,\" she said.\n\nIn a statement on X, Merseyside Police and Crime Commissioner Emily Spurrell also said she was \"absolutely appalled by the disgraceful scenes of violence\".\n\n\"This is a community which has faced unimaginable tragedy, and it is grieving.\n\n\"Such behaviour is abhorrent and only causes further harm and suffering,\" she added.\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy posted on X that more than 1,000 residents from Southport had come together at the vigil to remember the little girls who had died, those who were still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed and were traumatised by the events from yesterday.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_of_parliament", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, {"uri": "8251406332", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:10:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:10:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:07:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/violent-clashes-between-protesters-police-204512091.html", "title": "Violent clashes between protesters and police in Southport following stabbings", "body": "Officers were left injured in clashes with protesters outside a mosque in Southport on Tuesday after three girls were killed in a knife attack.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said police should be shown respect while they investigate the Southport attack as she condemned the \"thuggery\" of rioters.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport, Merseyside, on Monday.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nHundreds of people took part in a vigil on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nBut some protesters on Tuesday gathered outside a mosque in the town where missiles were thrown at police and cars were set alight.\n\nMerseyside Police said on X: \"A number of officers have been injured, cars set alight and a shop broken into and looted in Southport this evening. This is completely unacceptable.\n\n\"We're gathering evidence and those responsible will be brought to justice.\"\n\nOfficers earlier said they believed some of those involved in the disorder were \"believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\".\n\nThe unnamed 17-year-old suspect in the case is from Wales, police have said, but false claims had spread online that he was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nSpeaking to broadcasters on Tuesday night, Ms Cooper branded the incident \"a total disgrace\".\n\nShe said the community had thanked the police for their \"heroism\", adding: \"That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n\"It is a total disgrace. Frankly, this is a time when everyone should be showing respect for a community and for the police.\"\n\nShe went on: \"Frankly the scenes of thuggery that we have seen on the streets of Southport this evening bear no relation to the way in which the Southport community has been coming together to support each other and to support grieving families.\"\n\nIn the Commons she had earlier urged social media companies to \"take some responsibility\" for speculation in the aftermath of the attack, as the case was \"about children and their families who will be grieving\".\n\nPolice said a name shared on social media in connection with the suspect is \"incorrect\", adding: \"We would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.\"\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", {"uri": "2024-07-439339549", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:01:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:01:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:55:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.lancasterguardian.co.uk/news/crime/tower-lights-up-in-memory-of-children-killed-in-southport-knife-attack-4720911", "title": "Southport stabbings: Tower lights up in memory of children killed in knife attack", "body": "Locals in Southport have gathered for a clean-up operation outside a mosque after right-wing rioters brought further misery to a town already reeling from a knife attack that left three children dead.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said the English Defence League was to blame for the violence after false claims spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nOfficers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine; Bebe King, six; and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\n\"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. {"uri": "2024-07-439253394", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:52:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:52:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:32:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/a-violent-crowd-fights-with-riot-police-and-sets-police-vehicles-ablaze-outside-a-mosque-near-the-location-of-a-tragic-stabbing-in-southport/", "title": "A violent crowd fights with riot police and sets police vehicles ablaze outside a mosque near the location of a tragic stabbing in Southport. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "POLICE vans were set on fire as cops clashed with rioters outside a mosque in Southport near the scene of a horror stabbing that left three dead.\n\nLarge crowds fought with officers in the Merseyside town not far from where three children were killed in a sickening knife rampage on Monday.\n\nShocking footage from the scene showed bottles and bricks being thrown at police vans as other projectiles hurtled through the air.\n\nMerseyside Police said that the English Defence League was believed to be behind the violent protests.\n\nIt comes as tensions run high in the town following a stabbing attack, where three children were killed while attending a Taylor Swift-themed yoga and dance workshop.\n\nSpeculation about the alleged attacker's identity circulated online, fuelling the tension that already existed after Monday's horrific attack.\n\nDespite social media claims, the suspect was born in Cardiff.\n\nRiot police wearing helmets and carrying large shields huddled together as chaos outside the mosque in Southport raged on for hours.\n\nMore than one police vehicle was set alight, as thick smoke billowed into the balmy air.\n\nProtestors in the crowd were heard shouting, as a police helicopter was heard scouring the area from above.\n\nRiot police and dogs units were deployed to bring the crowd under control with multiple cops sustaining injuries.\n\nEmergency services confirmed 22 police officers were injured and 11 were hospitalised after violent clashes.\n\nOf those, eight sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nSome yobs even climbed on top of a building before throwing rocks down at police.\n\nBottles and wheelie bins were also hurled at officers responding to the incident in a night of violence.\n\nA fresh supply of riot cops then arrived to take on the crowds but they were met with a salvo of rocks and bricks.\n\nThe force managed to clear the area directly outside the mosque and stood guard with their batons raised.\n\nTwo more fires, which appear to be wheelie bins, were set alight as the crowds dispersed.\n\nMerseyside Police said that a 24-hour Section 60 Order has been introduced in the area.\n\nThe Order, under S60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994, gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals in the area and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nCops confirmed cars were set ablaze and multiple officers were injured after the \"unacceptable\" behaviour.\n\nThe force said that shops were also broken into and looted in Southport and warned that anyone responsible would be \"brought to justice\".\n\nA local man told The Sun: \"Surely the police could have done more to prevent this from happening.\n\n\"Burning, looting and bricks. Will we ever get over this.\"\n\nThe violence appears to have been linked to several false accusations spread online.\n\nThe area is around a five-minute walk from the scene of Monday's stabbing attack.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss says: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\"\n\nIt comes after hundreds of people rallied together in solidarity outside The Aktinson Art Gallery in Merseyside to pay their respects at a separate peaceful vigil.\n\nSome lit candles while others lay flowers and reflected on the tragedy.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said anyone involved in the disorder in Southport will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nHe added: \"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said it was \"appalling\" police officers in Southport were facing attacks from \"thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community\".\n\nThe MP for Southport says she was \"deeply concerned\" by the violent protest and has urged people to \"stay safe\".\n\nIn a statement on X, Patrick Hurley says he \"fully condemns any attack\" on emergency services, pointing out that these are the same services that responded to the tragic stabbing attack.\n\nHe added: \"I appeal to local people to avoid the area and stay safe, to allow the police to do their job. I want to thank our community for pulling together and supporting every person who has been affected by Monday's tragic attack.\"\n\nThe MP also thanked those who attended a vigil earlier to remember the three children - Bebe King, Elsie Dot Stancombe and Alice Dasilva Aguiar - who were killed in the attack, and the 10 other people who were injured.\n\n\"I was deeply saddened to hear the news today of the death of a third child. Bebe, Elsie and Alice are in all of our thoughts and hearts today,\" he adds.\n\nMeanwhile, a man \"wearing a balaclava\" and carrying a knife was arrested in Southport last night - just yards from the vigil.\n\nMerseyside Police confirmed they had arrested a 32-year-old on suspicion of possessing a bladed article - while the force's Detective Inspector condemned knife crime in the aftermath of the \"swift arrest\".\n\nIt comes as Bebe and Elsie, aged six and seven, were identified as the first victims in the attack on Tuesday .\n\nArmed police were called to the scene on Hart Street, Southport, at 11.47am on Monday.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio.\n\nMerseyside Police said the motive is currently unclear but it was not suspected to be terror-related.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast police said was believed to involve English Defence League supporters, began only a few streets away from the vigil location, near to a mosque on St Luke's Road in Southport.\n\nMerseyside Police said a number of officers had been injured, police vehicles had been damaged and set alight, and a shop had been looted in the disturbances which began at about 19:45 BST.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said it was \"sickening\" that this was happening within a \"devastated\" community.\n\nACC Goss added: \"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face.\n\n\"Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\"\n\nACC Goss said the protest involved many people \"who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside\".\n\nA 17-year-old boy has been arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after Monday's attack on a children's dance club in Hart Street.\n\nHe added: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK, and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nFamilies living nearby told the BBC they feared for their safety as stones flew past and police officers rushed to put on riot gear and pick up shields.\n\n\"I can't believe this is happening in Southport,\" one young woman shouted from the front of her car as she tried to drive her young daughter away.\n\nThe riot began after hundreds of protesters gathered near a local mosque attacking the front of it, throwing bricks, bottles, fireworks and rocks, many with hoods up and scarves hiding their faces.\n\nMerseyside Police said those behind the violence had been fired up by social media posts which incorrectly suggested an Islamist link to Monday's stabbings.\n\nThe Home Secretary Yvette Cooper had earlier warned about disinformation linked to the attack.\n\nThe suspect has no known links to Islam.\n\nMs Cooper later Southport", "body": "Community rallies together after 'people from out of town' riot in Southport\n\nPA Reporters\n\n31 July 2024 at 0:06 pm\n\nLocals in Southport are rallying together after right-wing rioters marred a night of remembrance for three murdered children.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder on Tuesday night.\n\nMr Balasuryla said he called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away.\n\nHe said he was \"terrified\" when he thought they would set fire to the premises because there is a woman and her daughter living in a flat above.\n\nHe said he later found out that the woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them.\n\n\"I got a couple of hours' sleep and then got a phone call saying 'You need to come down, there's lots of people waiting to help',\" Mr Balasuryla said.\n\nHe added that local people had said they would defend his shop if necessary.\n\n\"It was terrifying last night,\" he said.\n\n\"But I feel safe again because people are here to protect us.\"\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\n\"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brick", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"uri": "8251473035", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:27:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:27:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:26:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/world/523701/officers-hurt-and-police-van-set-alight-in-southport-uk", "title": "Officers hurt and police van set alight in Southport, UK", "body": "Several officers have been injured and a police van set on fire during a protest just hours after a vigil took place to remember the victims of a knife attack in which three children were killed.\n\nThe protest, which police said was believed to involve English Defence League supporters, began only a few streets away from the vigil location, near to a mosque on St Luke's Road in Southport.\n\nMerseyside Police said a number of officers had been injured, police vehicles had been damaged and set alight, and a shop had been looted in the disturbances which began at about 19:45 BST.\n\nAssistant chief constable Alex Goss said it was \"sickening\" that this was happening within a \"devastated\" community.\n\nHe said that on Monday the officers had been \"faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face\".\n\n\"Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\"\n\nHe added the protest involved many people \"who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside\".\n\nA 17-year-old boy has been arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after Monday's attack on a children's dance club in Hart Street.\n\nGoss said: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK, and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nPM Sir Keir Starmer said on X that the people of Southport were \"reeling\" after the \"horror inflicted on them yesterday\".\n\nHe said that those who had \"hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery\" had insulted the community and would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nFamilies living nearby told the BBC they feared for their safety as stones flew past and police officers rushed to put on riot gear and pick up shields.\n\n\"I can't believe this is happening in Southport,\" one young woman shouted from the front of her car as she tried to drive her young daughter away.\n\nThe riot began after hundreds of protesters gathered near a local mosque attacking the front of it, throwing bricks, bottles, fireworks and rocks, many with hoods up and scarves hiding their faces.\n\nMerseyside Police said those behind the violence had been fired up by social media posts which incorrectly suggested an Islamist link to Monday's stabbings.\n\nThe Home Secretary Yvette Cooper had earlier warned about disinformation linked to the attack.\n\nThe suspect has no known links to Islam.\n\nCooper later said it was \"appalling\" that police officers in Southport were facing attacks from \"thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community\".\n\n\"I think everyone should be showing some respect for the community that is grieving and also for the police who are pursuing an urgent criminal investigation now, and who showed such heroism and bravery yesterday in the face of these horrific attacks,\" she said.\n\nIn a statement on X, Merseyside Police and Crime Commissioner Emily Spurrell also said she was \"absolutely appalled by the disgraceful scenes of violence\".\n\n\"This is a community which has faced unimaginable tragedy, and it is grieving.\n\n\"Such behaviour is abhorrent and only causes further harm and suffering,\" she added.\n\nMerseyside Police chief constable Serena Kennedy posted on X that more than 1000 residents from Southport had come together at the vigil to remember the little girls who had died, those who were still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed and were traumatised by the events from yesterday.\n\n\"This is where all of our focus should be,\" she said.\n\nThe Liverpool Region Mosque Network said the violent scenes were \"causing further fear and anxiety within our communities\".\n\nIt added: \"We must all unite and stand together against all forms of hate, violence and division.\"\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said he was \"deeply concerned about reports of violent protests tonight\".\n\nHe said the protests involved \"people from outside our Southport community attacking our police and local people\".", "source": {"uri": "rnz.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "RNZ"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": far-right thugs in Southport", "body": "Those involved in the disorder - believed to include supporters of the racist organisation the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nThey also attacked police in the area, with 39 officers having to be taken to hospital for treatment to injuries.\n\nThe mob had hijacked an evening of peace in the town following Monday's shocking knife attack on a children's Taylor Swift-themed dance class which has left three young girls dead and several more children and adults critically injured.\n\nAlmost 40 police officers were injured in the violence (Image: PA)\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, have all died following the incident.\n\nHundreds attended a peaceful vigil in Southport for the victims before the night descended into anarchy.\n\nA statement from North West Ambulance Service said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers.\n\n\"27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\"\n\nEarlier hundreds had attended a vigil in the town for the victims of the knife attack (Image: PA)\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with two suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them, and a third suffered burns to her back leg.\n\nFar-right thugs targeted a mosque in Southport (Image: PA)\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nThree girls aged six to nine died in the knife attack (Image: PA)\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, living in Banks, Lancashire, and born in Cardiff, has been arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder and remains in custody.\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain says Islamophobic backlash began with a false rumour on the internet which was then stoked by misinformation from a Russian news site, which wrongfully associated the crime with Muslims.\n\nThe MCB paid tribute to the three young girls killed in Southport on Monday, before condemning \"shocking scenes of far-right rioters running amok outside a mosque\".", "source": {"uri": "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13694011/Merseyside-Police-call-neighbouring-forces-to-help-prevent-riots.html", "title": "Merseyside Police calls in neighbouring forces to help prevent...", "body": "Police in Merseyside have called in support from forces across the region to avoid a second night of rioting in tragedy-hit Southport.\n\nViolence erupted near the town's mosque on Tuesday after false rumours circulated online about the suspect in a mass stabbing that claimed the lives of three girls and left eight more children and two adults injured.\n\nFour people have been arrested over the unrest so far, which saw 53 officers and three police dogs injured.\n\nDuring a walkabout in the town on Wednesday, Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said she understood that communities in Southport were \"really worried\" about whether they would see a second night of unrest.\n\nShe said: \"We are absolutely planning for this evening and for the weekend ahead.\n\n\"We are being really well supported by police forces across the North West to make sure we have got sufficient resources so that we don't see a repeat of last night.\"\n\nA police van was set alight as trouble flared during the far-right protest on Tuesday (Richard McCarthy/PA)\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during unrest that followed a vigil for the murdered children.\n\nBaseless rumours were spread on social media, misidentifying the suspect and falsely claiming that he was a refugee when, in fact, he was born in Wales.\n\nActor Laurence Fox, one of the users of X who shared the information, called on supporters to gather at Downing Street at 7pm on Wednesday.\n\nDetectives have been given more time to question the 17-year-old, who was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder.\n\nThe law allows officers up to 96 hours, or four days, to hold the suspect, who has not been named because of his age, in custody.\n\nThree girls: Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine; Bebe King, six; and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven; were fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed children's holiday club on Monday.\n\nAfter rioting broke out, Elsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nLeft to right, six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine (Merseyside Police/PA)\n\nIn the wake of the violence, locals in Southport rallied together to support the Muslim community and clear up the mess left by rioters who it is claimed came from outside of the area.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, clearing bricks from a wall that was knocked down during the rioting.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nHe said: \"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMosque chairman Ibrahim Hussein told reporters he was trapped in the mosque with about eight others as the violence erupted, and only escaped with a police guard.\n\nSouthport mosque chairman Ibrahim Hussein told the media that he was trapped in the building with eight other people for several hours (James Speakman/PA)\n\nHe said: \"It was terrifying. It was absolutely, awful, horrendous. We couldn't understand this viciousness that was going on.\"\n\nLocals have brought flowers to the mosque and are helping organise repairs to the building, which Mr Hussein said was \"humbling\".\n\n\"I know the people of Southport and I know how beautiful they are but this was still a moving experience to see all that,\" he said.\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder on Tuesday night.\n\nHe called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away, and was \"terrified\" that they might set fire to the premises because a woman and her daughter live in the flat above.\n\nThe woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them, he said.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nAngela Rayner said that Home Secretary Yvette Cooper will look at whether the EDL should be banned, despite former leader Tommy Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 police officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nMembers of the public took part in a peaceful vigil near to the scene in Hart Street on Tuesday (James Speakman/PA)\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is {"uri": "8252223491", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:18:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:18:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:17:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/31/community-rallies-together-after-people-from-out-of-town-riot-in-southport/", "title": "Community rallies together after 'people from out of town' riot in Southport", "body": "Locals gathered with brushes and shovels to clean up after violence outside a mosque and pledged support for the owner of a looted shop.\n\nLocals in Southport are rallying together after right-wing rioters marred a night of remembrance for three murdered children.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder on Tuesday night.\n\nMr Balasuryla said he called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away.\n\nHe said he was \"terrified\" when he thought they would set fire to the premises because there is a woman and her daughter living in a flat above.\n\nHe said he later found out that the woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them.\n\n\"I got a couple of hours' sleep and then got a phone call saying 'You need to come down, there's lots of people waiting to help',\" Mr Balasuryla said.\n\nHe added that local people had said they would defend his shop if necessary.\n\n\"It was terrifying last night,\" he said.\n\n\"But I feel safe again because people are here to protect us.\"\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\n\"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "shropshirestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Shropshire Star"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brick", "type": "wiki", Police have not confirmed his identity due to his age but have said he was born in the UK.\n\nThere is no suggestion he is a Muslim.\n\nMerseyside Police has said a large group of people began throwing objects at the mosque on St Luke's Road at around 7.45 pm this evening.\n\nOfficers later put on helmets and riot gear as bottles and wheelie bins were thrown at them.\n\nA police officer suffered a broken nose, others have minor injuries and one of the force's vans was set on fire.\n\nThe force said additional patrols were later sent to the scene including a dog unit.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said that many of the people involved in tonight's violence do not live in Merseyside or care about the people who live in the county, says Sky News.\n\nHe added, \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nThe situation outside the mosque appeared to have calmed down as dark descended, with numbers on the street having thinned.\n\nMs Cooper said it was \"appalling\" police officers in Southport were facing attacks from \"thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community\", adding: \"It's a total disgrace\".\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said, \"I am incredibly proud of my officers and staff who have worked so hard to save the lives of children, investigate the horrific incident from yesterday, working with partners to provide reassurance to our communities and now they are facing this level of violence from these thugs.\"\n\nPolice were called to a premises on Hart Street in Southport shortly before midday on Monday after 11 children and two adults were stabbed.\n\nThree of the children later died and have
