{"uri": "8252679533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:58:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:58:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:55:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/merseyside-police-call-neighbouring-forces-145109615.html", "title": "Merseyside Police call in neighbouring forces to to help prevent further riots", "body": "Police in Merseyside have called in support from forces across the region to avoid a second night of rioting in tragedy-hit Southport.\n\nViolence erupted near the town's mosque on Tuesday after false rumours circulated online about the suspect in a mass stabbing that claimed the lives of three girls and left eight more children and two adults injured.\n\nDuring a walkabout in the town on Wednesday, Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said she understood that communities in Southport were \"really worried\" about whether they would see a second night of unrest.\n\nShe said: \"We are absolutely planning for this evening and for the weekend ahead.\n\n\"We are being really well supported by police forces across the North West to make sure we have got sufficient resources so that we don't see a repeat of last night.\"\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during unrest that followed a vigil for the murdered children.\n\nBaseless rumours were spread on social media, misidentifying the suspect and falsely claiming that he was a refugee when, in fact, he was born in Wales.\n\nActor Laurence Fox, one of the users of X who shared the information, called on supporters to gather at Downing Street at 7pm on Wednesday.\n\nDetectives have been given more time to question the 17-year-old, who was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder.\n\nThe law allows officers up to 96 hours, or four days, to hold the suspect, who has not been named because of his age, in custody.\n\nThree girls: Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine; Bebe King, six; and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven; were fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed children's holiday club on Monday.\n\nAfter rioting broke out, Elsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nIn the wake of the violence, locals in Southport rallied together to support the Muslim community and clear up the mess left by rioters who it is claimed came from outside of the area.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, clearing bricks from a wall that was knocked down during the rioting.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nHe said: \"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMosque chairman Ibrahim Hussein told reporters he was trapped in the mosque with about eight others as the violence erupted, and only escaped with a police guard.\n\nHe said: \"It was terrifying. It was absolutely, awful, horrendous. We couldn't understand this viciousness that was going on.\"\n\nLocals have brought flowers to the mosque and are helping organise repairs to the building, which Mr Hussein said was \"humbling\".\n\n\"I know the people of Southport and I know how beautiful they are but this was still a moving experience to see all that,\" he said.\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder on Tuesday night.\n\nHe called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away, and was \"terrified\" that they might set fire to the premises because a woman and her daughter live in the flat above.\n\nThe woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them, he said.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nAngela Rayner said that Home Secretary Yvette Cooper will look at whether the EDL should be banned, despite former leader Tommy Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 police officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport.\n\nPolice have said that although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death/Suicide", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death/Suicide", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/3PejH.TfeBpfXjLGGQStkQ--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTEyMDA7aD02NzU7Y2Y9d2VicA--/https://media.zenfs.com/en/pa_viral_news_uk_120/6df1d0110c388cd1891fc85910b8ec13", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9777011", "eventUri": "eng-9777011", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.207843137254902, "wgt": 182, "relevance": 1}

Eight other children suffered stab wounds during the attack - with a number of them said to remain in a critical condition in hospital. Two adults were also injured 'bravely' trying to save children. One is said to be fighting for her life.\n\nElsie Dot Stancombe was described by her school as a 'one of a kind pupil' and a 'a caring and charismatic young lady who loved to please'.\n\nREAD MORE: Southport stabbings LIVE: Nearly 40 police officers injured after violent unrest erupts following vigil\n\nHer mum, Jenni Stancombe, took to social media after police came under attack from large groups of yobs who initially surrounded a mosque in Southport close to the scene of the stabbings.\n\nPolice vehicles were set alight, bottles and bricks thrown and burning wheelie bins rammed at police lines as widespread rioting followed a peaceful vigil for the victims.\n\nParamedics treated 39 police officers in total, with 27 taken to hospital as North West Ambulance Service declared a major incident.\n\nMs Stancombe made an impassioned plea to 'stop the violence' in Southport after last night's shameful scenes, reports the Echo.\n\nWith the town continuing to try to come to terms with the appalling tragedy, hundreds of people made their way to a vigil in the town centre yesterday evening, which was respectfully observed. Trouble, however, was brewing nearby.\n\nPolice initially raced to the disturbance outside a mosque on St Luke's Road in the town before the violence spread.\n\nBricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire, police said. Eight police officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries. One was knocked unconscious.\n\nPolice said the violence started when a large group of people, believed by police to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards the mosque.\n\nIn a message widely shared on social media, Ms Stancombe said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nSpeaking about the police, she added: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nGreater Manchester Police officers were drafted in to support their Merseyside colleagues.\n\nMerseyside Police assistant chief constable Alex Goss said last night the force faced 'serious violence' and off-duty officers paraded back on.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park,\" he said.\n\nPrime Minister SIr Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. {"uri": "8251969886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:38:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:38:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:38:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.examinerlive.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/southport-mum-fatally-stabbed-daughter-29646976", "title": "Southport mum of fatally stabbed daughter calls for peace after violence", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nThe grieving mother of a seven year old victim in the Southport knife attack issued a touching plea to end the violence as chaos engulfed the town.\n\nJenni Stancombe, who lost her daughter Elsie Dot Stancombe in what has been described as an appalling crime at a Taylor Swift-themed dance party, turned to social media for her heartfelt call for peace. Monday's nightmarish event also claimed the lives of Alice Aguiar, aged nine, and six year old Bebe King, leaving two adults and five other children fighting for their lives in hospital.\n\nIn the wake of the tragedy, a large congregation held a vigil in the town centre last night which was initially marked by a solemn atmosphere. Despite the respectful tribute, a fracas ensued near the site, prompting law enforcement intervention outside a mosque on St Luke's Road, reports The Express.\n\nREAD MORE Brits heading to Spain warned over clothing rule 'no matter where you go'\n\nJenni Stancombe's widely circulated online message read: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nShe further honoured the efforts of the police force with these words: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\" A major incident was declared after disturbances saw officers injured, walls stripped of bricks for use as missiles, and civilian vehicles torched.\n\nEight police officers have been left with serious injuries, including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries, and one was even knocked unconscious. The violence broke out when a large group of people, believed by police to be supporters of the English Defence League, began hurling items at the local mosque on St Luke's Road on Tuesday evening.\n\nCars belonging to the public were torched, bricks were hurled at the mosque, and damage was inflicted on a local convenience store. Wheelie bins were also set alight, and three police dogs were injured. Photos and videos shared online depict large groups pelting rocks at police officers, clambering on police vans, and attempting to shatter the vehicles' windows.\n\nLast night, Merseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack. I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police, and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\"\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley has also condemned the \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks towards a mosque. \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all\", he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.\n\n\"Not least these beered-up thugs who have descended on the town last night intent on causing trouble. We all have to stand against that and Southport will not accept this. Southport will unite against this sort of thing.\"\n\nGet all the latest and breaking news in Yorkshire by signing up to our newsletter here.", "source": {"uri": "examinerlive.co.uk", "dataType": {"uri": "8252029923", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:18:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:18:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:17:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.lancs.live/news/lancashire-news/mum-girl-7-stabbed-death-29647159", "title": "Mum of girl, 7, stabbed to death in Southport issues plea to 'stop the violence'", "body": "The devastated mother of one of the three children tragically killed in the Southport knife attack has made a heartfelt plea to 'stop the violence' following last night's shocking events in the town.\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club. Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at around 7.45pm. Officers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nREAD MORE: 39 police officers injured with 27 in hospital after Southport riots as major incident declared\n\nJenni Stancombe, mum to seven-year-old Elsie, has now taken to social media to make her powerful appeal to those causing chaos on the town's streets. Elsie was described by her school as a 'one of a kind pupil' and a 'a caring and charismatic young lady who loved to please'.\n\nIn a message widely shared on social media, Ms Stancombe said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nSpeaking about the police, she added: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said. The troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nLancashire Constabulary officers were drafted in to support their Merseyside colleagues. Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back. Chairman of Merseyside Police Federation Chris McGlade said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nThe violent protests followed hundreds of people taking part in a peaceful vigil for the stabbing victims outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance. As well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road. Southport MP Patrick Hurley said on Wednesday that rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nMr Hurley condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nHe also hit out at the \"swirling morass\" of social media \"lies and propaganda\", saying they have fuelled rumours about the attacker's identity as well as criticism of politicians. False claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\". The suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks in West Lancashire, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related. A 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.\n\nSubscribe to our daily newsletter LANCS LIVE NEWS and get all the biggest stories from across Lancashire direct {"uri": "8252025415", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:15:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:15:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:14:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/southport-wakes-up-edl-mosque-33363068", "title": "Southport mosque riot that injured 40 cops leaves streets covered in rubbish", "body": "A road full of rubble and rubbish can be seen in Southport this morning with riot police on high alert after a night of violence.\n\nNearly 40 police officers sustained injuries and 27 were taken to hospital as chaos broke out on Tuesday as protestors met up following the frenzied stabbing attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club. After calm was finally restored, the extent of the chaos could be seen with smoke still rising from rubbish that had been set on fire and vehicles, including a police van that was burnt out.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them. A third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities. North West Ambulance Service said of the injured police officers: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\"\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence. A Section 34 Order has also been introduced, giving police the power to direct people engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support. Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\" Merseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe violence followed the stabbings of Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, at the Taylor Swift-themed holiday club. Eight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition. {"uri": "8252408683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:05:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:05:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:04:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.kentonline.co.uk/news/national/police-granted-more-time-to-question-southport-stabbings-suspect-124409/", "title": "Police granted more time to question Southport stabbings suspect", "body": "Detectives investigating the mass stabbing at a Southport holiday club that left three children dead have been granted more time to question the 17-year-old suspect.\n\nMerseyside Police confirmed that officers had asked magistrates for more time to question the teenager, who has not been named because of his age and remains in custody.\n\nThe law allows officers up to 96 hours, or four days, to hold a suspect in custody for serious crimes.\n\nThe 17-year-old was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the horror unfolded at a Taylor Swift-themed children's holiday club on Monday.\n\nThree girls - Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven - were fatally stabbed, while eight other children suffered knife wounds - five of whom are in a critical condition.\n\nTwo adults were also critically hurt.\n\nRight-wing rioters staged violent protests near Southport mosque on Tuesday, marring a night of remembrance for the little girls who lost their lives.\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during unrest that followed a vigil for the murdered children.\n\nBaseless rumours were spread on social media, misidentifying the suspect and falsely claiming that he was a refugee, when in fact he was born in Wales.\n\nIn the wake of the violence, locals in Southport rallied together to support the Muslim community and clear up the mess left by rioters who it is claimed came from outside the area.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, clearing bricks from a wall that was knocked down during the rioting.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nHe said: \"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMosque chairman Ibrahim Hussein told reporters he was trapped in the mosque with about eight others as the violence erupted, and only escaped with a police guard.\n\nHe said: \"It was terrifying. It was absolutely, awful, horrendous. We couldn't understand this viciousness that was going on.\"\n\nLocals have brought flowers to the mosque and are helping organise repairs to the building, which Mr Hussein said was \"humbling\".\n\n\"I know the people of Southport and I know how beautiful they are but this was still a moving experience to see all that,\" he said.\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder on Tuesday night.\n\nHe called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away, and was \"terrified\" that they might set fire to the premises because a woman and her daughter live in the flat above.\n\nThe woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them, he said.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nScotland's former first minister Humza Yousaf called for the EDL to be banned under terror laws in the wake of the unrest, despite former leader Tommy Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport.\n\nPolice have said that although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251689656", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:56:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:56:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:54:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/british-police-protesters-clash-outside-034228653.html", "title": "British police, protesters clash outside mosque following vigil for slain girls", "body": "July 30 (UPI) -- Dozens of police officers were injured Tuesday night as law enforcement and protesters clashed in Southport where a vigil was held hours earlier for three children killed and several injured during Monday's knife attack that has the British seaside town in mourning.\n\nThirty-nine police officers were treated for injuries sustained in the violence, including 27 who were taken to the hospital, North West Ambulance Service said in a statement early Wednesday.\n\nAuthorities said the violence began at about 7:45 p.m. local time Tuesday when a large group of people, police suspect are supporters of the English Defense League, began pelting a local mosque.\n\nThe English Defense League is a far-right, anti-Muslim and anti-immigrant group that sees itself as a Christian army, according to the U.S.-based Anti-Defamation League.\n\nProtesters set cars ablaze, threw bricks at the mosque and damaged a convenience store, Merseyside Police said.\n\nBricks stolen from garden walls were used to attack police, according to authorities.\n\nUncorroborated video clips of the violence posted online shows protesters, mostly men, throwing objects at police and the mosque. Some protesters are heard spouting Islamophobic chants.\n\nAt least eight officers suffered serious injuries, fractures, lacerations and concussion. At least one was knocked unconscious, Merseyside Police said.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured, one sustaining leg injuries from thrown bricks and another suffering burns to its back legs.\n\nThe disorder prompted authorities to issue a 24-hour Section 60 Order, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers in the designated area.\n\nThe cause of the revolt was not entirely clear, but Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss suggested in a statement that it was in connection to \"speculation and hypothesis\" surrounding the 17-year-old boy police arrested on suspicion of being responsible for Monday's knife attack.\n\nThe three children stabbed to death in Southport a day prior while attending a Taylor Swift-themed dance workshop have been identified as 9-year-old Alice Aguiar, 7-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and 6-year-old Bebe King. Five other children and two adults were also critically injured in the attack.\n\nPolice arrested the 17-year-old from Lancashire, Britain, who has been charged with suspicion of murder and attempted murder charges.\n\nGoss reiterated Tuesday: \"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the U.K. and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nHe added that many of those involved in the Tuesday violence do not live in the area \"or care about the people of Merseyside.\"\n\n\"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport,\" Goss said in an early Wednesday update.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nThe violence erupted after a vigil was held in the town for the children that was attended by Home Secretary Yvette Cooper and Prime Minister Keir Starmer who lay flowers during the ceremony.\n\nStarmer accused the protesters of having \"hijacked\" the vigil \"with violence and thuggery\" that insults the community in grieving.\n\n\"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and respect,\" he said in a statement, vowing that those responsible for the violence that followed the vigil \"will feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nFollowing Monday's devastating incident at Hart Street, Southport, today we were joined by Home Secretary @YvetteCooperMP and Prime Minister @Keir_Starmer to lay flowers for those who very sadly lost their lives.", vigil for three girls killed in Southport knife attack", "body": "Far-right protesters violently clashed with British police on Tuesday near a mosque in the northwest English town of Southport, a day after three young girls were stabbed to death in one of the worst assaults against children in the country in decades.\n\nBritish Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the group had \"hijacked\" a peaceful vigil held for those killed and injured in the attack \"with violence and thuggery\" and \"insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nThose involved \"will feel the full force of the law,\" Starmer added in the post on X.\n\nThe violence followed a peaceful vigil in the seaside town attended by hundreds of mourners who laid wreaths, toys and candles in an emotional tribute to the three girls who were killed during the attack during a Taylor Swift-themed event at a dance school.\n\nProtesters, believed to be supporters of the far-right English Defence League, took to the streets in anger throwing bricks at a local mosque, setting cars and police vehicles alight and hurling bottles at police, Merseyside Police said in a statement.\n\nPolice believe the crowd took to the streets over unconfirmed reports speculating on the identity of the teenage suspect, who was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder following Monday's knife attack.\n\nRiot police armed with shields and batons attempt to restore order in Southport, England on July 30, 2024.\n\nGetty Images\n\nOfficers \"sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion,\" Merseyside Police said. \"Other officers have suffered varying degrees of injury including head injuries, serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\"\n\nThree police dogs were also injured, with two sustaining leg injuries from bricks thrown at them and one suffering burns, it added.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said in a police statement, referring to the horrific knife attack.\n\n\"Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder,\" he said.\n\nThe North West Ambulance Service said it treated 39 police officers injured in the violence, 27 of whom were taken to hospital.\n\nFollowing the arrest in the stabbings case, an \"incorrect\" name linked to the suspect was spread on social media, police said.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Goss said.\n\n\"We have already said that the Two adults also remain in critical condition after being injured in the attack.\n\nPolice shared a tribute from the family of King, who said: \"No words can describe the devastation that has hit our family as we try to deal with the loss of our little girl Bebe.\"\n\nPrime Minister Starmer and other officials visited the site of the attack on Tuesday, paying tribute to the victims and thanking emergency responders who attended the scene.\n\nStarmer laid a wreath of cream and yellow-colored flowers, alongside floral tributes left by the local community.\n\nTaylor Swift, whose music was the {"uri": "8251785728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "05:21:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T05:21:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T05:20:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/uk-news/nearly-40-police-officers-injured-29646577", "title": "Nearly 40 police officers injured in riots after Southport stabbings", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nNearly 40 police officers sustained injuries at the scene of violent disorder in Southport, North West Ambulance Service said. The service said 27 officers were taken to hospital.\n\nA statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene. Merseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious. Three police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said. Merseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities. A 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced, giving police the power to direct people engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents. Merseyside police said these powers would not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support. \"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\" Merseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing attack in Southport on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club. The attack saw Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nEight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition. A 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain says Islamaphobic backlash began with a false rumour on the internet which was then stoked by misinformation from a Russian news site, which wrongfully associated the crime with {"uri": "8252460526", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:37:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:37:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:37:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.lancs.live/news/lancashire-news/southport-stabbings-latest-police-issue-29650074", "title": "Police issue update on 17-year-old arrested over Southport stabbings", "body": "Detectives investigating the mass stabbing at a Southport holiday club that left three children dead have been granted more time to question the 17-year-old suspect.\n\nMerseyside Police confirmed that officers had asked magistrates for more time to question the teenager, who has not been named because of his age and remains in custody. The law allows officers up to 96 hours, or four days, to hold a suspect in custody for serious crimes.\n\nThe 17-year-old was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the horror unfolded at a Taylor Swift-themed children's holiday club on Monday (July 29). Three girls - Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven - were fatally stabbed, while eight other children suffered knife wounds - five of whom are in a critical condition.\n\nREAD MORE: 'They destroyed our streets, now we're pulling together to clean up after night of chaos'\n\nTwo adults were also critically hurt. Right-wing rioters staged violent protests near Southport mosque on Tuesday, marring a night of remembrance for the little girls who lost their lives. Police officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during unrest that followed a vigil for the murdered children.\n\nBaseless rumours were spread on social media, misidentifying the suspect and falsely claiming that he was a refugee, when in fact he was born in Wales. In the wake of the violence, locals in Southport rallied together to support the Muslim community and clear up the mess left by rioters who it is claimed came from outside the area.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, clearing bricks from a wall that was knocked down during the rioting. Norman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nHe said: \"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem. People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMosque chairman Ibrahim Hussein told reporters he was trapped in the mosque with about eight others as the violence erupted, and only escaped with a police guard.\n\nHe said: \"It was terrifying. It was absolutely, awful, horrendous. We couldn't understand this viciousness that was going on.\"\n\nLocals have brought flowers to the mosque and are helping organise repairs to the building, which Mr Hussein said was \"humbling\".\n\n\"I know the people of Southport and I know how beautiful they are but this was still a moving experience to see all that,\" he said.\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder on Tuesday night. He called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away, and was \"terrified\" that they might set fire to the premises because a woman and her daughter live in the flat above.\n\nThe woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them, he said. Merseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nScotland's former first minister Humza Yousaf called for the EDL to be banned under terror laws in the wake of the unrest, despite former leader Tommy Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight. The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said. Merseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners. We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport. Police have said that although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nSubscribe to our daily newsletter LANCS LIVE NEWS and get all the biggest stories from {"uri": "2024-07-439355356", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:14:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:14:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:33:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.telegraphindia.com/world/mosque-targeted-around-40-police-officers-injured-in-mob-disorder-at-uk-stabbing-site/cid/2037623", "title": "Mosque targeted, around 40 police officers injured in mob disorder at UK stabbing site", "body": "According to reports, misinformation being spread on social media about the ethnicity and religion of the 17-year-old male suspect in police custody led to the rioting at the mosque in Southport\n\nA far-right mob targeted a mosque in north-west England that saw three young girls fatally stabbed during a peaceful vigil in their memory and around 40 police officers suffered injuries in the disorder.\n\nAccording to reports, misinformation being spread on social media about the ethnicity and religion of the 17-year-old male suspect in police custody led to the rioting at the mosque in Southport on Tuesday night.\n\nBritish Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who had earlier visited the site of Monday's brutal stabbing attack on a dance studio on Hart Street, condemned the mobs for hijacking the vigil and insulting the grieving community with their actions.\n\n\"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect,\" said Starmer.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law,\" he said.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, 9, Bebe King, 6, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, 7, were named as the victims of the fatal stabbing. Eight others were seriously injured, five of whom remain in critical condition in hospital.\n\nMerseyside Police have said it was currently not treating the incident as terror-related.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets. We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time,\" said Alex Goss, Assistant Chief Constable of the force.\n\nThe police said 22 of its officers sustained serious injuries, including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. The rioters set cars belonging to members of the public alight, threw bricks at the local mosque and damaged a local convenience store, and set large refuse bins on fire.\n\nAs a result, strict legal orders have been enforced in the area designed to minimise serious violence and giving additional powers to officers to tackle anti-social behaviour.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park. This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday,\" said Goss, as he appealed for information to bring those involved to justice.\n\nThe police attracted strong support from the local community, who believed the English Defence League (EDL) supporting mob was whipped up largely from outside the town.\n\nThe disorder flared up after thousands gathered at the peace vigil to pay tribute to three girls killed and pray for those fighting for their lives in the knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club dance event at Hart Street community centre.\n\nMeanwhile, two adults who were critically injured in the attack have been named locally as yoga teacher Leanne Lucas, who co-organised the dance session for a group of six to 11-year-olds, and John Hayes, who works at the Hart Space where the stabbings took place.\n\n\"It is extremely important that people don't spread damaging misinformation online. False information has already been extensively shared in the last 24 hours,\" urged UK Home Secretary Yvette Cooper.\n\n\"In these dark and difficult moments, the police must be able to get on with their work and communities must be given the time and space to grieve and heal without outside voices seeking to use events to stir up division or advance their own views,\" she said.\n\nMeanwhile, Merseyside Police confirmed officers are dealing with a disturbance on St Luke's Road in Southport which took place during a protest this evening (Tuesday).\n\nA large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque. Photos and video seen by the ECHO showed crowds gathered around police riot vans on St Luke's Road.\n\nIn one video, a man wearing a balaclava can be seen climbing on the top of a police van as people shout and cheer. Other videos show glass bottles being thrown at a police van and flares being set off.\n\nA police van was also seen up in flames. Police said officers at the scene are currently dealing with criminal behaviour and violence, with bottles and wheelie bins being thrown at them.\n\nAs a result, an officer has suffered a suspected broken nose and police vehicles have been damaged and set alight. Footage taken at the scene showed crowds gathering in front of officers carrying riot shields. Dozens of people were seen filming the scenes on their mobile phones.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives. In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavor to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside. Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behavior.\"\n\nIf you have any information on this incident or saw what happened, please contact our social media desk on Twitter @MerPolCC or Facebook 'Merseyside Police Contact Centre'. Southport stabbing", "body": "POLICE are fighting a mob of hundreds of protestors outside a mosque in Southport near the scene of the horror stabbing.\n\nLarge crowds were seen clashing with officers as police vans were set ablaze in Merseyside after three children were killed in a sickening knife rampage yesterday.\n\nShocking footage from the scene showed bottles and bricks being thrown at police vans as other projectiles hurtled through the air.\n\nMerseyside Police said that the English Defence League is believed to be behind the violent protests.\n\nSpeculation about the alleged attacker's identity circulated online, fueling the tension that already existed after Monday's horrific attack.\n\nRiot police wearing helmets and carrying large shields huddled together as chaos outside the mosque in Southport continues.\n\nMore than one police vehicle was set alight, with thick smoke billowing into the balmy air.\n\nIt comes as tensions run high in the town following yesterday's stabbing attack, where three children were killed while attending a Taylor Swift-themed yoga and dance workshop in Southport on Monday lunchtime.\n\nProtestors in the crowd can be heard shouting, as police sirens sound and a helicopter flies overhead.\n\nSome of the yobs have even climbed on top of a building and are throwing rocks down at police.\n\nBottles and wheelie bins have also been hurled at officers responding to the incident.\n\nRiot police and dogs units were deployed to bring the crowd under control, after officers sustained injuries including one with a suspected broken nose.\n\nThe force have now cleared the area directly outside the mosque and are standing guard with their batons raised.\n\nThe violence appears to be linked to several false accusations spread online.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss says: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\"\n\nIt comes after hundreds of people rallied together in solidarity outside The Aktinson art gallery in Merseyside to pay their respects earlier this evening at a separate peaceful vigil.\n\nSome lit candles while others lay flowers and reflected on yesterday's tragedy.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said it was \"appalling\" police officers in Southport were facing attacks from \"thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community\".\n\nShe branded tonight's violence a \"total disgrace\".\n\nThe MP for Southport says he is \"deeply concerned\" by the violent protests taking place this evening, and has urged people to \"stay safe\".\n\nIn a statement on X, Patrick Hurley says he \"fully condemns any attack\" on emergency services, pointing out that these are the same services that responded to the tragic stabbing attack yesterday.\n\n\"It's distressing to see people from outside our Southport community attacking our police and local people,\" he adds.\n\n\"I appeal to local people to avoid the area and stay safe, to allow the police to do their job. I want to thank our community for pulling together and supporting every person who has been affected by Monday's tragic attack.\"\n\nHe also thanks those who attended a vigil earlier this evening to remember the three children - Bebe King, Elsie Dot Stancombe and Alice Dasilva Aguiar - who were killed in the attack, and the 10 other people who were injured.\n\n\"I was deeply saddened to hear the news today of the death of a third child. Bebe, Elsie and Alice are in all of our thoughts and hearts today,\" he adds.\n\nMeanwhile, a man \"wearing a balaclava\" and carrying a knife has been arrested in Southport this evening - just yards from tonight's vigil.\n\nMerseyside Police confirmed they had arrested a 32-year-old on suspicion of possessing a bladed article - while the force's Detective Inspector condemned knife crime in the aftermath of the \"swift arrest\".\n\nA police statement said: \"We have arrested a man and seized a flick knife following an incident in Southport this evening.\n\n\"A report was received at 6.50pm that a man had been seen with a knife on Eastbank Street. Officers attended and a man was detained at around 6.55pm, and a flick knife recovered. There are no reports anyone was injured during the incident.\n\n\"A 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a bladed article, and taken into custody.\"\n\nIt comes as Bebe and Elsie, aged six and seven, were identified as the first victims in the attack just before midday.\n\nHeartbroken friends and family then paid tribute to Alice, saying she was killed by a \"despicable human being\".\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nMerseyside Police said the motive is currently unclear but it was not suspected to be terror-related.", "source": {"uri": "the-sun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The US Sun"}, The only details released about the suspect by police are that he is a 17-year-old from the village of Banks in Lancashire, who was born in Cardiff.\n\nAssistant chief constable Alex Goss, said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives ...\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\"\n\nHe added: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nRiot police charged the crowds of hundreds after a police van was set alight and other police vehicles were damaged on Tuesday evening. Officers also deployed tear gas to try to fight back the angry crowds of predominantly men covering their faces.\n\nSome officers appeared to be injured after plant pots and empty bins were among the missiles hurled at them and the Southport Mosque building while a group of people attempted to overturn a riot van.\n\nAs police tried to push the crowds back, some attacked yellow Matrix police vans by pulling at wing mirrors and jumping onto the roof.\n\nHundreds of youths and men gathered on the streets surrounding Hart Street, where Monday's knife attack took place. {"uri": "8252141291", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:27:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:27:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:27:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/uknews/2024/07/31/locals-clean-up-after-people-from-out-of-town-cause-mayhem-in-southport/", "title": "Locals clean up after 'people from out of town cause mayhem' in Southport", "body": "Locals in Southport have gathered for a clean-up operation outside a mosque after right-wing rioters brought further misery to a town already reeling from a knife attack that left three children dead.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine; Bebe King, six; and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said, on Wednesday, that rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during {"uri": "8252628533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:23:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:23:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:22:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/southport-stabbing-police-update-teenage-33368064", "title": "Southport stabbing police update as teenage suspect held for further questioning", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nDetectives have been given more time to question the 17-year-old suspect accused of conducting a mass stabbing in Southport.\n\nMerseyside Police confirmed officers had asked magistrates for more time to question the teenager, who has not been named because of his age. The law allows officers up to 96 hours, or four days, to hold a suspect in custody for serious crimes.\n\nThe 17-year-old was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the carnage unfolded at a Taylor Swift-themed dance club on Monday. Three girls - Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven - all died after sustaining stab wounds.\n\nEight other children were left injured, five of whom are in a critical condition. Two adults were also critically hurt. The tragedy was followed by riots near Southport mosque on Tuesday by right-wing groups.\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during unrest that followed a vigil for the murdered children. The violence was spurred on by baseless rumours on social media that misidentified the suspect.\n\nIn the wake of the turmoil, locals in Southport rallied together to support the Muslim community and clear up the mess left by rioters.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, clearing bricks from a wall that was knocked down during the rioting.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from other areas wreak havoc - leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nHe said: \"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem. People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire. But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up. Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMosque chairman Ibrahim Hussein told reporters he was trapped in the mosque with about eight others as the violence erupted, and only escaped with a police guard. He said: \"It was terrifying. It was absolutely, awful, horrendous. We couldn't understand this viciousness that was going on.\" Locals have brought flowers to the mosque and are helping organise repairs to the building, which Mr Hussein said was \"humbling\".\n\n\"I know the people of Southport and I know how beautiful they are but this was still a moving experience to see all that,\" he said. Shop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder on Tuesday night. He called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away, and was \"terrified\" that they might set fire to the premises because a woman and her daughter live in the flat above.\n\nThe woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them, he said.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League (EDL)\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nFormer First Minister Humza Yousaf called for the EDL to be banned under terror laws in the wake of the unrest, despite former leader Tommy Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight. The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nA total of 27 officers were taken to hospital while 12 others were treated and discharged at the scene. Eight cops suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners. We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\" Southport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\" Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport. Police have said that although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond - Sign up to our daily {"uri": "8252232200", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:23:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:23:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:21:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/world/uk-stabbing-mosque-targeted-40-police-officers-injured-in-violence-near-incident-site-12783186.html", "title": "UK stabbing: Mosque targeted, 40 police officers injured in violence near incident site", "body": "The rioters set cars belonging to members of the public alight, threw bricks at the local mosque and damaged a local convenience store, and set large refuse bins on fire.\n\nA far-right mob targeted a mosque in north-west England that saw three young girls fatally stabbed during a peaceful vigil in their memory and around 40 police officers suffered injuries in the disorder.\n\nAccording to reports, misinformation being spread on social media about the ethnicity and religion of the 17-year-old male suspect in police custody led to the rioting at the mosque in Southport on Tuesday night.\n\nBritish Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who had earlier visited the site of Monday's brutal stabbing attack on a dance studio on Hart Street, condemned the mobs for hijacking the vigil and insulting the grieving community with their actions.\n\n\"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect,\" said Starmer.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law,\" he said.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, 9, Bebe King, 6, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, 7, were named as the victims of the fatal stabbing. Eight others were seriously injured, five of whom remain in critical condition in hospital.\n\nMerseyside Police have said it was currently not treating the incident as terror-related.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets. We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time,\" said Alex Goss, Assistant Chief Constable of the force.\n\nThe police said 22 of its officers sustained serious injuries, including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. The rioters set cars belonging to members of the public alight, threw bricks at the local mosque and damaged a local convenience store, and set large refuse bins on fire.\n\nAs a result, strict legal orders have been enforced in the area designed to minimise serious violence and giving additional powers to officers to tackle anti-social behaviour.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park. This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday,\" said Goss, as he appealed for information to bring those involved to justice.\n\nThe police attracted strong support from the local community, who believed the English Defence League (EDL) supporting mob was whipped up largely from outside the town.\n\nThe disorder flared up after thousands gathered at the peace vigil to pay tribute to three girls killed and pray for those fighting for their lives in the knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club dance event at Hart Street community centre.\n\nMeanwhile, two adults who were critically injured in the attack have been named locally as yoga teacher Leanne Lucas, who co-organised the dance session for a group of six to 11-year-olds, and John Hayes, who works at the Hart Space where the stabbings took place.\n\n\"It is extremely important that people don't spread damaging misinformation online. False information has already been extensively shared in the last 24 hours,\" urged UK Home Secretary Yvette Cooper.\n\n\"In these dark and difficult moments, the police must be able to get on with their work and communities must be given the time and space to grieve and heal without outside voices seeking to use events to stir up division or advance their own views,\" she said.\n\nMeanwhile, more than GBP 2,15,000 has been raised by Taylor Swift fans via a \"Swifties for Southport\" Just Giving page for the funerals of the children who were killed and for the families of the
