{"uri": "8252715606", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:19:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:19:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:18:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/four-men-arrested-after-hundreds-29651586", "title": "Four men arrested after hundreds join far right riot in Southport", "body": "Four men have been arrested after more than 50 police officers were injured in a night of violent rioting in Southport in the wake of a mass stabbing that left three children dead.\n\nDisorder broke out on the streets of the seaside town last night (Tuesday), close to the scene of the knife attack at a children's dance event on Monday. Chaos erupted after a vigil was held to commemorate the children who lost their lives, as well as those who remain in a critical condition in hospital.\n\nBebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Aguiar, aged nine have been named as the children killed in the attack. In a tribute, Bebe King's family shared the following tribute: \"No words can describe the devastation that has hit our family as we try to deal with the loss of our little girl Bebe.\"\n\nREAD MORE: What caused the Southport riots?\n\nLast night frontline cops were hit with bricks and bottles and cars were set alight, including a police van, as hundreds of people swarmed outside a local mosque after false rumours spread online about the murder suspect. The violent clashes saw 53 officers injured, including 49 from Merseyside Police and four from Lancashire.\n\nThree police dogs were injured and eight Merseyside Police officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers sustained varying degrees of injury including head injures, serious facial injuries and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nPolice dog Zoe suffered a leg injury that required stitches, police dog Ike sustained a cut mouth and swelling to his front leg and police dog Quga suffered burns to her back leg. A fourth dog, Repo, was spared injury after their handler kicked petrol away.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Jenny Sims said: \"The wanton violence and destruction we saw is the very last thing the people of Southport need having been rocked by the awful events of Monday. The disrespect toward grieving families and the community is despicable, and I want to reassure residents in Southport that we will have a significantly increased police presence in the town in the coming days.\"\n\nMerseyside police said garden walls were broken down by protesters who threw the bricks at officers and the local mosque. Cars and wheelie bins were set alight, and a convenience store looted.\n\nA section 60 order, that gives police greater stop and search powers, has been out in place untill 7.45pm today, as well as a section 34 measure that gives them powers to stop anti-social behaviour. Extra officers will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said : \"Our priority was to try and keep the communities of Southport safe and also to make sure officers remained safe. Three arrests were made, however more will follow. It's impossible to say [how many will be arrested]. It's really early days in the investigation.\"\n\nShe added: \"Initially, there were about 70 people who made their way away from the vigil and were making their way towards the mosque. They suddenly became about 200 in number and then others joined that number.\"\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss added: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park. This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\n\"We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible. Anyone with information can DM @MerPolCC or contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.\"", "source": {"uri": "manchestereveningnews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manchester Evening News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kelly_ann_mills@manchestereveningnews.co.uk", "name": "Kelly-Ann Mills", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "imogen_clyde_smith@manchestereveningnews.co.uk", "name": "Imogen Clyde-Smith", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Victims", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Victims", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Unsolved", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Unsolved", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://i2-prod.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/article29651582.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/2_sdc_mdg_chp_67509jpg.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9777011", "eventUri": "eng-9777011", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.7254901960784313, "wgt": 178, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8251372311", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:30:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:30:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:29:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/uk-news/riot-police-subjected-relentless-sickening-29646248", "title": "Police subjected to relentless attack with vans set alight in night of chaos", "body": "Riot police were subjected to a relentless and 'sickening' attack, with vans set alight and wheelie bins hurled at officers in a night of chaos and disorder in Southport.\n\nSwathes of protestors, many armed with bricks and bottles, launched an attack on police who were called to St Luke's Road following a nearby mosque being targeted by suspected English Defence League supporters.\n\nThe violence came just after huge crowds of mourners had gathered together to remember the lives of three innocent children killed in the brutal stabbing rampage at a Taylor Swift-themed dance party on Monday morning (July 29).\n\nREAD MORE LIVE: 'Disorder' erupts outside Southport mosque after vigil to remember children killed in stabbings\n\nBebe King, six, Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, all died in the horror attack after a knifeman began targeting young children enjoying the music event.\n\nScenes of disorder started to break out at around 7.45pm on Tuesday (July 30), after a mosque on St Luke's Road, nearby to the scene of the stabbings, was targeted. Protestors then began hurling various items at the building.\n\nPolice were called to the incident, before the crowds grew in number and violent scenes escalated, leaving officers outnumbered. Worshippers were also said to be inside the mosque when flames began climbing up the building's fence.\n\nRiot vans and officers swarmed the area amid chants of \"No surrender\" and \"English till I die\" from sections of the crowd. Hundreds of youths and men continued to gather in streets surrounding Hart Street, where the fatal attack took place.\n\nFirecrackers were set off, as wheelie bins, bricks and glass bottles were launched at officers, clad in body armour, before a police van was set alight. Huge plumes of smoke could be seen billowing overhead above the escalating scenes of violence.\n\nMerseyside Police said one officer suffered a suspected broken nose before additional patrols, including the Dog Section and a helicopter were deployed.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy took to social media to slam the 'thugs' responsible, saying she was 'incredibly proud' of her officers that responded to the brutal stabbings on Monday.\n\nAs Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said officers 'should not have to face' the 'sickening' attack, fuelled in part by 'speculation' around the suspect arrested over the stabbings.\n\nHe said of the incident: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavor to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets. We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behavior.\"\n\nLocal MP Mr Patrick Hurley publicly condemned the attack, urging locals to 'avoid the area and stay safe'. He also thanked the community for their involvement in the vigil on Tuesday night, as he added: \"Nowhere was this more evident than the solidarity, remembrance and sympathy heard at today's vigil.\n\n\"To those who laid flowers, candles, toys, thank you. I was deeply saddened to hear the news today of the death or a third child. Bebe, Elsie and Alice are in all of our thoughts and hearts today.\"\n\nYilmaz Nasuh, 55, a Muslim born in Turkey has watched the riot unfold from his home. He told The Mirror: \"My first thought is that the people who lost their loved ones yesterday are having to deal with this insult on top of their sorrow.\n\n\"I'm seeing an organised criminal riot. I'm feeling that I've been here 40 years and this isn't the British experience. This is something alien.\n\n\"This is not love, this is not humanity. This is sad. I just feel so bad for the parents having to deal with this too. They live here. {"uri": "2024-07-438793605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:29:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:29:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:08:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/protesters-cause-chaos-outside-southport-mosque-after-tragic-knife-attack-police-warn-of-inaccurate-information-circulating-online/", "title": "Protesters cause chaos outside Southport mosque after tragic knife attack: Police warn of inaccurate information circulating online - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Huge crowds chanting 'English till I die' have clashed with police outside a mosque in Southport near to where three girls were killed in a horrific knife rampage on Monday.\n\nRiot officers have descended on the scene as they try to control the violence which has broken out amid speculation over the identity of the suspect.\n\nThe ugly scenes, which has seen a police van set on fire outside a mosque, comes as Merseyside Police issued a warning after an 'incorrect' name for the alleged Southport attacker was widely circulated online.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, originally from Cardiff but from the nearby village of Banks, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nThe violence appears to have been fuelled by false claims that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat have spread online.\n\nMerseyside Police said: 'We would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.'\n\nThe force confirmed that a large group of protesters - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League - began to launch items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road in Southport at around 7.45pm.\n\nOne officer has suffered a suspected broken nose and police vehicles have been damaged and set on fire.\n\nIt comes after the three girls stabbed to death at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class were today named by police as six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar.\n\nThey were among 11 children stabbed during a 'ferocious' knife attack which left mothers picking up their children screaming in horror.\n\nFive further children, aged between six and 11, are in a critical condition alongside two female adults, among them hero yoga teacher Leanne Lucas, who 'bravely tried to protect them'.\n\nAs thousands of mourners attended an emotional vigil in Southport on Tuesday night, protests broke out on the streets surrounding Hart Street, where the attack took place.\n\nFurious demonstrators tore down garden walls to use as missiles to pelt at police, with wheelie bins also thrown during the mayhem.\n\nA police van was set on fire by protesters. Angry mobs chanted 'Stop the boats' and kicked out at police vans sent to restore order.\n\nSome threw smoke bombs, with men wearing caps and shorts charging at outnumbered police.\n\nScores of riot vans and patrol cars raced to the scene as a police helicopter hovered overhead as the violence spread out of control.\n\nIt's understood a number of officers have suffered what looks to be minor injuries in the chaotic scenes outside of a mosque.\n\nHuge crowds of men, many masked and wearing hoodies, were seen clashing with police - as stones, bottles, bricks and fireworks were launched.\n\nDemonstrators could be heard shouting 'No surrender' and 'English till I die'.\n\nIt comes after inaccurate posts by social media sleuths about the identity of the perpetrator have received millions of views and engagements.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss: 'There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n'We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n'It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.'\n\nDowning Street also warned against 'unhelpful' speculation amid concerns that misreporting online could inflame community tensions.\n\nOfficers should be given the space to probe the case without people guessing at the possible motive or circumstances, No 10 said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, the Prime Minister was repeatedly asked 'how many more children will die?' as he placed flowers at the scene of the attack.\n\nSir Keir Starmer's brief visit, which lasted around two minutes, was interrupted by some members of the public heckling him.\n\nAs the Prime Minister walked past, one man declared: 'Here's your photo opportunity.'\n\nAnother shouted: 'How many more children? Our kids are dead and you're leaving already?'\n\nOther furious onlookers shouted 'scumbag', 'time for change' and 'go away, you're not wanted'.\n\nAnother woman said: 'I've just found out my friend's nine-year-old daughter was killed, the person I've held as a child, and you can't do s***.'\n\nAnd a different man shouted: 'Get the truth out!'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper has said social media companies 'need to take some responsibility' for some activity in the aftermath of the attack.\n\nResponding to shadow home secretary James Cleverly, she said: 'I agree with him too about the responsibility on every one of us. The police do need to be able to pursue this investigation.\n\n'There will be wider questions for other days, but the most important thing is that every one of us supports the police in their investigation now.\n\n'I agree with him too about the responsibility on social media companies, because we do need to recognise there are things that are taking place on social media that go against their terms and conditions, and their commitments as well. They need to take some responsibility for that.\n\n'Above all, this is about young children. This is about children and their families who will be grieving, and the many other children who were involved yesterday who will be facing great trauma as well.'", "source": {"uri": "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/24487282.nearly-40-police-officers-injured-southport-violent-disorder/", "title": "Nearly 40 police officers injured in Southport violent disorder", "body": "North West Ambulance Service said 27 police officers were taken to hospital.\n\nA statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced, giving police the power to direct people engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents.\n\nMerseyside police said these powers would not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing attack in Southport on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nThe attack saw Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nEight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance {"uri": "8252226345", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:19:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:19:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:18:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/uknews/2024/07/31/community-rallies-together-after-people-from-out-of-town-riot-in-southport/", "title": "Community rallies together after 'people from out of town' riot in Southport", "body": "Locals in Southport are rallying together after right-wing rioters marred a night of remembrance for three murdered children.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nMr Balasuryla said he called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away.\n\nHe said he was \"terrified\" when he thought they would set fire to the premises because there is a woman and her daughter living in a flat above.\n\nHe said he later found out that the woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them.\n\n\"I got a couple of hours' sleep and then got a phone call saying 'You need to come down, there's lots of people waiting to help',\" Mr Balasuryla said.\n\nHe added that local people had said they would defend his shop if necessary.\n\n\"It was terrifying last night,\" he said.\n\n\"But I feel safe again because people are here to protect us.\"\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\n\"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "jerseyeveningpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jersey Evening Post"}, "authors": [], The only details released about the suspect by police are that he is a 17-year-old from the village of Banks in Lancashire, who was born in Cardiff.\n\nAssistant chief constable Alex Goss, said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives ...\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\"\n\nHe added: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nRiot police charged the crowds of hundreds after a police van was set alight and other police vehicles were damaged on Tuesday evening. Officers also deployed tear gas to try to fight back the angry crowds of predominantly men covering their faces.\n\nSome officers appeared to be injured after plant pots and empty bins were among the missiles hurled at them and the Southport Mosque building while a group of people attempted to overturn a riot van.\n\nAs police tried to push the crowds back, some attacked yellow Matrix police vans by pulling at wing mirrors and jumping onto the roof.\n\nHundreds of youths and men gathered on the streets surrounding Hart Street, where Monday's knife attack took place. {"uri": "8251898584", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:50:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:50:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:49:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.nottinghampost.com/news/uk-world-news/grieving-southport-mother-calls-peace-9448628", "title": "Mum's plea as 'EDL' thugs attack mosque and clash with police after tragedy", "body": "The mother of one of the children tragically killed in the Southport knife attack has made a heartfelt plea to 'stop the violence' following last night's disturbing scenes in the town. Jenni Stancombe, whose seven-year-old daughter Elsie Dot Stancombe was one of the victims, used social media to make her powerful appeal.\n\nElsie was killed during a horrific attack at a Taylor Swift dance party on Hart Street on Monday lunchtime. Alice Aguiar, aged nine, and six-year-old Bebe King also lost their lives in the attack, while two adults and five other children are still fighting for their lives in hospital.\n\nAs Southport struggles to come to terms with this shocking tragedy, hundreds of locals attended a vigil in the town centre yesterday evening, which was observed respectfully. However, not far away, chaos was unfolding.\n\nRead more: 39 police officers injured as violence escalates with cars torched and mosque targeted Read more: Police name second man charged after stabbing at city centre bar\n\nPolice were called to a disturbance during a protest outside a mosque on St Luke's Road in the town. In what has been labelled as 'sickening' scenes, dozens of officers were injured and a major incident was declared. Bricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set ablaze, reports the Liverpool Echo.\n\nEight police officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries. One officer was knocked unconscious.\n\nViolence erupted in Southport when a group, believed to be English Defence League supporters, began attacking a local mosque on St Luke's Road and setting cars ablaze on Tuesday evening. The unrest saw damage to a convenience store, wheelie bins torched, and even three police dogs injured.\n\nSocial media has been flooded with images and footage of individuals throwing rocks at officers, climbing on police vans, and trying to break the windows. The outbreak of violence has drawn condemnation from figures including the Prime Minister and Home Secretary.\n\nHowever, perhaps the most poignant plea for peace comes from Jenni Stancombe, whose daughter was one of the three young girls tragically killed in Southport on Monday. In a heartfelt message that has gone viral on social media, she implored: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nMs Stancombe praised the police, saying: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss expressed his pride in the force's response to violence in Southport: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack. I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\"\n\nHe continued, detailing the damage caused by offenders: \"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer commented on the incident: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. {"uri": "8251876971", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:33:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:33:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:33:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13691963/calm-rioting-Southport-Stabbing-victims-mother-violence-police-officers-injured-vigil-three-murdered-girls.html", "title": "Southport Stabbing victim's mother says violence must end", "body": "One of the mothers of the Southport stabbing victims has called for calm on the streets of the Merseyside town after a night where rioters unleashed chaos, leaving 39 police officers injured.\n\nElsie Dot Stancombe, 7, was killed alongside six-year-old Bebe King and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar in a horrific knife rampage on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed summer holiday dance workshop.\n\nAnd following a peaceful vigil last night where thousands of mourners had gathered for a vigil to remember the victims who lost their lives, violent thugs were accused of showing 'no respect to a town that's grieving'.\n\nCrowds of yobs - many of whom are thought to have come from outside Southport - torched a police van and left 39 officers and three dogs injured, including 27 who needed treatment in hospital.\n\nBut as the community rallied together against the violence, Jenni Stancombe, the mother of little Elsie pleaded for the violence to end on social media.\n\n'This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight,' she said, the Liverpool Echo reports.\n\n'The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.'\n\nSouthport burns: A street near a mosque goes up in flames as violent thugs took to the streets last night\n\nRiot police hold back protesters near a burning police vehicle after disorder broke out in Southport\n\nA police van was set on fire near a mosque in Southport on Tuesday evening as riots broke out\n\nAround 200 protesters were seen taking to the streets. Police believe many were EDL supporters\n\nThree girls were killed in a bloody rampage on Hart Street on Monday. On Tuesday, a vigil was held for the victims on Lord Street. While it was going on, a man with a flick knife was arrested on Eastbank Street. On St Luke's Road, riots erupted outside a mosque - also on Tuesday\n\nRiot police vans were damaged amid the chaos near the Southport Mosque\n\nThugs, many hooded and wearing masks, launch wheelie bins at a riot van\n\nA burnt out police van near a mosque in Southport as shocking riots broke out on Tuesday\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds in the bloodbath. Five are in a critical condition, alongside two women who were also critically injured as they bravely tried to save the children.\n\nRead More Calls for calm as Southport locals say rioters have 'no respect for a town that's grieving'\n\nAnd today the coastal community united to bring order back to their quiet streets - on local Facebook groups some offered their rooms to people who needed a safe space, while others organised clean up crews to remove the carnage of the night before.\n\nBuilders offered their services for free to rebuild walls demolished after thugs threw rubble at police vehicles and others took to social media to praise brave officers.\n\nThe Bishop of Liverpool, John Perumbalath, paid tribute to the community, who is uniting through their grief.\n\nHe told the Today programme: 'It is absolute shock and sadness. I share that shock shared by the whole community here, in a quieter community where this has not been a kind of experience they have come across.\n\n'It is really a shock and the whole community is united together in their sadness.'\n\nThe Prime Minister and Home Secretary joined police chiefs in condemning the 'sickening' violence, which started barely an hour after thousands of mourners had gathered for a vigil to remember the victims who lost their lives.\n\nJust yards away from the emotional vigil, a 32-year-old man, dressed in all black with a hat on the joint-hottest day of the year, was separately arrested after being caught carrying a flick knife on Eastbank Street at 6.55pm.\n\nOn nearby St Luke's Street, rioters chanting 'English till I die' surrounded the Southport Mosque and Islamic Cultural Centre and began hurling rubble at police officers who had formed a protective line around the building.\n\nThe violence appears to have been fuelled by false claims online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe 17-year-old boy, who remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder, is originally from Cardiff but now lives in the nearby Lancashire village of Banks.\n\nFootage showed a man, dressed in all black in the scorching heat, being arrested near the vigil for the three girls who died\n\nThe riots came barely an hour after thousands of mourners gathered for a vigil at the Atkinson in Southport\n\nIn stark contrast to the riots on the streets, there was a sense of tranquility at the site of the vigil as night fell\n\nHome Secretary Yyvette Cooper, pictured leaving flowers at the scene of the attack yesterday, condemned the mob violence\n\nMerseyside Police has issued a warning over an 'incorrect' name being widely circulated online, adding: 'We would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.'\n\nThe service said 27 of its officers were taken to hospital following the violence.\n\nA statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nThe angry mob - who police 'believed to be supporters of the English Defence League' - started targeting the Muslim place of worship at around 7.45pm.\n\nEight police officers suffered serious injuries, including one who was knocked unconscious. Protesters also torched cars and wheelie bins belonging to members of the public, shattered the mosque windows with bricks and looted shops.\n\nOne Southport resident living near the mosque told how he, his partner and their young daughter fled for the evening, not wanting her to see the sickening violence.\n\nThe man said: 'We just couldn't stay while this was going on and allow our daughter to witness it.\n\n'This doesn't represent Southport - they're EDL thugs who are from Manchester and Liverpool who have just come here to cause trouble. They have no respect for a town that's grieving.'\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had 'hijacked' a vigil for victims and would 'feel the full force of the law'.\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir said: 'The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n'They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said 'scenes of thuggery' on the streets of Southport 'bear no relation' to the community which had been coming together.\n\nRead More Sir Keir Starmer is heckled on his visit to Southport and asked 'how many more children will die?\n\nShe told broadcasters: 'I think everyone should be showing some respect for the community that is grieving and also for the police who are pursuing an urgent criminal investigation now, and who showed such heroism and bravery yesterday in the face of these horrific attacks.\n\n'I think everyone needs to support the police in that work, and frankly the scenes of thuggery that we have seen on the streets of Southport this evening bear no relation to the way in which the Southport community has been coming together to support each other and to support grieving families.\n\n'We need to see some respect for the grieving community and for the police in their urgent work.'\n\nPolice have introduced a 24-hour Section 60 Order in the area where the riots took place and extra officers will remain in the area.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: 'Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.'\n\nHe added: 'Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\n\n'This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.'\n\nThe violence was condemned by Sir Keir Starmer, Mayor Steve Rotheram and the Liverpool Region Mosque Network on Tuesday night\n\nHundreds of protesters, many masked, battled with riot police officers\n\nEngland flags were on display at the anti-Muslim demonstration in Southport\n\nSmoke is seen billowing from a police van which was set ablaze. The mosque is seen on the right\n\nTensions flared in Southport last night, with police saying supporters of the EDL were targeting the mosque\n\nLocal mosque groups condemned the violence aimed towards Muslims, adding: 'We must not let those who seek to divide us and spread hatred use this as an opportunity.'\n\nAnd Steve Rotheram, mayor of the Liverpool city region, wrote: 'There are families just coming to terms with yesterday's events, parents grieving for their murdered children and survivors still trying to process what they witnessed.\n\n'The violent scenes in Southport tonight will only further traumatise a community that is already struggling to come to terms with this attack.\n\n'Mindless violence directed at the very people who ran towards the danger yesterday, and outright Islamaphobia, only distract from the work of delivering justice.\n\n'The real story tonight is of the thousands who gathered at the vigil in Southport in memory of Bebe, Elsie and Alice. For the sake of their loved ones, this disorder needs to stop so the police do their jobs.'\n\nPolice said that a number of officers were injured, while cars were set alight and shops were broken into and looted during the disorder.\n\nIn a desperate bid to protect themselves, officers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them. One officer has suffered a suspected broken nose and police vehicles have been damaged and set on fire as around 400 people gathered to watch.\n\nThe three girls who died were among 11 children stabbed during a 'ferocious' knife attack which left mothers picking up their children screaming in horror.\n\nChaotic scenes erupted near to where the knife rampage took place in Southport yesterday\n\nThe aftermath of the riots, where police vans were burnt and rocks were launched\n\nRioters wearing masks launch missiles towards police officers in Southport\n\nRiot police with shields and helmets hold back protesters after disorder broke out\n\nProtesters cheer as they launch bins at riot police vans amid ugly scenes in Southport\n\nRioters were seen jumping on police vans as things got out of control\n\nSmoke billows behind riot police officers amid riots in the seaside town\n\nA traffic cone is hurled by a masked man at a police officer near to a mosque in Southport\n\nA wounded police officer with blood pouring down his head after being caught up in the riots\n\nRiot police try to control the angry mob who have taken to the streets of Southport\n\nFive further children, aged between six and 11, are in a critical condition alongside two female adults, among them hero yoga teacher Leanne Lucas, who 'bravely tried to protect them'.\n\nOne source told The Sun that she needed an eight-hour operation and remains seriously ill in hospital. Dance tutor Heidi Liddle and window cleaner Joel Verite have also been hailed for their bravery during the attack.\n\nAs thousands of mourners attended an emotional vigil in Southport on Tuesday evening, protests broke out on the streets surrounding Hart Street, where the attack took place.\n\nFurious demonstrators tore down garden walls to use as missiles to pelt at police, with wheelie bins also thrown during the mayhem.\n\nA police van was set on fire by protesters. Angry mobs chanted 'Stop the boats' and kicked out at police vans sent to restore order.\n\nRead More Moment Southport rioter gets hit in the head with a brick... and then again where it REALLY hurts\n\nSome threw smoke bombs, with men wearing caps and shorts charging at outnumbered police.\n\nScores of riot vans and patrol cars raced to the scene as a police helicopter hovered overhead as the violence spread out of control.\n\nHuge crowds of men, many masked and wearing hoodies, were seen clashing with police - as stones, bottles, bricks and fireworks were launched.\n\nDemonstrators could be heard shouting 'No surrender' and 'English till I die'.\n\nOne police officer was seen being helped into a van by his colleagues with blood streaming down his face and a heavily bandaged head. A female officer was also seen with a cut cheek.\n\nBy 8pm, around 500 rioters had massed in two streets outside the mosque - Sussex Road and St Luke's Road - trapping around 40 police officers in the middle.\n\nMissiles were hurled at riot officers and dog handlers from both sides. Bottles, bricks, fireworks and lumps of concrete were thrown to cheers from the rioters, who goaded police and eyes each other on.\n\nAt about 8.15pm a crowd surrounded three riot vans and began rocking one to try and flip it over.\n\nMoments later a small explosion was heard and a mini-fireball erupted in the air as the van went up in flames.\n\nOne man shouted: 'We're doing this for our girls!' as officers drove the other vans away from the fire to stop them also being set alight.\n\nIn a desperate attempt to quell the disorder, a charge from riot police brandishing batons sent around 300 of the rioters fleeing down the street as reinforcements flooded the area.\n\nBut violence continued into the night, with rioters forming a burning barricade of wheelie bins as they hurled bricks and lumps of concrete at riot police.\n\nMobs chanting 'save our girls' clashed with police until 10.30pm outside the Southport Mosque and Islamic Cultural Centre.\n\nA nearby corner shop looked to have been broken into and looted. Rioters set alight at least five wheelie bins in the middle of Sussex Road sending flames and toxic black plumes of smoke shooting up into the night's sky.\n\nWith officers unable to charge due to the burning barricade, a volley of missiles was hurled from behind the makeshift bonfire.\n\nAt one point the ferocity of the violence sent the line of police retreating slightly. Officers in a Merseyside Police helicopter continued to monitor events from the air.\n\nThe crowd began to thin out around 11pm with reports of disturbances - including cars being torched - breaking out across Southport.\n\nDuring the demonstration, several people carried placards with slogans about stopping the boats. One read: 'Stop the boats! Send them back! Fight for our kids! Let's stand together!\n\nRiot police hold back protesters near a burning police vehicle\n\nA police officer holding a baton with a cut on her face after rioters stormed the area near the mosque\n\nRiot police intervene as activists cause chaos in Southend as rumours circulate over the suspect's identity\n\nA protester walks away holding his head as activists clashed with police on Tuesday\n\nClashes between protesters and police can be seen breaking out in the far distance\n\nSome held placards saying 'stop the boats'. This is despite police issuing a warning after an 'incorrect' name for the alleged attacker was widely circulated online\n\nWheelie bins and bricks were thrown at police, while a police van went up in flames - as police warned people not to speculate about the identity of the suspect\n\nHuge crowds have clashed with police in Southport as tensions boil over following the knife rampage\n\nActivists were seen launching missiles at police and attempting to damage riot vans\n\nOne woman carrying a placard said the disorder was because the knife man who attacked the children 'was a Muslim.'\n\nShe said: 'We are saying enough is enough. Why are they not stopping the migrants coming in?\n\n'How many more children will be killed because they are letting them all in? They should be at the borders stopping them.'\n\nHer comments came after inaccurate posts by social media sleuths about the identity of the perpetrator have received millions of views and engagements.\n\nSunder Katwala, director of the think-tank British Future, said a bogus news channel seemed to have invented a fake name for the suspect and run a false story that was shared online.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Goss said: 'There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n'We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n'It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.'\n\nThe riots went on late into the evening, with police officers desperately trying to regain control\n\nRiot police wearing helmets and shields try to defend themselves near the mosque\n\nRiot police officers storm into the area to try and disperse the growing crowd\n\nAlso on Tuesday evening, officers were called to reports of a man carrying a weapon at around 6.50pm, during which time the vigil was taking place at the Atkinson venue.\n\nPolice swooped on the scene and detained the man minutes later before seizing the flick knife.\n\nA 32-year-old man dressed in all black, from Standish, was arrested on suspicion of possession of a bladed article, and taken into custody. There were no reports of any injuries during the incident.\n\nDetective Inspector Gavin Mulcahy said: 'We know too well the devastating impact knife crime can have for victims, their families and friends, and those who carry them.\n\n'This week has seen an unspeakable tragedy unfold in Southport, and this incident occurred a short distance from where a vigil had been happening where the community was paying their respects to all those affected.\n\n'Officers made a swift arrest and have seized a knife that could have been used to cause harm in our communities.\n\n'Those offenders who carry them have no place whatsoever in our communities.\n\n'Every day we are carrying out stop checks, warrants and land searches to take knives off our streets, but as this incident shows, the assistance of members of the public in telling us where they are stored and who is carrying them is vital to ensure the safety of families and residents.'\n\nAt the vigil, tearful locals laid flowers outside the Merseyside town's grand Atkinson building after falling silent to remember Bebe, Elsie and nine-year-old Alice.\n\nIn the first week of the summer holidays, the seaside town should be bustling with happy families and tourists. But at 6pm on Tuesday, more than 5,000 people stood in silence outside the Atkinson building amid an outpouring of grief and shock.\n\nIn front of the Grade II-listed building, which comprises a theatre, museum and library, is the Town Hall Gardens, where a sea of floral tributes built up.\n\nOne heartbreaking poster surrounded by candles and flowers said 'never stop dancing'. The children had been enjoying a summer holiday dance workshop when a knifeman entered the studio and launched a frenzied attack.\n\nAmong the bouquets, there were also a number of Taylor Swift-style friendship bracelets. 'Thinking of you all,' a row of four of them spelt out.\n\nAhead of the vigil, the families and schools of the innocent girls who were fatally attacked by a crazed knifeman also released tributes.\n\nIn a statement, Bebe's family said: 'No words can describe the devastation that has hit our family as try to deal with the loss of our little girl Bebe.'\n\nThe family of Alice Dasilva Aguiar added: 'Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our Princess, like we said before to you, you're always our princess and no one would change that. Love from Your Hero Daddy and Mummy.'\n\nAnd the headteacher of Farnborough Road Infant School said they were 'heartbroken and devastated' by the death of pupil Elsie.\n\nJennifer Sephton said: 'Elsie has been a loving and bright member of our wonderful community since first being brought here on her father's shoulders, and even at her early age she was such a caring and charismatic young lady who loved to please.\n\n'Elsie was a kind and caring friend to all who met her and was adored by everyone in our community. Our hearts and most deeply-felt sympathies go out to Elsie's family, friends and our Farnborough community who have been left numb by what has happened.\n\n'It is immensely difficult to put into words how amazing Elsie was and the impact she had on those around her. We will miss you dearly Elsie. You were one of a kind.'\n\nAlder Hey Children's hospital this afternoon released a statement confirming that seven children had been taken to the site for treatment. One of those was Alice, and of the others, two remain in a critical condition, a spokesperson said.\n\nThe head of the school trust attended by Alice and Bebe said the girls 'will be in our hearts forever'.\n\nEndeavour Learning Trust chief executive David Clayton said 'no words can do justice to what has happened here in Southport.\n\nThe trust contains Churchtown Primary School in Southport, which Alice and Bebe had both attended.\n\nChurchtown Primary headteacher Jinnie Payne said the school had heard the 'tragic news' with 'great sadness', describing the stabbings as an 'atrocity'.\n\nIn a statement, Mr Clayton said: 'No words can do justice to what has happened here in Southport - and our hearts are broken for the families who have lost their children.\n\n'No one should ever have to experience horror like this.\n\n'Our immediate focus now is on providing support to the community as we start to understand what has happened. The death of a child is always a desperate tragedy for a school, and particularly so under such circumstances.\n\n'We will come together as a community, offering each other support and care as we work through this difficult time.\n\n'Alice and Bebe will be in our hearts forever.'\n\nMs Payne said Alice, a Year 4 pupil at Churchtown, was the 'happiest of souls, a true ray of sunshine'.\n\nThe Churchtown Primary headteacher added: 'She was known and loved by everyone in our school community of 700 children, a testament to her unique ability to connect with others.\n\n'Alice's radiant smile brightened our days, and she embraced every aspect of school life with enthusiasm and joy.\n\n'Her kindness, playful nature, and zest for trying new things will forever be remembered. Alice, you will always hold a special place in our hearts at Churchtown.'\n\nMs Payne said Bebe, a former pupil at the school, was a 'joyful girl' whose 'kindness radiated through the entire Churchtown community'.\n\nThe headteacher added: 'During her time at the school, Bebe's considerate nature and her love of learning shone through in everything that she did.\n\n'Each day, she would come into school ready to grasp every opportunity available to her and fun and laughter were never far away whenever Bebe was involved.\n\n'Her considerate nature meant that she had many friends and she always ensured all children felt included, whether that was through play or working together in the classroom.\n\n'Bebe's memory will live on in the hearts of all who knew her.'\n\nThe headteacher added: 'We know that a number of other children from Churchtown were also involved in the attack, along with much-loved colleagues.\n\n'We extend our heartfelt wishes to all those families affected by this horrific incident, including those currently in hospital or continuing to receive treatment.'\n\nDevastated relatives of Alice said she had been taken by a 'despicable human being.'\n\nHer mother Alexandra Aguiar is understood to be originally from Caracas in Venezuela and her dad David Aguiar is from the Portuguese island of Madeira.\n\nRelative Carina Aguiar, a hotel worker who lives in Camara de Lobos in Madeira, posted a link on her social media to news Merseyside Police had confirmed a third child' had died following the attack and wrote tear emojis beside it.\n\nEarlier she posted a photo of a black ribbon on her Facebook alongside Alice's name after writing in an emotional tribute: 'Princess Alice. In this moment of great pain my soul hurts, my body hurts, my mind hurts. I have a lump in my throat.\n\n'You were just an innocent child, a happy smiley girl with a bright life ahead of you which a despicable human being took away from you, without pity, for no reason.'\n\nReacting to the riots, Merseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy posted on X: 'I am incredibly proud of my officers and staff who have worked so hard to save the lives of children, investigate the horrific incident from yesterday, working with partners to provide reassurance to our communities and now they are facing this level of violence from these thugs\n\n'Over 1000 residents from Southport came together this evening to remember the little girls who have died, those who are still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed & are traumatised by the events from yesterday. This is where all of our focus should be.'\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said: 'It's distressing to see people from outside our Southport community attacking our police and local people.\n\n'I want to make it clear that I fully condemn any attack on our emergency services, these are the same services that responded to the tragic attack yesterday.\n\n'I appeal to local people to avoid the area and stay safe, to allow the police to do their job.'\n\nMr Hurley continued: 'I want to thank our community for pulling together and supporting every person who has been affected by Monday's tragic attack.\n\n'Nowhere was this more evident than the solidarity, remembrance and sympathy heard at today's vigil.\n\n'To those who laid flowers, candles, toys, thank you. I was deeply saddened to hear the news today of the death or a third child. Bebe, Elsie and Alice are in all of our thoughts and hearts today.'\n\nThe three girls stabbed to death at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class were yesterday named by police as nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and six-year-old Bebe King (L-R)\n\nAway from the protest, a vigil was being held for the three girls who died in the tragic incident\n\nIn stark contrast to the riots, there was a sense of tranquillity around the site of the vigil\n\nThe vigil was held at the Atkinson in Southport at around 6pm on Tuesday evening\n\nThe Southport Mosque said it was 'truly shocked and saddened to hear about the events that unfolded today'. They added: 'We extend our deepest sympathy to the families of all affected. Our thoughts and prayers are with you all.'\n\nThe Liverpool Region Mosque Network said it was 'shocked and horrified' by the knife rampage on Monday.\n\nBut it added: 'A minority of people are attempting to portray that this inhumane act is somehow related to the Muslim community. Frankly it is not, and we must not let those who seek to divide us and spread hatred use this as an opportunity.\n\n'This evening, we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protesters, gathering outside. This is causing further fear and anxiety within our communities. We must all unite and stand together against all forms of hate, violence and division.'\n\nAnd the The Muslim Council of Britain (MCB) condemned 'shocking scenes of far-right rioters running amok outside a mosque'.\n\nThe MCB says Islamaphobic backlash began with a false rumour on the internet which was then stoked by misinformation from a Russian news site, which wrongfully associated the crime with Muslims.\n\nMCB secretary-general Zara Mohammed said: 'At a time of great tragedy, loss, and mourning, we must stand firm against the cynical forces of hatred and division. This does not represent our diverse Britain and the people of Southport.\n\n'The Government must address the increasing rise of violent far-right extremism targeting Muslim communities. More must be done to tackle Islamophobia and offer reassurance at this time.'\n\nShe added: 'We commend the authorities for their swift action, and our prayers are with the mosque, the families of the victims of yesterday's attack, and the local community.'\n\nDowning Street also warned against 'unhelpful' speculation amid concerns that misreporting online could inflame community tensions.\n\nAn aerial view of Hart Street on Monday, where a horrifying knife attack took place just before midday\n\nOfficers should be given the space to probe the case without people guessing at the possible motive or circumstances, No 10 said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, the Prime Minister was repeatedly asked 'how many more children will die?' as he placed flowers at the scene of the attack.\n\nSir Keir's brief visit, which lasted around two minutes, was interrupted by some members of the public heckling him.\n\nAs the Prime Minister walked past, one man declared: 'Here's your photo opportunity.'\n\nAnother shouted: 'How many more children? Our kids are dead and you're leaving already?'\n\nOther furious onlookers shouted 'scumbag', 'time for change' and 'go away, you're not wanted'.\n\nAnother woman said: 'I've just found out my friend's nine-year-old daughter was killed, the person I've held as a child, and you can't do s***.'\n\nAnd a different man shouted: 'Get the truth out!'\n\nMs Cooper has said social media companies 'need to take some responsibility' for some activity in the aftermath of the attack.\n\nResponding to shadow home secretary James Cleverly, she said: 'I agree with him too about the responsibility on every one of us. The police do need to be able to pursue this investigation.\n\n'There will be wider questions for other days, but the most important thing is that every one of us supports the police in their investigation now.\n\n'I agree with him too about the responsibility on social media companies, because we do need to recognise there are things that are taking place on social media that go against their terms and conditions, and their commitments as well. They need to take some responsibility for that.\n\n'Above all, this is about young children. This is about children and their families who will be grieving, and the many other children who were involved yesterday who will be facing great trauma as well.'\n\nHer counterpart Mr Cleverly called for people not to 'get involved in the grief of others' by sharing misinformation relating to the Southport attack on social media.\n\n'Enough people are already distressed without their distress being amplified by speculation and gossip online,' he added.\n\nAhead of fears mounting over a far-right rally, Sir Keir's official spokesman said: 'Of course, people should listen the police, they should not do anything that is going to make the police's job harder to manage the situation, to conduct their investigations.\n\n'It is unhelpful to speculate on things like the motive and the circumstance around this.'\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", The unrest began when several hundred people, most of them men, began targeting a Southport mosque, setting vehicles and wheelie bins on fire and attacking a local shop.\n\nBottles and bricks were thrown at police who linked the rioters to the English Defence League, a group that has sometimes staged violent demonstrations against Islam.\n\nOff-duty officers and reinforcements from other forces were brought in to restore calm.\n\n\"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said in the statement, adding that officers had \"displayed ... courage whilst under constant and sustained attack\".\n\nThe violence broke out shortly after hundreds of people gathered in the town centre to pay tribute to those killed in the attack, laying flowers and toys. Three girls were killed in the attack while eight children were injured, with five of them in critical condition in hospital. Two adults who tried to protect them also remain in critical condition.\n\nUnited Kingdom Prime Minister Keir Starmer promised that the \"full force of the law\" would be used against the rioters.\n\n\"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday,\" he wrote on the social media platform X. \"They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nPolice have arrested a teenager for murder and attempted murder over the stabbings, saying the suspect was born in the Welsh city of Cardiff and lived in a village near Southport.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Goss said.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nGoss and local politicians said many of those involved in Tuesday's violence came from outside the area, while the Liverpool Region Mosque Network said a minority of people were trying to use the incident to spread hatred.\n\n\"This evening we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protesters gathering outside,\" it said in a statement. \"This is causing further fear and anxiety within our communities.\"\n\nThe three girls who died in the attack have been named as six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar, whose parents are Portuguese.\n\n\"Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our princess, like we said before to you, you're always our princess {"uri": "8251742595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "04:42:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T04:42:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T04:41:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/31/almost-40-police-officers-injured-at-scene-of-violent-disorder-in-southport/", "title": "Almost 40 police officers injured at scene of violent disorder in Southport", "body": "Merseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries.\n\nNearly 40 police officers sustained injuries at the scene of violent disorder in Southport, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nThe service said 27 officers were taken to hospital.\n\nA statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nMerseyside police said these powers would not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing attack in Southport on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nEight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain says Islamaphobic backlash began with a false rumour on the internet which was then stoked by misinformation from a Russian news site, which wrongfully associated the crime with Muslims.\n\nThe MCB paid tribute to the three young girls killed in Southport on Monday, before condemning \"shocking scenes of far-right rioters running amok outside a mosque\".", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Guernsey Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merseyside_Police", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "2024-07-439488033", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:02:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:02:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:48:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.itv.com/news/granada/2024-07-31/it-was-a-war-zone-southport-rallies-together-after-violence-outside-mosque", "title": "'It was a war zone': Southport rallies together after violence outside mosque", "body": "People in Southport are rallying together after \"violent thugs\" marred a night of remembrance for three murdered children.\n\nDozens of residents are outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels after violence by what's believed to be far-right activists broke out overnight.\n\nMore than 50 police officers were injured after stones and bottles were thrown, with cars set alight and destroyed.\n\nDavid Burgess is among those residents trying to clean up and rebuild walls destroyed during the protest.\n\n\"This road looked like a war zone,\" he said. \"They're not part of the Southport community.\n\n\"Our community is full of love and I hope this doesn't take away from the tragedy we have faced. To see this happen in the local community, we're absolutely appalled by it.\"\n\nDavid Burgess is among the local residents who have rallied together to clean up the mess left by far-right protesters.\n\n\"As a resident, we're furious,\" said Chloe Quinn, who has joined in on the clean up. \"How dare they come into our town and use it as a platform for violence.\"\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder on Tuesday night.\n\nMr Balasuryla said he called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away.\n\nHe said he was \"terrified\" when he thought they would set fire to the premises because there is a woman and her daughter living in a flat above.\n\nHe said he later found out that the woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them.\n\n\"I got a couple of hours' sleep and then got a phone call saying 'You need to come down, there's lots of people waiting to help',\" Mr Balasuryla said.\n\nHe added that local people had said they would defend his shop if necessary. \"It was terrifying last night,\" he said.\n\n\"But I feel safe again because people are here to protect us.\"\n\nChloe Quinn is a local resident in Southport who says the protesters ruined a day of peaceful vigils for three children killed.\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during the violence following a vigil for the three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7:45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said 50 officers were injured, eight seriously including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said: \"Police officers are not robots.\n\n\"We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners. We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nMeanwhile, Deputy Prime minister Angela Rayner condemned the riots and urged for everyone \"to step back You can check out at any time. More info\n\nThe heartbroken mum of a seven-year-old girl who was stabbed to death at a Taylor Swift camp in Southport is pleading with rioters to end the violence after a night of carnage.\n\nJust a day after the community was rocked by the mass stabbing that killed three children, rioters set fire to vehicles and tore down walls to throw bricks at police officers.\n\nVictim Elsie Dot Stancombe's mum Jenni Stancombe, took to social media with an impassioned plea to 'stop the violence. She wrote: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nSpeaking about the police, she added: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nPolice came under attack from large groups of yobs who initially surrounded a mosque in close to the scene of the stabbings that killed three kids and injured another eight youngsters. Two adults were also injured 'bravely' trying to save children. One is said to be fighting for her life, reports Manchester Evening News.\n\nCop vehicles were set alight, bottles and bricks thrown and burning wheelie bins rammed at police lines as widespread rioting followed a peaceful vigil for the victims.\n\nParamedics treated 39 police officers in total, with 27 taken to hospital as North West Ambulance Service declared a major incident.\n\nWith the town continuing to try to come to terms with the appalling tragedy, hundreds of people made their way to a vigil in the town centre yesterday evening, which was respectfully observed. Trouble, however, was brewing nearby.\n\nPolice initially raced to the disturbance outside a mosque on St Luke's Road in the town before the violence spread.\n\nBricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire, police said. Eight police officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries. One was knocked unconscious.\n\nPolice said the violence started when a large group of people, believed by police to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards the mosque.\n\nGreater Manchester Police officers were drafted in to support their Merseyside colleagues.\n\nMerseyside Police assistant chief constable Alex Goss said last night the force faced 'serious violence' and off-duty officers paraded back on.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park,\" he said.\n\nPrime Minister SIr Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.
