The protesters are believed to be supporters of the far-right English Defence League, police said.\n\nCars were set on fire and a local convenience store was also damaged, police said.\n\nThe protest followed a peaceful vigil for the victims of a deadly stabbing that occurred a day prior in the town.\n\nThree children were killed and nine others injured in the stabbing incident, police said. Two adults were also injured while trying to protect the children, police said.\n\nMerseyside police said the children were attending a Taylor Swift-themed event at a dance school at the time.\n\nMORE: Taylor Swift 'in shock' after horrific UK stabbing, as police say 3rd child dies\n\nA 17-year-old boy from Banks, a coastal village in Lancashire, just outside Southport, was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder, police said. The suspect, whose name was not released, was born in Cardiff, Wales, police said.\n\nThe motive remains unclear, police said.\n\nTuesday's protests were apparently fueled by \"speculation\" over the unidentified suspect, Merseyside Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Goss said in a statement. \"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nGoss said protesters used bricks to attack officers and damaged cars parked in the mosque parking lot. Officers sustained injuries including fractures, cuts, head injuries and a concussion, police said.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday,\" Goss said.\n\nMORE: 2 kids dead, 11 people hurt in 'ferocious' stabbing attack at dance event in United Kingdom, 17-year-old arrested\n\nU.K. Home Secretary Yvette Cooper also decried the violence, calling the attacks on police and the mosque \"appalling.\"\n\n\"The community of Southport are reeling from a horrifying ordeal and families are grieving,\" Cooper said in a statement. \"This violent thuggery, which has overshadowed a peaceful vigil for three little girls, is an insult to the community and to all those who need the space to process what has happened and to heal.\"\n\nEarlier Tuesday, hundreds of people attended a vigil for the stabbing victims in the center of Southport.\n\nThree girls -- 6-year-old Bebe King, 7-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and 9-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar -- were killed in the stabbing.\n\nFive children and two adults injured in the stabbing remained in critical condition on Tuesday, police said.", "source": {"uri": Officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following the vigil for three girls killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, aged nine, six-year-old Bebe King and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nREAD NEXT: Chaos in Southport as nearly 40 police officers injured during violent riots\n\nThe Manchester Evening News understands GMP dispatched two units of public order trained officers to Southport. None of its vehicles or officers were injured. Some 39 colleagues were hurt and 27 of them were taken to hospital, Merseyside Police has confirmed.\n\nThis morning residents in Southport have gathered for a clean-up operation outside a mosque after rioters brought further misery to a town already reeling from a knife attack that left three children dead. Dozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night. It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire. But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up. Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm. Some protesters are heard spouting Islamophobic chants.\n\nAt least eight officers suffered serious injuries, fractures, lacerations and concussion. At least one was knocked unconscious, Merseyside Police said.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured, one sustaining leg injuries from thrown bricks and another suffering burns to its back legs.\n\nThe disorder prompted authorities to issue a 24-hour Section 60 Order, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers in the designated area.\n\nThe cause of the revolt was not entirely clear, but Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss suggested in a statement that it was in connection to \"speculation and hypothesis\" surrounding the 17-year-old boy police arrested on suspicion of being responsible for Monday's knife attack.\n\nThe three children stabbed to death in Southport a day prior while attending a Taylor Swift-themed dance workshop have been identified as 9-year-old Alice Aguiar, 7-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and 6-year-old Bebe King. Five other children and two adults were also critically injured in the attack.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPolice arrested the 17-year-old from Lancashire, Britain, who has been charged with suspicion of murder and attempted murder charges.\n\nGoss reiterated Tuesday: \"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the U.K. and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nHe added that many of those involved in the Tuesday violence do not live in the area \"or care about the people of Merseyside.\"\n\n\"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport,\" Goss said in an early Wednesday update.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nThe violence erupted after a vigil was held in the town for the children that was attended by Home Secretary Yvette Cooper and Prime Minister Keir Starmer who lay flowers during the ceremony.\n\nStarmer accused the protesters of having \"hijacked\" the vigil \"with violence and thuggery\" that insults the community in grieving.\n\n\"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and respect,\" he said in a statement, vowing that those responsible for the violence that followed the vigil \"will feel the full force of the law.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8252389273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:53:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:53:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:52:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/woman-holds-hope-not-hate-29648946", "title": "Woman holds 'hope not hate' sign up in midst of Southport violence - Liverpool Echo", "body": "Powerful moment was captured amongst the grim and ugly scenes in the town last night\n\nIn the midst of Tuesday night's chaotic and ugly scenes on the streets of Southport, there was one woman who made a brave stand against the hatred on show.\n\nUnrest broke out in the seaside town last night a day after the horrific stabbing in Hart Street that left three children dead and many others in hospital. A peaceful vigil in the centre of the town was followed by a protest outside a mosque in St Luke's Road that quickly descended into mindless violence.\n\nIn what have been described as 'sickening' scenes, dozens of officers were injured and a major incident declared. Bricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire. Eight police officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries. One was knocked unconscious.\n\nThe violence started when a large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road on Tuesday evening. Cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire and bricks were thrown at a local mosque. Damage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set on fire, police said. Three police dogs have also been injured. Photos and videos shared online show large groups hurling rocks at police officers, climbing on police vans and attempting to smash the vehicles' windows.\n\nBut while many of the images shared of the night depict violence and thuggery, one woman was pictured attempting to project a different message altogether. The picture shows a woman stood in front of some of those violent scenes, holding aloft a sign which reads 'one race - human, hope not hate - racism, not welcome here.'\n\nVideo footage shared online shows the woman attempting to hold the sign up and being challenged and shouted at by those protesting. At one point someone tries to grab the sign out of her hands. The violence has been widely condemned - including by the Prime Minister and Home Secretary - but there will be no more powerful voice in this than of the mother of one of the three little girls so tragically killed in Southport on Monday. In a message widely shared on social media, Jenni Stancombe said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nSpeaking about the police, Ms Stancombe added: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\" Last night, Merseyside Police assistant chief constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack. I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. {"uri": "8252159698", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:38:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:38:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:37:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/news/report/mosque-cops-attacked-as-vigil-for-uk-stabbing-victims-turns-violent/20240731.htm", "title": "Mosque, cops attacked as vigil for UK stabbing victims turns violent", "body": "A far-right mob targeted a mosque in north-west England that saw three young girls fatally stabbed during a peaceful vigil in their memory and around 40 police officers suffered injuries in the disorder.\n\nIMAGE: Kindly note that this image has been posted for representational purposes only. Photograph: Temilade Adelaja/Reuters\n\nAccording to reports, misinformation being spread on social media about the ethnicity and religion of the 17-year-old male suspect in police custody led to the rioting at the mosque in Southport on Tuesday night.\n\nBritish Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who had earlier visited the site of Monday's brutal stabbing attack on a dance studio on Hart Street, condemned the mobs for hijacking the vigil and insulting the grieving community with their actions.\n\n\"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect,\" said Starmer.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law,\" he said.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, 9, Bebe King, 6, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, 7, were named as the victims of the fatal stabbing. Eight others were seriously injured, five of whom remain in critical condition in hospital.\n\nThe Merseyside police have said it was currently not treating the incident as terror-related.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets. We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time,\" said Alex Goss, assistant chief constable of the force.\n\nThe police said 22 of its officers sustained serious injuries, including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. The rioters set cars belonging to members of the public alight, threw bricks at the local mosque and damaged a local convenience store, and set large refuse bins on fire.\n\nAs a result, strict legal orders have been enforced in the area designed to minimise serious violence and giving additional powers to officers to tackle anti-social behaviour.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park. This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday,\" said Goss, as he appealed for information to bring those involved to justice.\n\nThe police attracted strong support from the local community, who believed the English Defence League (EDL) supporting mob was whipped up largely from outside the town.\n\nThe disorder flared up after thousands gathered at the peace vigil to pay tribute to three girls killed and pray for those fighting for their lives in the knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club dance event at Hart Street community centre.\n\nMeanwhile, two adults who were critically injured in the attack have been named locally as yoga teacher Leanne Lucas, who co-organised the dance session for a group of six to 11-year-olds, and John Hayes, who works at the Hart Space where the stabbings took place.\n\n\"It is extremely important that people don't spread damaging misinformation online. False information has already been extensively shared in the last 24 hours,\" urged UK Home Secretary Yvette Cooper.\n\n\"In these dark and difficult moments, the police must be able to get on with their work and communities must be given the time and space to grieve and heal without outside voices seeking to use events to stir up division or advance their own views,\" she said.\n\nMeanwhile, more than GBP 2,15,000 has been raised by Taylor Swift fans via a 'Swifties for Southport Just Giving' page for the funerals of the children who were killed and for the families of the injured.\n\nThe You can check out at any time. More info\n\nA large crowd has gathered on a Southport street, leading to heightened tensions this evening. Merseyside Police have confirmed they are responding to a disturbance on St Luke's Road in Southport, which occurred during a protest tonight (Tuesday).\n\nA significant group of individuals, believed by the police to be supporters of the English Defence League, started hurling objects towards a local mosque. Images and footage taken from the scene, depict crowds surrounding police riot vans on St Luke's Road.\n\nIn one clip, a man donning a balaclava is seen clambering atop a police van amidst shouts and cheers. Additional videos capture glass bottles being hurled at a police van and flares being ignited.\n\nA police van was also spotted ablaze. The police have reported that officers on site are presently dealing with criminal activity and violence, including bottles and wheelie bins being thrown at them.\n\nREAD MORE: Southport riots: Liverpool Mayor fears 'further trauma' as 'thugs' set fires and attack police officers\n\nConsequently, an officer has sustained a suspected broken nose, and police vehicles have been damaged and set on fire. Video from the scene shows crowds assembling in front of officers wielding riot shields, reports the Liverpool Echo.\n\nNumerous individuals were observed recording the scenes on their mobile phones.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss stated: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives. In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\"\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavor to prevent disorder.\"\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside. There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\"\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time. Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nIf you witnessed the incident or have any information, please get in touch with our social media desk on Twitter @MerPolCC or Facebook 'Merseyside Police Contact Centre'. Yobs demolished garden walls and used the bricks to pelt police. Locals hit out at the shameful displays as police were left picking up the pieces in an already devastated town.\n\nYilmaz Nasuh, 55, a Muslim born in Turkey, watched the riot unfold from his home. He told The Mirror: \"My first thought is that the people who lost their loved ones yesterday are having to deal with this insult on top of their sorrow.\n\n\"I'm seeing an organised criminal riot. I'm feeling that I've been here 40 years and this isn't the British experience. This is something alien. This is not love, this is not humanity. This is sad. I just feel so bad for the parents having to deal with this too. They live here. This is all I can think of.\"\n\nZulficar Ismail Ibrahim, 53, who worships at the mosque, said: \"This makes me very sad. It is not good for the community.\" Merseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident. Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside. There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time. Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy posted on X: \"I am incredibly proud of my officers and staff who have worked so hard to save the lives of children, investigate the horrific incident from yesterday, working with partners to provide reassurance to our communities and now they are facing this level of violence from these thugs.\n\n\"Over 1,000 residents from Southport came together this evening to remember the little girls who have died, those who are still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed & are traumatised by the events from yesterday. {"uri": "8252312765", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:07:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:07:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:06:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://whdh.com/news/violent-scenes-as-far-right-protesters-crash-vigil-for-three-girls-killed-in-southport-knife-attack/", "title": "Violent scenes as far-right protesters crash vigil for three girls killed in Southport knife attack - Boston News, Weather, Sports | WHDH 7News", "body": "(CNN) -- Far-right protesters violently clashed with British police on Tuesday near a mosque in the northwest English town of Southport, a day after three young girls were stabbed to death in one of the worst assaults against children in the country in decades.\n\nBritish Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the group had \"hijacked\" a peaceful vigil held for those killed and injured in the attack \"with violence and thuggery\" and \"insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\nThose involved \"will feel the full force of the law,\" Starmer added in the post on X.\n\nThe violence followed a peaceful vigil in the seaside town attended by hundreds of mourners who laid wreaths, toys and candles in an emotional tribute to the three girls who were killed during the attack during a Taylor Swift-themed event at a dance school.\n\nProtesters, believed to be supporters of the far-right English Defence League, took to the streets in anger throwing bricks at a local mosque, setting cars and police vehicles alight and hurling bottles at police, Merseyside Police said in a statement.\n\nPolice believe the crowd took to the streets over unconfirmed reports speculating on the identity of the teenage suspect, who was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder following Monday's knife attack.\n\nOfficers \"sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion,\" Merseyside Police said. \"Other officers have suffered varying degrees of injury including head injuries, serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\"\n\nThree police dogs were also injured, with two sustaining leg injuries from bricks thrown at them and one suffering burns, it added.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said in a police statement, referring to the horrific knife attack.\n\n\"Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder,\" he said.\n\nThe North West Ambulance Service said it treated 39 police officers injured in the violence, 27 of whom were taken to hospital.\n\nFollowing the arrest in the stabbings case, an \"incorrect\" name linked to the suspect was spread on social media, police said.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Goss said.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK, and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nPolice have said the suspect is from the village of Banks, near Southport, and was originally from Cardiff, Wales.\n\nGoss added that many of those involved in the violence were not local to the area, suggesting they traveled to Southport with the intention of causing unrest.\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain (MCB) paid tribute to the girls killed in the attack and said in a statement that \"Southport's tragedy was shamelessly exploited to spark outrage, with Islamophobia fueling the fire and leading to tonight's violence.\"\n\n\"This began with a false rumour on the internet, stoked by misinformation from a Russian news site, which wrongfully associated the crime with Muslims,\" it said.\n\nThe MCB said the government \"must address the increasing rise of violent far-right extremism targeting Muslim communities. More must be done to tackle Islamophobia and offer reassurance at this time.\"\n\nOn Tuesday, police named the three girls killed in the stabbing as Bebe King, 6, Elsie Dot Stancombe, 7, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, 9.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds in the attack and five of them are in critical condition, police said. Two adults also remain in critical condition after being injured in the attack.\n\nPolice shared a tribute from the family of King, who said: \"No words can describe the devastation that has hit our family as we try to deal with the loss of our little girl Bebe.\"\n\nPrime Minister Starmer and other officials visited the site of the attack on Tuesday, paying tribute to the victims and thanking emergency responders who attended the scene.\n\nStarmer laid a wreath of cream and yellow-colored flowers, alongside floral tributes left by the local community.\n\nTaylor Swift, whose music was the theme of the dance class targeted in the attack, said Tuesday she was \"completely in shock.\"\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 CNN. injured at scene of violent disorder in...", "body": "Nearly 40 police officers sustained injuries at the scene of violent disorder in Southport, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nThe service said 27 officers were taken to hospital.\n\nA statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order has been introduced in the above areas, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals in the area and is designed to minimise serious violence (Merseyside Police/PA)\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced, giving police the power to direct people engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents.\n\nMerseyside police said these powers would not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing attack in Southport on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nThe attack saw Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nEight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart {"uri": "8252249481", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:33:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:33:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:32:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/31/community-rallies-together-after-people-from-out-of-town-riot-in-southport/", "title": "Community rallies together after 'people from out of town' riot in Southport", "body": "Locals gathered with brushes and shovels to clean up after violence outside a mosque and pledged support for the owner of a looted shop.\n\nLocals in Southport are rallying together after right-wing rioters marred a night of remembrance for three murdered children.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, after violent protests that saw bricks, stones and bottles thrown at police and cars set alight.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nMr Balasuryla said he called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away.\n\nHe said he was \"terrified\" when he thought they would set fire to the premises because there is a woman and her daughter living in a flat above.\n\nHe said he later found out that the woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them.\n\n\"I got a couple of hours' sleep and then got a phone call saying 'You need to come down, there's lots of people waiting to help',\" Mr Balasuryla said.\n\nHe added that local people had said they would defend his shop if necessary.\n\n\"It was terrifying last night,\" he said.\n\n\"But I feel safe again because people are here to protect us.\"\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nMr Wallis, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road on Wednesday, said volunteers joined the clean-up partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe added: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\n\"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nScotland's former first minister Humza Yousaf called for the EDL to be banned under terror laws in the wake of the unrest, despite former leader Tommy Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy said the officers injured in Tuesday's protests will \"now be unavailable for duty in what is an incredibly busy time for the force\".\n\nVideos posted on social media showed people throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers who held riot shields to push the crowds back.\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\nThe vigil was followed by the protest outside the mosque as demonstrators chanted far-right slogans and clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice have said that although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nA 32-year-old man from Standish was arrested on suspicion of possession of a flick knife in Eastbank Street, near where the vigil took place on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe was taken into custody and there were no reports that anyone was injured during the incident, Merseyside Police said.", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Guernsey Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8251408940", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:10:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:10:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:10:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/muslim-mans-powerful-8-word-33362778", "title": "Muslim man's 8-word message to EDL rioters in Southport in front of his home", "body": "A Muslim man in Southport had an eight-word message for far-right thugs bringing violence and vandalism to heartbroken Southport.\n\nYilmaz Nasuh watched in abject horror as riots flared outside his home in the town on Tuesday night, saying, \"this is not love, this is not humanity - this is sad\". In a far cry from the peaceful vigil held minutes earlier commemorating the victims of Monday's stabbings, protesters hurled bricks at a mosque and abused police officers, setting fire to a van.\n\nAt least five officers were injured in the violence, with one suffering a suspected broken nose. Yobs demolished garden walls and used the bricks to pelt police. Locals hit out at the shameful displays as police were left picking up the pieces in an already devastated town.\n\nMr Nasuh, 55, a Muslim born in Turkey, watched the riot unfold from his home. He told The Mirror : \"My first thought is that the people who lost their loved ones yesterday are having to deal with this insult on top of their sorrow.\n\n\"I'm seeing an organised criminal riot. I'm feeling that I've been here 40 years and this isn't the British experience. This is something alien. This is not love, this is not humanity. This is sad. I just feel so bad for the parents having to deal with this too. They live here. This is all I can think of.\"\n\nZulficar Ismail Ibrahim, 53, who worships at the mosque, said: \"This makes me very sad. It is not good for the community.\" Merseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident. Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside. There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time. Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy posted on X: \"I am incredibly proud of my officers and staff who have worked so hard to save the lives of children, investigate the horrific incident from yesterday, working with partners to provide reassurance to our communities and now they are facing this level of violence from these thugs.\n\n\"Over 1,000 residents from Southport came together this evening to remember the little girls who have died, those who are still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed & are traumatised by the events from yesterday. {"uri": "8251861940", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:22:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:22:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:21:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/mum-southport-victim-powerful-plea-29646648", "title": "Mum of Southport victim in powerful plea to those causing chaos on town's streets - Liverpool Echo", "body": "Jenni Stancombe, whose seven-year-old daughter Elsie was killed in Monday's attacks, has spoken out about the violence seen in the town last night\n\nThe mother of one of the three children killed in the Southport knife attack made an impassioned plea to 'stop the violence' in Southport after last night's shameful scenes in the town. Jenni Stancombe, the mother of seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe took to social media to make the powerful appeal.\n\nHer young daughter died after the horror attack at a Taylor Swift dance party in Hart Street on Monday lunchtime. Nine-year-old Alice Aguiar and six-year-old Bebe King also died in the attack, while two adults and five other children remain critically ill in hospital.\n\nWith Southport continuing to try to come to terms with this appalling tragedy, hundreds of people made their way to a vigil in the town centre yesterday evening, which was respectfully observed. However, nearby, trouble was brewing. Police raced to a disturbance taking place during a protest outside a mosque on St Luke's Road in the town.\n\nIn what have been described as 'sickening' scenes, dozens of officers were injured and a major incident declared. Bricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire. Eight police officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries. One was knocked unconscious.\n\nThe violence started when a large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road on Tuesday evening. Cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire and bricks were thrown at a local mosque. Damage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set on fire, police said. Three police dogs have also been injured. Photos and videos shared online show large groups hurling rocks at police officers, climbing on police vans and attempting to smash the vehicles' windows.\n\nThe violence has been widely condemned - including by the Prime Minister and Home Secretary - but there will be no more powerful voice in this than of the mother of one of the three little girls so tragically killed in Southport on Monday. In a message widely shared on social media, Jenni Stancombe said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nSpeaking about the police, Ms Stancombe added: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\" Last night, Merseyside Police assistant chief constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack. I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\"\n\nPrime Minister SIr Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law.\"", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Liverpool Echo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "liam_thorp@liverpoolecho.co.uk", "name": {"uri": "2024-07-439493572", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:07:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:07:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:53:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/31/world/europe/uk-stabbing-southport-riot-police.html", "title": "U.K. Police Officers Injured in Far-Right Riot After Deadly Stabbing", "body": "Almost 40 police officers were injured in the northwestern English town of Southport on Tuesday evening after a day of mourning for children killed in a stabbing attack was disrupted by far-right protesters.\n\nA large group that the police say included supporters of the English Defence League, a far-right extremist organization, began attacking a mosque in Southport on Tuesday evening, according to a statement from the Merseyside Police Service, which covers the region.\n\nOfficials said that the targeting of the mosque and the ensuing riot appeared to be linked to online disinformation about the stabbing on Monday, when an attacker killed three children and injured eight other children and two adults at a dance class in Southport.\n\nThe police on Monday arrested a 17-year-old who was born in Cardiff, Wales, on suspicion of murder and attempted murder. In line with British law regarding minors, the police did not identify the suspect, and subsequently they warned that a name being circulated on social media was incorrect.\n\nAlex Goss, the assistant chief constable of the Merseyside police, said on Tuesday night, \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\"\n\nHe added, \"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the U.K. and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nMany of those involved in the unrest, he noted, \"do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\"\n\nThe outbreak of violence, in which rioters set police cars on fire, destroyed vehicles belonging to locals, threw bricks at the mosque and damaged a convenience store, was deeply distressing for a community still grappling with the raw emotions after Monday's attack.\n\nThe police have said that they are still investigating the motive for the attack, but said it was \"not being treated as terrorist-related.\"\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday night, the British prime minister, Keir Starmer, condemned the rioting and vowed to hold those who took part accountable.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves,\" Mr. Starmer wrote in a statement. \"They will feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nThe North West Ambulance Service, which covers the region, said that 39 patients, all of whom were police officers, had been treated for injuries. Twenty-seven of those officers had to be taken to the hospital.\n\nThe violence began shortly after thousands had gathered in the town for a vigil to honor the victims of the attack, with many crowding a central square grasping bouquets of flowers and teddy bears.\n\nA flood of disinformation online about the perpetrator of the attack was amplified by far-right influencers, including Tommy Robinson, an anti-Islam agitator and founder of the English Defense League, and Andrew Tate, another extremist online personality.\n\nMerseyside Police later said that 22 of its officers had been injured and that eight had sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and a concussion.\n\nOthers had head injuries, facial injuries and one was knocked unconscious, the force said.\n\nThe violence occurred a short walk from where the initial stabbings took place on Monday. As the evening light turned to darkness on Tuesday, smoke from the riot drifted over the makeshift memorial that had sprung up, the acrid black fumes visible on the horizon over the piles of flowers.\n\nMr. Goss of the Merseyside Police said that a number of off-duty police officers had been called in to support their colleagues, and he applauded their dedication while criticizing those who took part in the disorder.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community,\" he said, \"least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com",
