{"uri": "8252701823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:10:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:10:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:09:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/31/merseyside-police-call-in-neighbouring-forces-to-to-help-prevent-further-riots/", "title": "Merseyside Police calls in neighbouring forces to help prevent further riots", "body": "Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said she understands the community in Southport is worried but said the force has 'sufficient resources'.\n\nPolice in Merseyside have called in support from forces across the region to avoid a second night of rioting in tragedy-hit Southport.\n\nViolence erupted near the town's mosque on Tuesday after false rumours circulated online about the suspect in a mass stabbing that claimed the lives of three girls and left eight more children and two adults injured.\n\nFour people have been arrested over the unrest so far, which saw 53 officers and three police dogs injured.\n\nDuring a walkabout in the town on Wednesday, Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said she understood that communities in Southport were \"really worried\" about whether they would see a second night of unrest.\n\nShe said: \"We are absolutely planning for this evening and for the weekend ahead.\n\n\"We are being really well supported by police forces across the North West to make sure we have got sufficient resources so that we don't see a repeat of last night.\"\n\nBaseless rumours were spread on social media, misidentifying the suspect and falsely claiming that he was a refugee when, in fact, he was born in Wales.\n\nActor Laurence Fox, one of the users of X who shared the information, called on supporters to gather at Downing Street at 7pm on Wednesday.\n\nDetectives have been given more time to question the 17-year-old, who was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder.\n\nThe law allows officers up to 96 hours, or four days, to hold the suspect, who has not been named because of his age, in custody.\n\nAfter rioting broke out, Elsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, clearing bricks from a wall that was knocked down during the rioting.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nHe said: \"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMosque chairman Ibrahim Hussein told reporters he was trapped in the mosque with about eight others as the violence erupted, and only escaped with a police guard.\n\nLocals have brought flowers to the mosque and are helping organise repairs to the building, which Mr Hussein said was \"humbling\".\n\n\"I know the people of Southport and I know how beautiful they are but this was still a moving experience to see all that,\" he said.\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder on Tuesday night.\n\nHe called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away, and was \"terrified\" that they might set fire to the premises because a woman and her daughter live in the flat above.\n\nThe woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them, he said.\n\nAngela Rayner said that Home Secretary Yvette Cooper will look at whether the EDL should be banned, despite former leader Tommy Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 police officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport.\n\nPolice have said that although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Guernsey Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death/Suicide", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death/Suicide", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://www.guernseypress.com/resizer/v2/6NEHS7KQHVCUFHVYVBXGAJSPC4.jpg?auth=4a9e26c66e04bfb336eb77c1b1c8da288ad19de679e481be20f26bfca036b51c&width=1200&height=900", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9777011", "eventUri": "eng-9777011", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1764705882352942, "wgt": 166, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-439127304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:53:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:53:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:41:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/worshippers-trapped-mob-tries-burn-064145251.html", "title": "Worshippers trapped as mob tries to burn down Southport mosque", "body": "Worshippers trapped as mob tries to burn down Southport mosque\n\nNeil Johnston\n\n31 July 2024 at 8:41 am\n\nWorshippers were forced to take shelter in a Southport mosque as far-Right protesters attempted to set fire to the building.\n\nAround half a dozen members of the Southport Mosque and Islamic Centre were told to wait for a police escort as a mob attacked the property on Tuesday night.\n\nPolice were attacked with bottles, bricks, bins and missiles and a van was set on fire after a night of violence in the seaside town.\n\nDemonstrators, who police believe to have been from the English Defence League, started the disorder outside the mosque following the killing of three children at a holiday camp on Monday.\n\nThe three victims of the knife attack at a holiday club were yesterday named as six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds, with five of them in a critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old from the village of Banks, five miles away from Southport, was arrested on Monday afternoon on suspicion of murder and attempted murder and remains in police custody.\n\nDespite no evidence the killer is linked to the Muslim community, the protesters targeted the mosque as they chanted \"we are doing this for our girls\".\n\nThe violence came after false rumours circulated online that the 17-year-old suspect in custody on suspicion of murder over the deadly was an asylum seeker who came to Britain on a small boat.\n\nSoyful Alam, the former Imam of the mosque, told The Telegraph \"six or seven\" worshippers were trapped inside as the violence unfolded.\n\nSpeaking on behalf of those inside, he said they were taking advice from police to take shelter and stay away from windows as the disorder continued.\n\n\"I spoke to someone ten minutes ago and he was still inside the mosque,\" he said just after 10pm last night.\n\n\"He's been there for a long time. He's staying away from the windows and the main road,\" Mr Alam said.\n\n\"There is substantial damage. The outer fence has been damaged or burnt and I think some outer windows have been smashed.\n\n\"There are about six or seven people in there. The police are there and they will stay in a safe place until the police escort them to safety.\"\n\n'The whole town is grieving'\n\nAddressing the violence, Mr Alam said the town should come together rather than be divided by the tragedy.\n\n\"At a time of grieving and pain you would urge people to do their best for people to come together as a community.\n\n\"I think the whole town is grieving, the only thing on everybody's mind is the children. It's such a small town, it's a small community.\n\n\"I think the main thing at this time should be to support everyone affected.\"\n\nHe added that no matter what religion the man suspected of carrying out the attack on the dance class was violence was not justified.\n\n\"The identity of any criminal is irrelevant in any case. Whether the criminal is Muslim or a Christian or a Jew or of no faith,\" he said.\n\n\"That doesn't justify attacking the police. I mean the police have faced horrendous violence tonight.\n\n\"I don't know who these people are, I'm not sure what their actual objective of this is at this moment in time.\"\n\nParamedics treated 39 police officers for injuries at St Luke's Road in Southport, and 27 were taken to hospital following the disorder. Of those, eight sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured during the disorder which saw cars belonging to members of the public alight and damage to neighbouring properties. Those involved also tore down walls and threw the rubble towards officers.\n\nA mob gathered outside the mosque, hurling bricks, masonry and fireworks at officers, amid claims that police were not telling the truth about the suspect's background and his motives, with rumours swirling on social media.\n\nSmoke was seen billowing from the area after a police van was set on fire and protesters clashed with police wielding riot shields and batons with officers charging the crowds outside the mosque.\n\nThere were chants of \"No surrender!\" and \"English 'til I die!\".\n\nA 24-hour section 60 Order has been introduced in the area, giving officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals.\n\nMerseyside Police described last night's scenes as \"sickening\" and said people were using the speculation about the attack to \"bring violence and disorder to our streets\".\n\nPolice said officers who had already completed a shift on Tuesday returned to duty to help colleagues deal with the disorder.\n\n\"A number of officers have been injured, cars set alight and a shop broken into and looted in Southport this evening,\" police said in a statement.\n\n\"This is completely unacceptable. We're gathering evidence and those responsible will be brought to justice.\"", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "neil_johnston@aol.co.uk", {"uri": "8251940446", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:19:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:19:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:17:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2024/07/31/worshippers-trapped-inside-southport-mosque/", "title": "Worshippers trapped as mob attacks Southport mosque", "body": "Half a dozen people told to wait for police escort as violence erupted on Tuesday night\n\nWorshippers were forced to take shelter in a Southport mosque as hundreds of far-Right rioters attacked the building.\n\nAround half a dozen members of the Southport Mosque and Islamic Centre were told to wait for a police escort as a mob surrounded the property on Tuesday night.\n\nPolice were attacked with bottles, bricks, bins and missiles and a van was set on fire after a night of violence in the seaside town.\n\nDemonstrators, who police believe to have been from the English Defence League, started the disorder outside the mosque following the killing of three children at a holiday club on Monday.\n\nThe three victims of the knife attack were named as six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds, with five of them in a critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old from the village of Banks, five miles away from Southport, was arrested on Monday afternoon on suspicion of murder and attempted murder and remains in police custody.\n\nDespite no evidence the killer is linked to the Muslim community, the rioters targeted the mosque as they chanted \"we are doing this for our girls\".\n\nThe violence came after false rumours circulated online that the 17-year-old suspect in custody on suspicion of murder over the deadly was an asylum seeker who came to Britain on a small boat.\n\nSoyful Alam, the former Imam of the mosque, told The Telegraph \"six or seven\" worshippers were trapped inside as the violence unfolded.\n\nSpeaking on behalf of those inside, he said they were taking advice from police to take shelter and stay away from windows as the disorder continued.\n\n\"I spoke to someone ten minutes ago and he was still inside the mosque,\" he said just after 10pm last night.\n\n\"He's been there for a long time. He's staying away from the windows and the main road,\" Mr Alam said.\n\n\"There is substantial damage. The outer fence has been damaged or burnt and I think some outer windows have been smashed.\n\n\"There are about six or seven people in there. The police are there and they will stay in a safe place until the police escort them to safety.\"\n\n'The whole town is grieving'\n\nAddressing the violence, Mr Alam said the town should come together rather than be divided by the tragedy.\n\n\"At a time of grieving and pain you would urge people to do their best for people to come together as a community.\n\n\"I think the whole town is grieving, the only thing on everybody's mind is the children. It's such a small town, it's a small community.\n\n\"I think the main thing at this time should be to support everyone affected.\"\n\nHe added that no matter what religion the man suspected of carrying out the attack on the dance class was violence was not justified.\n\n\"The identity of any criminal is irrelevant in any case. Whether the criminal is Muslim or a Christian or a Jew or of no faith,\" he said.\n\n\"That doesn't justify attacking the police. I mean the police have faced horrendous violence tonight.\n\n\"I don't know who these people are, I'm not sure what their actual objective of this is at this moment in time.\"\n\nParamedics treated 39 police officers for injuries at St Luke's Road in Southport, and 27 were taken to hospital following the disorder. Of those, eight sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured during the disorder which saw cars belonging to members of the public alight and damage to neighbouring properties. Those involved also tore down walls and threw the rubble towards officers.\n\nA mob gathered outside the mosque, hurling bricks, masonry and fireworks at officers, amid claims that police were not telling the truth about the suspect's background and his motives, with rumours swirling on social media.\n\nSmoke was seen billowing from the area after a police van was set on fire and demonstrators clashed with police wielding riot shields and batons with officers charging the crowds outside the mosque.\n\nThere were chants of \"No surrender!\" and \"English 'til I die!\".\n\nA 24-hour section 60 Order has been introduced in the area, giving officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals.\n\nMerseyside Police described last night's scenes as \"sickening\" and said people were using the speculation about the attack to \"bring violence and disorder to our streets\".\n\nPolice said officers who had already completed a shift on Tuesday returned to duty to help colleagues deal with the disorder.\n\n\"A number of officers have been injured, cars set alight and a shop broken into and looted in Southport this evening,\" police said in a statement.\n\n\"This is completely unacceptable. injured in Southport violent disorder", "body": "Almost 40 police officers sustained injuries at the scene of violent disorder in Southend, emergency services said.\n\nNorth West Ambulance Service said 27 police officers were taken to hospital.\n\nA statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nMerseyside police said these powers would not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing attack in Southport on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nEight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain says {"uri": "8252299266", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:00:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:00:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:59:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.gmanetwork.com/news/topstories/world/915417/dozens-of-uk-police-hurt-in-clashes-after-3-girls-killed-in-stabbing-attack/story/", "title": "Dozens of UK police hurt in clashes after 3 girls killed in stabbing attack", "body": "SOUTHPORT, England -- Dozens of British police officers suffered injuries in violent clashes in an English seaside town late on Tuesday after three young girls were killed a day earlier in a violent stabbing attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance event.\n\nPolice vans were set on fire in Southport and protesters hurled bricks at both officers and at cars parked at a mosque, following speculation and unverified posts on social media that the suspect behind the attack was a Muslim and a migrant.\n\nAs well as killing three girls aged six to nine, Monday's horrific incident in the normally quiet town in northwest England saw eight other children stabbed. Five remain in a critical condition in hospital along with two adults who tried to protect them.\n\nPolice, who have arrested an unnamed 17-year-old male on suspicion of murder and attempted murder, have said the incident was not terrorism-related and sought to quash speculation on the suspect's origins, saying he was born in Britain.\n\nThat did not prevent protesters, from what Merseyside police believed were tied to the right-wing anti-Islam group, the English Defence League, from targeting a mosque in the town and attacking police who tried to stop them.\n\nPoliticians and police said most of those taking part in the violence were not from the area, and said the clashes detracted from a large vigil attended by thousands to pay tribute to the young victims.\n\n'Thugs from out of town'\n\nA total of 39 officers were treated for injuries, including 27 who were taken to hospital, North West Ambulance Service said on Wednesday. Police said eight had suffered serious injuries including fractures, and three police dogs were also hurt.\n\n\"Offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said in a statement.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, streets in Southport were littered with bricks from broken walls, smashed bottles, and large garbage bins -- which had been hurled at police the night before -- and their contents. Charred tarmac bore witness to the police vehicles which had been set alight.\n\n\"What I saw last night was absolutely appalling ... It was devastating and it's kind of taken away from actually what's gone on, which is the tragedy of those deaths,\" local resident David Burgess told Sky News.\n\n\"This is about the girls and the tragedy which has happened -- don't make it about this,\" he said, referring to the clashes. \"This isn't Southport. This isn't the community.\"\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer and senior ministers blamed \"violent thugs from out town,\" for the trouble.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law,\" Starmer said.\n\nMeanwhile, Taylor Swift's fans have so far raised more than \u00a3270,000 ($346,000) to help families of the victims and for the hospital {"uri": "8251753730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "04:52:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T04:52:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T04:51:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/southport-stabbing-mosque-protests-riot-edl-b2588605.html", "title": "What is happening in Southport? What we know about stabbing and subsequent riots", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nThree children have been killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in Southport.\n\nA nine-year-old girl has become the third victim, with Merseyside Police saying the youngster died in the early hours of Tuesday morning following the deaths of two other girls, aged six and seven.\n\nFive other children remain in critical condition in hospital with stab injuries, while two adults who are believed to have tried to protect the young victims remain critically ill.\n\nFollow our live blog for the latest as it happens in Southport\n\nArmed officers detained a 17-year-old boy from Banks and seized a knife after attending Hart Street in Southport at 11.50am on Monday.\n\nMerseyside Police said they do not believe the incident to be terror-related adding there is \"no wider threat to the public\".\n\nMeanwhile, a violent protest broke out on Tuesday evening among suspected members of the English Defence League, with a police van set on fire and bricks and bottles thrown at officers.\n\nIt occurred just one hour after a peaceful vigil which saw thousands of local residents, spiritual leaders and the Sefton mayor gather to pay tribute to the victims.\n\nHere is everything we know so far.\n\nEight children in total were stabbed as the dance class was drawing to a close on Monday.\n\nThe first victim to be named by family is Alice Aguiar, thought to be the nine-year-old who died early on Tuesday.\n\nHer aunt Carina Aguiar, a hotel worker who lives in Camara de Lobos in Madeira, Portugal, posted in an emotional tribute: \"Princess Alice. In this moment of great pain my soul hurts, my body hurts, my mind hurts.\n\n\"I have a lump in my throat. You were just an innocent child, a happy smiley girl with a bright life ahead of you which a despicable human being took away from you, without pity, for no reason.\n\n\"Look after your mum and dad who are suffering, who are desolate and broken. Fly high our little star. I love you.\"\n\nOfficials in Lisbon have confirmed she Portuguese national, and that her parents were originally from Madeira.\n\nThe family of Bebe King, 6, said: \"No words can describe the devastation that has hit our family as try to deal with the loss of our little girl Bebe.\"\n\nElsie Dot Stancombe, 7, was identified as one of the first victims in the attack.\n\nA Merseyside Police statement added: \"Their families, who are being supported by specialist officers, have issued photographs and have asked that their privacy is respected at this time.\"\n\nA dance class teacher left fighting for her life after desperately trying to defend the children has been named as \"beautiful\" and \"creative\" Leanne Lucas, 35.\n\nShe was named locally as one of the organisers of the dance workshop.\n\nShe and a colleague are said to have helped shield up to 16 innocent children from the onslaught.\n\nSharing a picture of Leanne on Facebook, Sunshine Yoga wrote: \"I'm absolutely devastated. Please please pray for Leanne.\n\n\"Leanne came on my training course in December. A beautiful young creative girl who was so passionate about helping children. I just can't believe it. Please pray.\"\n\nA Merseyside police spokesperson said: \"Sadly we can confirm that a third child has passed away as a result of injuries sustained in a knife attack in Southport yesterday morning, Monday 29 July. The nine-year-old girl died in hospital in the early hours of this morning, Tuesday, 30 July.\n\n\"We can confirm that the children who died yesterday were girls aged six and seven years.\n\n\"Eight other children suffered stab wounds sustained during the attack, and five of them are in a critical condition.\n\n\"Two adults are also in a critical condition after being injured during the incident.\n\n\"Our specialist Family Liaison Officers are providing support to the families at this terrible time.\"\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said that with \"great sadness\", the children died as a result of their injuries.\n\nShe added that officers were called at 11.47am and were shocked to discover multiple people had been \"subjected to a ferocious attack and had suffered serious injuries\".\n\n\"It is understood that the children were attending a Taylor Swift event at a dance school when the offender, who was armed with a knife, walked into the premises and started to attack those inside. We believe that the adults who were injured were trying to protect the children at the time they were attacked,\" she said.\n\nHundreds of people took part in a peaceful vigil on Tuesday evening outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, with many in tears as they laid flowers and cards of remembrance.\n\nThe vigil was followed by a protest outside a mosque in Southport as demonstrators chanting far-right slogans clashed with police in St Luke's Road.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nMerseyside Police said an officer suffered a suspected broken nose in chaotic scenes outside the mosque as missiles were thrown at the police.\n\nThe 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident in Hart Street, Southport, on Monday, Merseyside Police said.\n\nPolice said the suspect, who was born in Cardiff, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport, and a road in the area was cordoned off by detectives on Monday afternoon.\n\nMerseyside Police added: \"A name has been shared on social media in connection with the suspect in the incident in Southport.\n\n\"This name is incorrect and we would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.\"\n\nA local business owner, who was one of the people who called the police, said the incident in Southport was like a \"scene in a horror movie\".\n\nColin Parry, owner of Masters Vehicle Body Repairs on Hart Street, said he believed six or seven young girls had been stabbed.\n\nHe said: \"It's like something from America, not like sunny Southport.\"\n\nA local parent, who did not wish to be named, said his daughter was \"traumatised\" by the attack.\n\nHe said: \"My daughter was in it and she was traumatised. She ran away and she's safe.\"\n\nEyewitness Bare Varathan, 35, who owns a corner shop on Hart Street, said he was called by a staff member who told him, \"Boss, get to the shop!\"\n\nHe said: \"I saw seven to ten kids outside the nursery. They were injured, bleeding. They were in the road, running from the nursery.\n\n\"They had been stabbed, here, here, here, everywhere. (Mr Varathan indicated the neck, back and chest area).\n\n\"Somebody told me he had arrived in a taxi and had a knife.\"\n\nAccording to reports, personal trainer Joel Verite, 25, rushed to the aid of a woman who screamed \"forget about me, there's a fella in there stabbing kids\".\n\nHe is reported to have helped two other officers, one using a taser, to take down the suspect.\n\nThe 6ft personal trainer told Sky News: \"I just opened the door to see if anyone was there I go on to the bottom of the stairs and I look up and there's this guy there in a full tracksuit with his hood up and a knife. He didn't realise I would be there, we looked at each other and he's scurried off to the side.\n\n\"All I saw was a knife and I thought there was more people in there hurting people. I'm there by myself and I just wanted to hurt him so bad but at the same time I was scared for myself. I just wanted to help. I'm screaming then because I know where he is and I'm trying to get everyone to come to the door. We were there for ten minutes but it felt like a lifetime.\n\nHe added: \"Police finally turned up it was one officer he said to wait for backup because he only had one baton on him. His colleague came with a taser. These two officers go up the stairs and I'm right behind them. They tackle this guy down to the floor straight away. There was no kind of fight at all. I grabbed this girl and I start sprinting towards an ambulance... Once he was down it was kind of done but the damage had been done.\n\n\"I wish I had been able to do more to help. I feel disgusted at the entire situation.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said that the incident is not believed to be terror-related and that the motive currently remains unclear.\n\nOne of the events listed at the Hart Space, based on Hart Street, at the time of the stabbings was a Taylor Swift-themed dance class for children in school years two to six - aged between six and 11.\n\nA staff member at the Hart Space said there could have been as many as 25 children attending.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The events are just truly awful and I know the whole country is deeply shocked at what they have seen and what they have heard.\n\n\"I know I speak for everybody in the whole country in saying our thoughts and condolences are with the victims, their families, their friends and with the wider community.\n\n\"It is impossible to imagine what they are going through right now.\"\n\nSir Keir also thanked the emergency services for their response, saying: \"They have responded to an awful incident today. I want to thank them for the professionalism they have shown in doing so.\"\n\nYvette Cooper has warned against \"speculating or commenting\" on the criminal investigation into the Southport attack before updates have been provided by police.\n\nWhen asked whether she could provide more information, including whether the suspect was known to authorities, the Home Secretary said: \"Merseyside "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.theargus.co.uk/news/national/24487235.nearly-40-police-officers-injured-southport-violent-disorder/", "title": "Nearly 40 police officers injured in Southport violent disorder", "body": "Almost 40 police officers sustained injuries at the scene of violent disorder in Southend, emergency services said.\n\nNorth West Ambulance Service said 27 police officers were taken to hospital.\n\nA statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced, giving police the power to direct people engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents.\n\nMerseyside police said these powers would not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing attack in Southport on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nThe attack saw Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nEight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old More info\n\nA Muslim man in Southport has shared a powerful eight-word message for far-right thugs who started riots in Southport while broken residents tried to grieve.\n\nLocal Yilmaz Nasuh watched in horror as flares were flung outside his home in the town on Tuesday night after violence and vandalism took over the streets, as 39 police officers were injured.\n\nHe said: \"This is not love, this is not humanity - this is sad\". In a far cry from the peaceful vigil held minutes earlier commemorating the victims of Monday's stabbings, protesters hurled bricks at a mosque and abused police officers, setting fire to a van.\n\nAt least five officers were injured in the violence, with one suffering a suspected broken nose. Yobs demolished garden walls and used the bricks to pelt police.\n\nLocals hit out at the shameful displays as police were left picking up the pieces in an already devastated town.\n\nMr Nasuh, 55, a Muslim born in Turkey, watched the riot unfold from his home. He told The Mirror: \"My first thought is that the people who lost their loved ones yesterday are having to deal with this insult on top of their sorrow.\n\n\"I'm seeing an organised criminal riot. I'm feeling that I've been here 40 years and this isn't the British experience. This is something alien.\n\n\"This is not love, this is not humanity. This is sad. I just feel so bad for the parents having to deal with this too. They live here. This is all I can think of.\"\n\nZulficar Ismail Ibrahim, 53, who worships at the mosque, said: \"This makes me very sad. It is not good for the community.\"\n\nThe local force said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\"\n\nHe continued: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time. Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy posted on X: \"I am incredibly proud of my officers and staff who have worked so hard to save the lives of children, investigate the horrific incident from yesterday, working with partners to provide reassurance to our communities and now they are facing this level of violence from these thugs.\n\n\"Over 1,000 residents from Southport came together this evening to remember the little girls who have died, those who are still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed & are traumatised by the events from yesterday. {"uri": "8252694054", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:04:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:04:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:04:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/uknews/2024/07/31/merseyside-police-call-in-neighbouring-forces-to-to-help-prevent-further-riots/", "title": "Merseyside Police call in neighbouring forces to to help prevent further riots", "body": "Police in Merseyside have called in support from forces across the region to avoid a second night of rioting in tragedy-hit Southport.\n\nViolence erupted near the town's mosque on Tuesday after false rumours circulated online about the suspect in a mass stabbing that claimed the lives of three girls and left eight more children and two adults injured.\n\nDuring a walkabout in the town on Wednesday, Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said she understood that communities in Southport were \"really worried\" about whether they would see a second night of unrest.\n\nShe said: \"We are absolutely planning for this evening and for the weekend ahead.\n\n\"We are being really well supported by police forces across the North West to make sure we have got sufficient resources so that we don't see a repeat of last night.\"\n\nBaseless rumours were spread on social media, misidentifying the suspect and falsely claiming that he was a refugee when, in fact, he was born in Wales.\n\nActor Laurence Fox, one of the users of X who shared the information, called on supporters to gather at Downing Street at 7pm on Wednesday.\n\nDetectives have been given more time to question the 17-year-old, who was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder.\n\nThe law allows officers up to 96 hours, or four days, to hold the suspect, who has not been named because of his age, in custody.\n\nAfter rioting broke out, Elsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, clearing bricks from a wall that was knocked down during the rioting.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, said people had travelled from out of town to wreak havoc, leaving locals to clean up the mess.\n\nHe said: \"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMosque chairman Ibrahim Hussein told reporters he was trapped in the mosque with about eight others as the violence erupted, and only escaped with a police guard.\n\nLocals have brought flowers to the mosque and are helping organise repairs to the building, which Mr Hussein said was \"humbling\".\n\n\"I know the people of Southport and I know how beautiful they are but this was still a moving experience to see all that,\" he said.\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder on Tuesday night.\n\nHe called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away, and was \"terrified\" that they might set fire to the premises because a woman and her daughter live in the flat above.\n\nThe woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them, he said.\n\nAngela Rayner said that Home Secretary Yvette Cooper will look at whether the EDL should be banned, despite former leader Tommy Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 police officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, speaking on Wednesday, said rioters must face the \"full force of the law\", saying they were \"utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children\".\n\nHe condemned \"beered-up thugs\" who threw bricks, telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting as \"violent attacks from thugs on the streets\", which she branded \"appalling\".\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport.\n\nPolice have said that although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.", "source": {"uri": "jerseyeveningpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jersey Evening Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death/Suicide", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death/Suicide", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://d3gvyx4eg3tne0.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Img38693732.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9777011", "eventUri": "eng-9777011", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.09019607843137256, "wgt": 162, "relevance": 1}

"news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/merseyside-police-22-officers-injured-003636102.html", "title": "Merseyside Police say 22 officers injured in Southport violent disorder", "body": "Merseyside Police say 22 officers injured in Southport violent disorder\n\nRachel Vickers-Price, PA\n\n31 July 2024 at 2:36 am\n\nMerseyside Police have said 22 officers were hurt in Tuesday's Southport riots, with eight suffering serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced, giving police the power to direct people engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents.\n\nMerseyside police said these powers would not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing attack in Southport on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nThe attack saw Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, fatally stabbed at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nEight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder following the incident at the dance studio in Hart Street.\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain says Islamaphobic backlash began with a false rumour on the internet which was then stoked by misinformation from a Russian news site, which wrongfully associated the crime with Muslims.\n\nThe MCB paid {"uri": "8251542761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:57:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:57:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:56:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/southport-edl-riot-sees-22-33362927", "title": "'Thugs' riot and injure police after Southport stabbing whilst town mourns", "body": "Multiple streets in Southport have been left in ruins after far right 'thugs' fought with police for hours, throwing bottles and setting fires\n\nA riot in Southport in which members of the English Defence League attacked a mosque has left 22 officers injured in a 'shocking' rampage. It comes after the horrific knife attack that took place in a dance class and saw three children lose their lives.\n\nUnder the belief that the 17-year-old attacker was Muslim, EDL members set upon a mosque and a full blown riot unfolded. The claim that the murder suspect was associated with Islam was later debunked by officials.\n\nIn the violent affair on Tuesday evening (July 30), vehicles were set alight, multiple police officers were injured and the local area was wrecked. Though crowds began to disperse around 10.30pm, the aftermath of the riot has left bricks strewn across the area, after being ripped from garden walls.\n\nMeanwhile, the still-smouldering wreckage of the protesters' arson attacks, which have left a police van and multiple residents' cars in ruins, has left a trail smoke through the air - while three local families tonight grieve for their children killed in the attack.\n\nEight other young kids on their summer holidays were injured in the attack, which took place on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in Southport. The three tragically killed in the attack were named on Tuesday as Bebe King (6), Elsie Dot Stancombe (7), and Alice Dasilva Aguiar (9).\n\nREAD MORE: Southport stabbing victims, aged 6, 7, and 9, pictured by police\n\nThe riots are believed to be linked to misinformation spread on social media in the wake of the attack, which was later confirmed to be false. It has been reported that 22 police officers were injured in the riots, with one being knocked unconscious and others facing fractures and lacerations due to the hours-long battle.\n\nAround a third of those injured experienced concussion, facial injuries and broken bones. In the wake of the EDL violence, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper branded the crowd as \"thugs\".\n\nWhile thousands in Southport paid their respects to the three killed in the attack and threw their arms around the stricken community, hundreds of suspected EDL agitators gathered outside a mosque in the area and threw bricks and set fires. Now, police have been granted extreme powers to prevent another riot taking place.\n\nUntil 8pm tomorrow, Merseyside Police have a Section 60 and Section 34 Order in place, giving them greater power to disperse crowds, as well as seize items and vehicles being used in anti social behaviour. The force has emphasised that these powers will not be used for anyone visiting the area or going about their daily business.\n\nPolice also confirmed that three police dogs had been injured by the rioters, with two having bricks thrown at them and another being burnt on the back of its legs.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\n\n\"We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible.\n\n\"Anyone with information can DM @MerPolCC or contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.\"\n\nThe North West Ambulance Service confirmed the high number of police injuries, which forced them to declare a Major Incident late on Tuesday night. They said this was due to the high amount of resources they were having to dedicate to the scene, including 10 ambulances and multiple on-call doctors.\n\nNWAS stated: \"We have treated 22 police officers and so far, 11 of those have been taken to hospital.\n\n\"Due to the high number of resources required at scene and the ongoing disturbance, NWAS declared a major incident at approximately 23:00.\"\n\nMeanwhile, public officials have expressed fears for the riot's impact on the already traumatised local community.\n\nPosting a statement on X, Liverpool Mayor Steve Rotheram said: \"There are families just coming to terms with yesterday's events, parents grieving for their murdered children and survivors still trying to process what they witnessed.\n\n\"The violent scenes in Southport tonight will only further traumatise a community that is already struggling to come to terms with this attack.\"\n\nWhile Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said the thugs would feel the \"full force of the law\". He said in a statement on Tuesday night: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. {"uri": "8252289396", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:53:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:53:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:52:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/last-night-never-children-sheer-29647895", "title": "'Last night was never about the children, it was sheer thuggery' - Liverpool Echo", "body": "People have reacted in dismay to the violence that erupted in Southport last night, while the town tried to grieve after three children died in a mass stabbing\n\nPeople have reacted in pure dismay after violence erupted in Southport last night following a fatal mass stabbing on Monday. Hundreds of people descended on the town, setting fire to both police and civilian's vehicles, damaging a mosque and ripping bricks off walls in order to hurl at officers.\n\nAnti-Muslim chants were shouted, despite police confirming the 17-year-old suspect in relation to the mass stabbing was born in Cardiff in Wales and there being no evidence of him having any links to Islam.\n\nThe violence began when a large group of people began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road on Tuesday evening. Cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire and bricks were thrown. Damage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set on fire, police said.\n\nThree police dogs have also been injured. Photos and videos shared online show large groups hurling rocks at police officers, climbing on police vans and attempting to smash the vehicles' windows. The violence has been widely condemned - including by the Prime Minister and Home Secretary, and also by the mother of one of the three little girls so tragically killed on Monday. In a message widely shared on social media, Jenni Stancombe said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nShe added: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\" Many on social media have condemned the disorder.\n\nBev Lee wrote: \"It's disgusting that anyone would react with such violence after such a tragic 'violent' act that families are still grieving for and hoping that the other individuals survive! There is no excuse for their behaviour- it's disgusting and sick,. Maybe they should channel some of their anger into helping and supporting the people of Southport rather than destroying at such a sad time.\"\n\nLisa Marie said: \"In those houses surrounding would have been other children who, after hearing about the events on Monday, would have been scared and needed calm and reassurance that they're safe. I can't even imagine the trauma and fear now. The police will be the first to respond and give life saving treatment if there's a serious incident again; who's going to those incidents if numbers of an already overwhelmed, overstretched force are taken off with injuries [and] there's no vehicles to get there in?\"\n\nJulie Edwards added: \"Those rioting should have more respect for those poor families who are dealing with their devastating losses. \"Shouldn't be making it about their hatred - targeting a mosque and injuring police officers.\"\n\nReacting to Jenni Stancombe's comments, Paula Scanlon said: \"She shouldn't have to be coming out and saying that, she should be able to be grieving with her family.\"\n\nNeil Griffin said: \"Putting local residents to the effort (and cost) of having to repair their damaged homes is a great way of showing support to the local, grieving community, isn't it? Not.\n\n\"But, it was never about that. Or the poor kids who were brutally killed and injured. It was about a chance to hijack a tragedy to indulge in sheer thuggery.\"\n\nHe added: \"The people of Southport don't want or need these idiots. The traumatic experience is still fresh in their minds. Exactly how does a gang of thugs turning up in masks, with cans of ale, laughing and joking amongst themselves and singing footie style chants help this community? It doesn't. Stay away. Leave them be.\"\n\nLast night, Merseyside Police assistant chief constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack. I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\" North West Ambulance Service confirmed they treated 39 people at the protest, all of whom were police officers.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said: \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They'd earlier converged on a mosque, smashing its windows and chanting racist slogans.\n\nIt comes after false information spread online about the supposed identity of a 17-year-old arrested for stabbing three children to death at a dance class in the town. The ambulance service confirmed 27 officers were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\n\nREAD MORE: Mum of girl, 7, stabbed to death in Southport issues powerful plea to 'stop the violence'\n\nIt was declared as a \"major incident\" by emergency services. Bricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire.\n\nA large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road. Cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire and bricks were thrown at a local mosque.\n\nDamage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set on fire, police said. Three police dogs have also been injured. Police Dogs Zoe and Ike have sustained leg injuries from bricks thrown at them. A third dog, PD Quga, also suffered burns to her back leg.\n\nNorman Wallis, owner of Southport Pleasureland, is helping clear the rubble. He told the ECHO: \"We're all coming together to try and help the people in Sussex Road and the area to clean up for the mess that was made by all those people, those thugs, that came into their street.\n\n\"They just totally destroyed the street, pulled the walls down, pulled fences down, set cars on fire, just terrible. We're all coming together to just try and help as a community.\"\n\nNorman added that Southport is a \"wonderful\" place which needs to be \"shouted about\" and the behaviour of the people last night does not reflect the area.\n\nCathy McGrath has been out on the clean up since 7.15am this morning. She said that the town should be grieving. Speaking to the ECHO, she said: \"I feel just angry and upset really. I went to the vigil last night and it was beautiful for the girls and the children and then you see last night.\n\n\"Those people don't represent the community, these people represent the community. They've spoilt it really and that's why I have come out today.\"\n\nDenise Mace also said: \"It was terrifying to be honest. Seeing the police come marching down and it was right outside my house. These people weren't from Southport and it wasn't a peaceful protest.\" She added: \"When they moved it so far, everyone just come out and started clearing up.\"\n\nSefton Council said its cleaning teams and neighbourhood support teams have been out since 3am trying to clear away some of the destruction left by last nights disorder. It added they have been working hard to try and remove items and debris as quickly and as safely as possible. Our reporters have been chatting to those helping in the clear up.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives. The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets. We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the {"uri": "8251599378", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:10:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:10:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:10:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/violent-crowd-clashes-with-uk-police-after-young-girls-killed/articleshow/112152202.cms", "title": "Violent crowd clashes with UK police after young girls killed", "body": "In Southport, a violent clash erupted between anti-Muslim protesters and police after the stabbing death of three girls, aged 6,7 &9, at a Taylor Swift-themed event. Police confirmed the suspect was born in the UK and ruled out terrorism. Far-right groups incited violence, leading to damage and injuries, while the community held an emotional vigil.A large crowd of anti-Muslim protesters clashed with police on Tuesday in a northern English town where three girls were stabbed to death and five other children critically wounded during an attack on a Taylor Swift-themed event on Monday.\n\nThe horrific stabbing incident in Southport, a quiet seaside town north of Liverpool, has shocked the nation. Police have said it was not linked to terrorism and that the suspect was born in the UK.\n\nYet far-right groups have stoked speculation that the teenage suspect was involved with Islam, and police said Tuesday's violence erupted when several hundred people began to throw items at a mosque. Police linked the crowd to the English Defence League, a group which has sometimes staged violent demonstrations against Islam.\n\nPolice vehicles were damaged and set alight, officers were pelted by bricks and large garbage containers. One video posted online showed the crowd chanting \"we want our country back\".\n\nAway from the violence, hundreds had gathered for an emotional vigil to pay tribute to those killed in the attack, laying flowers and toys.\n\n\"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect,\" Prime Minister Keir Starmer said.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nA 17-year-old male is currently in police custody on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the bloody rampage at a \"Taylor Swift yoga and dance workshop\", a summer vacation event for children aged 6 to 11.\n\nWitnesses described the attack as being like a scene from a horror film. In addition to the three deaths, eight children suffered stab wounds. Five of them and two adults who had tried to protect them remain in a critical condition.\n\nThe police have said the motive remained unclear and have not given any details about the suspect, beyond saying he was born in Wales and lived in a village nearby.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" said Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nGoss and local politicians said those clashing with police involved many from outside the area, and the Liverpool Region Mosque Network said a minority of people were trying to use the incident to spread hatred.\n\n\"This evening we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protesters gathering outside,\" it said in a statement. \"This is causing further fear and anxiety within our communities,\"\n\nStarmer had earlier paid a sombre visit to the town to lay flowers, and King Charles and his family have expressed their horror. U.S. singer Swift herself wrote on Instagram that she was \"just completely in shock\".\n\nJUST LITTLE KIDS\n\n\"These were just little kids at a dance class. I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families,\" she said.\n\nHer fans have raised more than 250,000 pounds ($320,850)online to help families of the victims and for the hospital where some of the children were being treated.\n\nThe three girls who died in the attack were named as Bebe King, aged 6, 7-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, aged 9, whose parents are Portuguese.\n\n\"Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our Princess, like we said before to you, you're always our princess and no one would change that. Love from Your Hero Daddy and Mummy,\" Aguiar's family said in a statement.\n\nThere has been increasing concern at rising levels of stabbings and knife crime in Britain, and the Southport attack follows other recent similar, indiscriminate rampages.\n\n\"I'm absolutely determined that my government will get to grips with it,\" Starmer said.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", {"uri": "8252263227", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:45:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:45:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:40:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13692809/Dozens-UK-police-hurt-clashes-three-girls-killed-stabbing-attack.html", "title": "Dozens of UK police hurt in clashes after three girls killed in...", "body": "Violence in Southport after Monday's attack\n\n*\n\nThree children dead, five in critical condition\n\n*\n\nPolice believe anti-Islam group behind violence\n\n*\n\nPM Starmer blames 'thugs'\n\n(Adds new quotes, details throughout)\n\nBy Temilade Adelaja\n\nSOUTHPORT, England, July 31 (Reuters) -\n\nDozens of British police officers suffered injuries in violent\n\nclashes\n\nin an English seaside town late on Tuesday after\n\nthree young girls\n\nwere killed a day earlier in a violent stabbing attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance event.\n\nPolice vans were set on fire in Southport and protesters hurled bricks at both officers and at cars parked at a mosque, following speculation and unverified posts on social media that the suspect behind the attack was a Muslim and a migrant.\n\nAs well as killing three girls aged six to nine, Monday's horrific incident in the normally quiet town in northwest England saw eight other children stabbed. Five remain in a critical condition in hospital along with two adults who tried to protect them.\n\nPolice, who have arrested an unnamed 17-year-old male on suspicion of murder and attempted murder, have said the incident was not terrorism-related and sought to quash speculation on the suspect's origins, saying he was born in Britain.\n\nThat did not prevent protesters, from what Merseyside police believed were tied to the right-wing anti-Islam group, the English Defence League, from targeting a mosque in the town and attacking police who tried to stop them.\n\nPoliticians and police said most of those taking part in the violence were not from the area, and said the clashes detracted from a large vigil attended by thousands to pay tribute to the young victims.\n\n'THUGS FROM OUT OF TOWN'\n\nA total of 39 officers were treated for injuries, including 27 who were taken to hospital, North West Ambulance Service said on Wednesday. Police said eight had suffered serious injuries including fractures, and three police dogs were also hurt.\n\n\"Offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said in a statement.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, streets in Southport were littered with bricks from broken walls, smashed bottles, and large garbage bins - which had been hurled at police the night before - and their contents. Charred tarmac bore witness to the police vehicles which had been set alight.\n\n\"What I saw last night was absolutely appalling ... It was devastating and it's kind of taken away from actually what's gone on, which is the tragedy of those deaths,\" local resident David Burgess told Sky News.\n\n\"This is about the girls and the tragedy which has happened - don't make it about this,\" he said, referring to the clashes. \"This isn't Southport. This isn't the community.\"\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer and senior ministers blamed \"violent thugs from out town\", for the trouble.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law,\" Starmer said.\n\nMeanwhile, Taylor Swift's fans have so far raised more than 270,000 pounds ($346,000) to help families of the victims and for the hospital where some of the children were being treated.\n\n($1 = 0.7795 pounds) (Reporting by Sachin Ravikumar; writing by Michael Holden; Editing by Bernadette Baum)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", {"uri": "8252573099", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:47:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:47:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:46:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/update-issued-condition-leanne-lucas-29650605", "title": "Update issued on condition of Leanne Lucas and other Southport stabbings victims", "body": "Police have issued an update on the conditions of the victims of the Southport stabbing which tragically claimed the lives of three children.\n\nMerseyside Police confirmed the conditions of eight of the children and the two adults injured in the Hart Street attack on Monday July 29, remain the same. It is understood six of the eight children were in a critical condition and the two adults, including Leanne Lucas, were also severely injured. There has been no suggestion the condition of any of those injured has worsened, the Liverpool Echo reports.\n\nLeanne and another teacher bravely tried to save the children during the knife attack at the Taylor Swift dance event at The Hart Space. A local yoga page previously posted on Facebook posted a picture of children's yoga teacher Leanne, with the caption reading: \"I'm absolutely devastated. Please please pray for Leanne. Leanne came on my training course in December. A beautiful young creative girl who was so passionate about helping children.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Police issue update on 17-year-old arrested over Southport stabbings\n\nBebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Aguiar, aged nine were named as the children in the attack. In a tribute, Bebe King's family shared the following tribute: \"No words can describe the devastation that has hit our family as try to deal with the loss of our little girl Bebe.\"\n\nThe family of Alice Dasilva Aguiar paid this tribute: \"Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our Princess, like we said before to you, you're always our princess and no one would change that. Love from Your Hero Daddy and Mummy.\"\n\nTheir families, who are being supported by specialist officers, and have asked that their privacy is respected at this time. A 17-year-old boy, from Banks, Lancashire, and originally from Cardiff, was apprehended and continues to be questioned by police. Officers said he is being held on suspicion of murder and attempted murder.\n\nWith Southport continuing to try to come to terms with this appalling tragedy, hundreds of people made their way to a vigil in the town centre yesterday evening, which was respectfully observed. However, nearby, trouble was brewing. Police raced to a disturbance taking place during a protest outside a mosque on St Luke's Road in the town.\n\nIn what has been described as 'sickening' scenes, dozens of police officers were injured and a major incident declared. Bricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire. Eight police officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries. One was knocked unconscious.\n\nThe violence started when a large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road on Tuesday evening. Cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire and bricks were thrown at a local mosque. Damage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set on fire, police said. Three police dogs have also been injured. Photos and videos shared online show large groups hurling rocks at police officers, climbing on police vans and attempting to smash the vehicles' windows.\n\nThe violence has been widely condemned - including by the Prime Minister and Home Secretary - but there will be no more powerful voice in this than of the mother of one of the three little girls so tragically killed in Southport on Monday. In a message widely shared on social media, Jenni Stancombe said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nSpeaking about the police, Ms Stancombe added: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"", "source": {"uri": "manchestereveningnews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title":
