Bricks from destroyed garden walls were thrown at the mosque and police. Cars, bins and police vehicles were set alight.\n\nMerseyside Police said 39 of its officers were injured. A 17 year-old boy who lives in Lancashire has been arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder. The motive for the attack is still under investigation, but the police have been clear the suspect was born in the United Kingdom.\n\nThe prime minister, Keir Starmer, said those who had \"hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery\" would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nMerseyside Police have named the three victims as six year-old Bebe King; seven year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and nine year-old Alice Aguiar. {"uri": "8252397782", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:59:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:59:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:58:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/dozens-of-uk-police-hurt-in-clashes-after-three-girls-killed-in-stabbing-attack/article_bd52000b-8a07-535b-a479-12d5c2f54830.html", "title": "Dozens of UK police hurt in clashes after three girls killed in stabbing attack", "body": "By Temilade Adelaja\n\nSOUTHPORT, England (Reuters) - Dozens of British police officers suffered injuries in violent clashes in an English seaside town late on Tuesday after three young girls were killed a day earlier in a violent stabbing attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance event.\n\nPolice vans were set on fire in Southport and protesters hurled bricks at both officers and at cars parked at a mosque, following speculation and unverified posts on social media that the suspect behind the attack was a Muslim and a migrant.\n\nAs well as killing three girls aged six to nine, Monday's horrific incident in the normally quiet town in northwest England saw eight other children stabbed. Five remain in a critical condition in hospital along with two adults who tried to protect them.\n\nPolice, who have arrested an unnamed 17-year-old male on suspicion of murder and attempted murder, have said the incident was not terrorism-related and sought to quash speculation on the suspect's origins, saying he was born in Britain.\n\nThat did not prevent protesters, from what Merseyside police believed were tied to the right-wing anti-Islam group, the English Defence League, from targeting a mosque in the town and attacking police who tried to stop them.\n\nPoliticians and police said most of those taking part in the violence were not from the area, and said the clashes detracted from a large vigil attended by thousands to pay tribute to the young victims.\n\n'THUGS FROM OUT OF TOWN'\n\nA total of 39 officers were treated for injuries, including 27 who were taken to hospital, North West Ambulance Service said on Wednesday. Police said eight had suffered serious injuries including fractures, and three police dogs were also hurt.\n\n\"Offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said in a statement.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, streets in Southport were littered with bricks from broken walls, smashed bottles, and large garbage bins - which had been hurled at police the night before - and their contents. Charred tarmac bore witness to the police vehicles which had been set alight.\n\n\"What I saw last night was absolutely appalling ... It was devastating and it's kind of taken away from actually what's gone on, which is the tragedy of those deaths,\" local resident David Burgess told Sky News.\n\n\"This is about the girls and the tragedy which has happened - don't make it about this,\" he said, referring to the clashes. \"This isn't Southport. This isn't the community.\"\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer and senior ministers blamed \"violent thugs from out town\", for the trouble.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law,\" Starmer said.\n\nMeanwhile, Taylor Swift's fans have so far raised more than 270,000 pounds ($346,000) to help families of the victims and for the hospital where some of the children were being treated.\n\n($1 = 0.7795 pounds)\n\n(Reporting by Sachin Ravikumar; writing by Michael Holden; Editing by Bernadette Baum)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE {"uri": "8251757449", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "04:56:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T04:56:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T04:55:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/uk-news/southport-riot-39-police-officers-29646557", "title": "Southport riot sees 39 police officers injured in rampage while town mourns", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nTuesday night's riot in Southport left 39 police officers and three dogs injured by members of the far right, who attacked a mosque and hurled bricks at police - just a day after the horrific knife attack at a dance class, which tragically resulted in the loss of three young lives.\n\nAlleged English Defence League members targeted the mosque under the mistaken belief that the 17-year-old attacker was Muslim. Officials later debunked this claim, stating there was no association between the murder suspect and Islam.\n\nThe violent incident unfolded on Tuesday evening (July 30), with vehicles set ablaze, multiple police officers injured, and the local area left in disarray. By 10.30pm, crowds began to disperse, revealing the aftermath of their hours-long battle with police, as bricks littered the roads around the scene where the riot broke out), reports the Mirror.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool Mayor fears 'further trauma' as 'thugs' set fires and attack police officers\n\nThe smouldering remains of the protesters' arson attacks left a police van and several residents' cars destroyed, with smoke still visible in the air as night descended over the area. Meanwhile, three local families are mourning their children who were killed in the attack.\n\nEight other children were injured during the attack, which occurred on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in Southport. The three victims tragically killed were identified on Tuesday as Bebe King (6), Elsie Dot Stancombe (7), and Alice Dasilva Aguiar (9).\n\nViolence erupted after misinformation circulated online following the attack, which was subsequently debunked. Reports confirm that 39 police officers suffered in the clash, with one left unconscious and others sustaining fractures and gashes during the extensive confrontation.\n\nA significant number of those injured were reportedly dealing with concussion, facial trauma, and broken bones. Following the EDL-incited chaos, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper condemned the group as \"thugs\".\n\nWhile thousands in Southport solemnly honoured the three lives lost in the attack and supported the grieving community, clusters of presumed EDL troublemakers converged on a local mosque, pelting it with bricks and igniting fires. In response, authorities have now enacted robust measures to curb further unrest.\n\nMerseyside Police will be enforcing a Section 60 and Section 34 Order until 8pm tomorrow, granting them enhanced authority to scatter gatherings and confiscate potentially disruptive items and vehicles. The police have clarified, though, that this does not affect individuals attending for legitimate activities or their everyday routines.\n\nThe force also confirmed that rioters had wounded three police dogs, with two pelted by bricks and another sustaining burns to its hind legs.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss expressed his pride in the Merseyside Police's response to severe violence in Southport, stating: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\"\n\nHe also extended gratitude to neighbouring forces for their assistance: \"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\"\n\nHe detailed the damage caused by offenders, including attacks on police with bricks and setting public vehicles on fire: \"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\"\n\nGoss condemned the actions against the community and appealed for information: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nHe urged anyone with information or footage to come forward: \"We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible.\"\n\nHe provided contact details for tips: \"Anyone with information can DM @MerPolCC or contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.\"\n\nThe North West Ambulance Service (NWAS) confirmed the significant number of police injuries, which led them to declare a Major Incident late on Tuesday night. The declaration was due to the extensive resources required at the scene, including 10 ambulances and several on-call doctors.\n\nNWAS reported on the treatment of injured officers: \"We have treated 22 police officers and so far, 11 of those have been taken to hospital.\"\n\nThe North West Ambulance Service (NWAS) had to declare a significant incident last night around 23:00 due to the sheer amount of resources demanded at the scene as the unrest continued. The injured count has since risen to 39, with nearly two dozen officers needing hospital care.\n\nLocal community leaders have voiced concerns over the ongoing disorder's effect on residents who were already coping with previous traumas.\n\nMayor Steve Rotheram of Liverpool weighed in with a powerful statement shared on social media platform X, outlining the emotional toll on the community: \"There are families just coming to terms with yesterday's events, parents grieving for their murdered children and survivors still trying to process what they witnessed.\"\n\nHe further lamented, \"The violent scenes in Southport tonight will only further traumatise a community that is already struggling to come to terms with this attack.\"\n\nOn Tuesday evening, Sir Keir Starmer, the Prime Minister, commented on the situation, promising justice for those affected. He stated, \"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect.\"\n\nStarmer criticised the violence that overshadowed a mourning community: \"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. {"uri": "8251785594", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "05:21:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T05:21:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T05:20:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.nottinghampost.com/news/uk-world-news/southport-riots-39-police-officers-9448528", "title": "Almost 40 police officers injured as thugs throw bricks and set cars on fire", "body": "Nearly 40 police officers were injured in violent clashes in Southport, according to the North West Ambulance Service. The service reported that 27 of the officers needed hospital treatment after the disorder.\n\nIn a statement, a spokesperson said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\" Merseyside Police disclosed that eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion, while other officers sustained head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was rendered unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs also sustained injuries amidst the turmoil; Zoe and Ike both suffered leg injuries from bricks hurled at them. Adding to this, a third dog named Quga, who had been bitten, strangled, and kicked by an offender earlier in the month, experienced burns to her back leg, as confirmed by the force.\n\nRead more: Locked up in July in Nottingham - A month dominated by killings Read more: Pub could lose licence after landlady punched police officer\n\nMerseyside Police have implicated supporters of the English Defence League in the unrest that saw public cars set ablaze, local mosque bricked, damage inflicted on a local convenience store, and wheelie bins torched. Enhanced police presence continues in the affected area to provide reassurance, with a 24-hour Section 60 Order from 7.54pm on Tuesday granting officers broader stop and search powers aimed at curtailing serious violence.\n\nA Section 34 Order has been put into effect, allowing police to direct those exhibiting antisocial behaviour away from the area. Authorities have assured that these measures are not for those simply visiting or conducting daily activities.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, stated: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\"\n\nHe praised the immediate response of off-duty officers, as well as the cooperation from neighbouring forces: \"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\"\n\nRegrettably, the events took a violent turn, with individuals toppling garden walls to use bricks against officers, torching public vehicles, and damaging cars at a mosque, said ACC Goss. He expressed his concern over the community's well-being, especially after recent events: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police is reaching out for assistance from the public to obtain further information or video footage related to the disorder. The unrest coincided with a stabbing frenzy that occurred in Southport on Monday during a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nThe harrowing incident took place at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club, resulting in the tragic deaths of Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine; Bebe King, six; and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, who were fatally stabbed.\n\nA further eight children were injured in the knife attack, leaving five youngsters and two adults fighting for their lives in critical condition.\n\nFollowing the dreadful assault at the dance studio on Hart Street, a 17 year old boy has been detained. The teenager, whose identity is protected due to legal reasons, faces charges of murder and attempted murder.\n\nIn an escalation following the horrific event, the Muslim Council of Britain (MCB) has reported that an unfounded online rumour sparked Islamophobic backlash. This was inflamed by erroneous reporting from a Russian news source that incorrectly linked the tragedy with the Muslim community.\n\nOffering condolences to the families of the three young victims {"uri": "8252745310", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:42:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:42:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:38:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/peaceful-vigil-tragic-loss-three-153659221.html", "title": "How peaceful vigil for tragic loss of three young lives descended into violent riots in Southport", "body": "Southport should have been a town in mourning after the tragic loss of three young lives in horrific circumstances - instead, a peaceful vigil on Tuesday later descended into chaos as violent riots broke out on the streets.\n\nHours before the moving remembrance service, Merseyside Police confirmed that a third girl had been killed in the \"ferocious\" knife attack at the Taylor Swift-themed dance class on Hart Street. Shortly after, the force named the victims as Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, who were pronounced dead shortly after Monday's rampage, while Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, died from her injuries in hospital on Tuesday.\n\nAs five more children continued to fight for their lives following the tragedy, along with two dance class teachers who bravely tried to defend their pupils, the tight-knit community of Southport gathered in the town centre at 6pm to grieve together. Hundreds of people held each other and wiped away tears as Martin Abrahams, the spiritual leader at Southport Hospital, said the crowds \"show we want to stand together\".\n\nBut despite the mournful air, tensions that had been building throughout the day was palpable. Mr Abrahams was interrupted twice - once by a man shouting \"we stick together\", and then by panicked calls for paramedics from the centre of the crowd, which temporarily paused the event. It later emerged that a man was arrested with a flick knife just yards away from the vigil.\n\nThere were growing fears over how many were going to turn up to a far-right protest planned to take place outside a mosque on St Luke's Road that evening, an event police were understood to be monitoring.\n\nEarlier that day, Sir Keir Starmer had been hurriedly whisked away after being heckled as he placed a floral tribute at the Hart Street scene. His visit to the police cordon lasted barely two minutes as some watching members of the public shouted, \"How many more children? Our kids are dead and you're leaving already?\" and \"get the truth out!\"\n\nChief Constable Serena Kennedy, who attended with the prime minister, was asked why the alleged attacker had not been named and if he was on a \"watch list\".\n\nDetectives continued to question a 17-year-old suspect from Wales but Merseyside Police was forced to put out a statement urging people not to speculate after false claims the boy was an asylum-seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat spread online.\n\nWithin an hour of the vigil ending, crowds of men began gathering outside The Blue Anchor pub, some holding beers and wearing masks, in front of the hundreds of floral tributes that continued to pile up outside the police cordon at the top of Hart Street.\n\nWord came from St Luke's Road before the demonstration's official kick-off time at 8pm that the area near the mosque was already packed with angry protesters responding to the rallying cry of elements of the far-right on social media.\n\nThe air was charged with rage and anticipation as dusk began to descend on what had already been a highly emotional day.\n\nHundreds of men were already stationed directly outside the mosque and in the surrounding streets, while a number of police officers and riot vans were standing guard, amid chants of \"No surrender!\" and \"English till I die!\" from sections of the crowd.\n\nWith tensions already running high, events escalated rapidly into a riot, with violence breaking out and demonstrators clashing with police. Dozens of officers ended up suffering injuries in the disorder, leading North West Ambulance Service to declare a major incident.\n\nStones and bottles were launched at officers in helmets and riot gear, as police riot vans were attacked. Debris was scattered on the ground around the vans while police used their shields to deflect missiles thrown from the crowds.\n\nA crowd of men, many wearing masks and hoodies, were in a running battle with officers outside the mosque as more police arrived. Officers walked through crowds with police dogs as others with shields and batons were in a stand-off with protesters.\n\nFirecrackers and flares went off as multiple police sirens sounded, and a police helicopter hovered over the area. Shocked local residents were out on the streets, while roads were jammed with traffic, and numerous police cars and vans, blue lights flashing, were patrolling local streets.\n\nRiot police then charged the crowds outside the mosque as a police van was set on fire, sending black smoke into the air.\n\nThe force issued an update at around 9pm, disclosing that an officer had suffered a suspected broken nose in the disturbance and multiple police vehicles had been damaged and set alight - with the protesters believed to be supporters of the English Defence League (EDL).\n\nThe disorder continued into the night, with wheelie bins set alight and engulfed in flames in the streets, and shops, restaurants and hotels under lockdown amid the chaos. The sounds of sirens and the circulating police helicopter echoed around Southport well after midnight as I walked through the seaside town's deserted streets.\n\nThe prime minister was among those who took to social media to condemn the violence, writing on X just before midnight that the rioters had hijacked a vigil for victims and vowed they would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nAfter the chaos, the message from the people of Southport was clear; the town is mourning multiple tragedies and does not want the kind of trouble the rioters brought with them.\n\nHelping with the clean-up operation on Wednesday, Norman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland said: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done. It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire. But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here cleaning the mess up.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8252594229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:01:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:01:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:00:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/breaking-southport-stabbing-three-people-33364051", "title": "Three people arrested after hundreds join far right riot at Southport mosque", "body": "Three people have been arrested after more than 50 police officers were injured in a night of rioting after the murders of three children in Southport.\n\nFrontline cops were hit with bricks and bottles and cars were set alight, including a police van, as people swarmed outside a local mosque after false rumours spread online about the murder suspect. Violence broke out after the deaths of Bebe King, six, Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, in a knife attack at a summer holiday Taylor Swift dance workshop.\n\nThree police dogs were injured and eight Merseyside Police officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries, serious facial injuries and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nFollow along with our live blog for all the latest news on Southport\n\nPolice dogs Zoe and Ike have sustained leg injuries from bricks thrown at them. A third dog, PD Quga, who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month, has tonight suffered burns to her back leg. Merseyside Police said in a statement: \"As a result of the disorder, a 24-hour Section 60 Order has been introduced in the area (see attached), running from 19.54pm today and extra officers will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\n\"The Order, under S60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994, gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals in the area and is designed to minimise serious violence. A Section 34 Order has also been introduced under the Anti-Social Behaviour & Policing Act 2014, giving officers powers to direct people who are engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents. These powers will not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\n\"Under the legislation, officers have the power to seize any item, including vehicles, used in the commission of anti-social behaviour. Should a person who has previously been directed to leave the area return, an offence would be committed, which they may ultimately be arrested for.\"\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said three people were arrested on Tuesday night. She said: \"Our priority was to try and keep the communities of Southport safe and also to make sure officers remained safe. Three arrests were made, however more will follow. It's impossible to say [how many will be arrested]. It's really early days in the investigation.\"\n\nShe added: \"Initially, there were about 70 people who made their way away from the vigil and were making their way towards the mosque. They suddenly became about 200 in number and then others joined that number.\"\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack. I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park. This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\n\n\"We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible. Protesters gathered outside a local mosque in what Chairman of Merseyside Police Federation Chris McGlade said was a \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nThree victims killed in the knife attack have been named by police as nine-year-old Alice Aguiar from Portugal, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, aged seven. Six children were left in a critical condition following the attack with two adults also fighting for their lives.\n\nRioters threw stones, bottles and bricks at police while members of the crowd were heard shouting \"no more boats\" before a police van was set on fire. Around a third of those injured experienced concussion, facial injuries and broken bones. In the wake of the EDL violence, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper branded the crowd as \"thugs\".\n\nAnd in a powerful image captured by Mirror reporter Lucy Thornton, a brave female police officer is seen with blood dripping down her face as bricks are launched overhead and rioters set fire to shops and vehicles. Police officers armed with riot shields and helmets stood across the road as fires burned and debris was thrown.\n\nThe North West Ambulance service said 27 officers were taken to hospital. A statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\" Merseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\"\n\nA police van was set on fire and thick black smoke was seen rising from the vehicle while people were seen mounting the roof of another. Others were seen kicking down walls and throwing loose stones at officers in the unrest.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer was among those who criticised the mob, saying in a statement posted online that the perpetrators would \"feel the full force of the law\". He wrote: \"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nUntil 8pm tonight, Merseyside Police have a Section 60 and Section 34 Order in place, giving them greater power to disperse crowds, as well as seize items and vehicles being used in anti social behaviour. The force has emphasised that these powers will not be used for anyone visiting the area or going about their daily business.\n\nThe riots come after Merseyside Police arrested a 17-year-old boy, who lives in Lancashire but was born in Cardiff, in connection with the attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance party on Monday. The incident took place at a community centre known as The Hart Space, on Hart Street, Southport, where a class was taking place for children aged six to eleven during the school holidays.\n\nMeanwhile, tributes were paid on social media to the bravery of dance and yoga teacher Leanne Lucas after she was attacked in the incident. Ms Lucas was named as an organiser of the event run by Southport-based business Enlighten in a post on Facebook.\n\nThe fully booked club for children, which was advertised as a dance and yoga workshop as well as bracelet-making, quickly became something \"like a horror movie\", witnesses to the stabbings have said. US singer Taylor Swift said she was in \"completely in shock\" after the \"horror\" of the knife attack.\n\nFloral tributes were laid at Sussex Road at the junction in Maple Street, in memory of murdered children on Tuesday night during a vigil. Racism not welcome here.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Riot police subjected to relentless and 'sickening' attack with vans set alight in night of chaos in Southport\n\nProtests were sparked after rumours circulated online about the racial heritage of the 17-year-old boy who has been arrested over the attack. Merseyside Police have since warned against speculation, saying a name that has been cited is 'incorrect'.\n\nNearly 40 police officers were injured during the riots. Police have since said they believe supporters of the English Defence League (EDL) - a far-right organisation known for its Islamophobia - were behind the violence. Sir Keir Starmer last night said the rioters would 'feel the full force of the law'.\n\nHe said the 'hijacked' the vigil that was held between leaders and members of the local community to remember the lives of Bebe King, six, Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, who all died in the horror attack at the Taylor Swift-themed dance party.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said officers 'should not have to face' the 'sickening' attack, fuelled in part by 'speculation' around the suspect arrested over the stabbings.\n\nHe said of the incident: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavor to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets. We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n\"Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behavior.\"\n\nLocal MP Mr Patrick Hurley publicly condemned the attack and echoed the sentiments of the powerful sign seen held by a protester as he added: \"Nowhere was this more evident than the solidarity, remembrance and sympathy heard at today's vigil.\n\n\"To those who laid flowers, candles, toys, thank you. including shattering windows - after police issued a warning over an 'incorrect' name for the alleged attacker being widely circulated online.\n\nA 17-year-old boy, originally from Cardiff but from the nearby Lancashire village of Banks, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nThe violence appears to have been fuelled by false claims online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nMerseyside Police said: 'We would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.'\n\nLocal mosque groups condemned the violence aimed towards Muslims, adding: 'We must not let those who seek to divide us and spread hatred use this as an opportunity.'\n\nRiot police hold back protesters near a burning police vehicle after disorder broke out in Southport\n\nA police van was set on fire near a mosque in Southport on Tuesday evening as riots broke out\n\nA traffic cone is hurled by a masked man at a police officer near to a mosque in Southport\n\nA burnt out police van near a mosque in Southport as shocking riots broke out on Tuesday\n\nMerseyside Police confirmed that 22 officers were injured following the violent disorder.\n\nThey said that eight suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nRead MoreBREAKING NEWS Pictured: Three girls aged six, nine, and seven stabbed to death by knifeman\n\nThe force said that other police officers suffered head injuries, serious facial injures and one was even knocked unconscious.\n\nProtesters also set cars and wheelie bins belonging to members of the public alight, threw bricks at the local Mosque and damaged a local convenience store.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured. Police Dogs Zoe and Ike have sustained leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, PD Quga, who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month, suffered burns to her back leg.\n\nPolice have introduced a 24-hour Section 60 Order in the area and extra officers will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nThe three girls stabbed to death at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class were yesterday named by police as nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and six-year-old Bebe King (L-R)\n\nThree girls were killed in a bloody rampage on Hart Street on Monday. On Tuesday, a vigil was held for the victims on Lord Street. While it was going on, a man with a flick knife was arrested on Eastbank Street. On St Luke's Road, riots erupted outside a mosque - also on Tuesday\n\nThe Order, under S60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994, gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals in the area and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: 'Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\nRead MoreBREAKING NEWS Thousands of mourners gather at vigil for three girls killed in Southport knife rampage\n\n'I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n'Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\n\n'This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\n\n'We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible.\n\n'Anyone with information can DM @MerPolCC or contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.'\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters in Southport had 'hijacked' a vigil for victims and would 'feel the full force of the law'.\n\nWriting on X, formerly Twitter, Sir Keir said: 'The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n'They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper described the rioting outside a mosque in Southport as 'violent attacks from thugs on the streets', which she branded 'appalling'.\n\nMs Cooper told broadcasters that she saw a community 'coming together' during her visit to Southport on Tuesday, and thanked police for their 'heroism'.\n\nMs Cooper added: 'That is why it is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\n\n'It is a total disgrace. A major incident was declared by emergency services on St Lukes's Road, Southport on Tuesday, July 30.\n\nBricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire. A spokesperson for the ambulance service said they treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. Twenty-seven were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\n\nNWAS stood down from major incident at 1.25am on Wednesday, July 31, but at 1.40am said a small number of resources will remain at the scene on St Luke's Road to \"continue to support police colleagues\".\n\nA spokesperson added: \"We'd like to thank the many NWAS staff and other emergency service colleagues who have worked extremely hard over the last few hours in response to the disturbance.\"\n\nMerseyside Police said several officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries. One was knocked unconscious.\n\nA large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road on Tuesday evening. Cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire and bricks were thrown at a local mosque.\n\nDamage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set on fire, police said. Three police dogs have also been injured. Police Dogs Zoe and Ike have sustained leg injuries from bricks thrown at them. A third dog, PD Quga, also suffered burns to her back leg.\n\nPhotos and video seen by the ECHO showed crowds gathered around police riot vans on St Luke's Road. A police van was also seen up in flames. Merseyside Police said as a result of the disorder, a 24-hour Section 60 Order has been introduced in the area, running from 19.54pm on (Tuesday). Extra officers will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities. The order, under Section 60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994, gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals in the area and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack. I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday. lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order has been introduced in the above areas, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals in the area and is designed to minimise serious violence (Merseyside Police/PA)\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced, giving police the power to direct people engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents.\n\nMerseyside police said these powers would not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing {"uri": "8252515772", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:12:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:12:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:10:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/southports-true-spirit-brave-cops-33366351", "title": "Southport's strong heart - brave cops hurt, locals clean up and message of hope", "body": "The horrific brutality in Southport has been met with widespread condemnation from locals, who have praised their incredible police force and tight-knit community\n\nThe 'true spirit of Southport' shines brightly through the darkness that has fallen across the town.\n\nDisturbing violence rocked the area again on Tuesday when hundreds of rioters took to the streets, burning vehicles and hurling deadly missiles at police officers working to protect local residents. It came after misinformation was spread online about the identity of the suspect arrested over the frenzied stabbing at a children's dance class that killed three young girls.\n\nDozens of brave officers were injured, including police dogs, as a major incident was declared for the second time this week. Merseyside Police said the thugs involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - disgracefully set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nThe rioting followed the tragic deaths of Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, at the Taylor Swift-themed holiday club on Monday. Eight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition. A 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, remains in custody.\n\nPowerful message of peace\n\nOne woman was pictured standing up to a mob of jeering rioters with a powerful message of peace. In a clip that has gone viral on social media, the woman held a sign that read: \"One race - human, hope not hate, racism not welcome here\", as objects were being thrown. Her actions have been praised as \"brave\" and \"courageous\" online.\n\n\"What an incredibly brave woman. On nights like this, she's just given me a little bit of hope back in humanity,\" one Twitter user wrote. Another said: \"Applaud her trying to unite a community while literally staring hate in the face. She represents the people of Southport, not the thugs attacking religious buildings and emergency services!\"\n\nThe Mirror's own reporter Lucy Thornton, who witnessed the riot, described the woman as a beacon of light in the madness and said: \"Amid all this terror, I saw one defiant shining light, an incredibly brave woman, shaking like a leaf with youths screaming in her face but strong enough to hold up a poster saying 'Hope not Hate' while bricks fell around her.\"\n\nComing together to clean-up\n\nAfter calm was finally restored, the extent of the chaos could be seen today with rubbish, burnt-out vehicles and smashed windows scattered across the streets. But locals have been quick to get involved in the clean-up. One local said: \"At least the bin men don't have to empty the bins today - they've all been burnt.\"\n\nA local businessman, Andy Southwood, 54, said: \"I didn't sleep much last night. In half an hour it exploded. It was chaotic. Mainly young kids with masks. It looked organised to me. It's crazy. It's a massive stain on the town.\" But he pointed out: \"Random people are coming out with shovels and spades to help clean up. That's the true spirit of Southport.\"\n\nBrave off-duty police\n\nOff-duty police officers in Merseyside stepped up last night to courageously support their colleagues, despite many of them finishing full shifts. In a proud statement, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support. Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park. This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nNearly 40 officers sustained injuries at the scene of violent disorder, North West Ambulance Service confirmed, after they were forced to declare a 'major incident' on Tuesday night. A statement on X said: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\" Merseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries, including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nMerseyside Police is appealing to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in the rioting to come forward. Hope not hate. Racism not welcome here.\"\n\nMerseyside Police report that 22 officers were injured following the violent scenes in the town, with eight sustaining serious injuries \"including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion\".\n\nOther officers suffered head and facial injuries, one was knocked unconscious, and three police dogs were injured.\n\nCars and wheelie bins were set alight, bricks were thrown at the local mosque and a convenience store was damaged.\n\nThe rioting has been met with widespread condemnation from senior politicians, with Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer saying those who \"hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery\" have \"insulted the community as it grieves\".\n\nYvette Cooper, the home secretary, added: \"These disgraceful scenes of violence and disorder we are witnessing this evening, with attacks on the Merseyside Police and a local mosque, are completely appalling. Those responsible will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"It is appalling that the local police, who have already dealt with extraordinarily difficult circumstances this week, and are undertaking an urgent criminal investigation, should be on the receiving end of violence and abuse.\"\n\nJenni Stancombe, the mother of one of the girls killed in the attack - Elsie Dot Stancombe - also called for the violence to stop, with the Liverpool Echo reporting she said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight. {"uri": "8252622574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:20:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:20:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:18:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13693737/Home-Secretary-English-Defence-League-riots-Southport-knife-attack-dance-class.html", "title": "Home Secretary 'will be looking at banning' EDL after Southport riots", "body": "Ministers will consider banning the English Defence League following riots on the streets of Southport, Angela Rayner suggested today.\n\nThe deputy PM said the government 'will look at various different groups' amid widespread condemnation of violence that broke out after the horrific knife attack on children at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class.\n\nAngry politicians have blamed 'lies and propaganda' on social media for igniting the chaos, while heartbroken Southport families have accused hoodlums of showing 'no respect to a town that is grieving'.\n\nTributes have poured in for the three girls killed who police yesterday named as six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds at the summer holiday dance workshop. Five are in a critical condition, alongside two women who were also critically injured as they bravely tried to save the children.\n\nBut the rioting erupted barely an hour after thousands of mourners had gathered for a vigil to remember the victims.\n\nAsked during an interview on LBC whether the EDL's activities would be curbed, Ms Rayner said: 'We have laws and we have proscribed groups and we do look at that and it is reviewed regularly.\n\n'So I'm sure that that will be something that the Home Secretary will be looking at as part of the normal course of what we do and the intelligence that we have.'\n\nRiot police hold back protesters near a burning police vehicle after disorder broke out in Southport\n\nDeputy PM Angela Rayner said the government 'will look at various different groups' amid widespread condemnation of violence that broke out after the horrific knife attack on children at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class\n\nSouthport burns: A street near a mosque goes up in flames as violent thugs took to the streets last night\n\nThree girls were killed in a bloody rampage on Hart Street on Monday. On Tuesday, a vigil was held for the victims on Lord Street. While it was going on, a man with a flick knife was arrested on Eastbank Street. On St Luke's Road, riots erupted outside a mosque - also on Tuesday\n\nThe PM insisted that those who rioted in Southport last night will 'feel the full force of the law'\n\nKeir Starmer lays a floral tribute to the knife rampage victims in Southport yesterday\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper and local MP Patrick Hurley inspect tributes in Southport\n\nMs Rayner added: 'The inciting of violence and violence on the street has absolutely no place in our democracy, and we have to crack down on those that perpetuate violence and spread it within our communities.'\n\nHowever, she said 'the bigger issue is about taking on the minority of people that have got thuggish behaviour, that actually that's not our British values'.\n\nMerseyside's Police and Crime Commissioner Emily Spurrell said there is a 'strong feeling' that members of the EDL used the Southport stabbing to 'whip up hatred'.\n\nMs Spurrell told ITV's Good Morning Britain that the 'violence and abuse' towards police officers on Tuesday was 'utterly abhorrent and completely unacceptable'.\n\nShe said: '(Merseyside Police) will be reviewing the footage of exactly who was there last night, they have been monitoring the online activity as well, trying to understand who was doing what.\n\n'They have said that they believe it was members of the English Defence League (EDL), they don't believe it was individuals from the local area.\n\n'There is a strong feeling that there are individuals like the EDL, who have been using this incredibly tragic event to whip up hatred, incite violence, and that's the result of what we saw last night.'\n\nScotland's former first minister Humza Yousaf has called for the EDL to be banned under terror laws in the wake of the unrest, despite former leader Tommy Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nKeir Starmer has insisted those responsible for the rioting should face the 'full force of the law' after a police van was torched and several officers injured.\n\nOn St Luke's Street near the vigil, rioters chanting 'English till I die' surrounded the Southport Mosque and Islamic Cultural Centre and began hurling rubble at police officers who had formed a protective line around the building.\n\nThe violence appears to have been fuelled by false claims online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe 17-year-old boy, who remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder, is originally from Cardiff but now lives in the nearby Lancashire village of Banks.\n\nMerseyside Police said 22 of its officers were injured after clashes broke out in the seaside town.\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir said: 'The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n'They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said 'scenes of thuggery' on the streets of Southport 'bear no relation' to the community which had been coming together.\n\nShe told broadcasters: 'I think everyone should be showing some respect for the community that is grieving and also for the police who are pursuing an urgent criminal investigation now, and who showed such heroism and bravery yesterday in the face of these horrific attacks.\n\n'I think everyone needs to support the police in that work, and frankly the scenes of thuggery that we have seen on the streets of Southport this evening bear no relation to the way in which the Southport community has been coming together to support each other and to support grieving families.\n\n'We need to see some respect for the grieving community and for the police in their urgent work.'\n\nPatrick Hurley, Southport's Labour MP, said this morning that the riots occurred because of the 'propaganda and lies' spread on social media about the identity of the attacker.\n\nHe told Times Radio: 'Because of the propaganda and the lies that were being spread around on social media from within minutes of the news breaking on Monday afternoon about the tragic incident.\n\n'We'd had all sorts of lies being spread and misinformation being spread about the alleged perpetrator and some people with the best of intentions then they tried to rebut this, they tried to argue back, but all that happens is you're just amplifying people's false messaging.'\n\nHe added: 'This misinformation doesn't just exist on people's internet browsers and on people's phones. It has real world impact.\n\n'And what happened is that the real world impact of that was that we then had hundreds of people descending on the town, descending on Southport from outside of the area, intent on causing trouble, either because they believe what they've written, or because they are bad faith actors who wrote it in the first place, in the hope of causing community division.'\n\nMr Hurley told BBC Radio 4's Today programme the rioters were 'not from Southport' and must face the 'full force of the law'.\n\n'Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all,' he said.\n\n'Not least these beered-up thugs who have descended on the town last night intent on causing trouble.\n\n'We all have to stand against that and Southport will not accept this.\n\n'Southport will unite against this sort of thing.'\n\nA police van was set on fire near a mosque in Southport on Tuesday evening as riots broke out\n\nAround 200 protesters were seen taking to the streets. Police believe many were EDL supporters\n\nA burnt out police van near a mosque in Southport as shocking riots broke out on Tuesday\n\nRiot police vans were damaged amid the chaos near the Southport Mosque\n\nThe riots came barely an hour after thousands of mourners gathered for a vigil at the Atkinson in Southport\n\nIn stark contrast to the riots on the streets, there was a sense of tranquility at the site of the vigil as night fell\n\nMerseyside Police has issued a warning over an 'incorrect' name being widely circulated online, adding: 'We would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.'\n\nThe angry mob - who police 'believed to be supporters of the English Defence League' - started targeting the Muslim place of worship at around 7.45pm.\n\nEight police officers suffered serious injuries, including one who was knocked unconscious. Protesters also torched cars and wheelie bins belonging to members of the public, shattered the mosque windows with bricks and looted shops.\n\nOne Southport resident living near the mosque told how he, his partner and their young daughter fled for the evening, not wanting her to see the sickening violence.\n\nThe man said: 'We just couldn't stay while this was going on and allow our daughter to witness it.\n\n'This doesn't represent Southport - they're EDL thugs who are from Manchester and Liverpool who have just come here to cause trouble. They have no respect for a town that's grieving.'\n\nPolice have introduced a 24-hour Section 60 Order in the area where the riots took place and extra officers will remain in the area.", "source":
