{"uri": "8251979941", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:45:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:45:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:44:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/mother-of-little-girl-seven-stabbed-to-death-in-southport-calls-for-end-to-violence-as-community-rallies-to-clear-up-trail-of-devastation-left-by-rioters-after-knifeman-killed-three-at-dance-class/", "title": "Mother of little girl, seven, stabbed to death in Southport calls for end to violence as community rallies to clear up trail of devastation left by rioters after knifeman killed three at dance class", "body": "The mother of a little girl, seven, murdered in the Southport knife rampage has called for the violence to end after a night of rioting left 39 police officers injured.\n\nElsie Dot Stancombe was killed alongside six-year-old Bebe King and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar in a horrific knife rampage on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed summer holiday dance workshop.\n\nAnd following a peaceful vigil last night where thousands of mourners had gathered for a vigil to remember the victims who lost their lives, violent thugs were accused of showing 'no respect to a town that's grieving'.\n\nCrowds of yobs - many of whom are thought to have come from outside Southport - torched a police van and left 39 officers and three dogs injured, including 27 who needed treatment in hospital.\n\nBut as the community rallied together against the violence, Jenni Stancombe, the mother of little Elsie, pleaded for the violence to end on social media.\n\nShe said: 'This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n'The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.'\n\nElsie Dot Stancombe, 7, was one of the victims of a knife attack during a dance event in Southport,\n\nShe was killed alongside six-year-old Bebe King (left) and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar (right)\n\nSouthport burns: A street near a mosque goes up in flames as violent thugs took to the streets last night\n\nRiot police hold back protesters near a burning police vehicle after disorder broke out in Southport\n\nA police van was set on fire near a mosque in Southport on Tuesday evening as riots broke out\n\nAround 200 protesters were seen taking to the streets. Police believe many were EDL supporters\n\nThree girls were killed in a bloody rampage on Hart Street on Monday. On Tuesday, a vigil was held for the victims on Lord Street. While it was going on, a man with a flick knife was arrested on Eastbank Street. On St Luke's Road, riots erupted outside a mosque - also on Tuesday\n\nRiot police vans were damaged amid the chaos near the Southport Mosque\n\nThugs, many hooded and wearing masks, launch wheelie bins at a riot van\n\nA burnt out police van near a mosque in Southport as shocking riots broke out on Tuesday\n\nThe coastal community united to bring order back to their quiet streets - on local Facebook groups some offered their rooms to people who needed a safe space, while others organised clean up crews to remove the carnage of the night before (pictured)\n\nThe streets of Southport were left devastated by the riots - with the streets piled high with rubble and chaos\n\nLocal crews worked hard in the early morning to rid the streets of rubble as they brought in machinery\n\nWorkers remove debris from the scene after a night of disorder in Southport\n\nBuilders offered their services for free to rebuild walls demolished after thugs threw rubble at police vehicles and others took to social media to praise brave officers\n\nRubble already lies neatly piled by the sides of the quiet streets as locals unite to bring back order\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds in the bloodbath. Five are in a critical condition, alongside two women who were also critically injured as they bravely tried to save the children.\n\nAnd today the coastal community united to bring order back to their quiet streets - on local Facebook groups some offered their rooms to people who needed a safe space, while others organised clean up crews to remove the carnage of the night before.\n\nBuilders offered their services for free to rebuild walls demolished after thugs threw rubble at police vehicles and others took to social media to praise brave officers.\n\nThe Bishop of Liverpool, John Perumbalath, paid tribute to the community, who is uniting through their grief.\n\nHe told the Today programme: 'It is absolute shock and sadness. I share that shock shared by the whole community here, in a quieter community where this has not been a kind of experience they have come across.\n\n'It is really a shock and the whole community is united together in their sadness.'\n\nLabour MP for Southport Patrick Hurley reflected on the vigil in the town on Tuesday evening for victims of Monday's knife attack, saying the community were 'reeling' and 'in grief' following the death of three girls.\n\nHe condemned the 'beered-up thugs' who threw bricks towards a mosque, and said yobs had got the train in and used the tragic deaths 'for their own political purposes'.\n\nA baby seat can be seen in the back seat of a car whose windows have been smashed through outside the mosque in Southport\n\nThe car outside the religious building has been smashed following the rioting last night\n\nDamage to the Southport Islamic Society Mosque after rioters congregated around the sacred building\n\nWorkers have brought in machinery to clean away the chaos around the suburban Mosque\n\nSpeaking to the Today programme, he said: 'These were thugs who got the train in, these were not the people from Southport.\n\n'They were using the horrific incident on Monday, the deaths of three little kiddies, for their own political purposes and actually to attack the very same first responders and the very same police, who had been on the scene on Monday, were then being pelted with bricks the day after by these thugs.\n\n'There's no way to describe that other than to say it's utterly reprehensible and we must identify these people and make sure that the full force of the law is down against them.'\n\nHe went on: 'These people are utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children and utterly disrespecting the town.'\n\nHe continued: 'Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all. Not least these beered-up thugs who have descended on the town last night intent on causing trouble.\n\n'We all have to stand against that and Southport will not accept this. Southport will unite against this sort of thing.'\n\nThe Prime Minister and Home Secretary joined police chiefs in condemning the 'sickening' violence, which started barely an hour after thousands of mourners had gathered for a vigil to remember the victims who lost their lives.\n\nJust yards away from the emotional vigil, a 32-year-old man, dressed in all black with a hat on the joint-hottest day of the year, was separately arrested after being caught carrying a flick knife on Eastbank Street at 6.55pm.\n\nOn nearby St Luke's Street, rioters chanting 'English till I die' surrounded the Southport Mosque and Islamic Cultural Centre and began hurling rubble at police officers who had formed a protective line around the building.\n\nThe violence appears to have been fuelled by false claims online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nThe 17-year-old boy, who remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder, is originally from Cardiff but now lives in the nearby Lancashire village of Banks.\n\nLocals came out in force to clean the mess with any means they had - including by hand\n\nFamily homes were left damaged and devastated by the riots as walls and cars were ruined\n\nFootage showed a man, dressed in all black in the scorching heat, being arrested near the vigil for the three girls who died\n\nThe riots came barely an hour after thousands of mourners gathered for a vigil at the Atkinson in Southport\n\nIn stark contrast to the riots on the streets, there was a sense of tranquility at the site of the vigil as night fell\n\nHome Secretary Yyvette Cooper, pictured leaving flowers at the scene of the attack yesterday, condemned the mob violence\n\nMerseyside Police has issued a warning over an 'incorrect' name being widely circulated online, adding: 'We would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.'\n\nThe service said 27 of its officers were taken to hospital following the violence.\n\nA statement on X said: 'We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.'\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nThe angry mob - who police 'believed to be supporters of the English Defence League' - started targeting the Muslim place of worship at around 7.45pm.\n\nEight police officers suffered serious injuries, including one who was knocked unconscious. Protesters also torched cars and wheelie bins belonging to members of the public, shattered the mosque windows with bricks and looted shops.\n\nOne Southport resident living near the mosque told how he, his partner and their young daughter fled for the evening, not wanting her to see the sickening violence.\n\nThe man said: 'We just couldn't stay while this was going on and allow our daughter to witness it.\n\n'This doesn't represent Southport - they're EDL thugs who are from Manchester and Liverpool who have just come here to cause trouble. They have no respect for a town that's grieving.'\n\nThe Prime Minister said rioters had 'hijacked' a vigil for victims and would 'feel the full force of the law'.\n\nWriting on X, Sir Keir said: 'The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday.\n\n'They deserve our support and our respect. Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said 'scenes of thuggery' on the streets of Southport 'bear no relation' to the community which had been coming together.\n\nShe told broadcasters: 'I think everyone should be showing some respect for the community that is grieving and also for the police who are pursuing an urgent criminal investigation now, and who showed such heroism and bravery yesterday in the face of these horrific attacks.\n\n'I think everyone needs to support the police in that work, and frankly the scenes of thuggery that we have seen on the streets of Southport this evening bear no relation to the way in which the Southport community has been coming together to support each other and to support grieving families.\n\n'We need to see some respect for the grieving community and for the police in their urgent work.'\n\nPolice have introduced a 24-hour Section 60 Order in the area where the riots took place and extra officers will remain in the area.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: 'Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.'\n\nHe added: 'Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\n\n'This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.'\n\nThe violence was condemned by Sir Keir Starmer, Mayor Steve Rotheram and the Liverpool Region Mosque Network on Tuesday night\n\nHundreds of protesters, many masked, battled with riot police officers\n\nEngland flags were on display at the anti-Muslim demonstration in Southport\n\nSmoke is seen billowing from a police van which was set ablaze. The mosque is seen on the right\n\nTensions flared in Southport last night, with police saying supporters of the EDL were targeting the mosque\n\nLocal mosque groups condemned the violence aimed towards Muslims, adding: 'We must not let those who seek to divide us and spread hatred use this as an opportunity.'\n\nAnd Steve Rotheram, mayor of the Liverpool city region, wrote: 'There are families just coming to terms with yesterday's events, parents grieving for their murdered children and survivors still trying to process what they witnessed.\n\n'The violent scenes in Southport tonight will only further traumatise a community that is already struggling to come to terms with this attack.\n\n'Mindless violence directed at the very people who ran towards the danger yesterday, and outright Islamaphobia, only distract from the work of delivering justice.\n\n'The real story tonight is of the thousands who gathered at the vigil in Southport in memory of Bebe, Elsie and Alice. For the sake of their loved ones, this disorder needs to stop so the police do their jobs.'\n\nPolice said that a number of officers were injured, while cars were set alight and shops were broken into and looted during the disorder.\n\nIn a desperate bid to protect themselves, officers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them. One officer has suffered a suspected broken nose and police vehicles have been damaged and set on fire as around 400 people gathered to watch.\n\nThe three girls who died were among 11 children stabbed during a 'ferocious' knife attack which left mothers picking up their children screaming in horror.\n\nChaotic scenes erupted near to where the knife rampage took place in Southport yesterday\n\nThe aftermath of the riots, where police vans were burnt and rocks were launched\n\nRioters wearing masks launch missiles towards police officers in Southport\n\nRiot police with shields and helmets hold back protesters after disorder broke out\n\nProtesters cheer as they launch bins at riot police vans amid ugly scenes in Southport\n\nRioters were seen jumping on police vans as things got out of control\n\nSmoke billows behind riot police officers amid riots in the seaside town\n\nA traffic cone is hurled by a masked man at a police officer near to a mosque in Southport\n\nA wounded police officer with blood pouring down his head after being caught up in the riots\n\nRiot police try to control the angry mob who have taken to the streets of Southport\n\nFive further children, aged between six and 11, are in a critical condition alongside two female adults, among them hero yoga teacher Leanne Lucas, who 'bravely tried to protect them'.\n\nOne source told The Sun that she needed an eight-hour operation and remains seriously ill in hospital. Dance tutor Heidi Liddle and window cleaner Joel Verite have also been hailed for their bravery during the attack.\n\nAs thousands of mourners attended an emotional vigil in Southport on Tuesday evening, protests broke out on the streets surrounding Hart Street, where the attack took place.\n\nFurious demonstrators tore down garden walls to use as missiles to pelt at police, with wheelie bins also thrown during the mayhem.\n\nA police van was set on fire by protesters. Angry mobs chanted 'Stop the boats' and kicked out at police vans sent to restore order.\n\nSome threw smoke bombs, with men wearing caps and shorts charging at outnumbered police.\n\nScores of riot vans and patrol cars raced to the scene as a police helicopter hovered overhead as the violence spread out of control.\n\nHuge crowds of men, many masked and wearing hoodies, were seen clashing with police - as stones, bottles, bricks and fireworks were launched.\n\nDemonstrators could be heard shouting 'No surrender' and 'English till I die'.\n\nOne police officer was seen being helped into a van by his colleagues with blood streaming down his face and a heavily bandaged head. A female officer was also seen with a cut cheek.\n\nBy 8pm, around 500 rioters had massed in two streets outside the mosque - Sussex Road and St Luke's Road - trapping around 40 police officers in the middle.\n\nMissiles were hurled at riot officers and dog handlers from both sides. Bottles, bricks, fireworks and lumps of concrete were thrown to cheers from the rioters, who goaded police and eyes each other on.\n\nAt about 8.15pm a crowd surrounded three riot vans and began rocking one to try and flip it over.\n\nMoments later a small explosion was heard and a mini-fireball erupted in the air as the van went up in flames.\n\nOne man shouted: 'We're doing this for our girls!' as officers drove the other vans away from the fire to stop them also being set alight.\n\nIn a desperate attempt to quell the disorder, a charge from riot police brandishing batons sent around 300 of the rioters fleeing down the street as reinforcements flooded the area.\n\nBut violence continued into the night, with rioters forming a burning barricade of wheelie bins as they hurled bricks and lumps of concrete at riot police.\n\nMobs chanting 'save our girls' clashed with police until 10.30pm outside the Southport Mosque and Islamic Cultural Centre.\n\nA nearby corner shop looked to have been broken into and looted. Rioters set alight at least five wheelie bins in the middle of Sussex Road sending flames and toxic black plumes of smoke shooting up into the night's sky.\n\nWith officers unable to charge due to the burning barricade, a volley of missiles was hurled from behind the makeshift bonfire.\n\nAt one point the ferocity of the violence sent the line of police retreating slightly. Officers in a Merseyside Police helicopter continued to monitor events from the air.\n\nThe crowd began to thin out around 11pm with reports of disturbances - including cars being torched - breaking out across Southport.\n\nDuring the demonstration, several people carried placards with slogans about stopping the boats. One read: 'Stop the boats! Send them back! Fight for our kids! Let's stand together!\n\nRiot police hold back protesters near a burning police vehicle\n\nA police officer holding a baton with a cut on her face after rioters stormed the area near the mosque\n\nRiot police intervene as activists cause chaos in Southend as rumours circulate over the suspect's identity\n\nA protester walks away holding his head as activists clashed with police on Tuesday\n\nClashes between protesters and police can be seen breaking out in the far distance\n\nSome held placards saying 'stop the boats'. This is despite police issuing a warning after an 'incorrect' name for the alleged attacker was widely circulated online\n\nWheelie bins and bricks were thrown at police, while a police van went up in flames - as police warned people not to speculate about the identity of the suspect\n\nHuge crowds have clashed with police in Southport as tensions boil over following the knife rampage\n\nActivists were seen launching missiles at police and attempting to damage riot vans\n\nOne woman carrying a placard said the disorder was because the knife man who attacked the children 'was a Muslim.'\n\nShe said: 'We are saying enough is enough. Why are they not stopping the migrants coming in?\n\n'How many more children will be killed because they are letting them all in? They should be at the borders stopping them.'\n\nHer comments came after inaccurate posts by social media sleuths about the identity of the perpetrator have received millions of views and engagements.\n\nSunder Katwala, director of the think-tank British Future, said a bogus news channel seemed to have invented a fake name for the suspect and run a false story that was shared online.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Goss said: 'There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n'We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\n\n'It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.'\n\nThe riots went on late into the evening, with police officers desperately trying to regain control\n\nRiot police wearing helmets and shields try to defend themselves near the mosque\n\nRiot police officers storm into the area to try and disperse the growing crowd\n\nAlso on Tuesday evening, officers were called to reports of a man carrying a weapon at around 6.50pm, during which time the vigil was taking place at the Atkinson venue.\n\nPolice swooped on the scene and detained the man minutes later before seizing the flick knife.\n\nA 32-year-old man dressed in all black, from Standish, was arrested on suspicion of possession of a bladed article, and taken into custody. There were no reports of any injuries during the incident.\n\nDetective Inspector Gavin Mulcahy said: 'We know too well the devastating impact knife crime can have for victims, their families and friends, and those who carry them.\n\n'This week has seen an unspeakable tragedy unfold in Southport, and this incident occurred a short distance from where a vigil had been happening where the community was paying their respects to all those affected.\n\n'Officers made a swift arrest and have seized a knife that could have been used to cause harm in our communities.\n\n'Those offenders who carry them have no place whatsoever in our communities.\n\n'Every day we are carrying out stop checks, warrants and land searches to take knives off our streets, but as this incident shows, the assistance of members of the public in telling us where they are stored and who is carrying them is vital to ensure the safety of families and residents.'\n\nAt the vigil, tearful locals laid flowers outside the Merseyside town's grand Atkinson building after falling silent to remember Bebe, Elsie and nine-year-old Alice.\n\nIn the first week of the summer holidays, the seaside town should be bustling with happy families and tourists. But at 6pm on Tuesday, more than 5,000 people stood in silence outside the Atkinson building amid an outpouring of grief and shock.\n\nIn front of the Grade II-listed building, which comprises a theatre, museum and library, is the Town Hall Gardens, where a sea of floral tributes built up.\n\nOne heartbreaking poster surrounded by candles and flowers said 'never stop dancing'. The children had been enjoying a summer holiday dance workshop when a knifeman entered the studio and launched a frenzied attack.\n\nAmong the bouquets, there were also a number of Taylor Swift-style friendship bracelets. 'Thinking of you all,' a row of four of them spelt out.\n\nAhead of the vigil, the families and schools of the innocent girls who were fatally attacked by a crazed knifeman also released tributes.\n\nIn a statement, Bebe's family said: 'No words can describe the devastation that has hit our family as try to deal with the loss of our little girl Bebe.'\n\nThe family of Alice Dasilva Aguiar added: 'Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our Princess, like we said before to you, you're always our princess and no one would change that. Love from Your Hero Daddy and Mummy.'\n\nAnd the headteacher of Farnborough Road Infant School said they were 'heartbroken and devastated' by the death of pupil Elsie.\n\nJennifer Sephton said: 'Elsie has been a loving and bright member of our wonderful community since first being brought here on her father's shoulders, and even at her early age she was such a caring and charismatic young lady who loved to please.\n\n'Elsie was a kind and caring friend to all who met her and was adored by everyone in our community. Our hearts and most deeply-felt sympathies go out to Elsie's family, friends and our Farnborough community who have been left numb by what has happened.\n\n'It is immensely difficult to put into words how amazing Elsie was and the impact she had on those around her. We will miss you dearly Elsie. You were one of a kind.'\n\nAlder Hey Children's hospital this afternoon released a statement confirming that seven children had been taken to the site for treatment. One of those was Alice, and of the others, two remain in a critical condition, a spokesperson said.\n\nThe head of the school trust attended by Alice and Bebe said the girls 'will be in our hearts forever'.\n\nEndeavour Learning Trust chief executive David Clayton said 'no words can do justice to what has happened here in Southport.\n\nThe trust contains Churchtown Primary School in Southport, which Alice and Bebe had both attended.\n\nChurchtown Primary headteacher Jinnie Payne said the school had heard the 'tragic news' with 'great sadness', describing the stabbings as an 'atrocity'.\n\nIn a statement, Mr Clayton said: 'No words can do justice to what has happened here in Southport - and our hearts are broken for the families who have lost their children.\n\n'No one should ever have to experience horror like this.\n\n'Our immediate focus now is on providing support to the community as we start to understand what has happened. The death of a child is always a desperate tragedy for a school, and particularly so under such circumstances.\n\n'We will come together as a community, offering each other support and care as we work through this difficult time.\n\n'Alice and Bebe will be in our hearts forever.'\n\nMs Payne said Alice, a Year 4 pupil at Churchtown, was the 'happiest of souls, a true ray of sunshine'.\n\nThe Churchtown Primary headteacher added: 'She was known and loved by everyone in our school community of 700 children, a testament to her unique ability to connect with others.\n\n'Alice's radiant smile brightened our days, and she embraced every aspect of school life with enthusiasm and joy.\n\n'Her kindness, playful nature, and zest for trying new things will forever be remembered. Alice, you will always hold a special place in our hearts at Churchtown.'\n\nMs Payne said Bebe, a former pupil at the school, was a 'joyful girl' whose 'kindness radiated through the entire Churchtown community'.\n\nThe headteacher added: 'During her time at the school, Bebe's considerate nature and her love of learning shone through in everything that she did.\n\n'Each day, she would come into school ready to grasp every opportunity available to her and fun and laughter were never far away whenever Bebe was involved.\n\n'Her considerate nature meant that she had many friends and she always ensured all children felt included, whether that was through play or working together in the classroom.\n\n'Bebe's memory will live on in the hearts of all who knew her.'\n\nThe headteacher added: 'We know that a number of other children from Churchtown were also involved in the attack, along with much-loved colleagues.\n\n'We extend our heartfelt wishes to all those families affected by this horrific incident, including those currently in hospital or continuing to receive treatment.'\n\nDevastated relatives of Alice said she had been taken by a 'despicable human being.'\n\nHer mother Alexandra Aguiar is understood to be originally from Caracas in Venezuela and her dad David Aguiar is from the Portuguese island of Madeira.\n\nRelative Carina Aguiar, a hotel worker who lives in Camara de Lobos in Madeira, posted a link on her social media to news Merseyside Police had confirmed a third child' had died following the attack and wrote tear emojis beside it.\n\nEarlier she posted a photo of a black ribbon on her Facebook alongside Alice's name after writing in an emotional tribute: 'Princess Alice. In this moment of great pain my soul hurts, my body hurts, my mind hurts. I have a lump in my throat.\n\n'You were just an innocent child, a happy smiley girl with a bright life ahead of you which a despicable human being took away from you, without pity, for no reason.'\n\nReacting to the riots, Merseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy posted on X: 'I am incredibly proud of my officers and staff who have worked so hard to save the lives of children, investigate the horrific incident from yesterday, working with partners to provide reassurance to our communities and now they are facing this level of violence from these thugs\n\n'Over 1000 residents from Southport came together this evening to remember the little girls who have died, those who are still critical in hospital and all those who witnessed & are traumatised by the events from yesterday. This is where all of our focus should be.'\n\nMP Mr Hurley said: 'It's distressing to see people from outside our Southport community attacking our police and local people.\n\n'I want to make it clear that I fully condemn any attack on our emergency services, these are the same services that responded to the tragic attack yesterday.\n\n'I appeal to local people to avoid the area and stay safe, to allow the police to do their job.'\n\nMr Hurley continued: 'I want to thank our community for pulling together and supporting every person who has been affected by Monday's tragic attack.\n\n'Nowhere was this more evident than the solidarity, remembrance and sympathy heard at today's vigil.\n\n'To those who laid flowers, candles, toys, thank you. I was deeply saddened to hear the news today of the death or a third child. Bebe, Elsie and Alice are in all of our thoughts and hearts today.'\n\nThe three girls stabbed to death at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class were yesterday named by police as nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and six-year-old Bebe King (L-R)\n\nAway from the protest, a vigil was being held for the three girls who died in the tragic incident\n\nIn stark contrast to the riots, there was a sense of tranquillity around the site of the vigil\n\nThe vigil was held at the Atkinson in Southport at around 6pm on Tuesday evening\n\nThe Southport Mosque said it was 'truly shocked and saddened to hear about the events that unfolded today'. They added: 'We extend our deepest sympathy to the families of all affected. Our thoughts and prayers are with you all.'\n\nThe Liverpool Region Mosque Network said it was 'shocked and horrified' by the knife rampage on Monday.\n\nBut it added: 'A minority of people are attempting to portray that this inhumane act is somehow related to the Muslim community. Frankly it is not, and we must not let those who seek to divide us and spread hatred use this as an opportunity.\n\n'This evening, we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protesters, gathering outside. This is causing further fear and anxiety within our communities. We must all unite and stand together against all forms of hate, violence and division.'\n\nAnd the The Muslim Council of Britain (MCB) condemned 'shocking scenes of far-right rioters running amok outside a mosque'.\n\nThe MCB says Islamaphobic backlash began with a false rumour on the internet which was then stoked by misinformation from a Russian news site, which wrongfully associated the crime with Muslims.\n\nMCB secretary-general Zara Mohammed said: 'At a time of great tragedy, loss, and mourning, we must stand firm against the cynical forces of hatred and division. This does not represent our diverse Britain and the people of Southport.\n\n'The Government must address the increasing rise of violent far-right extremism targeting Muslim communities. More must be done to tackle Islamophobia and offer reassurance at this time.'\n\nShe added: 'We commend the authorities for their swift action, and our prayers are with the mosque, the families of the victims of yesterday's attack, and the local community.'\n\nDowning Street also warned against 'unhelpful' speculation amid concerns that misreporting online could inflame community tensions.\n\nAn aerial view of Hart Street on Monday, where a horrifying knife attack took place just before midday\n\nOfficers should be given the space to probe the case without people guessing at the possible motive or circumstances, No 10 said.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, the Prime Minister was repeatedly asked 'how many more children will die?' as he placed flowers at the scene of the attack.\n\nSir Keir's brief visit, which lasted around two minutes, was interrupted by some members of the public heckling him.\n\nAs the Prime Minister walked past, one man declared: 'Here's your photo opportunity.'\n\nAnother shouted: 'How many more children? Our kids are dead and you're leaving already?'\n\nOther furious onlookers shouted 'scumbag', 'time for change' and 'go away, you're not wanted'.\n\nAnother woman said: 'I've just found out my friend's nine-year-old daughter was killed, the person I've held as a child, and you can't do s***.'\n\nAnd a different man shouted: 'Get the truth out!'\n\nMs Cooper has said social media companies 'need to take some responsibility' for some activity in the aftermath of the attack.\n\nResponding to shadow home secretary James Cleverly, she said: 'I agree with him too about the responsibility on every one of us. The police do need to be able to pursue this investigation.\n\n'There will be wider questions for other days, but the most important thing is that every one of us supports the police in their investigation now.\n\n'I agree with him too about the responsibility on social media companies, because we do need to recognise there are things that are taking place on social media that go against their terms and conditions, and their commitments as well. They need to take some responsibility for that.\n\n'Above all, this is about young children. This is about children and their families who will be grieving, and the many other children who were involved yesterday who will be facing great trauma as well.'\n\nHer counterpart Mr Cleverly called for people not to 'get involved in the grief of others' by sharing misinformation relating to the Southport attack on social media.\n\n'Enough people are already distressed without their distress being amplified by speculation and gossip online,' he added.\n\nAhead of fears mounting over a far-right rally, Sir Keir's official spokesman said: 'Of course, people should listen the police, they should not do anything that is going to make the police's job harder to manage the situation, to conduct their investigations.\n\n'It is unhelpful to speculate on things like the motive and the circumstance around this.'\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.", "source": {"uri": "expressdigest.com", "dataType": In no time, there were hundreds.\"\n\nREAD NEXT: Chaos in Southport as nearly 40 police officers injured during violent riots\n\nA clothing bank in the grounds of the mosque was torched amid the disorder. The imam said he heard shouts of 'we want our country back' from outside. \"I was scared,\" he said. \"There were about eight of us and we had to barricade ourselves in.\"\n\nOyess Ali, 28, who attends the mosque, said the imam and others were inside praying when it was targeted. They were forced to barricade themselves inside the building, he said.\n\nMr Ali lives close to the scene where children were stabbed in Southport on Monday, and witnessed the horrific aftermath. \"Monday was horrific, then Tuesday happened, and now I'm thinking 'what's next?' The whole town is in shock.\"\n\nTracy Whitfield, whose partner runs a business in Sussex Road, revealed its windows were damaged by the heat from a police van that was set on fire outside. She described the mob which gathered as 'the worst of humanity'.\n\n\"I couldn't believe the aggression towards the police,\" she went on. \"There was one lady - a police officer - who looked out cold. She was being dragged by her colleagues to an ambulance.\"\n\nTracey said she came down to the shop to collect paperwork amid fears the building could be set on fire. \"There were people everywhere,\" she said. \"There were flames, fireworks, and the van was on fire. Every bang made me jump.\"\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, described those involved in last night's disorder as 'cowards'. \"These people have been bussed in to hijack a terrible tragedy,\" he said. \"They weren't from the town.\"\n\nMr Wallis said the disorder and those involved are 'not the face of the town'. \"Southport is not like that,\" he said. \"It's a very safe place.\"\n\nMr Wallis said he 'put the message out' for people to join in the community clean-up this morning. \"I thought we have to do something about it. Everyone has brought shovels and brushes to clean everything away. That's what the true community here is.\"\n\nChanaka Balasuriya, who runs Windsor Mini Mart which was broken into by rioters last night, shut the shop early after neighbours warned him about a possible 'protest' in the area.\n\nChanaka went home and he his wife, Thanuja watched through the shop CCTV as masked thugs descended on the area and hurled 'rocks' at his business. \"We knew they were going to come in,\" Thanuja said. \"They broke the glass then pulled the shutter open.\"\n\nThe shop has suffered considerable damage and Thanuja says 'everything has to be replaced'. The family has owned Windsor Mini Mart for four years and say they have 'never had a single incident' until last night.\n\nDozens of people entered the shop and stole items including alcohol and cash from the till, Thanuja said. \"It was terrifying to watch. They threw a stick on fire in. We thought they were going to burn it down so we turned it off because we didn't want to see.\"\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, aged nine, six-year-old Bebe King and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Southport on Monday, while a 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age, remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nThe Manchester Evening News understands GMP dispatched two units of public order trained officers to Southport. None of its vehicles or officers were injured. Some 39 colleagues were hurt and 27 of them were taken to hospital, Merseyside Police has confirmed.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nScotland's former first minister Humza Yousaf called for the EDL to be banned under terror laws in the wake of the unrest, despite former leader Tommy Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nElsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight. The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nThe troubling scenes saw 27 officers taken to hospital, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nChief mosque attacked in violent disorder in Southport on Tuesday night has told ITV News the attack was \"terrifying\" and described the whole building shaking as missiles were thrown.\n\nIbrahim Hussein was inside the mosque with around eight others when he says \"strangers\" started shouting abuse and throwing missiles.\n\nHe said: \"The whole building was shaking [because] of the missiles that they kept throwing, big bricks, and soon after they broke the fence, like you have seen outside, and they were using that to throw things at us.\n\n\"So, naturally it was a very, very unpleasant experience.\"\n\nHe added that rioters \"definitely\" tried to break into the mosque, explaining his fears they would \"burn it down\".\n\nIn the wake of the violence, Mr Hussein praised the Southport community for its support of the mosque, describing the rioters as \"prejudiced\" and \"from outside Southport\".\n\n\"We've got beautiful neighbours, absolutely lovely neighbours, and the messages of support that we've got from them is incredible,\" he added.\n\n\"So we knew them anyway and they know us, and they never have any trouble from us.\"\n\nMore than 50 police officers were injured as a result of the violence, with 27 officers taken to hospital, according to North West Ambulance service.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries, including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nSubscribe free to our weekly newsletter for exclusive and original coverage from ITV News. Why would anybody want to attack little children who did no harm to nobody?'\"\n\nHe added he and other members of Southport's Muslim community were frightened to attend the vigil.\n\n\"We'd have loved to be there, but we couldn't do it and then, of course, we were worried that they [rioters] would come in here.\"\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer joined police authorities in condemning the violent protests, saying rioters had \"hijacked\" a vigil for victims and will \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nThe mother of one of the three girls to have died in Monday's attack also criticised the protests, writing on social media: \"we don't need this\".\n\nIn a message widely shared online, Jenni Stancombe, the mother of seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe, said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nSpeaking about the police, Ms Stancombe added: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nChairman of the Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, condemned the \"sustained and vicious attack\" against police, saying: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. Not to hospital.\"\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain (MCB), meanwhile, paid tribute to the victims of the mass stabbing, before condemning \"shocking scenes of far-right rioters running amok outside a mosque\".\n\nMCB secretary general, Zara Mohammed, said: \"At a time of great tragedy, loss, and mourning, we must stand firm against the cynical forces of hatred and division.\n\n\"This does not {"uri": "8252553252", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:34:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:34:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:33:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/moment-southport-rioter-hit-head-29649349", "title": "Moment Southport rioter hit in head with brick then in groin during protest - Liverpool Echo", "body": "Violent scenes broke out during a riot on St Luke's Road in Southport\n\nA chaotic video showed the moment a rioter was hit in the head with a brick then his groin during protests in Southport. Violent scenes broke out on Tuesday, July 30 during protests taking place on St Luke's Road.\n\nThe latest figures from emergency services said 39 police officers were injured, with 27 of them being taken to hospital. Bricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire.\n\nIn one video, shared widely on social media, a man appears to be goading riot police officers, a brick can then be seen hitting the man's head. He can be seen touching his head and blood can be seen on his hand.\n\nOther people can be seen continuing to throwing wheelie bins and bricks at officers. As the man walks away from the scene, he is then hit with another brick in his groin. He can be seen keeled over and helped by another man as he leaves the scene.\n\nMerseyside Police said several officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries. One was knocked unconscious.\n\nA large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road on Tuesday evening. Cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire and bricks were thrown at a local mosque.\n\nDamage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set on fire, police said. Three police dogs have also been injured. Police Dogs Zoe and Ike have sustained leg injuries from bricks thrown at them. A third dog, PD Quga, also suffered burns to her back leg.\n\nPhotos and video seen by the ECHO showed crowds gathered around police riot vans on St Luke's Road. A police van was also seen up in flames. Merseyside Police said as a result of the disorder, a 24-hour Section 60 Order has been introduced in the area, running from 19.54pm on (Tuesday). Extra officers will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities. The order, under Section 60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994, gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals in the area and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack. I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday. We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible. Anyone with information can DM @MerPolCC or contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.\"", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Liverpool Echo"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251479172", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:37:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:37:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:35:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/taylor-swift-in-shock-after-southport-dance-class-stabbing-leaves-3-children-dead-and-several-injured/TKAPKNJSOVGVNNK7O7IRC4POOY/", "title": "'These were just kids': Taylor Swift addresses deadly UK dance class stabbing", "body": "In a post shared to Instagram, Swift described being \"completely in shock\" from the news and acknowledged that she would struggle ever being able to convey her \"sympathies\" to the families impacted.\n\nResponding to the tragic news, Swift wrote: \"The horror of yesterday's attack in Southport is washing over me continuously and I'm just completely in shock ...\n\n\"The loss of life and innocence, and the horrendous trauma inflicted on everyone who was there, the families, and first responders,\" she continued.\n\n\"These were just little kids at a dance class. I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families.\"\n\nSwift is currently completing the European leg of her Eras Tour. She will return to the UK in August to perform the show for five more nights in London.\n\nSwift fans created the \"Swifties for Southport\" campaign to fundraise money for the victims and their families through the Alder Hey Children's Charity. Originally setting a target goal of \u00a313,000 ($28,264), the page managed to raise \u00a3100,000 ($217,379) in under 24 hours.\n\nThe town of Southport has been reeling as locals work with police to learn what triggered the attack on the the group of young children, who were between 6 and 11 years old.\n\nA growing wall of flowers, written messages, and toys has emerged on a road near where the attack unfolded.\n\nA 17-year-old male was arrested after police responded to the \"ferocious attack\" on a class at a dance and yoga workshop at around 11.50am (local time). He was arrested under suspicion of murder or attempted murder.\n\nThe male suspect was born in Cardiff and lived in the nearby town of Banks, Lancashire, according to Merseyside Police. No further details on the perpetrator have been released as of yet.\n\nIn the day following the attack, shortly after a minute's silence was held the by the Southport community, hundreds of protesters gathered by a local mosque a few streets over, the BBC reported.\n\nMany of the protesters covered their faces with scarves and hoodies, vandalising the mosque with items like rocks and bottles.\n\nFalse reports had earlier circulated that the suspect was an asylum seeker who'd recently crossed the English Channel and was on an MI6 watchlist. Merseyside Police have linked the online rhetoric to the \"sickening\" violence that erupted the day after the attack.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" said Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nSpeaking on the unrest, Merseyside Police said that they were dealing with \"criminal behaviour\" while trying to process the events of the day before.\n\nEmergency vehicles were set on fire and burned, protesters threw heavy items at police officers, and a store was broken into and ransacked.\n\nSeveral officers were injured in the clashes, including an officer who suffered a \"broken nose\".\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face,\" said Constable Goss.\n\n\"Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\"\n\nUK Home Secretary Yvette Cooper called for an end to the violence and asked all parties to de-escalate the tension on Southport's streets, stating that the \"scenes of thuggery\" were not reflective of the community that had come together to mourn.\n\n\"I think everyone should be showing some respect for the community that is grieving and also for the police who are pursuing an urgent criminal investigation now, and who showed such heroism and bravery yesterday in the face of these horrific attacks,\" Cooper said.\n\n\"I think everyone needs to support the police in that work, and frankly the scenes of thuggery that we have seen on the streets of Southport this evening bear no relation to the way in which the Southport community has been coming together to support each other and to support grieving families.\n\n\"We need to see some respect for the grieving community and for the police in their urgent work.\"", "source": {"uri": "nzherald.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "NZ Herald"}, {"uri": "2024-07-439646343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:20:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:20:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:12:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/three-arrested-over-southport-riots-141226446.html", "title": "Three arrested over Southport riots", "body": "Three arrested over Southport riots\n\nHannah Al-Othman, Jamie Grierson, Josh Halliday and Vikram Dodd\n\n31 July 2024 at 4:12 pm\n\nThree men have been arrested in connection with far-right riots that broke out in Southport in which more than 50 police officers were injured as the community was still reeling from an horrific stabbing spree that claimed the lives of three children.\n\nThe Merseyside chief constable, Serena Kennedy, told reporters on a walkabout in Southport that the three were arrested in connection with riots, in which 54 police officers were injured, including 49 from Merseyside police and four from Lancashire.\n\n\"They were there purely for hooliganism and thuggery,\" Kennedy said of the rioters.\n\nAs the police force dealt with the fallout of the far-right violence, detectives were granted more time to question the 17-year-old boy held in connection with the atrocity, in which three girls, aged six, seven and nine, were killed, and eight other children and two adults were injured.\n\nThe boy, from the nearby village of Banks, was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the horror unfolded at a Taylor Swift-themed children's holiday club on Monday.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were fatally stabbed, while five children and two adults remain in critical condition.\n\nRightwing rioters staged violent protests near Southport mosque on Tuesday, marring a night of remembrance for the little girls who lost their lives.\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during unrest that followed a vigil for the murdered children.\n\nBaseless rumours were spread on social media, misidentifying the suspect and falsely claiming that he was an asylum seeker, when in fact he was born in Cardiff.\n\nIn Southport on Wednesday, the metro mayor of Liverpool, Steve Rotheram, said: \"What we saw last night was infiltration by people from all over the country, stirred up by social media and then whipped up into a frenzy whereby they were attacking the very people that everybody earlier in the day was celebrating for being the heroes, for running towards danger. It leaves a very sour taste in the mouth that these people believe they can come here and divide our community.\"\n\nOne of the victim's mothers intervened in a bid to cool tensions. Elsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nIn the wake of the violence, residents of Southport rallied together to support the Muslim community and clear up the mess left by rioters, who it is claimed came from outside the area.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, clearing bricks from a wall that was knocked down during the rioting.\n\nThe mosque chairman, Ibrahim Hussein, told the Guardian how he had been \"barricaded\" inside the building with eight worshippers when hundreds of rioters descended on the mosque.\n\nHe said: \"It really was terrifying and it was uncalled for. There was no reason for it whatsoever. We just have to keep on going, there's nothing else we can do.\"\n\nMerseyside police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League (EDL)\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nThe EDL is a far-right, Islamophobic group founded in 2009 by Tommy Robinson, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon.\n\nScotland's former first minister, Humza Yousaf, called for the EDL to be banned under terror laws after the unrest, despite Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nThe deputy prime minister, Angela Rayner, later said her colleague, the home secretary, Yvette Cooper, would \"be looking at\" whether the EDL should be proscribed under terrorism laws.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jamie_grierson@aol.co.uk", "name": "Jamie Grierson", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "josh_halliday@aol.co.uk", "name": "Josh Halliday", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "hannah_al_othman@aol.co.uk", "name": "Hannah Al-Othman", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [], "categories": [], "image": "https://media.zenfs.com/en/aol_the_guardian_uk_429/cf2fb5366dd387cf00ed37ea40af5244", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9777011", "eventUri": "eng-9777011", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.6627450980392157, "wgt": 153, "relevance": 1}

{"uri": "8251565658", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:27:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:27:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:25:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.asiaone.com/world/violent-crowd-clashes-uk-police-after-young-girls-killed", "title": "AsiaOne", "body": "SOUTHPORT -- A large crowd of anti-Muslim protesters clashed with police on Tuesday (July 30) in a northern English town where three girls were stabbed to death and five other children critically wounded during an attack on a Taylor Swift-themed event on Monday.\n\nThe horrific stabbing incident in Southport, a quiet seaside town north of Liverpool, has shocked the nation. Police have said it was not linked to terrorism and that the suspect was born in the UK.\n\nYet far-right groups have stoked speculation that the teenage suspect was involved with Islam, and police said Tuesday's violence erupted when several hundred people began to throw items at a mosque. Police linked the crowd to the English Defence League, a group which has sometimes staged violent demonstrations against Islam.\n\nPolice vehicles were damaged and set alight, officers were pelted by bricks and large garbage containers. One video posted online showed the crowd chanting \"we want our country back\".\n\nAway from the violence, hundreds had gathered for an emotional vigil to pay tribute to those killed in the attack, laying flowers and toys.\n\n\"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect,\" Prime Minister Keir Starmer said.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nA 17-year-old male is currently in police custody on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the bloody rampage at a \"Taylor Swift yoga and dance workshop\", a summer vacation event for children aged 6 to 11.\n\nWitnesses described the attack as being like a scene from a horror film. In addition to the three deaths, eight children suffered stab wounds. Five of them and two adults who had tried to protect them remain in a critical condition.\n\nThe police have said the motive remained unclear and have not given any details about the suspect, beyond saying he was born in Wales and lived in a village nearby.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" said Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nGoss and local politicians said those clashing with police involved many from outside the area, and the Liverpool Region Mosque Network said a minority of people were trying to use the incident to spread hatred.\n\n\"This evening we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protesters gathering outside,\" it said in a statement. \"This is causing further fear and anxiety within our communities,\"\n\nStarmer had earlier paid a sombre visit to the town to lay flowers, and King Charles and his family have expressed their horror. US singer Swift herself wrote on Instagram that she was \"just completely in shock\".\n\n\"These were just little kids at a dance class. I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families,\" she said.\n\nHer fans have raised more than 250,000 pounds (S$430,600) online to help families of the victims and for the hospital where some of the children were being treated.\n\nThe three girls who died in the attack were named as Bebe King, aged 6, 7-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, aged 9, whose parents are Portuguese.\n\n\"Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our Princess, like we said before to you, you're always our princess and no one would change that. Love from Your Hero Daddy and Mummy,\" Aguiar's family said in a statement.\n\nThere has been increasing concern at rising levels of stabbings and knife crime in Britain, and the Southport attack follows other recent similar, indiscriminate rampages.\n\n\"I'm absolutely determined that my government will get to grips with it,\" Starmer said.", "source": {"uri": "asiaone.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8252620667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:18:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:18:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:17:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/article/2024/jul/31/three-arrested-over-southport-riots", "title": "Three arrested over Southport riots", "body": "Arrests come after far-right rioters staged violent protests after horrific knife attack on Monday\n\nThree men have been arrested in connection with far-right riots that broke out in Southport in which more than 50 police officers were injured as the community was still reeling from a horrific knife attack that claimed the lives of three children.\n\nThe Merseyside chief constable, Serena Kennedy, told reporters on a walkabout in Southport that the three were arrested in connection with riots, in which 54 police officers were injured, including 49 from Merseyside police and four from Lancashire.\n\n\"They were there purely for hooliganism and thuggery,\" Kennedy said of the rioters.\n\nAs the police force dealt with the fallout of the far-right violence, detectives were granted more time to question the 17-year-old boy held in connection with the atrocity, in which three girls, aged six, seven and nine, were killed, and eight other children and two adults were injured.\n\nThe boy, from the nearby village of Banks, was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the horror unfolded at a Taylor Swift-themed children's holiday club on Monday.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were fatally stabbed, while five children and two adults remain in critical condition.\n\nRightwing rioters staged violent protests near Southport mosque on Tuesday, marring a night of remembrance for the little girls who lost their lives.\n\nPolice officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during unrest that followed a vigil for the murdered children.\n\nBaseless rumours were spread on social media, misidentifying the suspect and falsely claiming that he was an asylum seeker, when in fact he was born in Cardiff.\n\nIn Southport on Wednesday, the metro mayor of Liverpool, Steve Rotheram, said: \"What we saw last night was infiltration by people from all over the country, stirred up by social media and then whipped up into a frenzy whereby they were attacking the very people that everybody earlier in the day was celebrating for being the heroes, for running towards danger. It leaves a very sour taste in the mouth that these people believe they can come here and divide our community.\"\n\nOne of the victim's mothers intervened in a bid to cool tensions. Elsie's mother, Jenni Stancombe, wrote on Facebook: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nIn the wake of the violence, residents of Southport rallied together to support the Muslim community and clear up the mess left by rioters, who it is claimed came from outside the area.\n\nDozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels on Wednesday morning, clearing bricks from a wall that was knocked down during the rioting.\n\nThe mosque chair, Ibrahim Hussein, told the Guardian how he had been \"barricaded\" inside the building with eight worshippers when hundreds of rioters descended on the mosque.\n\nHe said: \"It really was terrifying and it was uncalled for. There was no reason for it whatsoever. We just have to keep on going, there's nothing else we can do.\"\n\nMerseyside police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League (EDL)\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the mosque in the seaside town at about 7.45pm.\n\nThe EDL is a far-right, Islamophobic group founded in 2009 by Tommy Robinson, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon.\n\nScotland's former first minister, Humza Yousaf, called for the EDL to be banned under terror laws after the unrest, despite Robinson's insistence that the group no longer exists.\n\nThe deputy prime minister, Angela Rayner, later said her colleague, the home secretary, Yvette Cooper, would \"be looking at\" whether the EDL should be proscribed under terrorism laws.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "vikram_dodd@theguardian.com", "name": "Vikram Dodd", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "jamie_grierson@theguardian.com", "name": "Jamie Grierson", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "josh_halliday@theguardian.com", "name": "Josh Halliday", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "hannah_al_othman@theguardian.com", "name": "Hannah Al-Othman", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riot", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Riot"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Far-right_politics", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Far-right politics"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southport", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Southport"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Southport"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "2024-07-439451079", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:30:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:30:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:50:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.itv.com/news/granada/2024-07-31/five-children-remain-in-critical-condition-after-southport-knife-attack", "title": "Five children remain in critical condition after Southport knife attack", "body": "Teachers from Elsie's school lay flowers at the scene on Wednesday.\n\nFive children and two adults remain in a critical condition in hospital after a deadly knife attack at a school holiday workshop in Southport.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed on Monday after a knifeman entered the Hart Centre where a Taylor Swift-themed class for young children was taking place.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, Merseyside Police said.\n\nMeanwhile, a 17-year-old teenage boy, who has not been identified due to his age, remains in police custody after he was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder.\n\nIt comes as the town recovers from a night of violence after hundreds of people, thought by police to be members of the English Defence League, gathered outside a mosque in protest.\n\nFifty officers suffered serious injuries when bricks, stones and bottles were thrown and cars were set alight during violent protests following a vigil for Alice, Bebe and Elsie.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" - began to throw items such as bricks towards the place of worship at about 7:45pm.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been \"broken into and looted\", adding that \"those responsible will be brought to justice\".\n\nA police cordon remains in place on Hart Street, two days after the attack, with mourners continue to lay flowers, balloons and messages of condolences for loved ones.\n\nRepresentatives from Farnborough Road Infant School, where Elsie attended, visited the scene on Wednesday to lay their own floral tributes.\n\nThe suspect, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, is from the village of Banks, just outside Southport.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nAngela Rayner has criticised the \"disgraceful\" rioting in Southport and \"disrespectful\" social media theories as she urged people to allow the police to establish the facts.\n\nSpeaking on ITV's This Morning, the Deputy Prime Minister said: \"I think there's been a couple of instances recently where, especially particularly online, where theories and things are whipped up, whereas actually it turns out to be not true or not the full picture.\n\n\"And I think there's a culture now where people want to instantly get the facts, but actually it's important that police and those people that are doing the work are able to carry out that work.\n\n\"And it's important for justice as well, because we have law and order in the UK, and it's important that those authorities are able to establish the facts and then to be able to bring those forward.\n\n\"But speculation and some of the untruths that have been put around social media, not only is that creating tensions and fear in the community, but it's disrespectful to family who maybe want those answers that haven't got those answers.\"\n\nShe added that it is \"really unhelpful for the police\" and \"my plea is that we all need to step back and just wait and then that information will come but allow the police to do their work\".", "source": {"uri": "itv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ITV Hub"}, The suspect then stabbed three children aged 6, 7, and 9 to death, and injured eight other children, five of whom are in critical condition, and two adults, according to a statement from the Merseyside Police.\n\nThe murders became a flash point for anti-immigration sentiment after it was revealed by neighbors of the suspect that the murderer was the son of Rwandan parents, but was born in the U.K., according to the Daily Express.\n\nDespite the suspect reportedly being raised by Christian parents, rioters assembled outside the Southport Islamic Society Mosque on Tuesday evening, chanting \"No surrender!\" and \"English till I die!\"\n\nAccording to The Guardian, others heard chants of \"Allah Allah, who the f**k is Allah?\"\n\nThe rioters are allegedly members of the far-right English Defence League, an organization that has been referred to as explicitly anti-immigrant and Islamophobic by activists.\n\n\"At around 7.45pm, a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League - began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road in Southport,\" Merseyside police wrote in a statement.\n\nPolice also stated that the riots \"involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\"\n\nAdditionally, a number of officers were injured, police confirmed, while a number of cars were also damaged and a shop was broken into and looted in Southport. \"This is completely unacceptable. We're gathering evidence and those responsible will be brought to justice,\" police said in an appeal on Facebook.\n\nOnline speculation and conspiracy theories claim that the suspect was not born in the U.K. and that he was being monitored by law enforcement before the attack, both of which are untrue.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time. Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper condemned the conspiracy theories in an address to the House of Commons on Tuesday evening saying, \"False information has already been extensively shared in the last 24 hours. Those who do this for their own purposes risk undermining a crucial criminal investigation, and I ask everyone to show some respect for the community in Southport and for families who are grieving and in trauma.\"\n\nFar-right activist, Tommy Robinson, who was arrested on suspected charges of terrorism on Sunday, went viral on Tuesday evening after he posted a rant to his X account in which he condemned the police for \"allowing people into our towns and cities that are raping their way through our towns.\"\n\n\"You care more for Afghanis, Somalis, Eritreans, Syrians, Pakistani... They are a danger to us,\" Robinson went on. The post has garnered 46k likes and millions of views at the time of publishing.\n\nMP Nigel Farage, whose Reform UK party has also been called anti-immigrant and racist by activist groups, echoed conspiracy theories about the suspect in a video posted to his X on Tuesday evening.\n\n\"Was this guy being monitored by the security services, some reports say he was, others less sure,\" Farage said. \"The police say it was a non-terror incident. Just as they said, the stabbing of an Army lieutenant colonel in uniform on the streets of Kent was a 'non-terror incident.' I just wonder if the truth is being withheld from us.\"\n\nFarage's post has similarly garnered more than a million views at the time of publishing.", "source": {"uri": "thedailybeast.com",
