were killed in a mass stabbing in Southport has taken to social media to ask people to \"stop the violence\".\n\nA crowd of men, many wearing masks and hoodies, were embroiled in a running battle with police officers outside a mosque in the Merseyside town on Tuesday evening .\n\nChants of \"English til I die\" were heard before the outbreak of the violence, in which at least 50 police officers were injured.\n\nTuesday evening's clashes came after false claims spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nSouthport stabbings latest: Farage accused of 'ramping up hatred'\n\nThe group descended on Southport as it was already reeling from the knife attack that left three children dead - with a peaceful vigil also held earlier in the evening.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were fatally stabbed outside a Taylor Swift-themed dance class on Monday.\n\nPolice have confirmed that a 17-year-old arrested over the attack was born in Wales.\n\nThe teenager, who has not been named because of his age, remains in custody having been arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder, and police have been granted more time to question him.\n\n'Stop the violence'\n\nThe mother of Elsie took to social media on Tuesday evening to ask people to \"stop the violence\" in Southport.\n\nShe said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic in these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nAs well as the three children who died, eight other youngsters suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured, police said.\n\n'Nothing better than Tommy Robinson in a suit'\n\nNigel Farage came under fire over claims he had \"whipped up\" rioters in Southport with the Reform UK leader branded \"nothing better than Tommy Robinson in a suit\".\n\nMr Farage doubled down on comments made on social media where he questioned \"whether the truth is being withheld from us\" following the attack.\n\nThe newly-elected MP has come in for strong criticism, including from Brendan Cox, husband of murdered MP Jo Cox.\n\nMr Cox told BBC Radio Four's Today programme Mr Farage's remarks made him \"nothing better than a Tommy Robinson in a suit\".\n\nHe added: \"It is beyond the pale to use a moment like this to spread your narrative and to spread your hatred, and we saw the results on Southport's streets last night.\"\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Click to subscribe to the Sky News Daily wherever you get your podcasts \ud83d\udc48\n\nBut Mr Farage defended his position and insisted he had \"merely expressed a sense of sadness and concern that is being felt by absolutely everybody I know - 'what the hell is going on?'\"\n\nWoman confronts rioters\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder.\n\nHe rang 999 after he spotted men trying to smash their way in on CCTV cameras from his home, five minutes away.\n\nMr Balasuryla said he was \"terrified\" when he thought they would set the property on fire, as there was a woman and daughter living in the flat above.\n\nBut he said he later found out that the woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them.\n\nRead more:\n\nThousands attend vigil as tributes paid to girls killed in attack\n\nPolice officers injured in disorder outside mosque\n\nHe added that local people had said they would defend his shop if necessary.\n\n\"It was terrifying last night,\" he said. \"But I feel safe again because people are here to protect us.\"\n\nLocals left to clean up\n\nOn Wednesday morning, dozens of residents were outside Southport mosque with brushes and shovels to clean up.\n\nFirefighters were also seen filling up buckets of water for the flowers left in tribute to the victims of the attack.\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, was among those helping.\n\nHe said: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night. It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire.\n\n\"But none of those people were the people of Southport. The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up.\n\n\"Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had a change of clothes. They just started to riot and do this.\"\n\nMore than 50 officers injured\n\nThe chairman of Merseyside Police Federation, Chris McGlade, said more than 50 officers had been hurt in the \"sustained and vicious attack\".\n\nHe added: \"Police officers are not robots. We are mothers and fathers. Sons and daughters. Husbands, wives and partners.\n\n\"We should be going home at the end of our shifts. {"uri": "8251566585", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:29:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:29:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:27:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.odt.co.nz/news/world/violent-clashes-after-children-killed-uk-stabbing-attack", "title": "Violent clashes after children killed in UK stabbing attack", "body": "The incident on Monday (local time) in Southport, a quiet seaside town north of Liverpool, has shocked the nation. Police have said it was not linked to terrorism and that the suspect was born in the UK.\n\nYet far-right groups have stoked speculation that the teenage suspect was involved with Islam, and police said Tuesday's violence erupted when several hundred people began to throw items at a mosque. Police linked the crowd to the English Defence League, a group which has sometimes staged violent demonstrations against Islam.\n\nPolice vehicles were damaged and set alight, officers were pelted by bricks and large garbage containers. One video posted online showed the crowd chanting \"we want our country back\".\n\nAway from the violence, hundreds had gathered for an emotional vigil to pay tribute to those killed in the attack, laying flowers and toys.\n\n\"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect,\" Prime Minister Keir Starmer said.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nA 17-year-old male is in police custody on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the bloody rampage at a \"Taylor Swift yoga and dance workshop\", a summer vacation event for children aged six to 11.\n\nWitnesses described the attack as being like a scene from a horror film. In addition to the three deaths, eight children suffered stab wounds. Five of them and two adults who had tried to protect them remain in a critical condition.\n\nThe police have said the motive remained unclear and have not given any details about the suspect, beyond saying he was born in Wales and lived in a village nearby.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" said Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nGoss and local politicians said those clashing with police involved many from outside the area, and the Liverpool Region Mosque Network said a minority of people were trying to use the incident to spread hatred.\n\n\"This evening we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protesters gathering outside,\" it said in a statement. \"This is causing further fear and anxiety within our communities,\"\n\nStarmer had earlier paid a sombre visit to the town to lay flowers, and King Charles and his family have expressed their horror.\n\nTaylor Swift 'completely in shock'\n\nUS singer Swift herself wrote on Instagram that she was \"just completely in shock\".\n\n\"These were just little kids at a dance class. I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families,\" she said.\n\nHer fans have raised more than 250,000 pounds ($NZ544,000)online to help families of the victims and for the hospital where some of the children were being treated.\n\nThe three girls who died in the attack were named as Bebe King, aged 6, 7-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, aged 9, whose parents are Portuguese.\n\n\"Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our Princess, like we said before to you, you're always our princess and no one would change that. Love from Your Hero Daddy and Mummy,\" Aguiar's family said in a statement.\n\nThere has been increasing concern at rising levels of stabbings and knife crime in Britain, and the Southport attack follows other recent similar, indiscriminate rampages.\n\n\"I'm absolutely determined that my government will get to grips with it,\" Starmer said.", "source": {"uri": "odt.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rioters clash with UK police after Southport stabbing", "body": "British police have clashed with a violent mob of far-right extremists outside a mosque in north-west England on Tuesday.\n\nThe disturbance erupted at the site of Monday's horrific attack on a Taylor Swift-themed dance party in Southport where three young girls were stabbed to death.\n\nIt has been understood the rioters belong to the English Defence League (EDL) and took to the streets fuelled by speculation surrounding the teenager arrested for the stabbing.\n\nPolice have said the assailant was born in Cardiff, Wales to Rwandan parents and had lived for years in a village about 5km from Southport.\n\nA false report had circulated online that the suspect was a recent immigrant who crossed the English Channel last week and was on an \"MI6 watchlist\".\n\nThe violence broke out after hundreds of people attended a peaceful vigil to mourn the victims injured and killed in the brutal stabbing.\n\nThe situation quickly deteriorated as the crowd near the mosque turned aggressive and set a police van ablaze, sending thick, black smoke into the sky.\n\nRioters chanted \"English til' I die\" and \"No surrender\" while throwing bottles and bins at officers.\n\nOne officer has suffered a suspected broken nose and police vehicles have been damaged and set alight, according to authorities.\n\nMerseyside Police Officer Alex Goss said: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody.\"\n\n\"Some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" the Assistance Chief Constable added.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nPolice arrested the boy on Monday after he allegedly attacked the girls at a Taylor Swift-themed dance and yoga workshop during their summer holiday.\n\nThe teenager, allegedly armed with a knife, entered the studio and began a vicious attack in which Alice Dasilva Aguiar, 9, Elsie Dot Stancombe, 7, and Bebe King, 6, were allegedly stabbed to death.\n\nEight children and two adults were also taken to hospital and have been receiving treatment for their injuries.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face,\" Mr Goss said.\n\n\"Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder... Our officers should not have to face this.\"\n\nThe stabbing incident has heightened concerns over rising knife crime in the UK, intensifying calls for stronger government action to address the {"uri": "8251940451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:19:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:19:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:17:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2024/07/31/southport-stabbing-latest-live-updates/", "title": "Southport attack latest: Victim's mother condemns violence", "body": "The mother of a victim in the Southport stabbing has condemned violence that broke out at a protest last night.\n\nA mob gathered outside a mosque on Tuesday following a knife attack on children attending a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club where three young girls were killed, with demonstrators throwing bricks, masonry and fireworks at officers.\n\nJenni Stancombe, the mother of seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe, who died on Monday, appealed on social media for the violence to end. She said: \"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\" Ms Stancombe added: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nA 17-year-old youth from the village of Banks, five miles away from Southport was arrested on Monday afternoon on suspicion of murder and attempted murder and remains in police custody. The violence broke out amid claims that the police were not telling the truth about the suspect's background and his motives, with rumours swirling on social media.\n\nEarlier, a vigil was held to remember the three girls who were killed with six-year-old Bebe King and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar also named as victims.\n\nFollow for the latest updates.\n\n8:15AM Southport riots 'appalling', says Labour housing minister\n\nMatthew Pennycook, a housing minister, labelled violent scenes in Southport overnight \"absolutely appalling\" and \"completely despicable\".\n\nThe Labour frontbencher told Sky News: \"We have had 22 officers now injured, seen reports of vehicles belonging to members of the public set on fire, bricks and fireworks thrown at a mosque.\n\n\"I think it is absolutely appalling if I am honest.\n\n\"The community in Southport is reeling from the horrific events two days ago. From what I can see they are trying to come together to support each other, to care for the families of the loved ones who have been killed and to have their space for them to process the trauma, to grieve, overshadowed by this violence and disorder I think is completely despicable.\"\n\n8:13AM Labour MP calls rioters 'utterly reprehensible'\n\nA Labour MP has called the rioters outside a mosque in Southport \"utterly reprehensible\".\n\nPatrick Hurley, the Labour MP for Southport, told BBC Radio 4 Today Programme: \"The town is reeling. You can imagine that yesterday was a very emotional day for so many people in Southport. We had a vigil with thousands of people paying their respects in a peaceful fashion and just having a space and a place where they can express their emotions.\"\n\nHe added: \"And then within an hour, an hour and a half, we also had this horrific riots. There's no other word to describe it. It was led by people from outside of town. These were thugs who got the train in. These were not people from Southport. They were using the deaths of three little kiddies for their own political purposes and to attack the very same first responders and the very same police who had been on the scene on Monday.\"\n\nMr Hurley added: \"There's no way to describe that other than to say it's utterly reprehensible and we must identify these people and make sure that the full force of the law is down against them.\"\n\n8:06AM Pictured: Aftermath of violent disorder outside mosque in Southport 8:00AM Councillor saw masked men arriving at scene\n\nCouncillor Mike Salmon, who saw the violence happening outside his home on Tuesday, told BBC Radio Merseyside several people arrived at the scene wearing \"masks and balaclavas\".\n\nHe said: \"A few hours ago there were lots of people arriving down my road. Many of them were wearing masks and balaclavas. They were all walking down the road and congregating on the corners. Within minutes I heard a loud bang, I think someone had thrown a brick at the mosque.\n\nHe added: \"And then they charged at the police. I was really really worried for the police, they needed more support.\"\n\n7:51AM Muslim Council of Britain will stand against 'forces of hatred' following mosque riot\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain (MCB) says it will \"stand firm\" against \"forces of hatred and division\" in the wake of a riot outside a Southport mosque.\n\nThe MCB paid tribute to the three young girls killed in Southport on Monday, before condemning \"shocking scenes of far-right rioters running amok outside a mosque\".\n\nIt said Islamaphobic backlash began with a false rumour on the internet which was then stoked by misinformation from a Russian news site, which wrongfully associated the crime with Muslims.\n\nZara Mohammed, the MCB secretary-general, said: \"At a time of great tragedy, loss, and mourning, we must stand firm against the cynical forces of hatred and division. This does not represent our diverse Britain and the people of Southport.\n\n\"The Government must address the increasing rise of violent far-right extremism targeting Muslim communities. More must be done to tackle Islamophobia and offer reassurance at this time.\"\n\nShe added: \"We commend the authorities for their swift action, and our prayers are with the mosque, the families of the victims of yesterday's attack, and the local community.\"\n\n7:45AM Labour minister condemns 'absolutely appalling' violence outside mosque in Southport\n\nA Labour frontbencher has condemned the \"absolutely appalling\" violence in Southport last night.\n\nA mob gathered outside a mosque and hurled bricks, masonry and fireworks at police officers, with 39 officers injured and 27 taken to hospital.\n\nMatthew Pennycock, the housing minister, told Times Radio: \"The people of Southport are obviously reeling from the horror that was inflicted upon them two days ago, they're doing their best to pull together, to have the process the space they need.\n\n\"To have that overshadowed by the violence and disorder is sickening... They should feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nAsked what message he would send to those minded to take part in further violence, Mr Pennycock said: \"Well, not to do it, to give the community the space to grieve, to process the trauma they've experienced. I think the community needs that space, it doesn't need violence and disorder, and from what we can tell lots of people who don't even live in Merseyside coming in and trying to stir up trouble.\"\n\n7:43AM Southport attack latest updates\n\nWelcome to our live blog where we will be bringing you the latest updates following the knife attack in Southport on Monday.\n\nFollow this story for the latest news.", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Telegraph"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dominic_penna@telegraph.co.uk", "name": "Dominic Penna", "type": Unsubstantiated claims further said that he had shouted 'Allahu akbar'.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper slammed online brutes for peddling misinformation that risked undermining the criminal investigation and was disrespectful to the dead children's families. Scotland's former first minister Humza Yousaf called for the English Defence League (EDL) to be proscribed under terrorism laws.\n\nThe windows of the Southport Islamic Society Mosque lay shattered this morning after yobs wielding bricks smashed the panes of glass, shouting 'English till I die' as they wrecked a path of destruction.\n\nIt came just after a peaceful vigil last night where thousands of mourners had gathered to remember six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar, who were killed in the bloodbath.\n\nAnd today used the Southport stabbing to 'whip up hatred'.\n\nMs Spurrell told ITV's Good Morning Britain that the 'violence and abuse' towards police officers on Tuesday was 'utterly abhorrent and completely unacceptable'.\n\nShe said: '(Merseyside Police) will be reviewing the footage of exactly who was there last night, they have been monitoring the online activity as well, trying to understand who was doing what.\n\n'They have said that they believe it was members of the English Defence League (EDL), they don't believe it was individuals from the local area.\n\n'There is a strong feeling that there are individuals like the EDL, who have been using this incredibly tragic event to whip up hatred, incite violence, and that's the result of what we saw last night.\n\n'There is a strong sense that this is people who have come from out-of-area simply to create violence and abuse against officers and towards a community who are not in any way accepting of this behaviour.'\n\nPeople living near the violence in the seaside town today spoke of their terror as rioting and fireballs exploded outside their doors.\n\nThugs tore garden walls down brick by brick as they used the stones as ammunition to hurl at police officers, setting fire to wheelie bins in a rampage near the mosque.\n\nAround 200 protesters were seen taking to the streets. Police believe many were EDL supporters\n\nWheelie bins that appear to have been melted lie in the road as the street is cleaned up around them\n\nSouthport burns: A street near a mosque goes up in flames as violent thugs took to the streets last night\n\nThree girls were killed in a bloody rampage on Hart Street on Monday. On Tuesday, a vigil was held for the victims on Lord Street. While it was going on, a man with a flick knife was arrested on Eastbank Street. On St Luke's Road, riots erupted outside a mosque - also on Tuesday\n\nRead More Calls for calm as Southport locals say rioters have 'no respect for a town that's grieving'\n\nOne terrified family - whose parents are originally immigrants from India - told the Mail that they feared their ethnicity would make them a target and locked their doors, turned their lights out and hid inside.\n\nIt came after a British conspiracy theorist had filmed the crime scene, calling for emergency military rule and mass deportations in a YouTube video that amassed 30,000 views in just two hours, The Guardian reports.\n\nThe newspaper revealed that the source of a false name given for the attacker was a website called Channel 3 Now, whose content includes potentially AI-generated US and UK news, before being shared on social media.\n\nPatrick Hurley, the MP for Southport slammed 'beered-up thugs' who threw bricks towards a mosque after misinformation was spread on social media about the identity of the attacker.\n\nHe told Times Radio: 'Because of the propaganda and the lies that were being spread around on social media from within minutes of the news breaking on Monday afternoon about the tragic incident.\n\n'We'd had all sorts of lies being spread and misinformation being spread about the alleged perpetrator and some people with the best of intentions then they tried to rebut this, they tried to argue back, but all that happens is you're just amplifying people's false messaging.'\n\nHe added to BBC Radio 4's Today programme: 'Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\n\n'Not least these beered-up thugs who have descended on the town last night intent on causing trouble.\n\nBroken glass amongst other items is pictured on Sussex road, after violent protest following a vigil for victims\n\nThe flowers appeared to be gratefully recieved, as it was given to the Mosque this morning\n\nA hanging basket of purple flowers were delivered to the religious centre, which became a focus for last night's violence\n\nRead More Sir Keir Starmer is heckled on his visit to Southport and asked 'how many more children will die?\n\n'We all have to stand against that and Southport will not accept this. Southport will unite against this sort of thing.'\n\nBacking the MP, Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner slammed the 'disgraceful' rioting in Southport and 'disrespectful' social media theories as she urged people to allow the police to establish the facts.\n\nSpeaking on ITV's This Morning, the Deputy Prime Minister said: 'I think there's been a couple of instances recently where, especially particularly online, where theories and things are whipped up, whereas actually it turns out to be not true or not the full picture.\n\n'And I think there's a culture now where people want to instantly get the facts, but actually it's important that police and those people that are doing the work are able to carry out that work. And it's important for justice as well, because we have law and order in the UK, and it's important that those authorities are able to establish the facts and then to be able to bring those forward.\n\n'But speculation and some of the untruths that have been put around social media, not only is that creating tensions and fear in the community, but it's disrespectful to family who maybe want those answers that haven't got those answers.'\n\nShe added that it is 'really unhelpful for the police' and 'my plea is that we all need to step back and just wait and then that information will come but allow the police to do their work'.\n\nITV's UK Editor also revealed the shocking threat of the thugs in a video which showed his team being followed by hooded yobs yelling abuse at him, and saying the deaths were 'all your fault'.\n\nPaul Brand told Good Morning Britain: 'It's difficult for us to engage with this crowd - they don't want us to be there because if they're captured on camera their criminality may well get them into trouble.'\n\nThe riots came barely an hour after thousands of mourners gathered for a vigil at the Atkinson in Southport\n\nIn stark contrast to the riots on the streets, there was a sense of tranquility at the site of the vigil as night fell\n\nThe car outside the religious building has been smashed following the rioting last night\n\nHundreds of protesters, many masked, battled with riot police officers\n\nRead More Moment Southport rioter gets hit in the head with a brick... and then again where it REALLY hurts\n\nHe added: 'These people had come already masked up. They had come with their hoods up. They wanted, in my view, a fight as they arrived into the town.'\n\nThe Malakar family live in Sussex Road where the rioting was going on. The parents were originally immigrants from India and their three children were born in the UK.\n\nUniversity student Raj Malakar, 19, told the Mail: 'It was crazy to witness everything. I don't see any justifiable point at what they were doing. It was heinous.\n\n'It was frightening, we were fearful for our own safety. Due to our ethnic origin we closed all the blinds, turned the lights off and hid ourselves inside. We were all very shaken and my mum didn't sleep last night. We didn't know what would happen to us.\n\n'I came home from university expecting to relax for three months and this happens.'\n\nFootage shows thugs smashing their front garden wall and using the bricks as ammunition.\n\nA few doors down the road Denise Mace, 51, and her chef husband Graham, 52, watched from inside also fearing for their safety and worrying their car parked outside would be smashed up.\n\nAs the police were forced back they quietly pleaded with officers to hold their ground as they filmed from an upstairs window.\n\nEngland flags were on display at the anti-Muslim demonstration in Southport\n\nSmoke is seen billowing from a police van which was set ablaze. The mosque is seen on the right\n\nTensions flared in Southport last night, with police saying supporters of the EDL were targeting the mosque\n\nRead MoreBREAKING NEWS Revealed: Hero window cleaner tackled Southport stabber attacking girls in Taylor Swift dance class\n\n'It was terrifying, absolutely horrendous. We didn't know if they would come into our house. We were very lucky compared to other people. We were scared they would break in.'\n\nMrs Mace, a care consultant, said the local imam used to live next door and was a 'beautiful man.'\n\n'He would bring us food at Ramadan,' she said. 'This is not Southport, it was by senseless yobs who have come here for a fight.\n\nPensioner May Small, 71, and husband David, 73, watched on helplessly as they yobs broke a neighbour's wall, took bricks from their wall and attacked police.\n\nShe said she was alerted by a commotion and then saw the rioters just 'piling in.'\n\n'It was frightening. They were throwing bottles, taking down walls and throwing bricks. I was stood outside watching and then backed away into my doorway. They even came down the path looking for missiles and I told them to clear off.'\n\nShe said she has lived in the street for 'many years' and there has never been trouble before.'\n\nThe pensioner added defiantly: 'I would like to kick their arse, but you can't can you?'\n\nThe aftermath of the riots, where police vans were burnt and rocks were launched\n\nRioters wearing masks launch missiles towards police officers in Southport\n\nProtesters cheer as they launch bins at riot police vans amid ugly scenes in Southport\n\nRead More How day of unimaginable tragedy unfolded on the streets of Southport\n\nChanaka Balasuriya, 48, was forced to watch on CCTV as rioters broke into his corner shop and looted the contents.\n\nA married father-of-two who runs the Windsor Mini Mart, he said the yobs smashed his windows, damaged his shutters and stole thousands of pounds of stock, which is not covered by insurance.\n\nHe had shut the shop for an hour while the vigil was going on in the town out of 'respect for the three girls' who died.\n\nMr Balauriya reopened the shop after 7pm but decided to close his business early to go home as strangers were arriving in force.\n\n'A neighbour came over and told me 'don't stay, go.''\n\nOver the next few hours he monitored his internal and external CCTV cameras as the rioters caused chaos.\n\n'There was hundreds and hundreds of people and they got metal poles to use as weapons,' he said.\n\nWhen the yobs began to smash his shop door down he called 999 but police were unable to stop them. 'They couldn't come closer,' he said.\n\nA wounded police officer with blood pouring down his head after being caught up in the riots\n\nRioters were seen jumping on police vans as things got out of control\n\nSmoke billows behind riot police officers amid riots in the seaside town\n\nA traffic cone is hurled by a masked man at a police officer near to a mosque in Southport\n\nRead More Pictured: Heroic businessman, 63, who was stabbed in the leg trying to disarm Southport knifeman\n\n'About 60 or 70 people forced their way into the shop. They mainly took all the expensive stuff like cigarettes and alcohol. Luckily they didn't damage my fridges.\n\n'It's pretty awful we have a very nice, quiet area and everyone is coming in to help.'\n\nAn added blow is that he had no insurance to cover the cost of the damage.\n\n'I lived in London for years and moved here to start this business four years ago. I have no insurance.'\n\nHe said he only restocked the shop the day before as he had been on holiday and returned to 'do shopping.' {"uri": "8251500360", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:03:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:03:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:02:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/3272552/violent-crowd-clashes-uk-police-after-young-girls-killed-stabbing", "title": "Violent crowd clashes with UK police after young girls killed in stabbing", "body": "Police said violence erupted in Southport when people began to throw items at a mosque amid speculation the suspect is involved with Islam\n\nA large crowd of anti-Muslim protesters clashed with police on Tuesday in a northern English town where three girls were stabbed to death and five other children critically wounded during an attack on a Taylor Swift-themed event on Monday.\n\nThe horrific stabbing incident in Southport, a quiet seaside town north of Liverpool, has shocked the nation. Police have said it was not linked to terrorism and that the suspect was born in the UK.\n\nYet far-right groups have stoked speculation that the teenage suspect was involved with Islam, and police said Tuesday\u2019s violence erupted when several hundred people began to throw items at a mosque.\n\nPolice linked the crowd to the English Defence League, a group which has sometimes staged violent demonstrations against Islam.\n\nPolice vehicles were damaged and set alight, officers were pelted by bricks and large garbage containers. One video posted online showed the crowd chanting \u201cwe want our country back\u201d.\n\nAway from the violence, hundreds had gathered for an emotional vigil to pay tribute to those killed in the attack, laying flowers and toys.\n\n\u201cThe people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect,\u201d Prime Minister Keir Starmer said.\n\n\u201cThose who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law.\u201d\n\nA 17-year-old male is currently in police custody on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the bloody rampage at a \u201cTaylor Swift yoga and dance workshop\u201d, a summer holiday event for children aged 6 to 11.This evening we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protesters gathering outside. This is causing further fear and anxiety within our communitiesMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss\n\nWitnesses described the attack as being like a scene from a horror film. In addition to the three deaths, eight children suffered stab wounds. Five of them and two adults who had tried to protect them remain in a critical condition.\n\nThe police have said the motive remained unclear and have not given any details about the suspect, beyond saying he was born in Wales and lived in a village nearby.\n\n\u201cThere has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\u201d said Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss.\n\n\u201cWe have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\u201d\n\nGoss and local politicians said those clashing with police involved many from outside the area, and the Liverpool Region Mosque Network said a minority of people were trying to use the incident to spread hatred.\n\n\u201cThis evening we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protesters gathering outside,\u201d it said in a statement. \u201cThis is causing further fear and anxiety within our communities.\u201d\n\nStarmer had earlier paid a sombre visit to the town to lay flowers, and King Charles and his family have expressed their horror.\n\nUS singer Swift herself wrote on Instagram that she was \u201cjust completely in shock\u201d.\n\n\u201cThese were just little kids at a dance class. I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families,\u201d she said.\n\nHer fans have raised more than \u00a3250,000 (US$320,850) online to help families of the victims and for the hospital where some of the children were being treated.\n\nThe three girls who died in the attack were named as Bebe King, aged six, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, aged nine, whose parents are Portuguese.\n\n\u201cKeep smiling and dancing like you love to do our Princess, like we said before to you, you\u2019re always our princess and no one would change that. Love from Your Hero Daddy and Mummy,\u201d Aguiar\u2019s family said in a statement.\n\nThere has been increasing concern at rising levels of stabbings and knife crime in Britain, and the Southport attack follows other recent similar, indiscriminate rampages.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m absolutely determined that my government will get to grips with it,\u201d Starmer said.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", {"uri": "8252198441", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:03:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:03:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:02:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/it-like-war-scene-streets-29647628", "title": "\"It was like a war scene on the streets of Southport - it's horrendous\"", "body": "Violent protests and riots on the streets of Southport in the wake of a stabbing have been likened to a 'war scene'.\n\nDisorder broke out on the streets of the seaside town last night (Tuesday), close to the scene of a brutal stabbing at a children's dance event on Monday. Chaos erupted after a vigil was held to commemorate the victims of the knife attack, as well as those who remain in a critical condition in hospital.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine; Bebe King, six; and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, have all been named as victims. A 17-year-old boy - who cannot be named for legal reasons because of his age - remains in custody accused of murder and attempted murder.\n\nREAD NEXT: Devastated parents are 'not speaking, only crying' after little girl, 9, killed in Southport stabbing\n\nMerseyside Police said the disorder began last night when 'a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League' - started to throw items such as bricks towards a mosque. Officers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched at them and police vehicles were damaged and set on fire.\n\nIn a post on social media, the force said shops had been 'broken into and looted', adding that 'those responsible will be brought to justice'. 27 police officers taken to hospital amid the chaotic scenes, with 12 others being treated and discharged at the scene, the North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nThis morning, dozens of local residents have turned outside the mosque with brushes and shovels to help with the clean-up operation. Norman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, who was helping at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road, said it was partly in response to a social media plea he put out after witnessing the violence on Tuesday evening.\n\nHe described the riots as being 'like a war scene' as he 'people came out of town to cause mayhem'. Mr Wallis said: \"It's horrendous what those hooligans have done last night.\n\n\"It was like a war scene. People from out of town just causing absolute mayhem.\n\n\"People in hoods climbing up lampposts, throwing bricks, they set a police car on fire. But none of those people were the people of Southport.\n\n\"The people of Southport are the ones here today cleaning the mess up. Those people from out of town - they came in in buses and cars and had change of clothes.\n\n\"They just started to riot and do this.\" He added: \"There are hundreds of people who have responded, and we've ended up with lots of people down here today, all from the local community and helping with the fantastic clean-up.\"\n\nShop owner Chanaka Balasuryla said the Southport community has rallied around him since his store was looted during the disorder. Mr Balasuryla said he called 999 after spotting men trying to smash their way in, on the CCTV camera from his home five minutes away.\n\nHe said he was 'terrified' when he thought they would set fire to the premises because there is a woman and her daughter living in a flat above. He said he later found out that the woman confronted the raiders, telling them it was her shop in an attempt to stop them.\n\nMr Balasuryla said: \"I got a couple of hours' sleep and then got a phone call saying 'You need to come down, there's lots of people waiting to help.\"\n\nHe added that local people had said they would defend his shop if necessary. He said: \"It was terrifying last night. But I feel safe again because people are here to protect us.\"\n\nPatrick Hurley, the Labour MP for Southport, said that 'beered-up thugs' were behind the riots. Speaking on the boy who was arrested after the stabbing on Monday, he said: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\n\n\"Not least these beered-up thugs who have descended on the town last night intent on causing trouble. We all have to stand against that and Southport will not accept this.\n\n\"Southport will unite against this sort of thing.\" He added: \"These were thugs who got the train in, these were not the people from Southport.\n\n\"They were using the horrific incident on Monday, the deaths of three little kiddies, for their own political purposes and actually to attack the very same first responders and the very same police, who had been on the scene on Monday, were then being pelted with bricks the day after by these thugs.\n\n\"There's no way to describe that other than to say it's utterly reprehensible and we must identify these people and make sure that the full force of the law is down against them. These people are utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children and utterly disrespecting the town.\"\n\nThe stabbing suspect, who remains in custody, was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, police said. Merseyside Police said more than 50 police officers were injured in a \"sustained and brutal attack\".\n\nStermer said on X that the protesters had \"hijacked\" a memorial dedicated to the victims of Monday's horrific attack at a children's dance and \"insulted a community in mourning\".\n\n\"They will feel the severity of the law\", the Prime Minister said.\n\nMerseyside police said the officers also suffered fractures, wounds, a suspected fractured nose and concussion. Three police dogs were also injured.\n\nPolice officers were given greater powers to detain and search as legal orders were introduced in the city to prevent a repeat of the riots.\n\n\"This is no way {"uri": "8252043024", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:26:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:26:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:25:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/how-did-a-horrific-attack-lead-to-a-violent-protest-in-southport_uk_66a9d941e4b0b88f4d8b420a", "title": "How Did A Horrific Attack On Young Children Lead To A Violent Protest In Southport? Here's What You Need To Know", "body": "A vigil for the three girls who died on Monday was hijacked by far-right activists.\n\nAfter a horrific attack on a children's dance class in Southport on Monday, far-right activists started a violent protest outside a local mosque the following night.\n\nWhen a knifeman entered a Taylor Swift-themed yoga and dance session two days ago, three girls were killed and eight others left in a critical condition.\n\nA vigil held for the deceased in Southport was then hijacked by far-right figures who soon started to attack the police and the surrounding areas, shouting offensive phrases.\n\nHere's a chronological look at what we know so far about these two horrendous incidents.\n\nOn Monday night, two girls died from stab wounds - six-year-old Bebe King and seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe. A third child, nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar, also died in hospital in the early hours of Tuesday morning.\n\nEight other children suffered from stab wounds in the attack, five of whom went into a critical condition.\n\nTwo adults were also injured, and are in a critical condition.\n\nThe attacker was quickly arrested and a knife was seized by the police.\n\nThe only detail released to the public about the suspect so far is that he is a 17-year-old from Banks village in Lancashire, and born in Cardiff - he cannot be named due to his age.\n\nHe has no known links to Islam and his motive remains unclear.\n\nPM Keir Starmer went to Stockport on Tuesday to join the vigil, but he was soon heckled by one woman for not being able to help the situation.\n\nHome secretary Yvette Cooper also called for the public to avoid \"unhelpful\" speculation around the attack on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nShe said: \"This is about children and their families who will be grieving, and the many other children who were involved yesterday who will be facing great trauma as well.\"\n\nThe incident sparked a response from the Royal Family, too.\n\nKing Charles and Queen Camilla released a statement saying they were \"profoundly shocked\" by the \"utterly horrific incident\".\n\nThe Prince and Princess of Wales also wrote on X, sending \"love, thoughts and prayers to all those involved in this horrid and heinous attack\".\n\nTaylor Swift also responded via her Instagram story, writing that the \"horror of yesterday's attack in Southport is washing over me continuously\".\n\nShe said: \"I'm just completely in shock. The loss of life and innocence and the horrendous trauma inflicted on everyone who was there, the families, and first responders.\n\n\"These were just little kids at a dance class. I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families.\"\n\nFns of the singer have since raised more than \u00a3272,000 on a Just Giving page to donate to Alder Hey Children's Hospital.\n\nDespite calls for calm, a protest erupted in Southport on Tuesday night.\n\nHundreds of far-right activists, potentially members of the English Defence League, threw bricks at police, set vehicles on fire and attacked a mosque.\n\nThe ambulance service says 39 people were treated after the protest - all of whom were police officers - 27 were taken to hospital, and 12 were treated and discharged at the scene.\n\nInjuries included fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and a concussion.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured having been hit by the bricks or burnt by the fires.\n\nLocal police say many of the crowd may not actually live in the Merseyside area.\n\nIt's believed some people may have been fired up by baseless claims on social media that the suspect had links to Islam, with false accusations and incorrect names of the attacker.\n\nThe local community has already condemned the protest - Southport MP Patrick Hurley said the rioters must face the \"full force of the law\".\n\nHe told the Today programme people \"were using the horrific incident on Monday, the deaths of three little kiddies, for their own political purposes\".\n\nHe said the protesters were \"beered-up thugs\", adding: \"Even if [the suspect] turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all\".\n\nOfficers were granted enhanced stop and search powers to stop any similar unrest breaking out again.\n\nSocial media companies are facing pressure to police content after misinformation and conspiracy theories took root on their platforms, helping to galvanise the far-right protests.\n\nThe prime minister has said the rioters will feel the \"full force of the law\", saying they had \"hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery\" and \"insulted the community as it grieves\".\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain's secretary general, Zara Mohammed, said: \"At a time of great tragedy, loss and mourning, we must stand firm against the cynical forces of hatred and division.\n\n\"This does not represent our diverse Britain and the people of Southport.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251946774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:22:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:22:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:22:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/gallery/southport-riot-locals-join-clean-33363168", "title": "Locals join clean-up operation after EDL chaos with 40 police injured", "body": "Images show the local community in Southport coming together in a major clean-up operation after bricks were thrown and vehicles set on fire in a night of violence\n\nResidents were up all night trying to clear their streets after rioters turned them into a \"war zone.\"\n\nA road full of rubble and rubbish could be seen in Southport with riot police watching on following the violence. Nearly 40 police officers sustained injuries and 27 were taken to hospital as chaos broke out on Tuesday as protestors met up following the frenzied stabbing attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nAfter calm was finally restored the extent of the chaos could be seen with rubbish burnt out vehicles and smashed windows but locals have been quick to get involved in the clean-up. One local said: \"At least the bin men don't have to empty the bins today - they've all been burnt.\"\n\nAndy Southwood, 54,local businessman, said: \"I didn't sleep much last night. In half an hour it exploded. It was chaotic. Mainly young kids with masks. It looked organised to me. It's crazy. It's a massive stain on the town.\" But he pointed out locals were up through the night cleaning up. \"Random people are coming out with shovels and spades to help clean up. That's the true spirit of Southport,\" he added.\n\nMerseyside Police said eight officers suffered serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion. Other officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThree police dogs were also injured in the chaos, with Zoe and Ike suffering leg injuries from bricks thrown at them. A third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nOne brave woman stood shaking crying holding up a 'hope not hate' poster despite being shouted at by the mob for being there. Several fires were started including what appeared to be an attempt to set fire to the mosque as burning bins and fence panelling erupted near the back entrance.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities. North West Ambulance Service said of the injured police officers: \"We treated 39 patients in total, all of which were police officers. 27 were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene.\"\n\nThe violence followed the stabbings of Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, at the Taylor Swift-themed holiday club. Eight other children were also stabbed, with five children and two adults left in a critical condition. officers injured in Southport violent disorder", "body": "Injuries included fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, a concussion, and other head and serious facial injuries.\n\nMerseyside Police have said 22 officers were hurt in Tuesday's Southport riots, with eight suffering serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries, and serious facial injuries, and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nA third dog, Quga - who was bitten, strangled and kicked by an offender at the beginning of this month - suffered burns to her back leg, the force said.\n\nMerseyside Police said those involved in the unrest - who they believe included supporters of the English Defence League - set alight cars belonging to members of the public, threw bricks at the local mosque, damaged a local convenience store, and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nExtra police will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area running from 7.54pm on Tuesday, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nMerseyside police said these powers would not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business.\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, Alex Goss, said: \"Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the mosque car park.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nMerseyside Police urged anyone with information on the disorder or who has video footage of those involved to contact the force.\n\nThe rioting followed a frenzied stabbing {"uri": "2024-07-439418002", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:03:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:03:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:17:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/dozens-of-uk-police-hurt-in-clashes-after-three-girls-killed-in-stabbing-attack/2200437/", "title": "Dozens of UK police hurt in clashes after three girls killed in stabbing attack", "body": "As well as killing three girls aged six to nine, Monday's horrific incident in the normally quiet town in northwest England saw eight other children stabbed. Five remain in a critical condition in hospital along with two adults who tried to protect them.\n\nPolice, who have arrested an unnamed 17-year-old male on suspicion of murder and attempted murder, have said the incident was not terrorism-related and sought to quash speculation on the suspect's origins, saying he was born in Britain.\n\nThat did not prevent protesters, from what Merseyside police believed were tied to the right-wing anti-Islam group, the English Defence League, from targeting a mosque in the town and attacking police who tried to stop them.\n\nPoliticians and police said most of those taking part in the violence were not from the area, and said the clashes detracted from a large vigil attended by thousands to pay tribute to the young victims.\n\n'THUGS FROM OUT OF TOWN'\n\nA total of 39 officers were treated for injuries, including 27 who were taken to hospital, North West Ambulance Service said on Wednesday. Police said eight had suffered serious injuries including fractures, and three police dogs were also hurt.\n\n\"Offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said in a statement.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, streets in Southport were littered with bricks from broken walls, smashed bottles, and large garbage bins - which had been hurled at police the night before - and their contents. Charred tarmac bore witness to the police vehicles which had been set alight.\n\n\"What I saw last night was absolutely appalling ... It was devastating and it's kind of taken away from actually what's gone on, which is the tragedy of those deaths,\" local resident David Burgess told Sky News.\n\n\"This is about the girls and the tragedy which has happened - don't make it about this,\" he said, referring to the clashes. \"This isn't Southport. This isn't the community.\"\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer and senior ministers blamed \"violent thugs from out town\", for the trouble.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law,\" Starmer said.\n\nMeanwhile, Taylor Swift's fans have so far raised more than 270,000 pounds ($346,000) to help families of the victims and for the hospital where some of the children were being treated.\n\n($1 = 0.7795 pounds)\n\n(Reporting by Sachin Ravikumar; writing by Michael Holden; Editing by Bernadette Baum)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", More info\n\nIn the wake of the horrific violence that saw three young children tragically killed at a Taylor Swift dance club in Southport on Monday, English Defence League rioters have taken over the streets near the incident, setting fires, throwing bricks, and attacking the police officers.\n\nYesterday, emergency service workers rushed to the horrifying scene at the dance club, arrested the attacker, and tried to save the lives of the more than a dozen young children who were injured in the knife attack. Today, as residents in the area report having their garden walls broken down by rioters, Liverpool's Mayor Steve Rotheram blasted the violent crowd for attacking \"the very people who ran towards the danger yesterday.\"\n\nThe violent crowd hurled residents' wheelie bins at police and attacked a nearby mosque, following unsubstantiated claims that the 17-year-old attacker was a Muslim. Shortly before a police vehicle was set on fire, Merseyside Police revealed that the suspect was born in Cardiff and moved to Southport 11 years ago, but due to age-related reporting restrictions, they cannot be identified.\n\nREAD MORE: Large disorder breaks out next to mosque after vigil for Southport knife victims\n\nOfficers at the scene equipped helmets and riot gear, with stones and bottles launched at them and police riot vans attacked. One was set on fire, while multiple officers are said to have been injured.\n\nLiverpool Echo and Manchester Evening News reporters at the scene reported balaclava-clad thugs breaking down garden walls for bricks, as well as widespread drinking and Islamophobic chants.\n\nFar from the violent crowds, thousands in Southport paid their respects to the young children who were killed in the shocking attack. Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer, who laid flowers near to the scene, personally thanked the emergency services and members of the public who risked their lives during the incident.\n\nMeanwhile, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper has called the rioters \"thugs\" and condemned their actions, while calling for \"respect\" for a community in grief. Send them back! Fight for our kids! Let's stand together!\"\n\nThe disgraceful scenes came after police condemned false rumours that the 17-year-old suspect in custody on suspicion of murder over the deadly attack in the town on Monday was an asylum seeker who came to Britain on a small boat.\n\nThey stressed that he was born in Cardiff and that his parents came to the UK from Rwanda.\n\nTensions had been rising all day, with a visit to the scene by Sir Keir Starmer marred by shouts of \"Disgrace!\" and \"You should be ashamed of yourself, killing our kids!\"\n\nOne woman at the riot said the disorder was because the knife man who attacked the children \"was a Muslim\".\n\nShe said: \"We are saying enough is enough. Why are they not stopping the migrants coming in? \"How many more children will be killed because they are letting them all in? They should be at the borders stopping them.\"\n\nThe furious mob tore down garden walls to use the bricks as missiles to pelt police.\n\nBricks were also thrown at the mosque and wheelie bins were hurled.\n\nSome thugs threw smoke bombs, with men wearing caps and shorts charging at outnumbered officers.\n\nScores of riot vans and patrol cars raced to the scene and a police helicopter hovered overhead as the violence spread out of control, with smoke pouring into the darkening skies.\n\nMerseyside Police's assistant chief constable Alex Goss said last night: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\n\n\"Yesterday our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\"\n\nThe appalling scenes came after the Prime Minister's official spokesman was asked whether he would appeal for calm before the planned far-Right rally.\n\nHe replied: \"Of course, people should listen to the police, they should not do anything that is going to make the police's job harder to manage the situation, to conduct their investigations.\"\n\nMerseyside Police yesterday issued a warning after an \"incorrect\" name for the alleged Southport attacker was widely circulated online.\n\nInaccurate posts by social media sleuths about the identity of the perpetrator have received millions of views and engagements. Downing Street also warned against \"unhelpful\" speculation amid concerns that misreporting online could inflame tensions.\n\nOfficers should be given the space to investigate the case without people guessing at the possible motive or circumstances, No 10 said.\n\nSunder Katwala, director of the think-tank British Future, said a bogus news channel seemed to have invented a fake name for the suspect and run a false story that was shared online.\n\nPolice have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related.\n\nEarlier yesterday, the Home Secretary called for social media firms to \"take some responsibility\" for inflammatory misinformation being spread online about the suspect.\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your {"uri": "8251428968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:33:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:33:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:32:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/uk-far-right-attacks-southport-mosque-after-misinformation-campaign", "title": "UK: Anti-Muslim mob attacks Southport mosque after misinformation campaign", "body": "A police van is set on fire as people chanting anti-Muslim slogans clash with police on 30 July, 2024 (Roland Lloyd Parry/AFP)\n\nA far-right mob chanting \"English till I die\" clashed with police outside a mosque in the UK town of Southport on Tuesday, after a misinformation campaign claimed that the 17-year-old who killed three children at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class was a Muslim.\n\nHundreds of men covering their faces converged outside the Southport Islamic Society Mosque late on Tuesday, barely an hour after thousands gathered nearby for a vigil to remember the victims of Monday's attack.\n\nScores of masked men could be seen hurling plant pots, bricks and empty bins at riot police, shortly before they set a police van on fire. According to the BBC, some of the mosque's windows were smashed in the process.\n\nMerseyside Police condemned the violence and said one of their officers had suffered a suspected broken nose. Photos and videos posted on social media showed several riot police officers with cuts and grazes to their faces following the clashes with the far-right mob.\n\n\"At around 7.45pm, a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League - began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road in Southport,\" the force said.\n\n\"Officers who are deployed are currently dealing with criminal behaviour and violence with bottles and wheelie bins being thrown at them.\"\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were all fatally stabbed in Monday's attack, whilst eight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in a critical condition, alongside two adults who were also critically injured.\n\nBBC News reported late on Tuesday that the 17-year-old suspect was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents and had moved to the Southport area in 2013. Because the suspect is under 18 he cannot be legally identified.\n\nPolice have provided no details except that he was born in the UK. The Sun newspaper reported that he was born in Cardiff in 2006 after his parents, who are Christian, moved from Rwanda.\n\nShortly after the violence began, far-right leader Tommy Robinson said the violent mob was \"justified\" in their actions and said they were driven by concerns over immigration.\n\nIn an expletive-laden rant posted on X, formerly known as Twitter, Robinson said: \"Before anyone starts condemning the angry English men up in Southport, ask yourselves this, what do you fucking expect them to do. Don't call them hooligans - they're justified in their anger.\"\n\nRobinson fled the UK on Sunday to \"put himself beyond the reach of [UK] authorities\" where he was due to be in court over alleged contempt proceedings.\n\nHis words appeared to refer to a rumour widely circulated on social media that the suspect arrested for the stabbing is from Syria.\n\nSeveral major social media accounts, including influencer Andrew Tate, also peddled the false claim the attacker was an illegal immigrant.\n\nYvette Cooper, the Home Secretary, had earlier warned against using the killing of three schoolgirls to \"stir up division\" and spread misinformation online.\n\n\"Above all, this is about young children,\" she said. \"This is about children and their families who will be grieving, and the many other children who were involved yesterday who will be facing great trauma as well.\"\n\nIn a statement on its Facebook page, made well before the violence erupted, the Southport Islamic Society Mosque posted that they were \"truly shocked and saddened\" about Monday's attack.", "source": {"uri": "middleeasteye.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Middle East Eye"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-07-439426106", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:10:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:10:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:04:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.nme.com/news/music/far-right-protestors-descend-on-southport-after-knife-attack-one-goes-viral-for-taking-rock-to-testicles-3779628", "title": "Far-right protestors descend on Southport after knife attack, one goes viral for taking rock to testicles", "body": "It comes after three children were killed during a mass stabbing at a Taylor Swift-themed event\n\nFar-right protestors have descended on Southport, following a mass stabbing at a Swift-themed event.\n\nThe far-right protestors - believed to be supporters of the far-right English Defence League - took to the streets of Southport yesterday (July 30), where they clashed with police and disrupted a peaceful vigil held for the victims of a recent attack.\n\nIt comes after three children were killed in a knife attack that took place at a Swift-themed dance and yoga workshop on Hart Street on Monday (July 29). As reported by Sky News, three of the victims - six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe, and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar - sadly passed, while five other children and two adults remain in critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old male was arrested on suspicion of murder and remains in custody. According to police, he is originally from Cardiff and lived in the village of Banks close to Southport in Merseyside, England.\n\nThe stabbing is currently believed to be an isolated incident, and it is not being treated as terror-related. Police are not looking for other suspects in connection with the attack. However, the motivation for the incident is currently \"unclear\".\n\nTo pay respects to the victims, a peaceful vigil was held in the seaside town, with hundreds arriving to lay wreaths, candles and toys in tribute to the three children who died in the attack.\n\nThings soon turned violent, however, when the protestors took to the streets - throwing bricks at local mosques, clashing with police, setting cars alight and causing physical violence.\n\nOfficers \"sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion,\" Merseyside Police said (via CNN), and a number of police dogs were also hurt.\n\nPolice believe that the violence ensued over the unconfirmed reports of the identity of the suspect, who has \"incorrectly\" been named on social media.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK, and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nGoss also added that many of those involved in the violence were not local to the area, and are likely to have travelled to Southport with the intention of causing unrest.\n\nThe Muslim Council of Britain (MCB) also weighed in on the recent events, paying tributes to the girls killed in the attack and highlighting how a \"false rumour on the internet\" has seen a rise in Islamophobia in the area.\n\n\"Southport's tragedy was shamelessly exploited to spark outrage, with Islamophobia fueling the fire and leading to tonight's violence. This began with a false rumour on the internet, stoked by misinformation from a Russian news site, which wrongfully associated the crime with Muslims,\" it said.\n\n\"[The government] must address the increasing rise of violent far-right extremism targeting Muslim communities. More must be done to tackle Islamophobia and offer reassurance at this time.\"\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer has commented on the incidents too, and described the protesters as having \"hijacked\" the peaceful vigil \"with violence and thuggery\", as well as \"insulted the community as it grieves\" (via The Guardian).\n\nHe added that those involved \"will feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nUnsurprisingly, footage of the protestors has been quick to circulate online, with clips of the group ensuing violence in the area and clashing with police spreading on platforms such as X.\n\nOne that has particularly caught people's attention is a video of one of the protestors being hit in the crotch by a rock as he walked away from a barricade of police officers. In the footage, police are seen standing in riot gear while items such as rocks and wheely bins are hurled at them. One protester in the midst of it all is seen getting hit in the head by an object thrown by the crowd, before turning around and getting hit in the crotch by a rock thrown.\n\nSince being uploaded, it has already gathered over 40,000 'likes' and received over 3.8million views. Check it out below.\n\nFollowing news breaking of the tragic mass stabbing, Taylor Swift shared a handwritten statement addressing the attack on her Instagram Stories feed. \"The horror of yesterday's attack in Southport is washing over me continuously, and I'm just completely in shock,\" she wrote.\n\n\"The loss of life and innocence, and the horrendous trauma inflicted on everyone who was there, the families and first responders. These were just little kids at a dance class. I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families.\"\n\nIt was later confirmed that two Swift fans had launched a fundraiser to help raise funds for those affected by the tragedy and have so far raised over \u00a3120,000.\n\n\"We are working with Alder Hey Children's Hospital to help raise money for the families affected by the tragedy in Southport, and raising funeral funds for the two young swifties who have tragically passed. Every donation through this link goes directly to the verified charity below, which will in turn help make a difference to those impacted in a time of great sadness,\" read the description on the JustGiving page.", "source": {"uri": "nme.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NME Music News, Reviews, Videos, Galleries, Tickets and Blogs | NME.COM"}, "authors": [{"uri": "liberty_dunworth@nme.com",
