{"uri": "8252696866", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:08:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:08:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:06:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/after-girls-killings-in-southport-spur-violence-uk-police-ready-for-more-clashes/article_bd52000b-8a07-535b-a479-12d5c2f54830.html", "title": "After girls' killings in Southport spur violence, UK police ready for more clashes", "body": "By Temilade Adelaja\n\nSOUTHPORT, England (Reuters) -Police are prepared for further trouble in the English seaside town of Southport after violent clashes followed the deaths of three young girls in a frenzied knife attack at a dance class, the area's top officer said on Wednesday.\n\nA 17-year-old male is in police custody on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the bloody rampage on Monday at a \"Taylor Swift yoga and dance workshop\", a summer vacation event for children aged 6 to 11.\n\nMore than 50 officers suffered injuries in disturbances in Southport on Tuesday night, after social media posts stoked speculation that the suspect was a radical Islamist migrant.\n\nPolice vans were set on fire and protesters hurled bricks, bottles and fireworks at officers and at cars parked at the town's mosque.\n\n\"Just to reassure the communities of Southport, who I am sure are really worried about 'are we going to see this again tonight?' - we are absolutely planning for this evening and for the weekend ahead,\" Serena Kennedy, chief constable of Merseyside Police, told reporters.\n\nAs well as killing three girls aged six to nine, Monday's attack in the normally quiet town in northwest England, saw eight other children stabbed. Five remain in critical condition in hospital, along with two adults who tried to protect them.\n\nPolice are legally restricted in the details they can provide about the alleged teenage attacker, but they have said the incident was not terrorism-related, and that he was born in Britain, quashing speculation on his origins.\n\nThat did not prevent protesters, who police believe were supporters of a right-wing group, from targeting the mosque and attacking police who tried to stop them.\n\n'THUGS FROM OUT OF TOWN'\n\nPoliticians and police said most of those taking part in the violence were not from the area, and that the clashes detracted from a large vigil attended by thousands to pay tribute to the young victims.\n\nKennedy said 54 officers were hurt, and 27 of them were taken to hospital for serious injuries that included fractures and head wounds. Three police dogs were also hurt.\n\nThe police chief said she was disgusted and appalled by the violence, and a full investigation was underway to identify those involved.\n\n\"They were there purely for hooliganism and thuggery in terms of bringing that level of violence and that behaviour onto the streets of Southport and that is not what this community is about,\" she said.\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer said the \"violent thugs from out town\" would \"feel the full force of the law\".\n\nOn Wednesday, streets in Southport were littered with bricks from broken walls, smashed bottles, large garbage bins and their contents. Charred tarmac bore witness to police vehicles set alight in the clashes a night earlier.\n\n\"What I saw last night was absolutely appalling ... It was devastating and it's kind of taken away from actually what's gone on, which is the tragedy of those deaths,\" local resident David Burgess told Sky News.\n\nMeanwhile, Taylor Swift fans have so far raised more than 270,000 pounds ($346,000) to help families of the victims and for the hospital where some of the children were being treated.\n\n$1 = 0.7795 pounds)\n\n(Reporting by Sachin Ravikumar and Kylie MacLellan; writing by Michael Holden; Editing by Bernadette Baum)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Victims", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Victims", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Unsolved", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Unsolved", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/gazette.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/c6/6c6f5637-6314-5729-a36c-7f6f17728631/66a97c9eab977.image.jpg?crop=800%2C420%2C0%2C56&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9777011", "eventUri": "eng-9777011", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.4352941176470588, "wgt": 146, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8251557240", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:18:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:18:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:15:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/violent-crowd-clashes-with-uk-police-after-young-girls-killed-6227514", "title": "Violent Crowd Clashes With UK Police After Young Girls Killed", "body": "Police vehicles were damaged and set alight, officers were pelted by bricks and large garbage containers.\n\nPolice have said it was not linked to terrorism and that the suspect was born in the UK.\n\nLondon:\n\nA large crowd of anti-Muslim protesters clashed with police on Tuesday in a northern English town where three girls were stabbed to death and five other children critically wounded during an attack on a Taylor Swift-themed event on Monday.\n\nThe horrific stabbing incident in Southport, a quiet seaside town north of Liverpool, has shocked the nation. Police have said it was not linked to terrorism and that the suspect was born in the UK.\n\nYet far-right groups have stoked speculation that the teenage suspect was involved with Islam, and police said Tuesday's violence erupted when several hundred people began to throw items at a mosque. Police linked the crowd to the English Defence League, a group which has sometimes staged violent demonstrations against Islam.\n\nPolice vehicles were damaged and set alight, officers were pelted by bricks and large garbage containers. One video posted online showed the crowd chanting \"we want our country back\".\n\nAway from the violence, hundreds had gathered for an emotional vigil to pay tribute to those killed in the attack, laying flowers and toys.\n\n\"The people of Southport are reeling after the horror inflicted on them yesterday. They deserve our support and our respect,\" Prime Minister Keir Starmer said.\n\n\"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nA 17-year-old male is currently in police custody on suspicion of murder and attempted murder after the bloody rampage at a \"Taylor Swift yoga and dance workshop\", a summer vacation event for children aged 6 to 11.\n\nWitnesses described the attack as being like a scene from a horror film. In addition to the three deaths, eight children suffered stab wounds. Five of them and two adults who had tried to protect them remain in a critical condition.\n\nThe police have said the motive remained unclear and have not given any details about the suspect, beyond saying he was born in Wales and lived in a village nearby.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" said Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nGoss and local politicians said those clashing with police involved many from outside the area, and the Liverpool Region Mosque Network said a minority of people were trying to use the incident to spread hatred.\n\n\"This evening we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protesters gathering outside,\" it said in a statement. \"This is causing further fear and anxiety within our communities,\"\n\nStarmer had earlier paid a sombre visit to the town to lay flowers, and King Charles and his family have expressed their horror. U.S. singer Swift herself wrote on Instagram that she was \"just completely in shock\".\n\nJUST LITTLE KIDS\n\n\"These were just little kids at a dance class. I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families,\" she said.\n\nHer fans have raised more than 250,000 pounds ($320,850) online to help families of the victims and for the hospital where some of the children were being treated.\n\nThe three girls who died in the attack were named as Bebe King, aged 6, 7-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, aged 9, whose parents are Portuguese.\n\n\"Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our Princess, like we said before to you, you're always our princess and no one would change that. Love from Your Hero Daddy and Mummy,\" Aguiar's family said in a statement.\n\nThere has been increasing concern at rising levels of stabbings and knife crime in Britain, and the Southport attack follows other recent similar, indiscriminate rampages.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\n\"I'm absolutely determined that my government will get to grips with it,\" A 17-year-old male from Banks, Lancashire, has been arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder over the incident. (James Speakman/PA via AP)\n\nLONDON (AP) -- Far-right protesters fueled by anger and false online rumors hurled bottles and stones at officers and set a police van ablaze Tuesday outside a northwest England mosque near where three girls were fatally stabbed a day earlier.\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the \"thuggery\" and said the crowd had hijacked what had earlier been a peaceful vigil attended by hundreds in the center of Southport to mourn the dead and 10 surviving stabbing victims, seven of whom were in critical condition.\n\nPolice said the violent crowd was believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, a far-right group, and the unrest was inspired by rumors about the identity of the teenage suspect arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Merseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said.\n\nPolice previously said a suspect's name circulating on social media accounts was incorrect and the boy was born in Britain, contrary to online claims that he was an asylum seeker.\n\nThe Liverpool Region Mosque Network posted a statement decrying the \"heinous\" stabbing as an attack against society that was unconnected to Islam.\n\n\"A minority of people are attempting to portray that this inhumane act is somehow related to the Muslim community,\" the group said on X. \"Frankly it is not, and we must not let those who seek to divide us and spread hatred use this as an opportunity.\"\n\nOfficers outside the Southport Mosque in riot gear were pelted with objects by members of the crowd, some of whom wore masks, amid chants of \"No surrender!\" and \"English til I die!\" Firecrackers exploded, sirens wailed and a helicopter hovering overhead added to the chaos.\n\nSome officers were bleeding after being struck by objects and police said one had a broken nose.\n\nA day earlier, a short distance from the turmoil, the girls had taken part in a Taylor Swift-themed dance and yoga workshop on the first week of summer vacation when a teen armed with a knife entered the studio and began a vicious attack, police said.\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, 9, Elsie Dot Stancombe, 7, and Bebe King, 6, died from their injuries.\n\nEight children and two adults remained hospitalized after the attack in Southport. Both adults and five of the children were in critical condition.\n\nSwift said earlier on Instagram that she was \"completely in shock\" and still taking in \"the horror\" of the event.\n\n\"These were just little kids at a dance class,\" she wrote. \"I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families.\"\n\nThe 17-year-old suspect was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder shortly after the attacks just before noon. Police said he was born in Cardiff, Wales, and had lived for years in a village about 3 miles (5 kilometers) from Southport. {"uri": "8251578933", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:45:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:45:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:43:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://lagatar24.com/violent-clashes-erupt-after-stabbing-attack-in-southport/182037/", "title": "Violent Clashes Erupt After Stabbing Attack in Southport - Lagatar English", "body": "London: A peaceful seaside town in northern England turned into a scene of violence on Tuesday as anti-Muslim protesters clashed with police after a tragic stabbing incident that left three young girls dead and five other children critically injured. The attack occurred during a Taylor Swift-themed event on Monday in Southport, north of Liverpool.\n\nThe stabbing incident, described by witnesses as horrific, shocked the nation. The police confirmed that the attack was not linked to terrorism, and the suspect, a 17-year-old male, was born in the UK. Despite this, far-right groups fueled speculation about the suspect's ties to Islam, leading to violent protests.\n\nA large crowd, believed to be linked to the English Defence League, gathered and threw items at a mosque. Police vehicles were damaged, and officers were pelted with bricks and other objects. A video posted online showed the crowd chanting, \"We want our country back.\"\n\nAmidst the chaos, hundreds of residents gathered for an emotional vigil to pay tribute to the victims, laying flowers and toys. Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the violence, stating, \"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves. They will feel the full force of the law.\"\n\nThe 17-year-old suspect is currently in police custody on charges of murder and attempted murder. The attack occurred during a \"Taylor Swift yoga and dance workshop,\" a summer vacation event for children aged 6 to 11. In addition to the three fatalities, eight children suffered stab wounds, with five of them and two adults who intervened remaining in critical condition.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss emphasized the importance of refraining from speculation about the suspect. \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Goss said.\n\nLocal politicians and community leaders, including the Liverpool Region Mosque Network, urged for calm and unity. \"This evening we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protesters gathering outside,\" the network said. \"This is causing further fear and anxiety within our communities.\"\n\nPrime Minister Starmer paid a somber visit to the town to lay flowers in memory of the victims. King Charles and his family expressed their horror, and Taylor Swift shared her shock on Instagram, stating, \"These were just little kids at a dance class. I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families.\"\n\nSwift's fans have raised over \u00a3250,000 ($320,850) to support the families of the victims and the hospital treating the injured children. The three girls who lost their lives were identified as 6-year-old Bebe King, 7-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe, and 9-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar, whose parents are Portuguese.\n\nIn response to the rising concern over knife crime in Britain, Starmer vowed that his government would address the issue. \"I'm absolutely determined that my government will get to grips with it,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "8251440310", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:10:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:10:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:45:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/riots-break-stabbings-taylor-swift-223750147.html", "title": "Riots Break Out After Stabbings at Taylor Swift-Themed Event in U.K.", "body": "Rioters have burnt police vehicles, thrown bricks and bottles at police and pelted a mosque in the town of Southport following the deadly stabbing spree that killed three children and injured eight more, including two adults at a Taylor Swift themed dance and yoga class on Monday.\n\nThe attack happened after a 17-year-old allegedly broke into the Hart Space Dance studio in Southport, U.K., during a Swift-themed yoga and dance class. The suspect then stabbed three children aged 6, 7, and 9 to death, and injured eight other children, five of whom are in critical condition, and two adults, according to a statement from the Merseyside Police.\n\nThe murders became a flash point for anti-immigration sentiment after it was revealed by neighbors of the suspect that the murderer was the son of Rwandan parents, but was born in the U.K., according to the Daily Express.\n\nDespite the suspect reportedly being raised by Christian parents, rioters assembled outside the Southport Islamic Society Mosque on Tuesday evening, chanting \"No surrender!\" and \"English till I die!\"\n\nAccording to The Guardian, others heard chants of \"Allah Allah, who the f**k is Allah?\"\n\nThe rioters are allegedly members of the far-right English Defence League, an organization that has been referred to as explicitly anti-immigrant and Islamophobic by activists.\n\n\"At around 7.45pm, a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League - began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road in Southport,\" Merseyside police wrote in a statement.\n\nPolice also stated that the riots \"involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\"\n\nAdditionally, a number of officers were injured, police confirmed, while a number of cars were also damaged and a shop was broken into and looted in Southport. \"This is completely unacceptable. We're gathering evidence and those responsible will be brought to justice,\" police said in an appeal on Facebook.\n\nOnline speculation and conspiracy theories claim that the suspect was not born in the U.K. and that he was being monitored by law enforcement before the attack, both of which are untrue.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time. Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper condemned the conspiracy theories in an address to the House of Commons on Tuesday evening saying, \"False information has already been extensively shared in the last 24 hours. Those who do this for their own purposes risk undermining a crucial criminal investigation, and I ask everyone to show some respect for the community in Southport and for families who are grieving and in trauma.\"\n\nFar-right activist, Tommy Robinson, who was arrested on suspected charges of terrorism on Sunday, went viral on Tuesday evening after he posted a rant to his X account in which he condemned the police for \"allowing people into our towns and cities that are raping their way through our towns.\"\n\n\"You care more for Afghanis, Somalis, Eritreans, Syrians, Pakistani... They are a danger to us,\" Robinson went on. The post has garnered 46k likes and millions of views at the time of publishing.\n\nMP Nigel Farage, whose Reform UK party has also been called anti-immigrant and racist by activist groups, echoed conspiracy theories about the suspect in a video posted to his X on Tuesday evening.\n\n\"Was this guy being monitored by the security services, some reports say he was, others less sure,\" Farage said. \"The police say it was a non-terror incident. Just as they said, the stabbing of an Army lieutenant colonel in uniform on the streets of Kent was a 'non-terror incident.' I just wonder if the truth is being withheld from us.\"\n\nFarage's post has similarly garnered more than a million views at the time of publishing.\n\nRead more at The Daily Beast.\n\nGet the Daily Beast's biggest scoops and scandals delivered right to your inbox. News", "body": "Supporters of the English Defense League throw items at Southport Mosque, police van set on fire\n\nViolent clashes broke out in Southport, a seaside town in Northwest England, Tuesday evening as police confronted demonstrators protesting in the wake of a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class the previous day that killed three girls.\n\nPolice said the situation escalated around 7.45 p.m. local time when supporters of the English Defence League -- a far-right, Islamophobic organization -- threw items at the Southport Mosque.\n\nThe tension quickly turned to violence as bottles and wheelie bins were thrown at officers, leading to a police van being set on fire.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Doss described the situation as \"sickening,\" particularly in light of the community's recent trauma following the tragic loss of three young lives in the stabbing incident.\n\nDoss emphasized that the unrest was being fueled by individuals from outside the Merseyside area, exploiting the recent tragedy to incite disorder.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody,\" he said. \"Some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\"\n\nThe home secretary earlier issued a warning against spreading disinformation about the stabbing attack, a {"uri": "8251767693", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "05:05:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T05:05:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T05:05:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://maktoobmedia.com/world/anti-muslim-mob-attacks-uk-mosque-after-misinformation-campaign/", "title": "Anti-Muslim mob attacks UK mosque after misinformation campaign", "body": "A far-right mob on Tuesday rioted outside a mosque in the United Kingdom's Southport and set a police van on fire after a misinformation campaign claimed that the 17-year-old who killed three children at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class was a Muslim.\n\n\"English till I die\" were among the racist and Islamophobic slogans raised by hundreds of men who pelted stones, and hurled bricks and bins at riot police. The Southport Islamic Society Mosque reportedly got damaged during the rioting.\n\nThirty-nine police officers have been injured after unrest broke out in Southport hours after a vigil took place to remember the victims of a knife attack in which three children were killed, the North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nOn Monday, Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were killed after being fatally stabbed at the children's dance club in Hart Street. Eight other children suffered stab wounds and five are in critical condition, alongside two adults.\n\nBBC News on Tuesday reported that the 17-year-old suspect was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents and had moved to the Southport area in 2013. Because the suspect is under 18 he cannot be legally identified.\n\nThis triggered a massive misinformation campaign that speculated or claimed the suspect was Muslim.\n\nMuslim groups in the UK condemned the attack. \"Weaponising the tragic killings of innocent children in such an overt display of Islamophobia is horrific,\" posted the Muslim Association of Britain.\n\nUK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said, \"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\n\"They will feel the full force of the law,\" he posted on X.\n\nMerseyside Police condemned the violence and said one of their officers had suffered a suspected broken nose. Photos and videos posted on social media showed several riot police officers with cuts and grazes to their faces following the clashes with the far-right mob.\n\n\"At around 7.45 pm, a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League - began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road in Southport,\" the force said.\n\n\"there were at least 27 million impressions for posts stating or speculating that the attacker was Muslim, a migrant, refugee or foreigner. There were people also denouncing these speculations - especially the more racist ones,\" Marc Owen Jones, an expert on misinformation, claimed.\n\nSeveral major social media accounts, including {"uri": "8252303518", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:02:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:02:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:01:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/angela-rayner-issues-plea-after-29648041", "title": "Angela Rayner issues plea after 'disgraceful' disorder in Southport - Liverpool Echo", "body": "The Deputy Prime Minister spoke on ITV's This Morning after violent scenes in Southport last night\n\nDeputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner described violent scenes in Southport yesterday as \"disgraceful\" as politicians widely condemned the disorder. 39 police officers were injured as a large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, threw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road on Tuesday evening.\n\nVehicles belonging to the police and members of the public were set on fire. Damage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set on fire, police said. A clean up operation has taken place this morning, with members of the local community stepping in to help.\n\nThe disorder last night came after a mass stabbing on Hart Street on Monday resulted in the death of three girls - Alice Aguiar, aged nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven. Merseyside Police have arrested a 17-year-old boy who is originally from Cardiff but lives in Banks, Lancashire, on suspicion of murder.\n\nSocial media has been awash with misinformation since Monday's tragic incident. A spokesperson for the Merseyside Police said an incorrect name has been shared on social media in connection with the suspect.\n\nThey added: \"We would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.\" This incident is not currently being treated as terror-related and detectives are not looking for anyone else in connection with it.\n\nAngela Rayner criticised the \"disgraceful\" scenes in Southport and \"disrespectful\" social media theories as she urged people to allow the police to establish the facts. Speaking on ITV's This Morning, the Deputy Prime Minister said: \"I think there's been a couple of instances recently where, especially particularly online, where theories and things are whipped up, whereas actually it turns out to be not true or not the full picture.\n\n\"And I think there's a culture now where people want to instantly get the facts, but actually it's important that police and those people that are doing the work are able to carry out that work. And it's important for justice as well, because we have law and order in the UK, and it's important that those authorities are able to establish the facts and then to be able to bring those forward.\n\n\"But speculation and some of the untruths that have been put around social media, not only is that creating tensions and fear in the community, but it's disrespectful to family who maybe want those answers that haven't got those answers.\" She added that it is \"really unhelpful for the police\" and \"my plea is that we all need to step back and just wait and then that information will come but allow the police to do their work\".\n\nHaving released a full statement condemning the violence yesterday, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper reiterated her message on Wednesday morning. Posting on X (formerly Twitter), the Home Secretary said: \"Brave police, firefighters & paramedics saved lives in the horrific Southport attack. Total disgrace those same emergency services were attacked & officers injured by violent thugs from out of town. Grieving community & emergency services deserve all our support & respect.\"\n\nLiverpool City Region Metro Mayor Steve Rotheram said: \"There are families just coming to terms with yesterday's events, parents grieving for their murdered children and survivors still trying to process what they witnessed. The violent scenes in Southport tonight will only further traumatise a community that is already struggling to come to terms with this attack.\n\n\"Mindless violence directed at the very people who ran towards the danger yesterday, and outright Islamophobia, only distract from the work of delivering justice. The real story tonight is of the thousands who gathered at the vigil in Southport in memory of Bebe, Elsie and Alice. For the sake of their loved ones, this disorder needs to stop so the police do their jobs.\"\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley said he was \"deeply concerned\" about the violent protests. In a statement, he added: \"It's distressing to see people from outside our Southport community attacking our police and local people. I want to make it clear that I fully condemn any attack on our emergency services, these are the same services that responded to the tragic attack yesterday.\"\n\nMr Hurley continued: \"I want to thank our community for pulling together and supporting every person who has been affected by Monday's tragic attack. Nowhere was this more evident than the solidarity, remembrance and sympathy heard at today's vigil. To those who laid flowers, candles, toys, thank you. I was deeply saddened to hear the news today of the death of a third child. Bebe, Elsie and Alice are in all of our thoughts and hearts today.\"\n\nMerseyside's Police Commissioner Emily Spurrell said: \"I am absolutely appalled by the disgraceful scenes of violence in Southport tonight. This is a community which has faced unimaginable tragedy, and it is grieving.\n\n\"Such behaviour is abhorrent and only causes further harm and suffering. Officers are working around the clock to get justice for the families. It is completely unacceptable that they - and the wider community - are now being put in danger by those who would bring violence and disorder to our streets.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-439230606", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:32:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:32:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T04:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-07-31/clashes-in-uks-southport-after-killing-of-three-girls-leaves-many-police-injured", "title": "Clashes in UK's Southport, After Killing of Three Girls, Leaves Many Police Injured", "body": "SOUTHPORT, England (Reuters) - Violent clashes in a seaside town in northwest England following the killing of three young girls at a dance workshop in a stabbing attack, left dozens of British police officers injured late on Tuesday.\n\nPolice vans were set on fire in Southport and protesters dismantled garden walls to hurl bricks at both officers and at a mosque following speculation on social media that the teenage suspect behind the attack was a Muslim.\n\nThe horrific incident in the normally quiet town, which left eight other children wounded, five of them in critical condition in hospital along with two adults who tried to protect them, was not linked to terrorism, police said.\n\nPolice have arrested an unnamed 17-year-old male on suspicion of murder and attempted murder. The suspect was born in Britain, they said.\n\nA total of 39 police officers were treated for injuries, including 27 who were taken to hospital, North West Ambulance Service said early on Wednesday.\n\n\"Offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said in a statement.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\"\n\nThe girls aged 6 to 9 were stabbed in a violent attack on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed dance and yoga event for children in the town north of Liverpool, leaving two children dead initially in an assault that has shocked the nation.\n\nSwift's fans have so far raised 270,000 pounds ($346,000) to help families of the victims and for the hospital where some of the children were being treated.\n\nPolice said violence erupted late on Tuesday when a large group of people, \"believed to be supporters of the English Defence League,\" a far right group, threw items towards a mosque in the town.\n\n($1 = 0.7795 pounds)\n\n(Reporting by Sachin Ravikumar; Editing by Bernadette Baum)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, {"uri": "8252688383", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:01:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:01:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:00:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.sthelensstar.co.uk/news/24489120.st-helens-man-arrested-connection-southport-protest/", "title": "St Helens man arrested in connection with Southport protest following stabbings", "body": "On Monday a 17-year-old man from Banks, near Southport, was arrested after a group of young girls at a dance studio in Southport were attacked, suffering stab wounds on Monday, July 29. He is in custody held on suspicion of murder and attempted murder.\n\nThree girls Bebe King, six; Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven; and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, died from their injuries and eight other girls are currently in hospital - five in critical condition.\n\n(Image: Merseyside Police)\n\nTwo adults also suffered injuries and are in hospital in critical condition.\n\nIn light of the tragedy a vigil was held in Southport yesterday Tuesday, July 30, and immediately following this a violent protest on a nearby street broke out close to a mosque.\n\nOfficers are appealing for footage and information after more than 50 officers were hurt during the disorder.\n\nOf the 53 injured, 49 were Merseyside Police officers and four were Lancashire Police officers. Eight sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion and were treated in hospital.\n\nOther officers suffered varying degrees of injury including head injuries, serious facial injuries and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nThe disorder began at around 7.45pm and the crowd had dispersed by around midnight.\n\nA total of four men have been arrested and taken into custody in connection with the disorder.\n\nAmong them a 31-year-old man from St Helens was arrested on suspicion of violent disorder.\n\nA 31-year-old man from West Derby, Liverpool was arrested on suspicion of violent disorder; a 39-year-old man from Southport was arrested on suspicion of violent disorder and a 32-year-old man from Manchester with a probation address in Southport was arrested on suspicion of affray and possession of a bladed article.\n\nBricks from garden walls were reportedly used as missiles to attack officers and set cars belonging to the public on fire at random.\n\n(Image: Pat Hurst/PA Wire)\n\nBricks were also reportedly thrown at a mosque, a convenience store was damaged, and wheelie bins set on fire. Three police dogs were also injured. After having bricks thrown at them, Police Dog Zoe sustained a laceration to her leg, has been stitched and is now resting, and PD Ike is recovering after sustaining a cut mouth and swelling to his front leg.\n\nPD Quga suffered burns to her back leg. A fourth dog, PD Repo, was spared injury after their handler kicked petrol away.\n\nAs a result of the disorder, a 24-hour Section 60 Order was introduced in the area and remains in place today.\n\nExtra officers will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities. The Order, under S60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994, gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals in the area and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nA Section 34 Order has also been introduced under the Anti-Social Behaviour & Policing Act 2014, giving officers powers to direct people who are engaging in antisocial behaviour or are likely to become involved in such incidents.\n\nThese powers will not be used for anyone visiting the area and going about their daily business. Under the legislation, officers have the power to seize any item, including vehicles, used in the commission of anti-social behaviour. Should a person who has previously been directed to leave the area return, an offence would be committed, which they may ultimately be arrested for.\n\n(Image: The damage in the road)\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Jenny Sims said: \"I know the wider community is as shocked as we are about the abhorrent events of last night.\n\n\"Through the night there has been a tremendous effort by members of the public who came out to help clean up the streets, using hose pipes and brushes and donating food and dog food to officers to restore the pride and respect they have for their town. Partner agencies, including Sefton Council, were also deployed to help clean up the damage left by those involved.\n\n\"We have been overwhelmed with messages of thanks from the community, and I know I speak on behalf of all those officers there last night when I say how grateful we all are for their support.\n\n\"We were joined by colleagues from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support, and I want to thank them publicly for their assistance. Sadly, 49 Merseyside officers and four Lancashire officers were injured in their efforts to prevent further disorder and protect the public.\n\n\"The wanton violence and destruction we saw is the very last thing the people of Southport need having been rocked by the awful events of Monday. The disrespect toward grieving families and the community is despicable, and I want to reassure residents in Southport that we will have a significantly increased police presence in the town in the coming days.\n\n\"We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible.\n\n\"Finally, I want to make this absolutely clear: anyone who intends to cause future damage and harm to our communities will be dealt with robustly, using all our available powers. There are extensive plans and resources in place to quickly deal with anyone intent on causing disorder over the coming days. We will look to bring to justice every person who is identified committing criminal damage and acts of violence against our officers and our communities.\n\n\"The Section 60 order will be rigorously enforced to move people on who are attending the area to commit such offences.\"\n\n\"Anyone with information can DM @MerPolCC or contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.\"", "source": {"uri": "sthelensstar.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "St Helens Star"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Theft", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Theft", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Victims", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Victims", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://www.sthelensstar.co.uk/resources/images/18371972/", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9777011", "eventUri": "eng-9777011", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-29", "textStart": 177, "textEnd": 184}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-30", "textStart": 625, "textEnd": 632}], "sentiment": -0.7098039215686274, "wgt": 141, "relevance": 1}

Thirty-nine police were treated for injuries, with 27 taken to hospital, the North West Ambulance Service said.\n\nStarmer, in a statement on X, said the protesters had \"hijacked\" a memorial for the victims of a horrific attack at a children's dance event on Monday and \"insulted the community as it grieves.\"\n\n\"They will feel the full force of the law,\" the prime minister said.\n\nEarlier, hundreds of mourners laid wreaths, toys and candles in tribute to the three girls -- Bebe King, 6, Elsie Dot Stancombe, 7, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, 9 -- who were fatally stabbed on Monday while attending a Taylor Swift-themed dance event. He said people had 'got the train in' to the Merseyside town 'intent on causing trouble'.\n\nHe added that those who threw bricks towards a mosque following a vigil used the incident 'for their own political purposes'. Mr Hurley spoke this morning after a night of terror and violence for residents, as chaotic scenes unfolded close to the scene of the fatal stabbing on Hart Street.\n\nREAD NEXT: Southport riots sparked by English Defence League supporters, police say\n\nBricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire, police said. 39 police officers were injured in the scenes of 'disorder', with 27 taken to hospital.\n\nThe disorder escalated after bricks were thrown at a local mosque. In a statement issued last night, police said they believed this initial disorder was sparked by a number of supporters of the EDL - a far-right organisation known for its Islamophobia.\n\nSpeaking to BBC Radio 4's Today programme earlier, Mr Hurley said 'under no circumstances' was the attack on the mosque justified'. Speaking on the 17-year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, who was arrested after the stabbing on Monday, he said: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\n\n\"Not least these beered-up thugs who have descended on the town last night intent on causing trouble. We all have to stand against that and Southport will not accept this.\n\n\"Southport will unite against this sort of thing.\" He added: \"These were thugs who got the train in, these were not the people from Southport.\n\n\"They were using the horrific incident on Monday, the deaths of three little kiddies, for their own political purposes and actually to attack the very same first responders and the very same police, who had been on the scene on Monday, were then being pelted with bricks the day after by these thugs.\n\n\"There's no way to describe that other than to say it's utterly reprehensible and we must identify these people and make sure that the full force of the law is down against them. These people are utterly disrespecting the families of the dead and injured children and utterly disrespecting the town.\"\n\nHe said that the riots happened because of 'propaganda and lies' spread on social media about the identity of the attacker. He told Times Radio: \"Because of the propaganda and the lies that were being spread around on social media from within minutes of the news breaking on Monday afternoon about the tragic incident.\n\n\"We'd had all sorts of lies being spread and misinformation being spread about the alleged perpetrator and some people with the best of intentions then they tried to rebut this, they tried to argue back, but all that happens is you're just amplifying people's false messaging.\"\n\nHe added: \"This misinformation doesn't just exist on people's internet browsers and on people's phones. It has real world impact. And what happened is that the real world impact of that was that we then had hundreds of people descending on the town, descending on Southport from outside of the area, intent on causing trouble, either because they believe what they've written, or because they are bad faith actors who wrote it in the first place, in the hope of causing community division.\"\n\nThe riots broke out after the brutal stabbing at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club on Hart Street on Monday. {"uri": "8251588199", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:56:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:56:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:56:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/world/uk-stabbing-violence-erupts-outside-southport-mosque-over-attack-that-killed-3-children-watch-snt-shgt79", "title": "UK stabbing: Violence erupts outside Southport mosque over attack that killed 3 children (WATCH)", "body": "Violent clashes have erupted between demonstrators and law enforcement outside a mosque in Southport following a stabbing attack that claimed the lives of three children earlier in the week. Videos shared on social media capture the chaos, with scenes of a police vehicle engulfed in smoke and crowds hurling bottles and bricks at officers behind riot shields. A journalist from PA Media recorded footage of burning vehicles and riot police attempting to control the situation with shields.\n\nAuthorities have identified the protesters as likely affiliates of the English Defence League (EDL), a far-right group known for its extremist views. The unrest follows a tragic incident on Monday, where three children were killed during a Taylor Swift-themed yoga and dance workshop in Southport.\n\nPolice have established a strong presence outside the mosque, with certain factions of the crowd chanting slogans such as \"No surrender!\" and \"English till I die!\"\n\nThe Telegraph reported that riot police, accompanied by dogs, were seen charging at the protesters, pushing them back towards a nearby railway bridge.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss addressed the media, highlighting the role of a 17-year-old male in police custody and condemning those who exploit his situation to incite further violence.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around his status, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Goss said.\n\nIn response to the escalating situation, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper spoke in the House of Commons on Tuesday evening, urging against the use of the tragic deaths of the three schoolgirls to \"stir up division\" and spread false information.\n\n\"False information has already been extensively shared in the last 24 hours. Those who do this for their own purposes risk undermining a crucial criminal investigation and I ask everyone to show some respect for the community in Southport and for families who are grieving and {"uri": "8251491775", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:51:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:51:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:50:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/22-police-officers-injured-11-29646348", "title": "22 police officers injured with 11 in hospital as major incident declared after Southport protest  - Liverpool Echo", "body": "11 officers have been taken to hospital following the violent scenes on St Luke's Road in Southport\n\n22 police officers were injured and a major incident has been declared following violent scenes during a protest in Southport. Police said they were dealing with a disturbance which took place during a protest on St Luke's Road on Tuesday.\n\nBricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire. Eight police officers sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion.\n\nOther officers suffered head injuries and serious facial injuries. One was knocked unconscious.\n\nNorth West Ambulance Service said it has declared a major incident due to the high number of resources required at scene and the ongoing disturbance. The ambulance service said it has treated 22 police officers and so far, 11 of those have been taken to hospital.\n\nA large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road on Tuesday evening. Cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire and bricks were thrown at a local mosque.\n\nDamage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set on fire, police said. Three police dogs have also been injured. Police Dogs Zoe and Ike have sustained leg injuries from bricks thrown at them. A third dog, PD Quga, also suffered burns to her back leg.\n\nPhotos and video seen by the ECHO showed crowds gathered around police riot vans on St Luke's Road. A police van was also seen up in flames.\n\nMerseyside Police said as a result of the disorder, a 24-hour Section 60 Order has been introduced in the area, running from 19.54pm on (Tuesday). Extra officers will remain in the area to provide a visible presence to reassure communities. The order, under Section 60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994, gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals in the area and is designed to minimise serious violence.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack. I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\n\n\"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday. We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible.\n\n\"Anyone with {"uri": "8252639476", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:28:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:28:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:28:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/three-arrests-made-chief-constable-29651272", "title": "Three arrests made as Chief Constable Serena Kennedy gives update on injured officers - Liverpool Echo", "body": "54 police officers were treated for injuries after last night's riot\n\nMerseyside Chief Constable Serena Kennedy has issued an update on the police officers injured in yesterday's riot in Southport. A major incident was declared by emergency services on St Lukes's Road, Southport on Tuesday, July 30. Ms Kennedy told the ECHO earlier today that 54 police officers were injured last night - 49 from Merseyside Police and five from Lancashire Constabulary.\n\nThis afternoon, she confirmed none of the officers who were injured are in a critical condition. Officers' injuries included broken bones, cuts and concussion. High visibility patrols will continue in these areas and a dispersal order is in place.\n\nMs Kennedy said: \"Being at Southport police station last night and seeing the officers being brought in from the street with their injuries was just devastating.\" She said it was a \"fast-moving investigation and its progressing well\".\n\nAccording to the Chief Constable, three people were arrested on Tuesday night. She said: \"Our priority was to try and keep the communities of Southport safe and also to make sure officers remained safe. Three arrests were made, however more will follow. It's impossible to say (how many will be arrested). It's really early days in the investigation.\"\n\nShe estimated 200 to 300 people were involved. She added: \"Initially, there were about 70 people who made their way away from the vigil and were making their way towards the mosque. They suddenly became about 200 in number and then others joined that number.\"\n\nEmily Spurrell, Merseyside's Police and Crime Commissioner paid tribute to the injured officers and said she was \"appalled\" by the scenes of violence yesterday.\n\nMs Spurrell said: \"I cannot even begin to imagine how the people of Southport are feeling today. A community trying to come to terms with the most unimaginable tragedy, rooted in grief, subjected to such mindless displays of violence.\n\n\"I am totally appalled by the senseless behaviour from those individuals who came to Southport last night with the sole intention of bringing mayhem and disorder to our streets. Streets that, just hours before, were full of compassion, of love, and unity, in memory of the three little girls killed in Monday's horrendous attack, as well as all those injured and deeply affected.\n\n\"The same community which is trying to come to terms with the horrific scenes they witnessed on Monday have this morning come together, to clean the debris from their streets, left behind in the wake of last night's disgraceful scenes. Many of them having had their own property vandalised, walls knocked over, vehicles set alight, and are now left counting the cost of such abhorrent behaviour.\n\n\"My heart goes out to everybody in those communities, and I hope they can find some comfort in the love and support they will receive from across Merseyside today, and in the days to come.\n\n\"I also want to pay tribute to the Merseyside Police officers who came under attack last night. Their bravery, dedication, and commitment to put the safety of our communities before their own cannot be overstated. As ever, we are in their debt.\n\n\"These are the same heroic police officers who were back on shift after responding to the knife incident the day before. The same officers who ran towards danger on Monday and, along with our other blue light services helped to save lives and care for the injured. The same officers faced with such awful and hateful behaviour from individuals seeking to use this tragedy to spread fear and hate, whilst risking the lives of the wider community.\n\n\"That 53 officers and three police dogs suffered injuries at those hands of these thugs is reprehensible and shameful. My thoughts are with them, and I wish them all a speedy and full recovery.\n\n\"The individuals that caused those injuries and took part in those appalling scenes are not representative of the people of Merseyside. The violence and hatred they peddle will never be welcome here. I know that officers are working around the clock to identify those who incited and took part in last night's events, and I'm assured that once identified they will feel the full weight of the law.\"\n\nThe Commissioner added: \"Southport is a beautiful place. A seaside town, that brings joy to many families, now suffering with unspeakable heartache, reeling from mindless violence and at the centre of a media storm. I want to reassure our communities that peace will return to their streets.\n\n\"Detectives are continuing to question a suspect and whilst I can understand the anger and frustration many may be feeling, I would ask urge people to show patience whilst this investigation continues and let the police do their job. This is vital if we are to get justice for the families of Bebe, Elsie, and Alice.\n\n\"In the coming days I will be meeting with our partners to discuss what took place and how we can work together to prevent any repeat of such unacceptable violence and disorder, while also providing vital reassurance and support to our communities.\n\n\"High visibility patrols will continue in these areas and a dispersal order is in place. Work will continue in the days and weeks ahead to reassure and support people living in Southport and keep our communities safe.\"\n\nIf you've been affected by yesterday's incident, support is available via our Victim Care Merseyside which offers free, confidential advice and emotional and practical support.\n\nCall Freephone 0808 175 3080 on weekdays between 8am and 6pm or online at any time.\n\nIf you witnessed anything, or have information that could help Merseyside Police's investigation, DM @MerPolCC or can contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or via their website www.crimestoppers-uk.org", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Liverpool Echo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "katie_westwood@liverpoolecho.co.uk", "name": "Katie Westwood", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Theft", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Theft", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Humor/Job-Related", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Humor/Job-Related", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://i2-prod.liverpoolecho.co.uk/article29651314.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/0_Police-dealing-with-trouble-on-St-Lukess-RoadSouthport.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9777011", "eventUri": "eng-9777011", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-30", "textStart": 292, "textEnd": 299}], "sentiment": -0.2627450980392156, "wgt": 139, "relevance": 1}

At the same time he was pelted in the back of the head.\n\nThe Southport rioter who was knocked in the back of the head by two bricks as tried to goad police before another hit his crotch is 39-year-old, father-of-two Brian Spencer\n\nBrian was seen wearing a grey tracksuit, dancing and jumping around in the street as the yobs ran riot in the town last night\n\nMinutes later he is seen approaching a line of police officers protecting themselves with riot gear, swinging his hips and gyrating, before striking a pose\n\nA police van was set on fire near a mosque in Southport on Tuesday evening as riots broke out\n\nAs Brian walks away from the group of officers rubbing the back in the head, he was hit by a third brick - this time in the crotch. He shouted 'f***ing hell boys' as two other rioters helped him out of the crowd.\n\nFriends told MailOnline Brian is known as party animal and has previously been filmed in a social media video dancing at a festival in a similar style to the one he used during last night's disturbances.\n\nOne Southport local said: 'People are saying the protesters were outsiders who came here to cause trouble - but Brian came from just up the road.\n\n'Everyone knows Brian. He's a bit of a party animal and I think he just got excited last night. His head will be hurting this morning.'\n\nThe 'sickening' violence, which started barely an hour after thousands of mourners had gathered for a vigil to remember the victims who lost their lives, with the Prime Minister, Home Secretary and police chiefs condemning the thuggery.\n\nThe violent group were accused of showing 'no respect to a town that's grieving'.\n\nTributes poured in for the three little girls killed who police yesterday named as six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar.\n\nEight other children suffered stab wounds at the Taylor Swift-themed summer holiday dance workshop. Five are in a critical condition, alongside two women who were also critically injured as they bravely tried to save the children.\n\nSeconds later he was nearly sent flying to the floor, after a giant brick smashed into his face after rebounding off a riot shield\n\nAs Brian walks away from the group of officers rubbing the back in the head, he was hit by a third brick - this time in the crotch\n\nA wounded police officer with blood pouring down his head after being caught up in the riots\n\nRiot police hold back protesters near a burning police vehicle after disorder broke out in Southport\n\nThree girls were killed in a bloody rampage on Hart Street on Monday. On Tuesday, a vigil was held for the victims on Lord Street. While it was going on, a man with a flick knife was arrested on Eastbank Street. On St Luke's Road, riots erupted outside a mosque - also on Tuesday\n\nThis afternoon Chairman of Merseyside Police Federation Chris McGlade revealed 56 officers had been hurt in a 'sustained and vicious attack', including one female officer with a broken nose.\n\nThe riot took place near a local mosque called Southport Islamic Society Mosque.\n\nMerseyside Police say the violence broke out following false rumours blaming a Muslim migrant for the murders of three young girls at a Taylor Swift dance workshop in Southport on Monday morning.\n\nPolice Chief Constable Serena Kennedy later revealed three people had been arrested on Tuesday night.She said: 'Our priority was to try and keep the communities of Southport safe and also to make sure officers remained safe.\n\n'Three arrests were made, however more will follow. It's impossible to say (how many will be arrested). It's really early days in the investigation.'\n\nPC Kennedy estimated 200 to 300 people were involved. She said: 'Initially, there were about 70 people who made their way away from the vigil and were making their way towards the mosque.\n\n'They suddenly became about 200 in number and then others joined that number.'\n\nResidents and locals were left terrified by the incident locking themselves up in their homes.\n\nSouthport burns: A street near a mosque goes up in flames as violent thugs took to the streets last night\n\nAround 200 protesters were seen taking to the streets. Police believe many were EDL supporters\n\nRioters wearing masks launch missiles towards police officers in Southport\n\nUniversity student Raj Malakar, 19, told the Mail: 'It was crazy to witness everything. I don't see any justifiable point at what they were doing. It was heinous.\n\n'It was frightening, we were fearful for our own safety. Due to our ethnic origin we closed all the blinds, turned the lights off and hid ourselves inside. We were all very shaken and my mum didn't sleep last night. We didn't know what would happen to us.\n\n'I came home from university expecting to relax for three months and this happens.'\n\nA few doors down the road Denise Mace, 51, and her chef husband Graham, 52, watched from inside also fearing for their safety and worrying their car parked outside would be smashed up.\n\nAs the police were forced back they quietly pleaded with officers to hold their ground as they filmed from an upstairs window.\n\n'It was terrifying, absolutely horrendous. We didn't know if they would come into our house. We were very lucky compared to other people. We were scared they would break in.'\n\nMrs Mace, a care consultant, said the local imam used to live next door and was a 'beautiful man.'\n\n'He would bring us food at Ramadan,' she said. 'This is not Southport, it was by senseless yobs who have come here for a fight.\n\nRiot police with shields and helmets hold back protesters after disorder broke out\n\nSmoke is seen billowing from a police van which was set ablaze. The mosque is seen on the right\n\nIqbal Ahmed, 32, was trapped inside the mosque for five and a half hours as hundreds of rioters pelted police with bricks, concrete and fireworks outside.\n\nMr Ahmed said he arrived for prayers at 7.30pm and was taunted with racist insults before heading to an upstairs prayer room where he and the others were forced to take shelter until 1am this morning.\n\nAs well as dodging broken glass, he said rioters were making sinister phone calls to the mosque on withheld numbers throughout the night threatening to kill them and their families.\n\nHis Volkswagen car, parked outside the mosque, also had its windscreen shattered by a hooded rioter.\n\nFollowing the riot - which left 27 officers needing hospital treatment and three police dogs injured - the mother of seven-year-old Elise spoke out to condemn the violence.\n\nGrieving Jenni Stancombe pleaded for the violence to end on social media.\n\nShe said: 'This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n'The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.'\n\nThe community has rallied together in the wake of the tragedy while others have offered rooms to those who needed a safe place to stay following the night of carnage.\n\nBuilders offered their services for free to rebuild walls demolished {"uri": "8252190029", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:58:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:58:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:57:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://guardian.ng/news/world/uk-vows-clampdown-after-clashes-over-deadly-stabbing/", "title": "UK vows clampdown after clashes over deadly stabbing", "body": "British Prime Minister Keir Starmer said those responsible for the violence that left police officers injured in protests after a mass stabbing that left three children dead would \"face the full force of the law\". Southport, a small seaside town near Liverpool in northwestern England, was reeling on Wednesday after clashes targeting a local mosque...\n\nBritish Prime Minister Keir Starmer said those responsible for the violence that left police officers injured in protests after a mass stabbing that left three children dead would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSouthport, a small seaside town near Liverpool in northwestern England, was reeling on Wednesday after clashes targeting a local mosque \"insulted the community as it grieved,\" Starmer said.\n\nSome 39 officers were injured, at least eight seriously, after a large group -- believed to be supporters of the far-right English Defence League (EDL) -- threw bricks at a local mosque and set cars on fire late on Tuesday, the local police and ambulance service said.\n\nAround 100 people battled police in riot gear and lit fires, according to an AFP reporter at the scene.\n\nThe violence broke out shortly after a vigil was held in the town centre, where hundreds fell silent in tribute to the victims of the mass stabbing at a Taylor Swift-themed event that also left five children and two adults critically injured.\n\nPolice have said they are not treating Monday's knife attack as terror-related, but have not released any details of the suspected attacker other than that he is 17 years old and born in the Welsh capital Cardiff. His parents were from Rwanda, according to the BBC.\n\n- Misinformation -\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male... and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Assistant Police Chief Alex Goss said after the clashes.\n\nHe said the violence had involved \"many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside\".\n\nHours after Monday's attack, social media was filled with posts spreading unverified information about the suspect's background.\n\nFar-right influencer Andrew Tate had posted a video on social media, viewed by nearly 15 million people, blaming the stabbing on an \"illegal migrant\".\n\nSpeaking to parliament before the clashes, interior minister Yvette Cooper said it was \"extremely important that people don't spread damaging misinformation online\".\n\nMayor of the Liverpool City Region, Steve Rotheram, said that \"haters\" would not prevail in Southport.\n\n\"We're known for our solidarity, people in our region will stick together, and the community will rebuild,\" Rotheram told AFP.\n\n- Town in shock -\n\nNine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar died in hospital early on Tuesday, police said. Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, died on Monday.\n\nPolice said the two wounded adults had been trying to protect the children. Tributes have been paid to the bravery of dance and yoga teacher Leanne Lucas, who was one of the wounded adults.\n\nUS pop star Swift said she was \"completely in shock\" over \"the loss of life and innocence, and the horrendous trauma inflicted on everyone\".\n\nAguiar was the daughter of Portuguese parents from Madeira. \"Her parents are in a state of shock,\" Portugal's communities minister Jose Cesario told AFP.\n\nHer family said in a tribute, \"Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our princess.\"\n\nResidents of the seaside town said they were struggling to come to terms with the deaths.\n\n\"You can feel in the air that it's affected the whole town. We're just a small little town, everyone knows everyone,\" mental health nurse Katy Watkinson told AFP.\n\nSara Taylor, a Southport resident from Portugal, used to see Alice Aguiar at the local Portuguese shop.\n\n\"When I first saw her picture... I just felt a chill down my spine,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "guardian.ng", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438796911", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:33:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:33:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:25:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/violence-erupts-southport-child-killings-212526212.html", "title": "Violence erupts in Southport after child killings", "body": "Violence erupts in Southport after child killings\n\nMartin Evans\n\n30 July 2024 at 10:25 pm\n\nViolent protests broke out in Southport on Tuesday night as hundreds of demonstrators clashed with police following the deadly knife attack on children attending a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nA mob gathered outside a mosque, hurling bricks, masonry and fireworks at officers, amid claims that police were not telling the truth about the suspect's background and his motives, with rumours swirling on social media.\n\nSmoke was seen billowing from the area after a police van was set on fire. A number of officers were injured, including one who suffered a suspected broken nose.\n\nIt came as a vigil was taking place nearby to remember the three girls who were killed in the attack, identified on Tuesday as six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar.\n\nThe violence flared hours after Yvette Cooper, the Home Secretary, warned that divisions were being stirred up in the wake of the attack. There has been mounting speculation online about the identity of the attacker and the motive behind his rampage.\n\nMerseyside Police described Tuesday night's scenes as \"sickening\" and said people were using the speculation about the attack to \"bring violence and disorder to our streets\".\n\nRussian state media were among those falsely identifying the suspect as an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat last year and sharing claims that he was on an MI6 watch list and was known to local mental health services.\n\nUnsubstantiated claims that the attacker shouted \"Allahu Akbar\" have also circulated on social media.\n\nIn a statement to the Commons, Ms Cooper said those peddling misinformation about the tragedy risked undermining the ongoing criminal investigation and were being disrespectful to the grieving families.\n\nHowever, her statement did not rule out that the investigation could become a terror inquiry.\n\nDowning Street also appealed for calm after Sir Keir Starmer was heckled during a visit to Southport, with some protesters accusing the police of covering up aspects of the case.\n\nNigel Farage, the Reform UK leader, said the heckling of the Prime Minister demonstrated how unhappy the public were with the state of law and order in the country.\n\nHe said important questions about the case remained, including whether there was any truth in suggestions that the suspect was on a security services watch list and whether it was terror-related.\n\nIn a video statement, Mr Farage said: \"I just wonder whether the truth is being withheld from us. I don't know the answer, but I think it is a fair and legitimate question. What I do know is that something is going horribly wrong in our once beautiful country.\"\n\nMerseyside Police officers are continuing to question a 17-year-old on suspicion of murder and attempted murder in connection with the attack.\n\nIt is understood that although police are not treating the attack as terror-related, it has not been ruled out. Counter-terror police are continuing to support the investigation.\n\nMs Cooper's statement raised the prospect that the investigation could become a terror inquiry. She said the authorities would examine what contact the suspect had with \"different agencies\", which could include the security services and police, as well as mental health services.\n\nThe Home Secretary also made reference to Martyn's Law, legislation about the safety of public venues that was proposed following the Manchester Arena terror attack in 2017, saying the Southport case would no doubt feature in the debates over the measure.\n\nA source said: \"Terror has not been entirely ruled out at this point. We recognise that it can go in any direction. All agencies are still involved, including counter-terror police. They are not leading the investigation, and it is not being treated as a terror incident, but they are still on hand. We don't want to categorically rule anything out.\"\n\nRussia Today cited claims by a website called Channel 3 Now that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat last year and was on an MI6 watch list. The Russian state-controlled television channel later updated its story to reflect that the claim had been retracted.\n\nChannel 3 Now claims to be a US-based website, although its Facebook page showed that it is partly managed from Pakistan, while its YouTube channel contains dozens of Russian-language videos.\n\nWith an incorrect name of the alleged attacker being shared widely online, Merseyside Police was forced to issue a statement.\n\nA spokesman for the force said: \"This name is incorrect, and we would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing.\"\n\nSpeaking about the violent protests on Tuesday night, Alex Goss, the Merseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable, said: \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\n\"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK, and speculation helps nobody at this time. Our officers should not have to face this, but we will be there tonight to ensure the safety of the local community who have suffered enough, and will arrest those involved in criminal behaviour.\"\n\nThe teenager being questioned by police cannot be named because of his age, but was born in Cardiff in 2007. It is understood his parents came to the UK from Rwanda in 2002.\n\nMs Cooper urged people to avoid speculating on the case and allow the police to get on with their job.\n\nShe told MPs: \"False information has already been extensively shared in the last 24 hours. Those who do this for their own purposes risk undermining a crucial criminal investigation, and I ask everyone to show some respect for the community in Southport and for families who are grieving and in trauma.\n\n\"In these dark and difficult moments, the police must be able to get on with their work and communities must be given the time and space to grieve and heal without outside voices seeking to use events to stir up division or advance their own views.\"\n\nThe Prime Minister's official spokesman said: \"People should listen to the police - they should not do anything that is going to make the police's job harder to manage the situation, to conduct their investigations. It is unhelpful to speculate on things like the motive and the circumstances around this.\"\n\nSteve Rotheram, the Mayor of Liverpool City Region, said: \"I don't understand that people want to weaponise the deaths of three children before the investigations have concluded.\"\n\nJames Cleverly, the shadow home secretary, called for people not to \"get involved in the grief of others\" by sharing misinformation relating to the attack on social media.\n\nMr Goss added: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. Tonight, they find themselves being attacked as they endeavour to prevent disorder.\n\n\"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about
