{"uri": "8251929075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:10:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:10:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:10:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/officers-injured-violent-disorder-southport-6451096-Jul2024/", "title": "Total of 22 officers injured in violent disorder in Southport in fallout from mass stabbing", "body": "Eight sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion, Merseyside Police said.\n\nA TOTAL OF 22 officers have been injured following \"violent disorder\" in Southport yesterday evening, Merseyside Police have said.\n\nViolent clashes between protesters and police erupted outside a mosque in Southport in the UK yesterday after three girls were killed in a knife attack.\n\nThe disorder yesterday involved protestors setting cars belonging to members of the public alight, bricks thrown at the local Mosque, the damage of a local convenience store, and wheelie bins set alight, police said.\n\nOf the 22 police officers, eight sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion. Other officers have suffered varying degrees of injury including head injuries, serious facial injuries, and one officer was knocked unconscious, the police department said.\n\nThree police dogs have also been injured, police reported - two having sustained leg injuries from bricks thrown on them, and another dog suffered burns to her back leg.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA 24-hour Section 60 Order, which gives officers enhanced stop and search powers to stop individuals in the area, has been introduced to the area running from 7:54pm today. Extra officers will remain in the area \"to provide a visible presence to reassure communities.\n\nA Section 34 Order, which gives officers powers to direct people who are engaging in anti-social behaviour or are likely to become in such incidents, has also been introduced.\n\nUnder the legislation, officers have the power to seize any item, including vehicles, used in the commission of anti-social behaviour.\n\n\"These powers will not be used for anyone visiting the area or going about their daily business,\" Merseyside Police said.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss, speaking last night, said of the conflict: \"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\n\n\"We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible.\"\n\nReaders like you are keeping these stories free for everyone... {"uri": "8251690714", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:56:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:56:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:56:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/uk/stabbing-of-3-girls-violence-near-southport-mosque-all-you-need-to-know/articleshow/112152576.cms", "title": "Stabbing of 3 girls, violence near Southport mosque: All you need to know - Times of India", "body": "A horrific stabbing incident at a Taylor Swift-themed dance event in Southport, northwest England, has left three young girls dead and eight others injured. The attack, which occurred at a community center, shocked the nation and led to widespread grief and outrage. In the aftermath, tensions flared, resulting in violent clashes between far-right protesters and police near a local mosque.\n\nThe suspect, a 17-year-old male, was arrested shortly after the attack.While police have confirmed that the attack is not being treated as terrorism-related, misinformation and false rumors have fueled anger, leading to violent protests. Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the violence, urging calm and unity as the community mourns the tragic loss of innocent lives.\n\nHere is all you need to know:\n\nWhat happened in Southport?\n\nOn Monday, a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance event in Southport resulted in the deaths of three young girls and injuries to eight others. The attacker, a 17-year-old male, entered the dance studio and began stabbing attendees.\n\nWho were the victims?\n\nThe victims were identified as Alice Dasilva Aguiar, 9, Elsie Dot Stancombe, 7, and Bebe King, 6. Alice's parents described her as their \"princess\" and said, \"Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our princess.\" Bebe King's family expressed their devastation, stating, \"No words can describe the devastation that has hit our family.\"\n\nWhat led to the violent clashes?\n\nFollowing the attack, fueled by false online rumors, protesters encircled the Southport Mosque and Islamic Cultural Centre, shouting \"English till I die\" as they hurled bottles and stones at cops, set a police van ablaze, and injured 22 officers. The protesters were believed to be supporters of the English Defence League.\n\nWhat did the police say about the suspect?\n\nMerseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said, \"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody.\" Police clarified that the suspect, born in Britain, was not an asylum seeker as some rumors claimed.\n\nHow did the community respond?\n\nThe community held a peaceful vigil to mourn the victims, but it was overshadowed by the violence that erupted later. Local leaders called for calm and unity. June Burns, the mayor of the Sefton region, urged people to be good to one another, stating, \"It's unbelievable that we find ourselves laying flowers for little girls who just wanted to dance.\"\n\nWhat was Prime Minister Keir Starmer's response?\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the violence, calling it \"thuggery\" and stating, \"Those who have hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\" He also emphasized the importance of addressing knife crime in the country.\n\nWhat is the significance of this incident in the context of UK knife crime?\n\nThe Southport attack is one of the most shocking incidents involving children in recent years. The rise in knife crime has been a growing concern in the UK, with calls for the government to take stronger action against bladed weapons. The attack has reignited debates about knife crime and public safety.\n\nHow did Taylor Swift react to the incident?\n\nTaylor Swift expressed her shock and sorrow on Instagram, saying, \"These were just little kids at a dance class. I am at a complete loss for how to ever convey my sympathies to these families.\" Her fans have raised over \u00a3250,000 to support the victims' families and the hospital treating the injured.\n\nWhat measures are being taken to prevent further violence?\n\nPolice have been deployed to maintain order and prevent further clashes. Authorities are urging the public to avoid spreading false information and to allow the investigation to proceed without speculation. The Liverpool Region Mosque Network called for unity and condemned the violence, stating, \"A minority of people are attempting to portray that this inhumane act is somehow related to the Muslim community. Frankly, it is not.\"\n\n(With inputs from agencies)\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. With an unwavering commitment to accuracy, depth, and timeliness, we strive to keep you informed about the ever-evolving world, delivering a nuanced understanding of international affairs to our readers. near the site of U.K. stabbing attack that killed 3 girls", "body": "Far-right protesters fueled by anger and false online rumors hurled bottles and stones at police, wounding more than 20 officers Tuesday outside a northwest England mosque near where three girls were fatally stabbed a day earlier.\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the \"thuggery\" and said the crowd had hijacked what had earlier been a peaceful vigil attended by hundreds in the center of Southport to mourn the dead and 10 surviving stabbing victims, seven of whom were in critical condition.\n\nPolice said the violent crowd that torched a police van and several cars was believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, a far-right group, and the mayhem was inspired by rumors about the identity of the teenage suspect arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Merseyside Police Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said.\n\nPolice previously said a suspect's name circulating on social media was incorrect and the boy was born in Britain, contrary to online claims he was an asylum seeker.\n\nThe Liverpool Region Mosque Network posted a statement decrying the \"heinous\" stabbing as an attack against society that was unconnected to Islam.\n\n\"A minority of people are attempting to portray that this inhumane act is somehow related to the Muslim community,\" the group said on the X social media platform. \"Frankly it is not, and we must not let those who seek to divide us and spread hatred use this as an opportunity.\"\n\nOfficers outside the Southport Mosque in riot gear were pelted with bricks torn from garden walls in the residential neighborhood by members of the crowd, some of whom wore masks, amid chants of \"No surrender!\" and \"English till I die!\" Firecrackers exploded, sirens wailed and a helicopter hovering overhead added to the chaos.\n\nTwenty-two officers were hurt, with eight suffering from more serious injuries that included fractures, lacerations and a concussion. Two police dogs were wounded by bricks and a third suffered burns.\n\nA day earlier, a short distance from the turmoil, the girls had taken part in a Taylor Swift-themed dance and yoga workshop on the first week of summer vacation when a teen armed with a knife entered the studio and began a vicious attack, police said.\n\n\"It's difficult to comprehend or put into words the horror of what {"uri": "8252394229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:57:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:57:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:56:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.newagebd.net/post/europe/241292/39-police-officers-injured-in-unrest-after-3-girls-killed-in-uk", "title": "39 police officers injured in unrest after 3 girls killed in UK", "body": "The United Kingdom prime minister, Keir Starmer, said those responsible for the violence that left police officers injured in protests after a mass stabbing that left three children dead would 'face the full force of the law'.\n\nSouthport, a small seaside town near Liverpool in northwestern England, was reeling on Wednesday after clashes targeting a local mosque 'insulted the community as it grieves', Starmer said.\n\nSome 39 officers were injured, at least eight seriously, after a large group -- believed to be supporters of the far-right English Defence League (EDL) -- threw bricks at a local mosque and set cars on fire late on Tuesday, the local police and ambulance service said.\n\nAround 100 people battled police in riot gear and lit fires, according to an AFP reporter at the scene.\n\nThe violence broke out shortly after a vigil was held in the town centre, where hundreds fell silent in tribute to the victims of the mass stabbing at a Taylor Swift-themed event that also left five children and two adults critically injured.\n\nPolice have said they are not treating Monday's knife attack as terror-related, but have not released any details of the suspected attacker other than that he is 17 years old and born in the Welsh capital Cardiff. His parents were from Rwanda, according to the BBC.\n\n'There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male... and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,' Assistant Police Chief Alex Goss said after the clashes.\n\nHe said the violence had involved 'many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside'.\n\nHours after Monday's attack, social media was filled with posts spreading unverified information about the suspect's background.\n\nFar-right influencer Andrew Tate had posted a video on social media, viewed by nearly 15 million people, blaming the stabbing on an 'illegal migrant'.\n\nSpeaking to parliament before the clashes, interior minister Yvette Cooper said it was 'extremely important that people don't spread damaging misinformation online'.\n\nMayor of the Liverpool City Region Steve Rotheram said that 'haters' would not prevail in Southport.\n\n'We're known for our solidarity, people in our region will stick together, the community will rebuild,' Rotheram told AFP.\n\nNine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar died in hospital early on Tuesday, police said. Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, died on Monday.\n\nPolice said the two wounded adults had been trying to protect the children. Tributes have been paid to the bravery of dance and yoga teacher Leanne Lucas, who was one of the wounded adults.\n\nUS pop star Swift said she was 'completely in shock' over 'the loss of life and innocence, and the horrendous trauma inflicted on everyone'.\n\nAguiar was the daughter of Portuguese parents from Madeira. 'Her parents are in a state of shock,' Portugal's communities minister Jose Cesario told AFP.\n\nHer family said in a tribute: 'Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our princess.'\n\nResidents of the seaside town said they were struggling to come to terms with the deaths.\n\n'You can feel in the air that it's affected the whole town. We're just a small little town, everyone knows everyone,' mental health nurse Katy Watkinson told AFP.\n\nSara Taylor, a Southport resident from Portugal used to see Alice Aguiar at the local Portuguese shop.\n\n'When I first saw her picture... Tensions have been high since the attack on Monday, July 29, and a large group of people have been seen shouting and pushing one another this evening (Tuesday, July 30) with police drafted in in an attempt to calm the escalating scenes.\n\nBroken bottles can be seen smashed in the middle of the street and items are being hurled at police vans, Manchester Evening News reports. Some police officers have suffered what appeared to be minor injuries in chaotic scenes outside the mosque.\n\nGet breaking news on BirminghamLive WhatsApp, click the link to join\n\nOfficers at the scene have equipped helmets and riot gear, with stones and bottles launched at them and police riot vans attacked. Firecrackers could be heard going off along with multiple police sirens sounding.\n\nMultiple men wearing masks and hoodies to cover their faces have been seen in a running battle with officers. Others were pictured with a George Cross flag next to a crate of cider.\n\nVideo on social media showed more police arriving with some officers seen walking through crowds with police dogs. Debris can be seen on the ground around the vans while police have been using their shields to deflect missiles thrown from the crowds.\n\nA helicopter is hovering over the area, and shocked local residents are out on the streets with roads busy with traffic. One man said Southport is \"edgy\" and others described the situation as \"horrendous\". Officers were also injured in the clashes, including one who suffered a broken nose.\n\nBut who exactly is the far right group that turned what was meant to be a peaceful night of remembrance for the three young girls killed and multiple other victims of the incident? The group was initially co-founded by Tommy Robinson in 2009, which he led until 2013.\n\nA partial statement from Merseyside Police this evening read: \"At around 7.45pm, a large group of people - believed to be supporters of the English Defence League - began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road in Southport.\"\n\nIt continued: \"The actions in Southport tonight will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside. We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\nThe EDL is a far-right organisation known for its Islamophobia. It views Islam as a primitive religion that is not compatible with life in England but claims to be a non-racist group, despite a number of members clearly spouting racist remarks over the course of its existence.\n\nDespite the EDL claiming it is not a racist organisation that advocates white supremacy, investigations into the group have unearthed some members using derogatory slurs about people often with South Asian or Arabic backgrounds. The group has claimed they wish to use peaceful and non-violent means to protest, but its members have been responsible for violent demonstrations across the country.\n\nStephen Yaxley-Lennon (aka Robinson) created the hateful group alongside Kevin Carroll, before eventually quitting the group in part due to infighting. Robinson cited the \"dangers of far-right extremism\" as a reason for leaving. {"uri": "8252715607", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:19:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:19:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:18:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/uk-news/streets-southport-theyre-heartbroken-horrified-29650553", "title": "On the streets of Southport they're heartbroken and horrified", "body": "Watching on through his shop CCTV cameras, Chanaka Balasuriya knew what was coming next. A crowd of masked thugs had gathered outside Windsor Mini Mart, and they were hurling rocks and other projectiles.\n\nFortunately, Chanaka had left the shop an hour earlier after concerned neighbours warned him to 'be careful' as a 'protest' was about to take place nearby. He headed straight home, where he and his wife, Thanuja, watched on helplessly as their shop was looted.\n\n\"We knew they were going to come in,\" Thanuja said. \"They broke the glass then pulled the shutter open.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Police issue update on 17-year-old arrested over Southport stabbings\n\nAfter prising open the front door, dozens of rioters poured inside the shop. They ransacked the shelves and smashed open the till, swiping the cash inside.\n\nOver the next few hours, looters came and went. So did the stock; alcohol, sweets, soft drinks, even ice creams were among the items taken.\n\n\"They were coming and going in dozens,\" said Thanuja. \"It was terrifying to watch.\"\n\nAt one stage, Thanuja says rioters 'threw a stick on fire' inside the shop. That was the moment it all became too much for her and her husband.\n\n\"We thought they were going to burn it down,\" she said. \"We turned it off because we didn't want to see.\"\n\nChanaka and Thanuja are not the only ones who have been left reeling following a night of violent disorder in Southport last night (Tuesday).\n\nNearly 40 police officers were injured after riots erupted outside a mosque in the town. The unrest started after a vigil was held to remember the lives of three little girls killed in a brutal stabbing in Southport on Monday.\n\nAs tensions ran high, a large mob - who police believe included supporters of the English Defence League - pelted police with rocks and bottles, set cars alight, threw bricks at a mosque and set wheelie bins on fire.\n\nThe night of carnage was the last thing Southport needed as it reeled in the aftermath of Monday's unthinkable tragedy, which claimed the lives of Bebe King, six, Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine.\n\nAfter the rioters dispersed yesterday evening, Chanaka and Thanuja headed down to their shop. They were greeted by a scene of devastation.\n\n\"There was a lot of damage,\" Thanuja said. \"Everything has to be replaced. I don't see the purpose of it.\"\n\nThe couple stayed at the shop until 4am before heading home to catch some sleep. When they returned this morning, police officers were carrying out investigations inside their store.\n\nAs they stood in the street, the owner of a neighbouring business pulled them to one side. \"If we can do anything, anything at all,\" she told Thanuja.\n\nShe is not the only one to have rallied around the couple, who have owned Windsor Mini Mart for four years. Before yesterday, they said they 'never had a single incident'.\n\n\"We have got so much support from the community,\" Thanuja explained. \"We feel blessed.\"\n\nOn the streets of Southport this morning (Wednesday), there was eerie sense of calm as residents rallied with brushes and shovels to begin the clean-up. Outside Southport Mosque, where the riots began, a crowd of people repaired a wall that had been damaged amid the disorder.\n\nAmong those handing out water to those cleaning the streets was Imam Ibrahim Hussein, who was inside the mosque when it was targeted last night. He had rushed down to the mosque, at the junction of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road, after hearing rioters were planning to gather outside.\n\n\"They started throwing things and hailing abuse,\" the Imam said. \"In no time, there were hundreds.\"\n\nRioters torched a clothing bank outside the mosque as the Imam said he heard shouts of 'we want our country back'.\n\n\"I was scared,\" he said. \"There were about eight of us inside and we had to barricade ourselves in.\"\n\nThis morning, a car with a smashed windscreen remained in the car park of the mosque - a casualty of last night's chaos.\n\nOyess Ali, 28, attends the mosque and lives close to the scene where the children were stabbed during a Taylor Swift-themed dance class on Monday. He heard 'screams' and witnessed the horrific aftermath as some of the victims were treated in the street outside.\n\n\"It's the worst thing that's happened in Southport,\" he said.\n\n\"Monday was horrific, then Tuesday happened, and now I'm thinking 'what's next?' The whole town is in shock.\n\n\"Southport is normally a very boring place, it's a small, quiet seaside town. We all get along.\"\n\nA combination of conspiracy theories, disinformation on social media, and a 'fake' Russian-based website laid the ground for the shocking rioting. This toxic mix linked to an entirely false, 'Arabic' name being circulated on social media - which far right yobs took as a cue to scapegoat Muslims.\n\nMr Ali said he heard talk of a 'protest' taking place outside the mosque earlier on Tuesday, but said he \"didn't really believe it was going to happen\".\n\n\"This riot took place because people were misled,\" he said. \"The majority of them were out of towners.\n\n\"They came prepared. They were in balaclavas and masks, they didn't come for the vigil.\"\n\nAs the crowds ran riot, several businesses and homes were caught in the crossfire. Tracey Whitfield's partner runs a plumbing and heating business in Sussex Road. Its windows were damaged by the heat from a police van that was set on fire by rioters.\n\nWhen she saw the footage of the van in flames, Tracey became worried that the shop may be next. She went down to collect some paperwork and described the scenes she witnessed as 'the worst of humanity'.\n\n\"It was absolutely horrendous,\" she said. \"There were people everywhere. There were flames, fireworks, and the van was on fire. Every bang made me jump.\n\n\"I couldn't believe the aggression towards the police. There was one lady - a police officer - who looked out cold. She was being dragged by her colleagues to an ambulance.\"\n\nNorman Wallis, chief executive of Southport Pleasureland, was among thousands who attended last night's vigil to remember the three girls killed earlier this week. After hearing something was going on outside the mosque, he said he went to \"have a look\".\n\nHe described those involved in last night's disorder as 'cowards'.\n\n\"These people have been bussed in to hijack a terrible tragedy,\" he said. \"They weren't from the town.\"\n\nMr Wallis said the disorder and those involved are 'not the face of the town'.\n\n\"Southport is not like that,\" he said. \"It's a very safe place.\n\n\"Southport is a very close community and everyone knows someone who knows these girls who have died and been stabbed.\n\n\"We're all heartbroken. I put my arms around my kids every day and I can't imagine not being able to do that again.\"\n\nAfter witnessing the disorder, Mr Wallis said he 'put the message out' for people to take part in a community clean-up this morning.\n\n\"I thought we have to do something about it,\" he explained. \"Everyone has brought shovels and brushes to clean everything away. {"uri": "8252303281", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:02:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:02:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:01:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.ewn.co.za/2024/07/31/uk-government-vows-clampdown-after-clashes-over-deadly-stabbing", "title": "UK government vows clampdown after clashes over deadly stabbing", "body": "SOUTHPORT, United Kingdom - British Prime Minister Keir Starmer said those responsible for the violence that left police officers injured in protests after a mass stabbing that left three children dead would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSouthport, a small seaside town near Liverpool in northwestern England, was reeling on Wednesday after clashes targeting a local mosque \"insulted the community as it grieves\", Starmer said.\n\nSome 39 officers were injured, at least eight seriously, after a large group - believed to be supporters of the far-right English Defence League (EDL) - threw bricks at a local mosque and set cars on fire late on Tuesday, the local police and ambulance service said.\n\nAround 100 people battled police in riot gear and lit fires, according to an AFP reporter at the scene.\n\nThe violence broke out shortly after a vigil was held in the town centre, where hundreds fell silent in tribute to the victims of the mass stabbing at a Taylor Swift-themed event that also left five children and two adults critically injured.\n\nPolice have said they are not treating Monday's knife attack as terror-related, but have not released any details of the suspected attacker other than that he is 17 years old and born in the Welsh capital Cardiff. His parents were from Rwanda, according to the BBC.\n\nMISINFORMATION\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male... and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Assistant Police Chief Alex Goss said after the clashes.\n\nHe said the violence had involved \"many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside\".\n\nHours after Monday's attack, social media was filled with posts spreading unverified information about the suspect's background.\n\nFar-right influencer Andrew Tate had posted a video on social media, viewed by nearly 15 million people, blaming the stabbing on an \"illegal migrant\".\n\nSpeaking to parliament before the clashes, interior minister Yvette Cooper said it was \"extremely important that people don't spread damaging misinformation online\".\n\nMayor of the Liverpool City Region Steve Rotheram said that \"haters\" would not prevail in Southport.\n\n\"We're known for our solidarity, people in our region will stick together, the community will rebuild,\" Rotheram told AFP.\n\nTOWN IN SHOCK\n\nNine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar died in hospital early on Tuesday, police said. Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, died on Monday.\n\nPolice said the two wounded adults had been trying to protect the children. Tributes have been paid to the bravery of dance and yoga teacher Leanne Lucas, who was one of the wounded adults.\n\nUS pop star Swift said she was \"completely in shock\" over \"the loss of life and innocence, and the horrendous trauma inflicted on everyone\".\n\nAguiar was the daughter of Portuguese parents from Madeira. \"Her parents are in a state of shock,\" Portugal's communities minister Jose Cesario told AFP.\n\nHer family said in a tribute: \"Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our princess.\"\n\nResidents of the seaside town said they were struggling to come to terms with the deaths.\n\n\"You can feel in the air that it's affected the whole town. Many were hurt by flying bricks with dozens of officers having to be led away from rioters to get treatment. One male officer appeared to have a head injury as he was driven for hospital treatment. A police riot van, mosque fencing, a pink car and a minimarket was looted during the violence, which has been met with widespread condemnation from locals.\n\nDo you know this brave woman? Get in touch at webnews@reachplc.com\n\nMerseyside Police believe the protesters included supporters of the far right English Defence League, who are believed to have travelled to Southport from outside the area.\n\nIn a clip that has gone viral on social media, one woman stood in front of the rioters holding up a sign with a message of peace as bricks and other objects were being thrown, ignoring the jeers from the mostly male crowd. Her sign read: \"One race - human, hope not hate, racism not welcome here.\"\n\nHer actions have been praised as \"brave\" and \"courageous\" online.\n\nTrouble erupted around 8pm after social media reports a protest was being held outside a local mosque. Gangs of masked men started to appear on the streets before throwing bricks at a local mosque smashing their windows as people hid inside. Later several jumped on top of a police riot van before it was torched. Then followed hours of violence with waves of attacks on police front lines.\n\nSeveral fires were started including what appeared to be an attempt to set fire to the mosque as burning bins and fence panelling erupted near the back entrance. Eventually after reinforcements arrived from Lancashire and elsewhere in the region the rioters were forced away from the mosque.\n\nThis morning the clear up was ongoing. The riot van has already been removed from the scene. One local said: \"At least the bin men don't have to empty the bins today - they've all been burnt.\" Andy Southwood, 54,local businessman, said: \"I didn't sleep much last night. In half an hour it exploded. It was chaotic. Mainly young kids with masks. It looked organised to me. It's crazy. It's a massive stain on the town.\"\n\nBut he pointed out locals were up through the night cleaning up. \"Random people are coming out with shovels and spades to help clean up. Riot police were called to St Luke's Road where hundreds of people had gathered on Tuesday evening.\n\nMerseyside Police confirmed officers are dealing with a disturbance on St Luke's Road in Southport which took place during a protest. A large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque.\n\nPhotos and video seen by the ECHO showed crowds gathered around police riot vans on St Luke's Road. A police van was also seen up in flames. Police said officers at the scene were dealing with criminal behaviour and violence, with bottles and wheelie bins being thrown at them.\n\nAs a result, an officer has suffered a suspected broken nose and police vehicles have been damaged and set alight. Frankly it is not, and we must not let those who seek to divide us and spread hatred use this as an opportunity.\n\n\"This evening, we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protestors, gathering outside. During a protest, a large group of people, who police said were believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque.\n\nPolice said officers at the scene are currently dealing with criminal behaviour and violence, with bottles and wheelie bins being thrown at them. In a statement posted by the Home Office on X, Ms Cooper said anyone responsible will face the 'full force of the law'.\n\nShe said: \"This morning when I visited Southport I saw a grieving community pulling together to support each other and care for the families who have lost loved ones in the face of an unspeakable tragedy.\n\n\"I met police officers and emergency service workers who showed incredible bravery in response to yesterday's attack and are leading an urgent and serious criminal investigation with the support of the community behind them.\n\n\"So these disgraceful scenes of violence and disorder we are witnessing this evening, with attacks on the Merseyside Police and a local mosque, are completely appalling. Those responsible will face the full force of the law.\"\n\nMs Cooper added: \"The community of Southport are reeling from a horrifying ordeal and families are grieving. This violent thuggery, which has overshadowed a peaceful vigil for three little girls, is an insult to the community and to all those who need the space to process what has happened and to heal.\n\n\"It is appalling that the local police, who have already dealt with extraordinarily difficult circumstances this week and are undertaking an urgent criminal investigation, should be on the receiving end of violence and abuse.\n\n\"Our focus must remain on supporting the police in their urgent criminal investigation into yesterday's attack and on supporting the families and community who have faced such tragedy and deserve everyone's prayers tonight.\"\n\nEarlier today, the Home Secretary spoke to the ECHO after she laid a floral tribute at the scene on Hart Street. scene.\n\nAlso read Third child dies following mass stabbing in UK 'Absolute farce': UK gripped by latest Boris Johnson plot twist British MP's killer was referred to counter-terrorism scheme: Reports stabbing at a Taylor Swift-themed event that also left five children and two adults critically injured.\n\nPolice have said they are not treating Monday's knife attack as terror-related, but have not released any details of the suspected attacker other than that he is 17 years old and born in the Welsh capital Cardiff. His parents were from Rwanda, according to the BBC.\n\nMisinformation\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male... and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Assistant Police Chief Alex Goss said after the clashes.\n\nHe said the violence had involved \"many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside\".\n\nHours after Monday's attack, social media was filled with posts spreading unverified information about the suspect's background.\n\nFar-right influencer Andrew Tate had posted a video on social media, viewed by nearly 15 million people, blaming the stabbing on an \"illegal migrant\".\n\nSpeaking to parliament before the clashes, interior minister Yvette Cooper said it was \"extremely important that people don't spread damaging misinformation online\".\n\nMayor of the Liverpool City Region Steve Rotheram said that \"haters\" would not prevail in Southport.\n\n\"We're known for our solidarity, people in our region will stick together, the community will rebuild,\" Rotheram told AFP.\n\nTown in shock\n\nNine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar died in hospital early on Tuesday, police said. {"uri": "8252071236", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:45:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:45:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:44:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/news/world-news/southport-protester-hit-brick-groin-33363981", "title": "Watch as rioting Southport 'thug' has bricks hit his head, back and privates", "body": "On Tuesday night, residents in Southport were forced to watch as far-right and English Defence League \"thugs\" took over their streets, tearing down their brick walls for projectiles to throw at police and setting fire to nearby vehicles.\n\nThe violent incidents occurred just a day after the community was rocked by a shocking mass stabbing which saw three young children killed at a Taylor Swift dance class.\n\nBut as videos of the violence began to circulate on social media, one clip showed a member of the rioting crowd squaring up to police, before being smacked hard in the head by a brick. Putting his hand to the back of his head after being struck, it looks like he sees blood on his hand - but then the man in a full grey Polo tracksuit has worse problems as he is hit by another brick, right where it hurts.\n\nREAD MORE: Southport stabbing: Violence erupts on streets as mosque attacked and police van set on fire\n\nREAD MORE: Southport stabbing victim, 9, named as family pay tribute and slam 'despicable' killer\n\nWincing from the first brick, which was aimed at a line of police officers, another brick can be seen sailing through the air, before smashing directly into the protester's testicles. This second blow clearly connected, as the man doubles over immediately.\n\nIn a moment of pain that half the population will likely be able to feel themselves, the man can be seen gingerly hobbling away from the police line that he had, only moments before, been aggressively approaching.\n\nThe rioters, who in their hours-long battle with Merseyside Police injured a whopping 39 officers and triggered a major incident for the North West Ambulance Service, can be heard asking the man if he is alright, as the masked people around him continued to hurl objects at police. Another can be heard reprimanding the aim of the thugs throwing bricks.\n\nOne social media user viewing the video commented \"serves him right\", while another X user shared the video, saying: \"Whatever your take on the goings on in Southport, this is inarguably very funny. Concussion, no b******** and nicked tomorrow for rioting.\"\n\nIn a statement on the riots, released late on Tuesday night, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\"\n\nHe continued: \"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park. This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\n\n\"We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible. Anyone with information can DM @MerPolCC or contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.\"\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. {"uri": "8252126049", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:18:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:18:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:17:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/thugs-came-streets-now-residents-29647415", "title": "'Thugs came into our streets' now residents pull together to clean up after a night of violence - Liverpool Echo", "body": "People from Southport have today been cleaning the streets after a \"major incident\" was declared\n\nResidents are today cleaning up in the aftermath of a protest in Southport. North West Ambulance Service confirmed paramedics treated 39 police officers after violent scenes broke out during a protest on St Luke's Road in Southport on Tuesday, July 30.\n\nThe ambulance service confirmed 27 officers were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene. It was declared as a \"major incident\" by emergency services.\n\nBricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire. A large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road. Cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire and bricks were thrown at a local mosque.\n\nDamage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set on fire, police said. Three police dogs have also been injured. Police Dogs Zoe and Ike have sustained leg injuries from bricks thrown at them. A third dog, PD Quga, also suffered burns to her back leg.\n\nPhotos and video seen by the ECHO showed crowds gathered around police riot vans on St Luke's Road. A police van was also seen up in flames. Following the scenes, residents living on the road and the surrounding area have come out in force to help with the clean up.\n\nNorman Wallis, owner of Southport Pleasureland, is helping clear the rubble. He told the ECHO: \"We're all coming together to try and help the people in Sussex Road and the area to clean up for the mess that was made by all those people, those thugs, that came into their street.\n\n\"They just totally destroyed the street, pulled the walls down, pulled fences down, set cars on fire, just terrible. We're all coming together to just try and help as a community.\"\n\nNorman added that Southport is a \"wonderful\" place which needs to be \"shouted about\" and the behaviour of the people last night does not reflect the area.\n\nCathy McGrath has been out on the clean up since 7.15am this morning. She said that the town should be grieving. Speaking to the ECHO, she said: \"I feel just angry and upset really. I went to the vigil last night and it was beautiful for the girls and the children and then you see last night.\n\n\"Those people don't represent the community, these people represent the community. They've spoilt it really and that's why I have come out today.\"\n\nDenise Mace also said: \"It was terrifying to be honest. Seeing the police come marching down and it was right outside my house. These people weren't from Southport and it wasn't a peaceful protest.\" She added: \"When they moved it so far, everyone just come out and started clearing up.\"\n\nSefton Council said its cleaning teams and neighbourhood support teams have been out since 3am trying to clear away some of the destruction left by last nights disorder. It added they have been working hard to try and remove items and debris as quickly and as safely as possible. Not satisfied with the damage they had caused, they surrounded one and began jostling to flip it over.\n\nMoments later there was a loud bang, launching a fireball into the sky to loud cheers from the protesters that left smoke billowing into the sky.\n\nIt followed chants of \"No Surrender\" and \"English till I die\" as balaclava-clad thugs hurled bricks and fireworks at police and the Southport Islamic Society Mosque.\n\nSome later ran away as police charged with dogs towards them after the mob tore down garden walls and hurled rubble at vans.\n\nThe violence flared in the wake of the mass knife attack on Monday at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club in which three schoolgirls were killed.\n\nSpeculation has swirled online about the identity of the attacker and his motives, and last night police claimed that people used this \"to bring violence and disorder to our streets.\n\nMerseyside Police said \"a large group of people believed to be supporters of the English Defence League\" began to throw items towards the mosque at around 7.45pm.\n\nThe mosque at the centre of the protest had extended its 'deepest sympathies' to the families of those caught up in the Southport knife attack on Monday.\n\nYet it became the flashpoint for rioters who shouted \"we are doing this for our girls\" as they threw missiles at police and the building.\n\nOfficers put on helmets and riot gear after stones and bottles were launched and police vehicles damaged and set on fire.\n\nMeanwhile, figures in masks scoured the ground for bricks littering the floor to throw at lines of officers.\n\nHeavy thuds were heard as the vans took hits and police raised their shields against incoming missiles.\n\nWhile many ran away from police chasing them with batons, others went in the opposite direction, scuffling with those in uniform. One police officer was seen with blood streaming down her face. Police said an officer suffered a suspected broken nose.\n\nThe mob grew quickly as protesters arrived on bike and on foot only an hour after a vigil took place on the other side of the seaside town. There, it was grief, rather than anger, that was on display.\n\nDarren Colenutt, 58, brought three generations of his family to quietly mourn the killings of the three little girls.\n\nHis stepdaughter Chelsea Porter, 28, had brought her daughters River, two, and Lilly, nine, who was booked in to attend one of the workshops at the Hart Space later in the year.\n\nMr Colenutt's daughter Sovereign Porter, 22, was also there, among thousands who gathered outside the 19th century Atkinson Theatre, a mile from the attacks, with his other granddaughter Isabella, four.\n\n\"Nobody would think this would happen in Southport,\" Mr Colenutt said.\n\n\"My granddaughter was due to go to an event later in the year with the same organisers. It could have been anyone, we are just a lovely little town.\"\n\nSovereign said: \"Even though it's not our family it affects you so, so much. Southport is in mourning. We are all in shock. We haven't been out until now. My heart can't take it.\"\n\nTwo days ago, the town of 95,000 was only known as the quiet seaside resort associated with beaches, piers and fairground rides.\n\nOn Tuesday, it was acknowledged that Southport is now a world-famous name for all the wrong reasons.\n\nAs mourners held white candles, purple balloons or clutched teddies and unicorns, Martin Abrahams, the spiritual leader at Southport Hospital, said: \"Southport is not used to global attention.\n\n\"To be known around the globe for a defining incident has shook us all to the core.\n\n\"Taylor Swift, who herself has commented on events, and her bracelets of friendship, which people are encouraged to make and swap and share, remind us we should never feel alone.\n\n\"Clearly the crowds tonight show we want to stand together.\"\n\nWhile those at the vigil shed tears rather than hurling bricks, the mourners, like the protesters, are looking for answers.\n\n\"It's just kids enjoying a holiday, it's unheard of,\" Mr Colenutt said. \"There are little bits of crime on estates but nothing like this. We all want answers. The kids are petrified.\n\n\"It's a very friendly town, it's welcoming. Your heart melts, you can feel how the families feel.\"\n\nLesley Francis, 64, who works in a nursery, was waiting in the queue to leave flowers.\n\n\"You can't stop thinking about those people living a nightmare,\" Ms Francis said. \"Why would somebody target children?\"", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "neil_johnston@aol.co.uk", {"uri": "8252589299", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:58:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:58:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:57:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/what-caused-the-southport-riots-29647232", "title": "What caused the Southport riots", "body": "It's the last thing Southport needed. Far right thugs, intent on trouble, rioting in the town as it reeled in the aftermath of the unthinkable. Southport isn't used to days like these. Summer holidays in the traditional seaside resort are usually a time of joy, as visitors from across the north west and beyond flock to its coast.\n\nInstead, these are days of mourning and disbelief. Three children are dead and five are in a critical condition after a stabbing attack at a dance class. And then, on Tuesday, the town became the scene of violent clashes in and around a mosque as far right thugs, fuelled by lies, sought to exploit the tragedy.\n\nThe truth behind Monday's awful crime will, in time, be unravelled by investigators. We can't yet say how such horror descended on suburban streets. But how it was that a grieving community found itself swamped by agitators fighting with police is a question that can begin to be answered now. How on earth did that happen?\n\nREAD MORE: Southport stabbings LIVE: Community clean-up begins after 'disgraceful' night of violence and rioting\n\nA combination of conspiracy theories, disinformation on social media, and a 'fake' Russian-based website laid the ground for the shocking rioting, which led to 39 police officers being treated by paramedics and families and children already rocked by tragedy cowering behind curtains, it emerged today.\n\nThis toxic mix linked to an entirely false, 'Arabic' name being circulated on social media - which far right yobs took as a cue to scapegoat Muslims. Windows of the mosque were smashed and cars parked near it attacked. Police were pelted with rocks and bottles. Yobs knocked down walls to hurl masonry at officers and police vehicles and wheelie bins were set alight. The sky burned.\n\nWorryingly, this is the second time in the last week that trouble has flared after agitators have seized on a sensitive situation, without all the facts being known, to pursue a divisive agenda.\n\nDays ago, it was feared that a video of a police officer's conduct during an incident at Manchester Airport would trigger serious unrest - tensions which only eased after the M.E.N exclusively obtained and published another video which helped increase understanding of the context.\n\nWhile the events in Southport and Manchester Airport were not in any way linked, in both there was a rush to judgement, with the most sinister consequences felt in Southport, where a tragedy was hijacked and a shellshocked community was subjected to yet more anguish.\n\nIt started on Tuesday afternoon with a series of posts on a website. Named as Channel 3 Now, and said to be linked to Russia, the website posted a fake name for the attacker, which was subsequently shared by millions online.\n\nThis name - Ali Al-Shakati - appeared to have been generated by the website - which, the Guardian reports, 'mixes potentially AI-generated US and UK news content and is styled like a mainstream American network news channel' - before being shared online on X by far right influencers and social media accounts.\n\nIt's understood that conspiracy theorist 'content creators' headed to Southport amid unsubstantiated claims that police were somehow 'suppressing' information.\n\nMerseyside Police was even forced into issuing a statement to confirm a name for the 17 year-old arrested being shared online was wrong, amid false claims he's an asylum seeker.\n\nBy this stage, a violent mob was hellbent on terrorising a mosque near the scene of the stabbings. This violence 'will involve many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside', Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss, in a statement last night, said.\n\nThe senior officer went on to reference 'much speculation and hypothesis around the status' of the teenager arrested and said 'some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets', adding: \"We have already said that the person arrested was born in the UK and speculation helps nobody at this time.\"\n\n\"What was done for clicks, what was done to socialise hatred/violence via misinformation after these shocking murders and what platform responsibility is are important questions,\" Sunder Katwala , director of the thinktank British Future, wrote of the incident.\n\nHe also referenced the Channel 3 Now website, calling it a 'scam/fake news channel' that 'seems to have invented a fake Arab name and run a false story about Southport, generating 1.4m impressions'.\n\nMr Katwala said the 'pace' with which misinformation was spreading after the incident 'presents important challenges to social media platforms and ultimately for policymakers as regulators and lawmakers if platforms cannot respond'.\n\n\"There are different types of bad faith actor spreading misinformation at pace in heightened circumstances,\" he said. \"There may be low quality feeds masquerading as news sites, even scraping social media rumours to produce AI-generated content.\n\n\"There can be more deliberate networks of extreme actors, including far right groups and foreign intelligence actors. The platforms will struggle to get everything right in real time. But it matters as to whether they have the will and capacity to respond to the most serious threats, such as those breaching legal constraints and injunctions and those using heightened moments with the intent of socialising people towards extremism and violence.\"\n\nThe far-right, it appears, seized on the narrative it wanted. That isn't the narrative that is welcome in Southport, as evidenced by the family of one of the girls murdered, seven year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe. Despite her grief, mum Jenni wrote: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\"\n\nPolice, she added, have been 'nothing but heroic' and 'they and we don't need this'. In her darkest hour, it was a post she shouldn't have had to make.\n\nAfter yobs said by police to be linked to the English Defence League surrounded his mosque in Southport, mosque chairman Ibrahim Hussein revealed today he's been sent flowers and people have offered to repair damaged walls for free.\n\nThe love he felt today was in stark contrast to the hate waged last night. Mr Hussein was trapped in the mosque with eight others and said he feared it was going to be burnt down. He only managed to leave under a police guard.\n\nAsked if he thought the far-right had hijacked his town, Mr Hussein said: \"Naturally. This is a beautiful town. We've lived here 30 years, no bother at all. We love this community. The community loves us. We don't have any issues.\"\n\nNazir Afzal, the former chief prosecutor who is Chancellor of the University of Manchester, said rioters were 'encouraged' with 'lies and bigotry'. He said the 17 year-old boy arrested was born in Britain to Rwandan parents - and Rwanda 'is 98 per cent Christian'.\n\n\"So why attack a mosque,\" he wrote on X, formerly Twitter. \"Responsibility for the riots lies with all who participated and all who encouraged it.\"\n\nA statement from the Liverpool Region Mosque Network, meanwhile, said the stabbings, which they called 'heinous', were 'unconnected to Islam'. \"A minority of people are attempting to portray that this inhumane act is somehow related to the Muslim community,\" they said. \"Frankly it is not, and we must not let those who seek to divide us and spread hatred use this as an opportunity.\"\n\nFalse claims had also spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat. Police have said that, although the motive for the attack is unclear, it is not believed to be terror-related, although Yvette Cooper, the Home Secretary, said the police investigation would pursue 'any contact the suspect may or may not have had with different agencies' before the incident.\n\nThere were concerns in Downing Street even before a brick was thrown, with No 10 urging the public to avoid 'unhelpful' speculation about the stabbings amid concerns that misreporting online could inflame community tensions.\n\nThe Home Secretary, meanwhile, giving a statement in the Commons ahead of the summer recess, urged social media companies to 'take some responsibility' for the wild speculation.\n\nSouthport MP Patrick Hurley, meanwhile, condemned 'beered-up thugs' involved. Images from the peaceful vigil outside Southport's Atkinson arts venue, staged before the violence, showed a number of men who turned up with a crate of cider and flags.\n\nMr Hurley told the BBC: \"Even if this lad, the 17-year-old, turns out to be Muslim, under no circumstances does that justify any attack on a mosque by anybody at all.\" He also hit out at the 'swirling morass' of social media 'lies and propaganda.\n\nMr Hurley pointedly said the riots in Southport occurred because of the 'propaganda and lies' spread on social media about the identity of the attacker.\n\nHe told Times Radio: \"We'd had all sorts of lies being spread and misinformation being spread about the alleged perpetrator and some people with the best of intentions then they tried to rebut this, they tried to argue back, but all that happens is you're just amplifying people's false messaging.\n\n\"This misinformation doesn't just exist on people's internet browsers and on people's phones. It has real world impact.\n\n\"And what happened is that the real world impact of that was that we then had hundreds of people descending on the town, descending on Southport from outside of the area, intent on causing trouble, either because they believe what they've written, or because they are bad faith actors who wrote it in the first place, in the hope of causing community division.\"\n\nThe EDL - co-founded by Tommy Robinson - today faced calls for it to be proscribed under terrorism laws. In a letter to the Home Secretary, Scotland's former first minister Humza Yousaf claimed 'Britain has a far-right problem', urging her to use anti-terrorism powers to make membership of the group illegal.\n\n\"It is time we took on the English Defence League and the evil ideology that drives them,\" he wrote. He added that such action would not provide an 'overnight fix', but would demonstrate the Government's intention to be 'proactive in tackling far-right violence and terror that has been allowed to run rampant in the streets of the UK for far too long'.\n\nMeanwhile, the Deputy Prime Minister, Angela Rayner, criticised the \"disgraceful\" rioting in Southport and \"disrespectful\" social media theories as she urged people to allow the police to establish the facts.\n\nShe said: \"I think there's been a couple of instances recently where, especially particularly online, where theories and things are whipped up, whereas actually it turns out to be not true or not the full picture.\n\n\"And I think there's a culture now where people want to instantly get the facts, but actually it's important that police and those people that are doing the work are able to carry out that work. And it's important for justice as well, because we have law and order in the UK, and it's important that those authorities are able to establish the facts and then to be able to bring those forward.\n\n\"But speculation and some of the untruths that have been put around social media, not only is that creating tensions and fear in the community, but it's disrespectful to family who maybe want those answers that haven't got those answers.\"\n\nThe mayor of Liverpool, Steve Rotheram, said it was 'too easy for people with nefarious intent to go online and to say things that aren't factual and then for people to believe those things'. \"It leaves a very sour taste in the mouth that these people believe they can come here and divide our community,\" he said. \"They won't be doing that and the haters won't win out.\"\n\nHe said 'the one' thing 'social media wants to find out is the religion' of the teenager arrested.\n\n\"So you have to ask yourself the questions, why would anybody want to know the religion of the perpetrator of this vicious and heinous crime? And it's to do exactly what we just talked about earlier, which is to stir up more tension in this community,\" he said.\n\nPolice today announced they've been given more time by a magistrate to continue to question the 17 year-old arrested. It's been confirmed that he was born in the U.K, to Rwandan parents, lived in Cardiff before moving north, and is from the Banks area of Southport.", "source": {"uri": "manchestereveningnews.co.uk", More info\n\nA courageous woman was pictured bravely standing up to EDL thugs by holding up a powerful sign during riots in Southport.\n\nA major incident was declared on July 30, after hundreds of rioters took to the seaside town streets, lobbing bricks and flares outside a mosque while more than 50 cops trying to control the crowds.\n\nIn a clip that has gone viral on social media, one woman stood in front of the thugs holding up a sign with a message of peace with a sign that read: \"One race - human, hope not hate, racism not welcome here.\"\n\nDespite bricks and other items being lobbed at her as well as aggressive jeers from the crowd the lady bravely stood her ground to get the message across, reports the Mirror. Her brave actions amidst a night of disgraceful behaviour have been widely praised by many.\n\nDozens of cops were hurt by flying bricks and had to be taken away from the chaos to get treatment, and one male officer appeared to have a head injury as he was driven for hospital treatment. A police riot van, mosque fencing, a pink car and a minimarket were looted during the violence, which has been met with widespread condemnation from locals.\n\nMerseyside Police believe the protesters included supporters of the far-right English Defence League, who are believed to have travelled to Southport from outside the area. Trouble erupted around 8pm after social media reports a protest was being held outside a local mosque.\n\nGangs of masked men started to appear on the streets before throwing bricks at a local mosque smashing their windows as people hid inside. Later several jumped on top of a police riot van before it was torched. Then followed hours of violence with waves of attacks on police front lines.\n\nThe violence followed the stabbings of Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, at A large group of people attacked the Southport Islamic Society Mosque on the corner of Sussex Road and St Luke's Road.\n\nFollowing a vigil for those affected by the Southport stabbings, the group tore bricks from garden walls and threw them at the mosque, smashing some of its windows, and a convenience store. Police officers were attacked and cars belonging to members of the public were torched. Police said the group was made up of English Defence League supporters.\n\nAn ambulance service spokesperson said 39 patients were treated - all of them police officers. Twenty-seven were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at the scene.\n\nWhen contacted by the ECHO, a mosque spokesperson condemned yesterday's attacks. They said: \"First and foremost we are all very shocked and saddened about what occurred on Monday. Our thoughts and prayers are with the families of those affected. What followed last night on the part of the far-right was an insult to the families and a town that is collective in its grieving.\"\n\nResidents of Southport are cleaning up in the aftermath of the horrific scenes. Norman Wallis, owner of Southport Pleasureland, told the ECHO: \"We're all coming together to try and help the people in Sussex Road and the area to clean up for the mess that was made by all those people, those thugs, that came into their street. They just totally destroyed the street, pulled the walls down, pulled fences down, set cars on fire, just terrible. We're all coming together to just try and help as a community.\"\n\nResident Cathy McGrath said: \"I feel just angry and upset really. His parents were from Rwanda, according to the BBC.\n\nMisinformation\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male... and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" Assistant Police Chief Alex Goss said after the clashes.\n\nHe said the violence had involved \"many people who do not live in the Merseyside area or care about the people of Merseyside.\"\n\nHours after Monday's attack, social media was filled with posts spreading unverified information about the suspect's background.\n\nFar-right influencer Andrew Tate had posted a video on social media, viewed by nearly 15 million people, blaming the stabbing on an \"illegal migrant.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSpeaking to parliament before the clashes, interior minister Yvette Cooper said it was \"extremely important that people don't spread damaging misinformation online.\"\n\nMayor of the Liverpool City Region Steve Rotheram said that \"haters\" would not prevail in Southport.\n\n\"We're known for our solidarity, people in our region will stick together, the community will rebuild,\" Rotheram told AFP.\n\nTown in shock\n\nAdvertisement\n\nNine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar died in hospital early on Tuesday, police said. Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, died on Monday.\n\nPolice said the two wounded adults had been trying to protect the children. Tributes have been paid to the bravery of dance and yoga teacher Leanne Lucas, who was one of the wounded adults.\n\nUS pop star Swift said she was \"completely in shock\" over \"the loss of life and innocence, and the horrendous trauma inflicted on everyone.\".\n\nAguiar was the daughter of Portuguese parents from Madeira. \"Her parents are in a state of shock,\" Portugal's communities minister Jose Cesario told AFP.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHer family said in a tribute: \"Keep smiling and dancing like you love to do our princess.\"\n\nResidents of the seaside town said they were struggling to come to terms with the deaths.\n\n\"You can feel in the air that it's affected the whole town. Times of India", "body": "Violent clashes have erupted between demonstrators on Wednesday and law enforcement after a sizable group assembled near a mosque in Southport, UK.\n\nVideos of the demonstration shared on social media platforms depicted a police vehicle engulfed in smoke and crowds launching bottles and bricks at police officers huddled together behind riot shields.\n\nA video shared by journalist associated with PA Media shows vehicles on fire and riot police with shields in an attempt to stop the violence.\n\nThe incident occurs amid heightened tensions in the town following a stabbing attack yesterday, which claimed the lives of three children while they were participating in a Taylor Swift themed yoga and dance workshop in Southport on Monday afternoon.\n\nPolice vans and officers are maintaining a presence outside the mosque, against the backdrop of chants from certain sections of the crowd, including \"No surrender!\" and \"English till I die!\"\n\nThe Telegraph observed riot police accompanied by dogs charging at protesters, forcing them back towards a nearby railway bridge.\n\n\"There has been much speculation and hypothesis around the status of a 17-year-old male who is currently in police custody, and some individuals are using this to bring violence and disorder to our streets,\" said assistant chief constable Alex Goss.\n\nMeanwhile, in an address to the House of Commons on Tuesday evening, Yvette Cooper, the home secretary, cautioned against exploiting the tragic deaths of three schoolgirls to \"stir up division\" and disseminate false information online.\n\nShe told MPs, \"False information has already been extensively shared in the last 24 hours. {"uri": "8252670646", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:51:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:51:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:49:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/watch-southport-demonstrator-hit-brick-115045357.html", "title": "Watch: Southport rioter hit by bricks", "body": "Footage has emerged of a rioter in Southport being hit in the groin with a brick.\n\nVideo showed the man - who had been squaring up to police in riot gear just a few seconds earlier - doubling over in pain and staggering away after being hit by the object, thrown by a fellow agitator.\n\nThe incident happened during a night of violence in the seaside town on Tuesday, during which police were attacked with bottles, bricks, bins and other missiles. A van was also set on fire.\n\nThe disorder followed a vigil to commemorate three children who were killed while attending a Taylor Swift-themed yoga and dance workshop on Monday.\n\nFootage of the violence spread widely on social media, including a video that showed a man, dressed in a grey tracksuit, appearing to taunt police officers by putting his hands on his hips and dancing.\n\nHe was then struck in the back of the head by a projectile object and retreated back into the mob, holding his head in his hands and checking for blood.\n\nAs he walked away, another brick hit him, this time in the groin, with such force that it caused him to double over and wince in pain. He was then helped away by rioters, including one wearing a balaclava.\n\nOne demonstrator could be heard saying: \"Ooh, d--- shot.\" Another said: \"F---ing hell, boys.\"\n\nThe riot was condemned by police and politicians, with Sir Keir Starmer saying the mob had \"hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery\" and \"insulted the community as it grieves\".\n\nMerseyside Police Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said three people were arrested on Tuesday night.\n\n53 officers were injured of which 49 were Merseyside Police and four were Lancashire Police\n\nEight sustained serious injuries including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion and were treated in hospital.\n\nOther officers suffered varying degrees of injury including head injuries, serious facial injuries and one was knocked unconscious.\n\nFour men were arrested and taken into custody, three on suspicion of violent disorder and one on suspicion of affray and possession of a bladed article\n\nWorshippers were forced to take shelter in a mosque as a mob attacked the building.\n\nThe ugly scenes followed the killings of six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot People dressed in dark clothing with their faces covered were spotted jumping on police vehicles and one emergency service van was then set alight.\n\nRiot police were then deployed to St Luke's Road in Southport where the violent scenes were taking place. And it is there where a bloke was filmed - in a now-viral moment - goading the riot police before swiftly being caught in the balls by what appears to be a large rock during mid-trajectory towards the officers.\n\nREAD MORE: Southport stabbing: Girl, 9, becomes third child to die after attack at Taylor Swift class\n\nClick here for the latest news from the Daily Star\n\nThe clip shared widely on Twitter/X shows the unnamed man jumping up and down chanting something unintelligible towards officers while standing by a police riot van.\n\nAnd then moments later, in a different location but standing directly in front of the cops, he was seen attempting to goad them . . . before turning round and being hit directly in the private parts, before hunching over in pain.\n\nThe clip was dubbed \"cinema,\" with social media users showing very little sympathy for the bloke. One said: \"Yup that's the greatest. Pure Cinema.\" And a second called it \"perfect karma\".\n\nAnother said it was a \"splendid end to his evening,\" while a fourth said it was \"poetic justice\" - and another called him a \"human riot shield\".\n\nThere was a serious side to the riots, which were sparked by far right groups descending on the area after the alleged murder of three young girls during a stabbing spree, in which five other children and two adults, one believed to be class organiser Leanne Lucas, were left in a critical condition.\n\nA 17-year-old boy has been arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder in relation to the stabbings.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said moments after the riots started: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\n\n\"In the last 24 hours, we have seen overwhelming support and sympathy from the community and wider Merseyside communities for the families who are currently trying to deal with their loss and care for victims injured during the major incident.\n\n\"Yesterday, our officers and other members of the emergency services were faced with one of the most difficult situations they will ever face. The suspect was born in Britain, they said.\n\nA total of 39 police officers were treated for injuries, including 27 who were taken to hospital, North West Ambulance Service said early on Wednesday.\n\n\"Offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park,\" Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss of Merseyside Police said in a statement.\n\n\"This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of {"uri": "8252318849", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:10:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:10:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:09:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.indy100.com/news/southport-far-right-protester-brick", "title": "Southport far-right rioter receives brick to the gentials in 'brutal' viral video", "body": "As the community of Southport and indeed the rest of the country continues to process Monday's fatal stabbing of three girls at a Taylor Swift dance event, and the far-right violence which unfolded in the town on Tuesday night, Twitter/X users have found comfort in a \"brave\" woman confronting protesters - and laughter in a far-right rioter being hit in the nether regions by a brick from his own mob.\n\nIn the footage, which has gone viral on the platform, a white man in a grey hoodie and jogging bottoms can be seen approaching riot police with his hands on his hips, mocking officers with a small dance.\n\nExcept moments later, an object - believed to be a brick - is seen connecting with the back of his head, just after another object hits his chest.\n\nThen, as he slowly retreats back to the mob and places a hand to his head to check for blood, a brick is thrown which hits him straight in his 'Crown Jewels', so to speak - with the individual doubling over in pain as a result as he staggers to safety.\n\nIt's been described as \"lovely stuff\" and \"one small positive\" by those condemning the disorder:\n\nIt's even sparked Simpsonsreferences:\n\nWhile other users have compared the video of the man's bricked a with one filmed moments earlier, in which he displays \"bravado\":\n\nMerseyside Police has reported that 22 officers were injured following the violent scenes in the town on Tuesday night, with eight sustaining serious injuries \"including fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and concussion\".\n\nOther officers suffered head and facial injuries, one was knocked unconscious, and three police dogs were injured.\n\nCars and wheelie bins were set alight, bricks were thrown at the local mosque and a convenience store was damaged.\n\nThe prime minister, Sir Keir Starmer, said those who took part in the \"violence and thuggery\" had \"insulted the community as it grieves\", while Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the disorder as \"appalling\".\n\nShe added: \"It is appalling that the local police, who have already dealt with extraordinarily difficult circumstances this week, and are undertaking an urgent criminal investigation, should be on the receiving end of violence and abuse.\"\n\nJenni Stancombe, the mother of one of the girls killed in the attack - Elsie Dot Stancombe - also called for the violence to stop, with the Liverpool Echo reporting she said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight. The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nA 17-year-old male from Banks in Lancashire, born in Cardiff, has been arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder in connection with Monday's stabbing.\n\nPolice are urging anyone with information or video footage of the incident, or of the violence and disorder which followed the next day,
