{"uri": "8252321956", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:12:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:12:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:11:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://www.breitbart.com/europe/2024/07/31/riots-erupt-in-england-after-mass-stabbing-left-three-children-dead/", "title": "Pix: Riots Erupt in England After Mass Stabbing Left Three Children Dead", "body": "Riots broke out in the English seaside town of Southport on Tuesday after the gruesome mass stabbing, allegedly by a migrant-heritage teen that left three children dead.\n\nMerseyside Police announced that a \"major incident\" had been declared after riots saw 39 police officers injured, 27 of whom were hospitalised after violence erupted during a protest over the attack on a children's 'Taylor Swift' dance party in Southport on Monday that left three young girls dead and a further ten people injured.\n\nThe force said that officers sustained bone fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose, and a concussion during the mayhem outside a local mosque, which saw people throw bricks, bottles, and other makeshift missiles at the police and law enforcement vehicles set on fire.\n\nAs a result, Merseyside Police put in place a 24-hour Section 60 Order to give officers the right to stop and search anyone in the area without the need to demonstrate a cause.\n\nThe force also instituted a Section 34 Order, which gives officers \"the power to seize any item, including vehicles, used in the commission of anti-social behaviour\". It also allows for police to arrest anyone returning to the area who had been instructed by police to leave.\n\nAccording to the local Liverpool Echo newspaper, police suspect that the riots were encouraged by the English Defence League (EDL), an organisation that has been disbanded for nearly a decade and whose founder, Tommy Robinson, left the country prior to this week's attack. Many legacy media outlets and political figures characterised the protests on Tuesday as \"far-right\".\n\nLeading the condemnation was Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer, who pledged to bring down the \"full force of the law\" on those involved in the riots.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper branded the outbreak of violence as a \"a total disgrace,\" saying: \"It is so appalling to now see those same police facing violent attacks from thugs on the streets who have no respect for a grieving community.\"\n\nBut some were quick to note the difference in the Home Secretary's tone following the Southport riots to during Roma riots in Leeds just five days earlier, in which she did not refer to the rioters as \"thugs\" but merely \"individuals.\" Lord Goldsmith, a former government minister, opined it was right to be strong on disorder but said Cooper's statement \"couldn't contrast more starkly with Home Office Ministers' reactions to the Manchester riots where violent thugs demanded instant justice 'or else' & where Ministers bent over backwards to explain that they 'understood' the anger.\"\n\nHe asked: \"Why has the Home Office response to these two events been so different? Can they not see how this feeds the narrative of a two tier approach and drives people to the far right? It is extraordinarily shortsighted and unwise\".\n\nOthers were very keen to see ulterior motives. Former Scottish First Minister, Humza Yousaf, said people who protest against the killings of children don't actually care about children. He said: \"Attacking mosques and chanting Islamaphobic abuse. Let's not pretend the far-right care one jot about children murdered in Southport. These thugs are scum who are exploiting the killing of children for their own bigoted ends. This is what happens when you appease the far-right.\"\n\nFollowing the mass stabbing the day prior, Yousaf, Scotland's first Muslim leader, said: \"Simply awful. Our only response to the evil we witnessed in Southport yesterday should be an outpouring of grief for the children and adults killed in such a senseless attack. Another rioter, wearing a full grey polo tracksuit, in then wacked right in the testicles by a an object which was aimed at a line of cops. More info\n\nOn Tuesday evening, Southport was subjected to a harrowing scene as far-right and English Defence League rioters, branded \"thugs\" by Home Secretary Yvette Cooper, wreaked havoc on their streets. They dismantled brick walls to use as missiles against the police and set fire to residents cars - just one day after the community was left reeling from the horrific mass stabbing at a Taylor Swift dance class that claimed the lives of three young children.\n\nHowever, amidst the circulating social media footage of the violent protest, one video captured a rioter confronting the police, only to be struck in the head by a flying brick. After feeling the impact and checking for blood, the man, dressed in a full grey Polo tracksuit, is dealt a second, more painful blow as another brick hits him squarely in the groin.\n\nThe initial brick, intended for the police, is followed by another that flies through the air and lands with incredible precision on the rioter's groin, causing him to double over in agony. In a moment that will resonate with many, the footage shows the man, who had been advancing towards the police line aggressively just seconds earlier, now hobbling away in evident distress, reports the Mirror.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool Mayor fears 'further trauma' as 'thugs' set fires and attack police officers\n\nDuring the chaotic scenes in Southport, where a staggering 39 Merseyside Police officers were injured and a Major Incident was declared by the North West Ambulance Service, rioters were caught on camera checking on a man's wellbeing amidst the violence. As the masked crowd continued to launch missiles at the police, one voice is heard questioning the accuracy of those throwing bricks.\n\nA viewer of the footage on social media remarked: \"serves him right\". {"uri": "8252390418", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:54:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:54:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:53:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://www.newstatesman.com/comment/2024/07/we-cannot-let-the-southport-stabbings-be-used-to-incite-hatred", "title": "We cannot let the Southport stabbings be used to incite hatred", "body": "It is disgusting that anyone would use the violent murder of three young girls to further their own divisive political cause.\n\nThree little girls have been murdered. Six-year-old Bebe King, seven-year-old Elsie Dot Stancombe, and nine-year-old Alice Dasilva Aguiar had barely begun to live when their lives were violently taken away. It is impossible to comprehend how anyone could target children. Children doing what children do: having fun, dancing to pop songs. Their pictures are haunting: smiling innocence, still so young that their were teeth missing.\n\nI can't stop thinking about the graphic descriptions of the attack on a children's Taylor Swift-themed dance class in Southport, in which eight other girls were also stabbed. One victim was the same age as my eldest. I can't quite bring myself to process how frightened they must have been. The disbelief of the local community is palpable.\n\nWhen something so awful happens, we need answers. We demand them. We can't accept that something so senseless could be just that - senseless. In today's fast-paced, social-media-dominant world, we seemingly can't and won't wait. We, at times, inhibit the police from doing their job; we demand a running commentary. And when we don't receive it, into that void of information rushes dangerous speculation.\n\nWithin hours of news of the stabbing taking place, the crime was attributed to 17-year-old \"Ali Al-Shakati\", an asylum seeker who'd arrived in the UK on a boat last year, and who was supposedly on an MI6 watch list. None of this was true. The name was fake. People didn't stop to ask why MI6 would be monitoring people on British soil, when that would generally be the preserve of MI5. Or how, when there are reporting restrictions for those under 18, the name might have leaked. Millions saw it online, and believed it.\n\nSome people didn't ask questions because those looking for a villain who fitted their wider political and world view had what they needed: an excuse to stoke fear and division; to tell people that they can't trust those who we rely on to protect us, namely the police or the government. By the time Merseyside Police felt the need to state officially that, \"This name is incorrect and we would urge people not to speculate on details of the incident while the investigation is ongoing,\" it was too late. The denial became part of the conspiracy: why are the police lying to us?\n\nThe police have now confirmed that the 17-year-old who has been arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted to murder was from Banks in Lancashire, and was born in Cardiff. It's understood his parents are Rwandans. But this hasn't stopped elected officials subtly undermining trust in the police and politicians, and sowing seeds of doubt. In response to the attack, Nigel Farage, MP for Clacton and leader of Reform UK, asks: \"Was this guy being monitored by the security services?\". This is quickly followed by: \"I just wonder whether the truth is being withheld from us.\" He made similar remarks on GB News. The former actor turned right-wing contrarian Laurence Fox declared, \"We are going to have to take our country back. Street by street. The politicians couldn't care less about your kids... When they appeal for calm, I hear 'Shut up and stop complaining.'\"\n\nThis is something I never thought I would hear - certainly not on this scale - in Britain. It frightens me. While the majority of people in Southport attended a deeply moving, peaceful vigil last night, others went to riot. A group of mostly men gathered outside Southport Mosque, chanting anti-Muslim abuse and hurling rocks at it. It seems highly unlikely that the 17-year-old alleged perpetrator is a Muslim, given the biggest religion followed in Rwanda is Christianity. But why let the facts get in the way of hatred and violence? Those attacking the mosque, including those believed to be supporters of the far-right English Defence League, attacked police officers: a police van was set alight and missiles were thrown. The Home Secretary, Yvette Cooper, branded the scenes a \"disgrace\".\n\nThat anyone would use the violent murder of three young girls for their own hateful and divisive political cause is disgusting. Speaking after Tuesday night's violent scenes, Merseyside Police assistant chief constable Alex Goss said: \"It is sickening to see this happening within a community that has been devastated by the tragic loss of three young lives.\" He stated clearly that the speculation around the identity and status of the suspect was being used \"to bring violence and disorder to our streets\".\n\nWe know, as Taylor Swift said in her response to this horror, that the victims \"were just little kids at a dance class\". I, like her, am at a complete loss as to how to ever convey my sympathies to the families forever changed by the attack. But I hold nothing but contempt for those seeking to manipulate such senseless violence to further their own agendas.", "source": {"uri": "newstatesman.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New Statesman"}, "authors": [{"uri": "hannah_barnes@newstatesman.com", "name": "Hannah Barnes", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MI6", "type": {"uri": "8252506381", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:05:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:05:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:04:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/kids-knew-what-after-horrible-29649831", "title": "Kids knew what to do after 'horrible' scenes trashed their town - Liverpool Echo", "body": "Sebastian and Evelyn joined their mum Gemma in cleaning up Southport's streets\n\nA mum and her young children remained defiant despite being scared during last night's violent scenes in Southport. Gemma Taylor joined her son Sebastian, 10, and daughter Evelyn, seven, in cleaning up following the disturbances.\n\nPolice officers were attacked and riot vans set alight on St Luke's Road. A nearby mosque and convenience store were also targeted.\n\nA large group of people, which police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, took bricks from garden walls and began throwing them. The North West Ambulance Service confirmed 27 officers were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene. Three police dogs were also injured. It was declared a \"major incident\" by emergency services.\n\nThis morning, residents began the task of clearing up the damage to their community. Sebastian was helping sweep up near the mosque with his sister Evelyn and Gemma. Sebastian said his family lives just a short distance from where the violence erupted.\n\nGemma told PA: \"The first I saw was a load of people walking down our road which you wouldn't walk down unless you lived down there. I thought 'it's happening' and got them all upstairs and shut all the blinds. Unfortunately, you can't keep them away from it if it's right on our doorstep and they looked out of the window.\"\n\nSebastian said: \"It was really scary. Mum told us to go upstairs for some strange reason. Last night was just horrible so we were like 'you know what, we should help because everyone was helping'. We were sweeping up bricks and metal and bottles and we were sweeping up burnt pieces of bins which had been on fire.\"\n\nSebastian said he watched as local volunteers removed all the bricks from a wall which was partially demolished around the mosque so it can be rebuilt. Those helping move the bricks said builders in the area had already told them they would help repair walls for free.\n\nOther residents of Southport have been cleaning up in the aftermath of the horrific scenes. Norman Wallis, owner of Southport Pleasureland, told the ECHO: \"We're all coming together to try and help the people in Sussex Road and the area to clean up for the mess that was made by all those people, those thugs, that came into their street.\n\n\"They just totally destroyed the street, pulled the walls down, pulled fences down, set cars on fire, just terrible. We're all coming together to just try and help as a community.\"\n\nResident Cathy McGrath said: \"I feel just angry and upset really. I went to the vigil last night and it was beautiful for the girls and the children and then you see last night. Those people don't represent the community, these people represent the community. They've spoiled it really and that's why I have come out today.\"\n\nMeanwhile, members of the Southport Islamic Society Mosque, which was targeted last night, have spoken out. A spokesperson for the mosque said: \"First and foremost we are all very shocked and saddened about what occurred on Monday. Our thoughts and prayers are with the families of those affected. What followed last night on the part of the far-right was an insult to the families and a town that is collective in its grieving.\"\n\nBelow you can leave your tribute to the little girls who lost their lives in the attack\n\nThe Liverpool Region Mosque Network, who work in collaboration, said it was horrified \"by the heinous acts. They added: \"This is an attack against society, irrespective of faith or background.\n\n\"A minority of people are attempting to portray that this inhumane act is somehow related to the Muslim community. Frankly it is not, and we must not let those who seek to divide us and spread hatred use this as an opportunity.\n\n\"This evening, we have seen distressing scenes outside Southport Mosque with angry protestors, gathering outside. This is causing further fear and anxiety within our communities. We must all unite and stand together against all forms of hate, violence and division.\n\n\"We thank Merseyside Police, Metro Mayor Steve Rotheram, and other political and community leaders for their {"uri": "8252738532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:34:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:34:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:34:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4431372582912445, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/remain-calm-message-misinformation-spreads-29651793", "title": "'Remain calm' message as 'misinformation' spreads after Southport  riots - Liverpool Echo", "body": "Sefton Council has said there is no disruption or disorder in Southport at this time\n\nPeople have been urged to remain calm in Southport amid 'misinformation' telling people to avoid the town centre today. Tensions are running high in the seaside town following last night's riots which followed the tragic killing of three young girls on Monday.\n\nAfter Tuesday night's 'sickening scenes', Merseyside Police has said it is prepared for further violence, with misinformation being shared on social media. In a statement this afternoon, Wednesday, Sefton Council said there is categorically no disruption or disorder taking place in Southport at this time and that the town centre is open.\n\nThe statement from the local authority follows reports this afternoon that some businesses have decided to close early and some staff members have reportedly advised to go home early over fears of further violent scenes in the town. Sefton Council is now calling for calm as it seeks to reassure people that Southport is a safe place to go.\n\nA statement from Sefton Council released this afternoon said: \"We are aware of misinformation online whereby people are being told to avoid Southport Town Centre this afternoon (Wednesday July 31). We have confirmed that there is NO disruption or disorder in Southport at this time and the town centre remains fully open for business.\n\n\"We urge people to remain calm and if they need, to please seek advice from official channels such as Sefton Council and Merseyside Police. We understand this is a highly emotional time and we would like to reiterate that Southport stands united and open.\"\n\nRumours had circulated on social media about more planned protests in the town today, but this has so far not materialised. Earlier Merseyside Police's Chief Constable Serena Kennedy said her officers were prepared to manage any future demonstrations. She said: \"I am absolutely concerned about repeats, there is that misinformation out there on social media, but please be reassured we are absolutely planning for that, please be reassured that we are planning for what might take place this evening and over the weekend. We were really supported by colleagues from other forces last night and that support is available to us again.\"\n\nCC Kennedy confirmed that in last night's grim scenes, which saw police vans set on fire and local people's property destroyed, a total of 53 officers were injured and in need of medical attention. She said: \"Our officers were then faced with the most horrendous violence against them last night. 54 police officers were injured last night, 49 from Merseyside Police and four from Lancashire Constabulary.\n\n\"It is completely unacceptable. All the blue light services responding yesterday, their focus is around protecting and keeping our communities safe and yet they were faced with that disgusting level of violence from people who do not represent our communities here in Southport.\"\n\nShe confirmed that three people were arrested following the violence last night, with more expected to follow.\" Asked if her force was prepared for what arrived, she added: \"This was well planned and well organised but kept off social media. We were absolutely prepared, we had sufficient resources on the ground.\n\n\"This is a tight-knit community, I do not want my officers on the streets of a community like Southport in riot gear, based on the intelligence we were dealing with, that would not have been appropriate. However the situation very quickly changed and we were able to take control of the position where those people were attending. we are a town of love and this is how we show it.\"\n\nAmong those who suffered during the riot last night were a shopkeeper who lost \u00a310,000 of stuff when it was looted by rioters, despite white members of the local community trying to protect it.\n\nThe show of solidarity also saw a call from the mum of Elsie Stancombe - one of three victims so far from the attack - make an appeal for the violence to stop.\n\nIn a message widely shared online, Jenni Stancombe said: \"This is the only thing that I will write, but please stop the violence in Southport tonight.\n\n\"The police have been nothing but heroic these last 24 hours and they and we don't need this.\"\n\nA couple whose business was at the epicentre of the street battle between police and thugs are now counting the cost.\n\nRob and Tracey Whitfield own a heating and plumbing business on St Luke's Road where yobs targeted the Islamic centre.\n\nA police van was torched inches from the couple's shop.\n\nLast night they watched in horror as an army of bare chested racists battled police outside their shop.\n\nRob said: \"The windows are cracked and there is heat damage from the fire. It will cost several thousand pounds to repair, at the least.\"\n\nThe couple were also concerned for a woman who lives in a flat above the shop.\n\nTracey said: \"This is the worst event I can remember in Southport's history. There is rumour they will be back at some point soon so we will wait and see.\"\n\nA shopkeeper whose business was looted by yobs thanked the community for helping to save it.\n\nChanuka Balasuriya, 47, said that locals warned him to close the Windsor Mini-Mart last night as thugs fought with police in the street.\n\nMerseyside Police has said 39 officers suffered injuries, with 27 taken to hospital.\n\nThe shop was a few hundred yards from a major flashpoint outside the mosque on the corner of Sussex Road.\n\nChanuka, a father-of-two, said that after closing up shortly after 7pm he went home, but was forced to return following reports that the shop had been broken into.\n\nChanuka told of his terror as thugs smashed their way inside the shop and then set fire to a wheelie bin in the doorway.\n\nHe said: \"At one point the streets were like a war zone. It's a safe place for everyone.\"\n\nNorman Wallis, 61, the chairman of the Pleasureland amusement park, said of the riots: \"It was absolute mayhem - it was like a war zone. {"uri": "8252657901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:42:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:42:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:40:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/police-preparing-repeat-violence-southport-29650919", "title": "Police preparing for repeat violence in Southport  - Liverpool Echo", "body": "Chief Constable says force is ready for what might take place this evening and over the weekend after Tuesday's night of violence\n\nMerseyside Police's top officer has said her force are concerned about a repeat of the violence seen on the streets of Southport last night and are preparing for what may come. Chief Constable Serena Kennedy was speaking after violent scenes in the town that resulted in injuries to 54 officers.\n\nViolence erupted in and around St Luke's Road after a large group, which police have linked to the far-right English Defence League, gathered outside a Mosque, attempting to damage the building. Those gathered then turned on the police, setting fire to vehicles and hurling rocks at officers, resulting in many injuries and terrifying scenes.\n\nSpeaking to reporters today, Chief Con Kennedy was asked if she was concerned about further violent scenes in the town in the coming days. She said: \"I am absolutely concerned about repeats, there is that misinformation out there on social media, but please be reassured we are absolutely planning for that, please be reassured that we are planning for what might take place this evening and over the weekend. We were really supported by colleagues from other forces last night and that support is available to us again.\"\n\nOn Tuesday night's violence, she said: \"My officers and staff who responded along with blue light colleagues to the incident on Monday, they are traumatised by what they dealt with and what they have been continuing to deal with over the last 48 hours. Their number one priority was to save as many lives as they could on Monday, working with our colleagues - but also to provide that really important support to the community in Southport, which is a small, tight-knit community that is also traumatised by what has happened.\n\n\"Our officers were then faced with the most horrendous violence against them last night. 54 police officers were injured last night, 49 from Merseyside Police and five from Lancashire Constabulary. It is completely unacceptable. All the blue light services responding yesterday, their focus is around protecting and keeping our communities safe and yet they were faced with that disgusting level of violence from people who do not represent our communities here in Southport.\"\n\nAsked if her force was prepared for what arrived, she added: \"This was well planned and well organised but kept off social media. We were absolutely prepared, we had sufficient resources on the ground. This is a tight-knit community, I do not want my officers on the streets of a community like Southport in riot gear, based on the intelligence we were dealing with, that would not have been appropriate. However the situation very quickly changed and we were able to take control of the position where those people were attending. When we frustrated their attempts at what they were trying to do, they then turned on my officers and became violent and we very quickly had to change.\"\n\nCC Kennedy said she shares people's 'horror and disgust' at what took place on Tuesday night, adding: \"What I would say is please be reassured in terms of that level of support in terms of policing and from our partners.\"\n\nShe added: \"I am so proud of my officers and staff in terms of what they have dealt with over the past 48 hours and the incredible hours they have worked. Everyone has pulled together, working as one team. Staff are working incredibly long hours to make sure we can deal with the events of Monday, which is a really unusual and unfortunately unique investigation but obviously then dealing with the events of yesterday. Those officers had to quickly switch from providing that reassurance at the vigil to then dealing with those mindless hooligans, who inflicted such violence on them, so yes my officers and staff are traumatised by what they have witnessed.\"\n\nThe force leader said online 'misinformation' is a major concern at present, adding: \"There is a lot of speculation out there. We are working really closely with our stakeholders, with our elected members and key members of the community to make sure they have the information which is truthful, using ourselves as that single source of the information so we can try and manage that misinformation out. It is really not helpful to the communities of Southport. We will give you the information when we can, this is a delicate but fast moving investigation and we will get that information out when we can. But there has been lots of untruthful misinformation out there.\"", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Liverpool Echo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "liam_thorp@liverpoolecho.co.uk", "name": "Liam Thorp", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "patrick_edrich@liverpoolecho.co.uk", "name": "Patrick Edrich", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Theft", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Theft", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Transgendered/Coming_Out", "label": "dmoz/Society/Transgendered/Coming Out", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Humor/Job-Related", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Humor/Job-Related", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://i2-prod.liverpoolecho.co.uk/article29650530.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/0_riot-southport-5.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9777011", "eventUri": "eng-9777011", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.3333333333333334, "wgt": 111, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8252292416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:56:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:56:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:54:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://www.nottinghampost.com/news/uk-world-news/southport-community-unites-clean-up-9449412", "title": "Residents come together to clean up after 'thugs' wreak havoc on streets", "body": "Southport community members are cleaning up their streets, following disarray left by a protest that turned violent. The North West Ambulance Service reports that 39 police officers required medical attention after Tuesday's disturbance on St Luke's Road.\n\nAccording to the ambulance service, 27 of those officers were taken to hospital and the remaining 12 received treatment on-site. The incident was swiftly elevated to a \"major incident\" status by emergency services due to its severity.\n\nAggressors armed with bricks from nearby garden walls targeted both police and vehicles, sparking fires. Tensions escalated near a local mosque, where police allege supporters of the English Defence League began hurling objects.\n\nGet the latest news straight to your phone by joining us on WhatsApp\n\nMultiple cars were torched and the mosque sustained damage from the thrown bricks. Further vandalism occurred at a local shop, and various wheelie bins were set ablaze. Moreover, the riotous activity resulted in injuries to three police dogs, reports the Liverpool Echo.\n\nPolice Dogs Zoe and Ike suffered leg injuries from bricks, while PD Quga endured burns to her back leg. Imagery and recordings show large crowds surrounding police riot vans on St Luke's Road, where a van was captured engulfed in flames. In the wake of these events, the residents around St Luke's Road have banded together in a significant community effort to restore the area.\n\nNorman Wallis, the owner of Southport Pleasureland, joined forces to tackle the debris left behind. Speaking with the ECHO, he said: \"We're all coming together to try and help the people in Sussex Road and the area to clean up for the mess that was made by all those people, those thugs, that came into their street.\"\n\n\"They just totally destroyed the street, pulled the walls down, pulled fences down, set cars on fire, just terrible. We're all coming together to just try and help as a community.\"\n\nWallis further remarked on the town's virtues, saying Southport is a \"wonderful\" place that deserves more recognition, and stressed that the destructive actions are not representative of the area.\n\nCathy McGrath has been participating in the cleanup efforts since early this morning and shared her feelings with the ECHO: \"I feel just angry and upset really. I went to the vigil last night and it was beautiful for the girls and the children and then you see last night.\"\n\n\"Those people don't represent the community, these people represent the community. They've spoilt it really and that's why I have come out today.\"\n\nDenise Mace recalled the unrest as being frightening: \"It was terrifying to be honest. Seeing the police come marching down and it was right outside my house. These people weren't from Southport and it wasn't a peaceful protest.\"\n\nDenise continued, highlighting the community's goodwill: \"When they moved it so far, everyone just come out and started clearing up.\" Sefton Council has reported that its cleaning and neighbourhood support teams have been working since 3am to clear the aftermath of last night's disorder. The council stated that they are striving to remove debris and items as swiftly and safely as possible.", "source": {"uri": "nottinghampost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Nottingham Post"}, from a woman bravely confronting rioters with a \"hope not hate\" sign, to a number of people helping to repair a wall near the local mosque which was ripped down on Tuesday night.\n\nMerseyside Police says 22 of its officers were injured following the violent scenes in the town, sparked by a stabbing at a Taylor Swift dance event on Monday which has claimed the lives of three young girls, and has seen a 17-year-old male arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder.\n\nCars and wheelie bins were set alight, a local convenience store was damaged and bricks were thrown at a mosque.\n\nOne video of the disorder even captured a far-right rioter being hit in the back of the head - and, subsequently, in the gentials - by his own side amid the chaos.\n\nNow, one clip which has gone viral from the town is that of individuals coming together to repair some of the damage caused by the far-right, with local news service On The Spot News (OTS News) quoting one individual who said of the action: \"We're fixing the damage that these scumbags did.\"\n\nOTS News also reports that around 100 community members worked to repair the damage to the mosque, and after more residents arrived to help, they were told that \"much of the work has already been done\".\n\nIn a Twitter/X thread, they wrote: \"It's worth mentioning that to genuine residents this is not a surprising response.\n\n\"Take our own experience while we've reported the aftermath of Monday's horrific atrocity. Putting his hand to the back of his head after being struck, it looks like he sees blood on his hand - but then the man in a full grey Polo tracksuit has worse problems as he is hit by another brick, right where it hurts.\n\nWincing from the first brick, which was aimed at a line of police officers, with another brick can be seen sailing through the air, before smashing directly into the protester's testicles. This second blow clearly connected, as the man doubles over immediately.\n\nREAD MORE: EDL riot sees 39 police officers injured in 'shocking' rampage whilst town mourns\n\nIn a moment of pain that half the population will likely be able to feel themselves, the man can be seen gingerly hobbling away from the police line that he had, only moments before, been aggressively approaching.\n\nThe rioters, who in their hours-long battle with Merseyside Police injured a whopping 39 officers and triggered a Major Incident for the North West Ambulance Service, can be heard asking the man if he is alright, as the masked people around him continued to hurl objects at police. Another can be heard reprimanding the aim of the thugs throwing bricks.\n\nOne social media user viewing the video commented: \"serves him right\". While another X user shared the video, saying: \"Whatever your take on the goings on in Southport, this is inarguably very funny.\n\n\"Concussion, no b******** and nicked tomorrow for rioting.\"\n\nIn a statement on the riots, released late on Tuesday night, Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said: \"Tonight, Merseyside Police has faced serious violence in Southport and I am so proud to have witnessed off-duty officers (many of whom had not long finished a full shift) parade back on duty to support their colleagues who had displayed such courage whilst under constant and sustained attack.\n\n\"I would also like to thank officers from Greater Manchester Police, Cheshire Police, Lancashire Police and North Wales Police who also provided mutual aid and support.\"\n\nHe continued: \"Sadly, offenders have destroyed garden walls so they could use the bricks to attack our officers and have set cars belonging to the public on fire, and damaged cars parked in the Mosque car park. This is no way to treat a community, least of all a community that is still reeling from the events of Monday.\n\n\"We would appeal to anyone who has information or video footage of those involved in this shocking behaviour to come forward so we can identify and arrest those responsible.\n\n\"Anyone with information can DM @MerPolCC or contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-439094171", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:16:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:16:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://www.politico.eu/newsletter/london-playbook/far-right-thugs-hijack-southport-vigil/", "title": "Far-right thugs hijack Southport vigil", "body": "WHILE YOU WERE SLEEPING: Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh has been killed in Tehran, the Palestinian militant group and Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard said in early-hours statements. Hamas said Haniyeh was killed in \"a treacherous Zionist raid on his residence in Tehran.\" Read more.\n\nHORROR UPON HORROR: Southport is waking up to the aftermath of far-right protesters fired up by misinformation staging running battles with police, in horrific scenes that piled further trauma on the town already grieving the fatal stabbing of three girls at a children's dance club. Keir Starmer warned last night that those behind the unrest will \"feel the full force of the law\" after a mosque was attacked, police vehicles torched and officers targeted with bricks and bottles. Expect plenty of tough questions about the role social media played in stoking the violence.\n\nDeveloping overnight: The North West Ambulance Service said its staff treated 39 police officers, with 27 taken to hospital. Merseyside Police said injuries included fractures, lacerations, a suspected broken nose and a concussion. Three police dogs were injured, too. Officers were given enhanced stop-and-search powers as legal orders were imposed on the town to prevent disorder from breaking out again.\n\n**A message from Lloyds Banking Group: Tonight, over 145,000 children will go to bed in temporary accommodation. That's why we've committed \u00a3200 million to support local providers who deliver housing for those who need it most. Find out more here.**\n\nWhat happened: A peaceful vigil was held to mourn the deaths of Bebe King, 6, Elsie Dot Stancombe, 7, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, 9. But a short while later, a large group of people, who police believe were supporters of the English Defence League, began to hurl items at a mosque close to the scene of the fatal stabbings. Assistant Chief Constable Alex Goss said offenders destroyed garden walls to grab bricks to hurl at officers during the chaotic clashes. Expect news of arrests to follow.\n\nProviding answers: Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner will follow Housing Minister Matthew Pennycook's morning round (timings at the bottom of the email) by talking to ITV's This Morning at 10.30 a.m. and Jeremy Vine on Radio 2 at midday.\n\nThe reaction so far: The prime minister, who was heckled as he laid flowers at the scene of the stabbings, said those who \"hijacked the vigil for the victims with violence and thuggery have insulted the community as it grieves.\" Home Secretary Yvette Cooper, who is being kept closely up to date on the situation, used a broadcast clip from parliament's central lobby to blame the \"appalling\" attacks on \"thugs on the streets.\" Southport MP Patrick Hurley blamed \"people from outside our Southport community\" for the violence.\n\nWhat's known: The BBC reports the 17-year-old suspect -- born in Cardiff to parents from Rwanda -- has no known links to Islam, but social media has been rampant with rumors there's an Islamist connection to the killings. Police say the motive is unclear but is not currently believed to be terror-related.\n\nThe misinformation: The Guardian's Ben Quinn has a good piece on the flood of misinformation from far-right activists, fake news websites and conspiracy theorists. In the Commons before the clashes, Cooper said social media companies \"need to take some responsibility.\"\n\nOn the ground: Reporters posted disturbing footage of the violence, with the Guardian's Josh Halliday capturing the blazing police van and reporting chants of \"who the f*** is Allah.\" His colleague Hannah Al-Othman recorded shouts of \"we want our country back\" as well as various scenes of disorder, as she was caught up in the tear gas. The Mail reports there were chants of \"no more boats,\" with one demonstrator carrying a placard reading \"Stop the boats! Send them back!\" ITV's Paul Brand faced some nasty harassment.\n\nLeaning in: Nigel Farage broke ranks with other MPs to bring politics into the killings. In a video on X posted before the rioting, he said the heckling of Starmer shows the public's unhappiness at the \"state of law and order in our country.\" The Reform leader asked: \"Police say it was a non-terror incident ... I just wonder whether the truth is being withheld from us?\" He said what he does know is \"something is going horribly wrong in our once beautiful country\" and suggested there are reports the suspect was being monitored by the security services.\n\nBut but but: Farage didn't say where he saw those reports -- and they're definitely not widespread in the British media. However, Martin Evans and Charles Hymas write in the Telegraph's splash that Russian state-controlled media was among those spreading false claims including that the suspect was on an MI6 watch list, having arrived as an asylum seeker on a boat last year. They point out that Russia Today went on to update its story to say the claim had been retracted. Will Farage have anything to add?\n\nA SUMMER OF TAX SPECULATION\n\nAND BREATHE ... The first day of summer recess means exhausted MPs and political staffers will be settling into a well-earned rest after the grueling weeks of campaigning were followed by the dizzying days of political overhaul. But the great wheels of speculation shall not be slowed -- thanks to Rachel Reeves giving them a good old spin with a suggestion of impending tax hikes.\n\nThe admission: The chancellor gave a heavy hint in her Commons statement on the \u00a322 billion \"black hole\" that she'd be making \"difficult decisions,\" including on tax, in her Oct. 30 budget -- and then she basically confirmed to the News Agents podcast that they will indeed be coming. \"I think that we will have to increase taxes in the budget,' she told Emily Maitlis and Jon Sopel. At least for Reeves' sake, recess means Speaker Lindsay Hoyle will be discreetly fulminating in Lancashire rather than loudly in the Commons at the chancellor not giving that scoop to the chamber.\n\nFor whom the tax tolls? Pressed by the podcasting duo, Reeves didn't rule out hiking taxes on inheritance or capital gains or easing the relief on pension contributions. She was, however, standing by the manifesto pledges not to hike income tax, VAT or national insurance. No doubt Rayner and Pennycook will face questions on this in their media grillings.\n\nOn the Hunt: The tax admission from Reeves was like a fox-scented rag for Jeremy Hunt. The shadow chancellor, already enraged by the black hole attacks on his legacy, issued a \"we told you so\" statement, saying: \"Just as we warned -- they were always planning to do this, they just didn't have the courage to be honest about it\".\n\nBlame game, the sequel: The bitter row over just how much the Tories are to blame -- and how much Reeves is milking this funding deficit to justify painful policies -- was taking place on the front page of the Financial Times. The pink 'un has a good go at getting to the bottom of just what Labour knew. Hunt hit back at Reeves' \"desperate\" attack and former Home Secretary James Cleverly insisted it's \"nonsensical\" to feign surprise that asylum support had been funded through reserves. Read the piece here.\n\nIt's all in the phrasing: Showing just why this messaging war is so important is this new Savanta polling. The survey shared with Playbook suggests 64 percent of Britons would \"be happy\" to be taxed more to cover a pay rise for NHS nurses. But this drops to 49 percent when people are asked about hikes to recruit and train more police, 48 percent to pay teachers better and 44 percent to fund new infrastructure projects. Hard to see those \"unfunded\" or \"unaffordable\" rail, road and hospital projects being revived any time soon then ...\n\nWHAT LABOUR ACTUALLY WANTS TO TALK ABOUT: Angela Rayner, in her role as housing secretary, is announcing she's launched a task force to recommend where to build a promised series of new towns. But the task force, led by English Cities Fund Chair Michael Lyons, isn't expected to produce its final report for up to a year, raising questions about just how quickly these towns will be realized.\n\nSoftly does it: After announcing sweeping reforms to deliver 1.5 million more homes this decade, Rayner sought to win round the NIMBYs with an op-ed in the Telegraph. To those who reckon England's green and pleasant land has been concreted over, she says: \"I could gently reassure them. Or, more likely, I can just say: 'It's nonsense.'\" Read her case here.\n\nOAPeeved off: Between ending winter fuel payments and taking aim at the housing hesitant, Labour appears increasingly willing to piss off one of the country's most powerful interest groups: old people. My colleague Esther Webber writes today that it makes sense for the government to make a bold play while it's at its most powerful -- and will deepen Tory fears that they're losing the battle for working-age votes. Read her piece here.\n\nMission bored? Energy Secretary Ed Miliband is chairing another one of those \"mission boards,\" summoning ministers to discuss plans to make Britain a clean energy superpower. Expect a statement after they meet.\n\nSomething to cheer about: The former Labour leader is rather gleeful about throwing more money to renewables developers, raising the budget for the ongoing auction round for clean energy projects nearly 50 percent to \u00a31.5 billion, energy guru and POLITICO colleague Nicholas Earl writes in to say. \"This will restore the U.K. as a global leader for green technologies and deliver the infrastructure we need to boost our energy independence, protect billpayers and become a clean energy superpower,\" Miliband beamed.\n\nPLANET TORY\n\nALL CALM: Kemi Badenoch came out swinging at the Guardian last night after Pippa Crerar reported allegations that the Tory leadership frontrunner has been accused of \"bullying and traumatizing\" behavior towards officials in the Department for Business and Trade.\n\nA very civil service: The report details claims that Badenoch presided over a toxic and intimidating atmosphere while running the government department -- claims she rather sharply denied. At least three officials were said to have found her behavior so poor they felt they had no choice but to quit. It's worth reading Pippa's piece in full here.\n\nKemi strikes back: Badenoch used a mini-thread on X to return fire. The shadow housing secretary called the piece a \"hit job\" and -- never one to miss an opportunity -- argued that her campaign has \"spooked the lefties\" because she's the \"one person they know can beat Keir Starmer.\"\n\nThere's more: Badenoch pointed out that no official complaints to the department were made about her conduct there, as backed up by a statement from the DBT. She claimed the allegations are \"smears from former staff who I sacked\" after they were themselves accused of bullying and lying, though that's a bit confusing because ministers (other than the PM) don't have the authority to dismiss civil servants.\n\nSecuring maximum coverage: The angry denial led several rival papers' stories. It also offered further evidence to Tory MPs weighing up whether to back Badenoch that she's never one to resist a public scrap.\n\nTODAY IN WESTMINSTER\n\nWITH PARLIAMENT IN RECESS: Foreign Secretary David Lammy and Defence Secretary John Healey are in Qatar to call for de-escalation in the Middle East, meeting U.K. personnel working on supporting stability in the region.\n\nNOT POLITICS, BUT: Huw Edwards is due before Westminster Magistrates' Court this morning charged with making indecent images of children. The former BBC presenter is alleged to have committed three offenses between December 2020 and April 2022. PA previews the appearance.\n\nIT'S CHRONIC: Junior doctors have been told the next \"window of opportunity\" for strikes is about 12 months away, \"when Labour's honeymoon period ends,\" the Times reports. The comments came from the BMA's junior doctors committee Co-Chair Robert Laurenson after the government offered a 22 percent pay rise to end the strikes.\n\nMore health problems: Boris Johnson's plan to build 40 new hospitals by 2030 is set to be missed following a project review, the i's Hugo Gye and Ben Gartside report. The construction of the majority of these new hospitals is yet to begin and is set to be paused until later in the year once the review has concluded. A Department for Health spokesperson said: \"The previous government's commitment to build 40 new hospitals by 2030 is undeliverable and unaffordable. The funding allocated by the previous government runs out in March.\"\n\nSNP STRUGGLES: The SNP has been licking its wounds and its members letting loose at each other since its humiliation in July's election, POLITICO's Andrew McDonald writes in a great piece on the nationalist plight. Blame is still flying around the party, while the financial implications of the big defeat have hit hard with a big staffing cut at Westminster.\n\nYellow fever: \"Parties die. If we don't change, we will die,\" one SNP figure told Andrew, as it gears up for a big challenge from Scottish Labour at Holyrood in two years. More recriminations and analysis in the piece here.\n\nSCOOP -- ASBESTOS BREACH: Parliamentary authorities broke health and safety law during an asbestos incident in the Palace of Westminster in 2021, my colleague Esther Webber writes in to say. The Health and Safety Executive has finally concluded an inquiry into the exposure that occurred as part of fire safety work being carried out in Speaker's House, first reported by POLITICO. The watchdog is not expected to take enforcement action but found \"material breaches\" of asbestos control regulations, and criticized the use of a contractor that was not properly qualified.\n\nIt's all adding up: The House of Commons will issue a response today but has already undertaken to foot the bill for the HSE investigation into the incident, which resulted in dozens of people working on the estate being notified of possible asbestos exposure. Meanwhile, plans for the wholesale restoration of parliament remain in limbo.\n\nCOOLING IT DOWN: The DWP held a late afternoon briefing to soothe the nerves of MPs worried about winter fuel payment changes, Playbook's Bethany Dawson heard. PoliticsHome's Nadine Batchelor-Hunt hears the same, and reports the meeting was hosted by Chief Secretary to the Treasury Darren Jones.\n\nBREAKFAST WITH RACHEL: Chancellor Rachel Reeves is hosting a bevy of deep-pocketed tech companies and investors for breakfast this morning to talk tech and AI, my colleagues on our Morning Tech newsletter report. Senior execs from Google, Microsoft, Meta, Amazon and Nvidia are expected.\n\nANOTHER TYPE OF CHANCELLOR: The Financial Times reports that former Labour Secretary of State Peter Mandelson and former Conservative Leader William Hague are in the race to be the next chancellor of the University of Oxford, along with former Prime Minister Theresa May. The election will take place in the Michaelmas term (which, for normies, is between October and December).\n\nMORE ELECTION DATES: The House of Commons has announced select committee nominations will run until Sept. 9, with the ballot scheduled for Sept. 11.\n\nDON'T BE A HERO: The IPPR's Commission on Health and Prosperity, chaired by experts including Ara Darzi and charged by the health secretary with undertaking an independent investigation into the state of the NHS, has produced a report revealing the annual cost of employee sickness has risen \u00a330 billion since 2018. The report says employees lose the equivalent of 44 days of productivity soldiering through illness, with 6.7 days lost each year to sick leave.\n\nREPORTS OUT TODAY: The IFG has produced a list of 20 ways the civil service can be improved, including the introduction of a new civil service board and the default external advertising of roles ... Centre for Cities says 68 percent of households in England could have their annual council tax bill reduced by \u00a3494 if council taxes were set locally.\n\nTRIBUTES PAID: To the Independent's War and Diplomatic Correspondent Kim Sengupta, who has died at age 68. Foreign Secretary David Lammy wrote that his \"brave dispatches will be sorely missed,\" and Defence Secretary John Healey described his expertise on defense as \"unparalleled.\" There were also warm words from Sky's Jon Craig and the BBC's Quentin Sommerville.\n\nBEYOND THE M25\n\nLEBANON AIRSTRIKE: The Israel Defense Forces claimed they killed a senior Hezbollah commander in an airstrike on the Lebanese capital of Beirut on Tuesday, a significant escalation in the long-running conflict between Israel and the militant group that European capitals fear could quickly snowball into a regional conflict. Earlier on Tuesday, Foreign Secretary David Lammy said Britons in Lebanon should leave to avoid \"becoming trapped in a warzone.\"\n\nSWEDISH FEARS: A spate of deadly gang violence is part of a brutal summer troubling Sweden's government, my colleague Charlie Duxbury reports. On July 22, a person hurled a hand grenade into a shop in S\u00f6dert\u00e4lje, where several bystanders were injured and one woman in her 50s had to be airlifted to the hospital. Only a day later, a man was shot and injured on a street nearby. There have been 148 shootings in Sweden this year, killing 20 and injuring 26. In 2023, there were a total of 53 gun deaths.\n\nSECRET RELOCATIONS: More than 5,000 former military and intelligence operatives in Afghanistan have been evacuated from the Taliban-ruled country to the U.K. by the MoD since October, the National reports, and are now living in surplus military housing across the country. The MoD declined to comment.\n\nDC TENSIONS: Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe Jr. repeatedly raised his voice during a senate hearing on the shooting of Donald Trump, as he pushed back against withering criticism of his agency's performance. Rowe acknowledged the Secret Service made catastrophic errors, but vowed to prevent his agency's leaders from being \"unfairly persecuted.\"\n\nOver in Atlanta: Vice President Kamala Harris has once again challenged Trump to a televised debate, saying \"I do hope Trump will agree to meet me on the debate stage, because as the saying goes, if you got something to say, say it to my face.\"\n\n**A message from Lloyds Banking Group: At Lloyds Banking Group, we've been championing the social housing sector for decades. Since 2018, we've provided more than \u00a318.5 billion of funding to the sector and currently work with over 340 housing associations of all sizes to expand the availability of quality social housing across the UK. We've announced a new \u00a3200 million financing commitment to support small housing providers across the country to increase the number of quality homes they are able to make available for the most in need. especially those experiencing homelessness or individuals with special needs. Find out more about how we are supporting the social housing sector here.**\n\nMEDIA ROUND\n\nHousing Minister Matthew Pennycook broadcast round: Times Radio (7.05 a.m.) ... Sky News (7.15 a.m.) ... BBC Breakfast (7.30 a.m.) ... Today (7.50 a.m.) ... LBC (8.05 a.m.) ... GMB (8.30 a.m.).\n\nPOLITICO UK: Humiliated, Scotland's independence warriors lick their wounds.\n\nDaily Express: Why were they taken from us?\n\nDaily Mail: Faces of the innocent little Taylor Swift fans killed in cold blood by a 'despicable human being.'\n\nFinancial Times: Reeves warns Budget will raise taxes as row over \u00a322bn fiscal hole deepens.\n\nThe Guardian: 'You can't help but cry:' hundreds pay tribute to stabbing victims.\n\nWESTMINSTER WEATHER: It's predicted to be another scorcher, but the Met Office has a yellow warning out for thunderstorms. Be careful what you wish for. High 28C, low 18C.\n\nEVERYDAY SEXISM TAKES TOILETS: Chancellor Rachel Reeves told the News Agents podcast that the bathroom serving her office cannot be altered, as it is listed. Therefore, her not-built-for-women loo has ... a urinal.\n\nBACK FROM THE ... VOTE: Former Greenpeace Zombie and now Labour MP Alistair Strathern has been elected chair of the Environment APPG.\n\nDATE FOR YOUR DIARY: Reform has announced its conference will take place in Birmingham from Sept. 20-21, with the local Wetherspoons opening after Nigel Farage's speech.\n\nNOW READ: Patrick Maguire's analysis in the Times of the new Labour Growth Group, on the caution and optimism expressed around the newly formed caucus.", "source": {"uri": "politico.eu", "dataType": "news", "title": "POLITICO"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sam_blewett@politico.eu", "name": "Sam Blewett", North West Ambulance Service confirmed paramedics treated 39 police officers after violence flared during a protest on St Luke's Road in Southport on Tuesday, July 30.\n\nThe ambulance service confirmed 27 officers were taken to hospital and 12 were treated and discharged at scene. It was declared as a \"major incident\" by emergency services.\n\nBricks taken from garden walls were used to attack officers and a police van was torched. A large group of people, who police said are believed to be supporters of the English Defence League, began to throw items towards a local mosque on St Luke's Road. Cars belonging to members of the public were set on fire and bricks were thrown at a local mosque.\n\nDamage was also caused to a local convenience store and wheelie bins were set alight, police said. Jack Richards, 21, lives at home with his mum, dad and 21-year-old sister.\n\nHe spoke to the ECHO about what unfolded. He said people used bins in the roads as barricades. Jack said: \"After the vigil we saw lots of people running down towards Hart Street, the streets filled up with cars parking up, and then everything happened. It started on St Luke's Road then started progressing from there, they raided the little mini mart up the road and marched down onto Queen's Road, people saying 'do you want a beer lad or some vapes' and shouting over.\n\n\"Once it started to turn dark they were all leaning on my sister's car, my sister politely asked them to get off, she told them she loves that car and asked them to stop leaning on it, and to be fair they said yeah - then they started taking the p*** - they noticed all the police coming and started putting all the bins in the roads as barricades and while they were lighting the bins someone ran down the road and jumped on my sister's windscreen and two footed it.\"\n\nJack added his family had to put fires out as emergency services dealt with various incidents of disorder.\n\nHe said: \"Fires started getting a lot bigger, they started to clear off once the fires were going so we came out with the garden hose and started trying to put the fire out, my dad had two fire extinguishers as well. It was right next to the cars, we were trying to put it out before it set the cars alight.\n\n\"Police and fire engines couldn't get here because they were too busy everywhere else so we were trying to police everyone ourselves to stop them from coming down the road, it was me and my mum at the top of the road, everyone was taking the p***, laughing, saying they lived down here when they weren't even from here.\n\n\"One lad on a bike was riding off shouting 'make sure you lock your doors, we will be back.' It was disgusting, it's scary on your doorstep it's not something you are used to in Southport. Jack Heathcote took out his camera while he was on the way to rescue his brother, who lives near to where the riot, broke out on St Luke's Road.\n\nA protest was organised following the murder of three young children in the town on Monday. Hundreds of people descended on Southport, setting fire to both police and civilian vehicles, damaging a mosque and ripping bricks off walls in order to hurl at officers. The march has been widely condemned - including by Home Secretary Yvette Cooper and Prime Minister Keir Starmer.\n\nJack, a gardener who is from the area, had attended the touching vigil at the Atkinson when he went back home to get his dinner. He told the ECHO: \"I'd got home when I began to get calls from my family telling me that it's all kicking off. I rang my brother, because he lives close to the protest, and asked him if he needed to get out.\n\nSouthport stabbing\n\n\"He said 'yes' so I took the car down. When I got there, there was smoke and a police van had been set on fire. I thought it was important that I photographed it, so I took out my camera.\" The 32-year-old captured images which include riot police protecting a burning vehicle and a policewoman with blood streaming down the side of her face. He also photographed the plumbing business of Robert Whitfield, 67, who was this morning counting the cost of the night of violence after his business was attacked.\n\nSpeaking about the riot, Jack said: \"It was shocking. I thought it was going to be naked aggression from the crowd but what disturbed me was that it was sadistic. People were enjoying it, they weren't angry about the girls - they were just using that as an excuse.\"\n\nThe North West Ambulance Service confirmed they treated 39 police officers after the protest
